title: In College Football, No Player Escapes the Eye of the Strength Coach
description: On a humid summer morning recently, Tom Herman, the University of Houstons football coach, stopped by the teams weight room and was surprised to find a few of his players shooting the bull with Yancy McKnight, the programs strength coach. A few hours earlier, McKnight had, in Hermans words, pounded the players into the ground with a 6 a.m. run.

title: Where CPR on a Boy Is Time Wasted: U.S. Doctors Recall Aleppos Horrors
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  In the Syrian city of Aleppo, children carrying groceries climb 15-foot mounds of rubble on their way home. Shoppers ignore vibrations from falling bombs. Buildings stand sliced in half, wires and beds and bathtubs exposed, with families still living inside. Most days, doctors have just seconds to decide which children to try to save and which to let die, as parents shriek and explosions shake the ground.

title: Israels Benjamin Netanyahu, Still a Step Ahead of Scandals, Faces a New Inquiry
description: JERUSALEM  He and his family have been accused of improprieties as strange as trying to palm off their used lawn furniture to the prime ministers residence, and as serious as pocketing illegal contributions from foreign donors.

title: 9 Years in Jail, 3 Trials, 12 Judges and No Verdict in Bronx Murder Case
description: Carlos Vegas story is written across his face. Two teardrop tattoos run down his cheek, one for each family member he watched die as a child. A jagged scar cuts across his jaw  the lasting mark of an attack by another inmate.

title: Theranos Damage Control, Tesla Earnings and the Jobs Report
description: Heres a look at whats coming up this week:

title: Russias Acres, if Not Its Locals, Beckon Chinese Farmers
description: OPYTNOE POLE, Russia  Perched in the cabin of a clunky Russian tractor, Li Chengbin, a 62-year-old peasant farmer from China, drove round and round in ever widening circles, plowing a field to get it ready for planting  and rejoicing at the opportunities offered by untamed lands in the Russian Far East almost empty of people.

title: Dave Schwartz, 63, Dies; Was Weather Channel Meteorologist
description: Dave Schwartz, a longtime Weather Channel meteorologist who early this year told his viewers about his struggle with cancer, died of the disease on Saturday. He was 63.

title: Exaggerator Storms Down the Stretch to Win the Haskell Invitational
description: OCEANPORT, N.J.  The trainer Keith Desormeaux spent a month preparing the Preakness winner Exaggerator for a race at Saratoga Race Course before an abrupt change of heart led him to enter the $1 million Haskell Invitational on Sunday at Monmouth Park.

title: Why Monthly Auto Sales Numbers May Not Be What They Seem
description: DETROIT  The steady growth in the American automobile market has been an economic success story: Carmakers set a record last year by selling more than 17.4 million new vehicles.

title: Pacific Northwest Weighs Response to Risks Posed by Oil Trains
description: MOSIER, Ore.  The Chinook salmon that Randy Settler and other Yakama tribal fishermen are pulling from the Columbia River are large and plentiful this summer, part of one of the biggest spawning runs since the 1960s. It is a sign, they say, of the rivers revitalization, through pollution regulations and ambitious fish hatchery programs.

title: Tim Kaine Recalled for Commitment to Richmonds African-Americans
description: RICHMOND, Va.  He offered the first formal apology for this citys role in the slave trade. He led the effort to add a statue of Arthur Ashe, a Richmond native, to its Monument Avenue. He attended a largely black church and sent his children to racially mixed schools.

title: Clinton? Trump? Either Way, Count on Deficit Spending to Rise
description: For most voters, the idea of more government borrowing and spending is about as popular as the Zika virus. And while Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump agree on almost nothing, mainstream Democrats and Republicans alike often talk about the national debt the way prohibitionists once discussed booze.

title: Let LeBron James and Others Bail From Rio. These Women? Not a Chance.
description: The most credentialed backcourt mates in womens basketball history are back, and of course they are. Certified gym rats do not abandon ship, even one that might be unsinkable without them.

title: After Rains and a Rare Allowance at the P.G.A. Championship, a Shot at That Elusive 62
description: SPRINGFIELD, N.J.  Phil Mickelson first raised the tantalizing possibility early Saturday afternoon. He reaffirmed it after his round finished Sunday.

title: How Paul Manafort Wielded Power in Ukraine Before Advising Donald Trump
description: WASHINGTON  Few political consultants have had a client fail quite as spectacularly as Paul Manaforts did in Ukraine in the winter of 2014.

title: Pupils at New Yorks Most Troubled Schools Keep Pace With Peers
description: On statewide tests for third through eighth graders this year, New York Citys most troubled schools kept pace with the rest of city schools, showing similar gains in reading and math.

title: Review: The Iron Heel Reworks a Jack London Dystopia
description: Jack Londons novel The Iron Heel is usually described as an early example of dystopian fiction. The book, from 1908, predicts a future in which the American working class has soundly defeated capitalism. For some modern readers, this is a nightmare scenario.

title: Jazz at Lincoln Center and Rockefeller Foundation Pair Up for School Tour
description: Jazz at Lincoln Center and the Rockefeller Foundation have announced a new education outreach program for students in disadvantaged schools. The program, Jazz for Young People: The Resilient Cities Tour, will connect live jazz performances to an American history curriculum, reaching 60 schools in five cities: Chicago; New Orleans; St. Louis; San Juan, P.R.; and Sydney, Australia.

title: The Night Of Season 1, Episode 4: Friends or Foes
description: As Nazir Khan, Riz Ahmed has excelled at playing a passive character, which is one of the more difficult assignments for an actor  or at least one of the more thankless, given the absence of emotional pyrotechnics. Fear and desire have motivated Naz, as Nazir is known, at every turn, leaving him paralyzed to the point where hes drifted through his time with Andrea and his time in the justice system in the same trance-like state of shock. Though the time between when he slept with Andrea and when we woke up downstairs in the kitchen has not been accounted for, his innocence seems assured because he does not seem capable of taking the aggressive, decisive action necessary to commit such a horrific crime of passion.

title: Review: Spouses, the Antichrist, and a Shrink and Ex-Patient Meet in Summer Shorts
description: We spend only about 15 minutes with the unnamed couple in Neil LaButes After the Wedding, and we want to know more about them. It is a testimony to Mr. LaButes skill that our curiosity should be so tickled, because these characters (played by the pitch-perfect Frank Harts and Elizabeth Masucci) are borderline sociopathic.

title: Review: Does Cats Have Nine Lives on Broadway? Two, Certainly
description: If I soon end up in a psychiatric ward, could someone please send the bill to Andrew Lloyd Webber?

title: With a Stunning Shot, Jason Day Almost Sanctifies His 2-Iron for the Ages. Almost.
description: SPRINGFIELD, N.J.  There was Jack Nicklauss 1-iron. Now there is Jason Days 2-iron.

title: Taliban Claim Responsibility for Bombing at a Kabul Hotel for Foreigners
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A powerful explosion shook Kabul, the Afghan capital, in the early hours of Monday, and Taliban militants claimed that they had targeted a heavily guarded guesthouse for foreign contractors on the outskirts of the city.

title: No Corrections: August 1, 2016
description: No corrections appeared in print.

title: Clean Athletes, and Olympic Glory Lost in the Doping Era
description: FOUNTAIN VALLEY, Calif.  Shirley Babashoff gazed out at the Los Angeles Basin, tucked in a flat sheet of sunshine, and sighed. The same storm clouds that washed away her prospects of seven gold medals at the Montreal Olympics 40 years ago are gathering over the Summer Games in Rio de Janeiro, which begin this week, threatening a rush of new members into an elite club no one wants to join: athletes who were denied a gold medal, or any medal at all, by competitors who were doping.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: People looked at me like I was the worst person in the world for saying the East German women looked like men. I said what I felt. Apparently, it didnt go over very well.

title: Uber to Sell to Rival Didi Chuxing and Create New Business in China
description: HONG KONG  Ubers future in China seemed to hold promise.

title: Whats on TV Monday: Iris and Meet the Donors: Does Money Talk?
description: In Iris, Albert Maysles celebrates the boldly eccentric style of the nonagenarian fashion plate Iris Apfel. Alexandra Pelosi finds out why the wealthy spend their cash on presidential campaigns in Meet the Donors: Does Money Talk? And Ashley Jensen, so long a sidekick, becomes a star in Agatha Raisin.

title: Cycling Along the Great Victorian Rail Trail
description: TALLAROOK, Australia  On the last afternoon of my bike ride through a rural part of the Australian state of Victoria, I pedaled past a whimsical sculpture of a motorcyclist who had plowed headfirst into a bale of hay.

title: Rediscovering the Kitchen, and Other Tips for Heart Health
description: First the bad news: After decades of major progress in reducing deaths from diseases of the heart and blood vessels, the decline in cardiovascular mortality has slowed significantly, according to the latest report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The researchers called their findings alarming, suggesting that cardiovascular benefits from medical interventions may have reached a saturation point and that further improvements depend largely on changes in society and personal behavior.

title: On Getting the Children to Read
description: To the Editor:

title: Making the Transition to Renewable Energy
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tale of Two Migration Flows
description: The Obama administration last week announced a series of modest, but sensible, steps to respond more humanely to the influx of migrants from Central America.

title: Americas Global Corruption Crusade
description: Last week, the Justice Department took the boldest action to date in its crackdown on international kleptocrats by suing three men close to Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia for allegedly pilfering more than $3 billion from the governments investment fund.

title: Hillary Clinton Made Me Cry
description: Bozeman, Mont.  My name is Geraldine Ferraro. In 1984, those words were, hands down, the most exciting sound I had ever heard coming out of a television. (No offense, Ted Koppel.) I was 14 years old.

title: Worthy of Our Contempt
description: Donald Trump said some more disgusting things over the weekend. If this surprises you, you havent been paying attention. Also, dont be surprised if a majority of Republicans approve of his attack on the parents of a dead war hero. After all, a YouGov survey found that 61 percent of Republicans support his call for Russian hacking of Hillary Clinton.

title: How Religion Can Lead to Violence
description: The latest victim is a French priest, murdered in his church by killers shouting Allahu akbar! Following such attacks, Muslim leaders assure us that, as Tariq Ramadan said after the Paris massacre, the murders are a pure betrayal of our religion. After the shootings in Brussels, the leading Sunni university, Al-Azhar, issued a statement saying,

title: Off to the Races
description: Attending both political parties conventions last month, I certainly had some upside-down-world moments.

title: Donald Trump Ducks Tax Disclosure
description: As Donald Trumps tweets pile one atop another, generating sensational headlines, issues of true substance are tending to get lost in the shuffle. None is more important for voters to keep in mind than the failure of Mr. Trump to disclose his full income tax returns, something he is not likely to do by Election Day.

title: Make Algorithms Accountable
description: Algorithms are ubiquitous in our lives. They map out the best route to our destination and help us find new music based on what we listen to now. But they are also being employed to inform fundamental decisions about our lives.

title: In Shinjuku, Blade Runner in Real Life
description: Daido Moriyamas images of Shinjuku are like being in Blade Runner, a futuristic place of phantoms, electric energy and tension.

title: Want a Copy of the Constitution? Now, Thats Controversial!
description: Passing out the Constitution on campus isnt the benign activity one might expect, especially when egged on by the Foundation for Individual Rights in Education. The group provides a pocket-size Student Activist Edition of the Constitution, which includes directions on how to hand it out and what to do if you get stopped: Refer administrators to the First Amendment (p. 43); Consider taking a video of the conversation; Contact FIRE for further assistance.

title: Restaurant Owner Spurns Those Who Are O.K. With AR-15s
description: PORTLAND, Me.  After a gunman killed 49 people in June at a gay nightclub in Orlando, Fla., Anne Verrill, a prominent Maine restaurateur, swung through a range of familiar emotions: frustration, anger, helplessness.

title: Putting Your Baby to Sleep: Some Advice and Good News
description: I remember thinking, after my pregnant wifes water broke minutes after I went to bed, anguishing really, over one thought as we drove to the hospital: Im never going to be well rested again.

title: Cambodia, Home of The Killing Fields, Becomes a Retirement Haven
description: Cambodia is a country of many a bad memory. American B-52s carpet-bombed it during the Vietnam War. It barely survived the rise of a despot named Pol Pot and the genocidal killing fields of his Khmer Rouge regime.

title: Hillary Clinton Targets a Skeptical Crowd: White Male Voters
description: HATFIELD, Pa.  Hillary Clinton would like to discuss some football.

title: Climate Change Divide Bursts to Forefront in Presidential Campaign
description: WASHINGTON  During the 2012 race for president, the issue of climate change was nearly invisible. President Obama and his Republican opponent, Mitt Romney, almost never spoke about it, and it did not come up during their debates. There was far more talk of increasing oil and gas production than of cutting emissions.

title: Fighting for Free Speech on Americas Campuses
description: The free-speech watchdog FIRE is a familiar irritant to college administrators, but until this past year, the rest of the country wasnt paying much attention. An epic year is what Greg Lukianoff, president and chief executive of the Foundation for Individual Rights in Education, calls it. Colleges and universities were forced to publicly and painfully deal with a confluence of national issues  race, sexual assault, gay rights, politically correct speech  mirrored and magnified in the microcosm of campus life.

title: Only 9% of America Chose Trump and Clinton as the Nominees
description: While Donald J. Trump or Hillary Clinton will represent the entire country, the Americans who selected them are a small part of it.

title: Inside St. Pauls Chapel in Lower Manhattan
description: The church is being renovated before its 250th anniversary in October.

title: Super White or White Dove? Restoring St. Pauls Colonial Color
description: King George III ruled New York when St. Pauls Chapel was built in Lower Manhattan.

title: In Shinjuku, Blade Runner in Real Life
description: When I walk in the evening with my camera from Kabuki-cho to Kuyakusho-dori and then along Okubo-dori toward Shin-Okubo Station, I sometimes feel a shiver running down my spine. I find myself flinching for some reason, even though nothing in particular has happened. Shadow-spirits squirm amid the darkness of the back streets, under the lights and neon signs. The sight line of the small camera in my hand picks up the sensitive reactions of these wraiths, like electrical impulses. As they perceive coarse tremors in the surrounding air, my cells quiver with tension. Wandering around, enveloped in the vaguely violent atmosphere, I persuade myself that it is my duty as a photographer to photograph Shinjuku without shrinking back.

title: A Debut Novel Grapples With Work, Marriage and Fertility
description: BREAK IN CASE OF EMERGENCYBy Jessica Winter269 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $25.95.

title: Tribes of TriBeCa: Jay McInerneys Latest Downtown Novel
description: BRIGHT, PRECIOUS DAYSBy Jay McInerney397 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $27.95.

title: Ask Polly, and Heather Havrilesky Will Answer
description: HOW TO BE A PERSON IN THE WORLDAsk Pollys Guide Through the Paradoxes of Modern LifeBy Heather HavrileskyIllustrated. 254 pp. Doubleday. $24.95

title: Inside Luca Guadagninos Home
description: The directors exquisitely art-directed movies have become something of an obsession among interior designers. But his ultimate set is own apartment outside of Milan.

title: Cancer in the Family: Compliments on Being Thin
description: Im so jealous. Youve lost so much weight, you look amazing, a friend says to me. Id love to catch the stomach bug this year and lose a few pounds myself.

title: Morning Agenda: Uber and Didi Chuxing Team Up in China
description: UBER AND DIDI CHUXING TEAM UP IN CHINA The battle for ride-sharing in China is over. Didi Chuxing plans to buy Uber China, according to people with knowledge of the deal. After spending tens of millions of dollars every month fighting for market share, the two companies will combine into a new one worth about $35 billion.

title: One Italian Filmmakers Ultimate Set  His Own Home
description: I hate the concept of beauty for the sake of it. It is overrated, says the Italian filmmaker Luca Guadagnino. This might sound odd coming from the creator of such movies as 2009s I Am Love and this years A Bigger Splash, each filled with ravishing, fashionable people moving through exquisitely appointed, haute bourgeois settings  a style that could be described as high aesthete with latent passions lurking beneath. Environment is essential. I like anything that has to do with form and space, says Guadagnino. But I am also a humanist [with] a very strong love and attraction for character. Thats the mixture.

title: Hillary Clinton, Donald Trump, P.G.A. Championship: Your Monday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Tim Kaine Begins Solo Trip With Homecoming Rally in Virginia
description: He made his debut with Hillary Clinton at a rally in South Florida, an occasion that gave him a chance to show off his Spanish.

title: Of Retirement Age, but Remaining in the Work Force
description: Students will soon return to Manse Elementary School in Pahrump, Nev., so Judith Lister has been getting her kindergarten classroom ready, filling the bookshelves and arranging floor pillows for read-aloud time. Shes about to tackle the bulletin boards.

title: Watching TV Tied to Fatal Clot Risk
description: The more television you watch, the greater your risk for a fatal blood clot, according to a new study.

title: New York Today: Olympians From New York
description: Updated, 10:54 a.m.

title: Learning to Stop Before Just Enough Becomes Way Too Much
description: The more you consume, the less content you are.

title: Attention, Teenagers: Nobody Really Looks Like That
description: The universal truth of puberty and adolescence is body change, and relatively rapid body change. Teenagers have to cope with all kinds of comparisons, with their peers, with the childhood bodies they leave behind, and with the altered images used in advertising and in the self-advertising on social media.

title: Trump and Clinton Chart Courses as General Election Season Begins
description: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton begin the post-convention general election campaign with a dash across the country, as Mrs. Clinton seeks to make inroads in Mr. Trumps base  and as Mr. Trump tries to stretch an electoral map that has rapidly contracted in recent days.

title: Once Mocked, the G Train Is Now Cool. Kind Of.
description: The G train has long been the outcast of New York Citys subway system. It was short. It came sporadically. It did not even go to Manhattan.

title: Taiwans President Apologizes to Aborigines for Centuries of Injustice
description: HONG KONG  President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan offered a formal apology on Monday to aboriginal peoples for centuries of pain and mistreatment, and she promised to take concrete steps to rectify a history of injustice.

title: Obamas American Idea
description: There is a line from a conversation 20 years ago between Barack Obama and the photographer Mariana Cook that offers an important insight into the president: All my life, he said, I have been stitching together a family, through stories or memories or friends or ideas.

title: Review: Jesus Christ Superstar, The Trial of Jane Fonda and Now We Are Here
description: LONDON  You might expect Londons summer theater to take on a correspondingly sunny hue, but no. While the stage event of the season, Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, delivers up an epic rife with family fissures and forces of darkness, a number of smaller productions are speaking to humans capacity for suffering, then and now.

title: Review: Harry Potter and the Cursed Child Explores the Power of Time
description: J. K. Rowlings magical seven-volume Harry Potter series is the ultimate bildungsroman, tracing that young wizards coming of age, as he not only battles evil but also struggles to come to terms with the responsibilities, losses and burdens of adulthood. In the course of those books, we see a plucky schoolboy, torn by adolescent doubts and confusions, grow into an epic hero, kin to King Arthur, Luke Skywalker and Spider-Man.

title: Burning Economic Issues Behind Americas Wildfire Problem
description: The West, and federal taxpayers, have a serious and growing problem as communities continue to expand in and around forested and grassy landscapes prone to fire.

title: 1916: Zeppelin Raid on England
description: LONDON  The latest information issued regarding last nights German air raid shows that six or seven Zeppelins took part in it, but although a number of bombs were dropped during the flight of the raiders over seven counties, it is officially announced that no one was killed or injured.

title: Not Forgotten: Yves Saint Laurent, Who Changed the Color of Couture
description: The designer was an early champion of black models and a proponent of pantsuits.

title: Turkeys Fractured State
description: GOTHENBURG, Sweden  The Turkish military is known to be a stronghold of Kemalism, the secularist and nationalist ideology of the founder of Turkey, Mustafa Kemal Ataturk. So when the Islamic conservative Justice and Development Party, known as the A.K.P., came to power in 2002, many then feared that the military would stage a coup in the name of Kemalism.

title: Russian Military Helicopter Is Shot Down in Syria, Killing 5
description: MOSCOW  A Russian military transport helicopter was shot down on Monday in the Syrian province of Idlib, killing the three crew members and two officers on board in the deadliest episode for the Russian military since it intervened in the country, Russian officials said.

title: Poultry Producer Sanderson Farms Stands Its Ground: Its Proud to Use Antibiotics
description: In the last couple of years, the poultry industry has sharply reduced its use of antibiotics, responding to concerns among public health officials and regulators about the rise of antibiotic-resistant bacteria.

title: The New Ideology of the New Cold War
description: HAMBURG, Germany  In its heyday, Communism claimed that capitalism had betrayed the worker. So what should we make of Moscows new battle cry, that democracy has betrayed the voter?

title: New Poll Reflects a Post-Convention Bounce for Hillary Clinton
description: Hillary Clinton received a surge of support after the Democratic National Convention, according to a new national poll that showed her opening a lead against Donald J. Trump with fewer than 100 days to go before the presidential election.

title: John McCain Denounces Donald Trumps Comments on Family of Muslim Soldier
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain sharply criticized Donald J. Trumps comments about the family of a fallen Muslim Army captain on Monday, a rebuke that provided an opening for other vulnerable Republican senators to do the same, even though they all stopped short of rescinding their endorsements of him.

title: In Tesla and SolarCity Deal, a Glimpse of Musks Clean-Energy Aspirations
description: In the face of questions about debt, widening losses, governance and strategic logic, Tesla Motors and SolarCity announced a $2.6 billion stock merger on Monday.

title: How Does an Australian Town of 100 Attract Tourists? A Music Festival and Camel Pie
description: BIRDSVILLE, Australia  Birdsville sits perched on the edge of the vast Simpson Desert, hundreds of miles from the nearest city, on the far reaches of the Australian outback.

title: A Chocolate for the Scotch Lover
description: Outside, these dark chocolate truffle squares from Los Angeles are adorned with arresting designs. Inside, they boast bold fillings, the newest of which are honey-peanut butter with sea salt, and Macallan 18-year-old single-malt Scotch: Comparts Chocolatier dark chocolate truffles, 5 to 20 truffles for $16 to $60 depending on the flavor, 310-826-3380, compartes.com.

title: A California Ice Cream Summers in New York
description: This summer, two Maman cafes are serving McConnells Fine Ice Creams from Santa Barbara, Calif. Six flavors are available in cups or waffle cones from a cart at Maman in TriBeCa. Sandwiches made with vanilla ice cream and unbaked chocolate-chip cookie dough will also be sold at the cart and at Mamans location in Greenpoint, Brooklyn: Ice cream, $4 to $8, Maman TriBeCa, 211 West Broadway (Franklin Street); Maman Greenpoint, 80 Kent Street (Franklin Street), mamannyc.com.

title: Cold-Brewed Coffee Without the Hourslong Wait
description: Cold-brewed coffee, for many the gold standard when it comes to a smooth-tasting cup, takes planning and time. Now the product developers at FirstBuild, a subsidiary of GE Appliances, have come up with the Prisma. The machine uses a vacuum infusion system to produce excellent cold-brewed coffee in a mere 10 minutes. The gadget has a handblown 23.7-ounce carafe and takes regular pleated-paper basket filters. But theres still a wait as presale orders will not deliver for about a year: Prisma Cold Brew Coffee Maker, $240 (discounted from what will be the regular price of $299), indiegogo.com.

title: A Hops Farm Turns to Brewing
description: A few years ago, Blake Arrowood, an English teacher in Southeast Asia, decided to become a farmer and cultivated 48 acres in the Hudson Valley, not far from New Paltz, N.Y. He grew hops along with rye, and raised ducks, too, and took on a brewing partner, Jacob Meglio, after the state passed legislation making it easier for farmers to brew beer. The farm now produces nine beers, including one made with organic rye. All are served at the farm, along with duck prosciutto made in-house. The brews are sold and served in the Hudson Valley and also at Malt and Molds two Manhattan locations. When the new Rouge Tomate reopens later this summer in Chelsea, a selection of Arrowoods beers will be the only ones offered on tap: Arrowood Farms, 236 Lower Whitfield Road, Accord, N.Y., 845-253-0389, arrowoodfarms.com.

title: New Inspiration for Summer Salads
description: Heres a cookbook to inspire when the heat is off the charts. Prep time for many of the salads in this colorful volume from Leon, a casual English chain, is five minutes. Bright ideas fill categories like classics, including a Greek salad topped, inventively, with fried feta. Polish herring and potatoes with beets in horseradish cream, and chicken tonnato with artichokes and haricots verts, are meal-worthy. The BKT salad swaps out lettuce for kale, and there are many cool Asian influences in the sprightly dressings. Basic ingredients, salad-making principles (including the architecture involved), an array of crunchy garnishes and dressings are included: Leon Happy Salads by Jane Baxter and John Vincent (Conran Octopus, $19.99).

title: His Assignment: Find the Worlds Best Bacon
description: Scott Gold, a 39-year-old food writer specializing in meat, beat out around 1,000 applicants for the title of bacon critic for Extra Crispy, Time Inc.s new website about breakfast, brunch and the foods involved. This job is tailor-made for me, he said with gusto. When it comes to bacon, he likes a medium-thick slice and a balance of smoke, fat and salt with an intensely porcine quality. He cant resist the bacon at Peter Luger Steak House in Brooklyn. Bacon is rarely terrible, he said. Who sends back bacon? At the same time, he acknowledges that spectacular bacon is hard to find. But now he is on the case, given three months to travel around the globe, reporting weekly on his discoveries. In November, at the end of his assignment, hell crown one bacon as the best: extracrispy.com.

title: 1966: Texas Sniper Slays 14
description: AUSTIN, TEXAS  A student sniper shot 12 persons to death and injured another 29 today [Aug. 1] in an 80-minute fusillade from the 26th floor of the University of Texas tower. Police finally shot him dead.

title: Harry Potters a Dad: Accio, Pacifier!
description: Our family is just home from the bookstore, with multiple copies of Harry Potter and the Cursed Child in hand, gamely reading in a new format  the book is the script of the play by the same name, and thus a different reading experience from the seven novels that came before it.

title: New Fund From Technology Crossover Ventures Draws $2.5 Billion
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The venture capital industry faced worries earlier in the year that it had hit a rocky patch. Yet investors keep pouring money into mammoth new venture funds.

title: Recipes for High Summer
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Sharing Video Streams on Facebook
description: Q. How do you make a Facebook Live video? Can anybody on Facebook see it?

title: Long Island Company Charged in Insurance Scheme After Hurricane Sandy
description: A Long Island engineering company and one of its former executives were charged on Monday in a scheme to minimize insurance payments to homeowners whose residences were damaged by Hurricane Sandy in 2012.

title: The Most Dominant American Basketball Team? The Olympic Women
description: Five straight gold medals, seven over all. A 41-game winning streak. A 58-3 record.

title: Oracle, Having Bet Billions on Its Future, Sets Sights on Data Analysis
description: Oracle Corporation may well be the single most important technology firm for businesses. Over 300,000 companies around the world use its database, and 100,000 customers have purchased its business applications. Even companies gunning for Oracle  like Amazon, Google and Salesforce  have used Oracles technology.

title: Ten Years Later, the Real JT LeRoy Tells All
description: In a new documentary, Author: The JT LeRoy Story, Laura Albert, who posed as a teenage male-prostitute-turned-novelist in the late 90s, finally tells her side of the story. Here, she reflects on how times have changed.

title: With Room Service and More, Hospitals Borrow From Hotels
description: At the Henry Ford West Bloomfield Hospital outside Detroit, patients arrive to uniformed valets and professional greeters. Wi-Fi is free and patient meals are served on demand 24 hours a day. Members of the spa staff give in-room massages and other treatments.

title: A United Effort to Overhaul Corporate Governance
description: A newly released compendium of common-sense principles offers a promising basis from which boards may recalibrate their approach to fundamental elements of corporate governance.

title: Why Are Eggs Sold by the Dozen? Why Not by 10s or 8s?
description: Ask The Times, a Times Insider feature, draws on New York Times expertise to answer questions about current events, science, sports, culture and whatever else is making headlines.

title: U.S. Conducts Airstrikes Against ISIS in Libya
description: WASHINGTON  The United States escalated its war against the Islamic State in Libya on Monday, conducting airstrikes in the coastal city of Surt as part of a new military campaign against the extremist Sunni terrorist groups stronghold in North Africa.

title: Meet Deitas, the Line Making Sleek Silk Pieces
description: For her four-year-old line, the designer Josephine Dahlin is most inspired by the act of travel.

title: Brand to Know: The Line Making Silk Modern (and Packable)
description: Ask any artist, clothier or writer where they find inspiration and theyre bound to mention travel. The Swedish designer Josephine Dahlin is no exception  but she doesnt just mean beautiful vistas, museum visits and unexpected discoveries. Shes talking about the fundamentals, too, like packing and planning the days activities. I wanted to have a collection that you can pack in a suitcase to cover all your needs, she says of her clothing line Deitas. So itll always remain capsule size. With simple lines, mixable pieces and a muted palette, Deitas cuts down on the plague of morning indecision by offering the ease of a weekend-away-wardrobe at home.

title: The Same Court Time
description: Our puzzle this week was suggested by Marco Moriconi, a regular Numberplay contributor who makes his home in Rio, site of the upcoming Olympic Games.Marco is also a professor of physics at the Universidade Federal Fluminense,andwrites a monthly math column for the Brazilian national science magazine, Cincia Hoje (Science Today), called Qual o Problema? (Whats the Problem?)

title: This Is Your Life, Brought to You by Private Equity
description: Since the financial crisis, the private equity industry has become hugely influential. Heres how it plays out in your daily life.

title: The Economy Has Slowed Down
description: For three quarters in a row, the growth rate of the economy has hovered around a mere 1 percent. In the last quarter of 2015 and the first quarter of 2016, the economy expanded at feeble annual rates of 0.9 percent and 0.8 percent, respectively. The initial reading for the second quarter of this year, released on Friday, was a disappointing 1.2 percent.

title: As ISIS Posts in Portuguese, U.S. and Brazil Bolster Olympics Security
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Worried about possible terrorist attacks at the Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, Brazils government is working closely with American law enforcement and intelligence services to identify threats and thwart potential disasters at the Games.

title: Indictment in Hurricane Sandy Fraud Case
description: Eric T. Schneiderman, the New York attorney general, accused GEB Hi-Rise Engineering, of Uniondale, N.Y., and Matthew Pappalardo, a former director, of altering engineering reports that had been used to assess the structural damage to residential properties caused by Hurricane Sandy.

title: Drakes Views Numbers Slip, but He Holds on to a 12th Week at No. 1
description: This week on the album chart, Drake reached No. 1 for a 12th time, but his reign may be winding down.

title: What You Should Watch : Films New to Netflix and Gilmore Girls
description: Welcome to Watching, The New York Timess what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. You can browse previous guides here, and to receive recommendations straight to your inbox, sign up here. Stay tuned for our coming website.

title: Zika Surge in Miami Neighborhood Prompts Travel Warning
description: Federal health officials on Monday urged pregnant women to stay away from a Miami neighborhood where they have discovered additional cases of Zika infection  apparently the first time the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has advised people not to travel to a place in the continental United States.

title: Pocket Constitution Sales Soar After Trump Feud With Khan Family
description: The Constitution appears to be having a moment.

title: Streaming the News
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Top Facialists and What Theyre Recommending for Summer Skin
description: Summer sun can be glorious with its bronzing rays and natural dose of vitamin D. But along with it comes the dark spots, the photo-aging and the clogged pores. Here, three facialists who have been heating up the beauty scene with their deft skills (and celebrity clientele) suggest the best skin care remedies for the season.

title: F.B.I. Employee Pleads Guilty to Acting as an Agent of China
description: The authorities secured a guilty plea on Monday from a longtime employee of the Federal Bureau of Investigation accused of lying about his relationship with a Chinese technology company and various Chinese associates.

title: In an Effort to Maintain U.S. Ties, Turkey Softens Its Tone
description: ANKARA, Turkey  In the two weeks since a failed coup, Turkish officials and the pro-government media have whipped up anti-American sentiment by suggesting that the United States played some role in the botched conspiracy to topple the government.

title: Accessible Child Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Lives Matter Coalition Makes Demands as Campaign Heats Up
description: More than 60 organizations associated with the Black Lives Matter movement have released a series of demands on Monday, including for reparations.

title: Yes, We Have No Peaches
description: Along with humidity and the hum of cicadas, every August in central Connecticut brings the Lyman Orchards Peach Festival, a day of outdoor cooking and music, face-painting and pony rides.

title: Dog-Days Pet Protections
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Universe Defends Miss Teen USA After Her Apology for Using Racial Slur
description: The Miss Universe Organization on Monday defended the new Miss Teen USA, Karlie Hay, 18, after reports revealed this weekend that she had repeatedly used a racial slur online against African-Americans.

title: Times Insider Photo Challenge: Caption This!
description: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. Occasionally, we have some fun.

title: Schuberts Sonata in B flat, D. 960
description: Paul Lewis performs the last page of Schuberts final piano sonata.

title: Can You Sign Here? Alabama Law Aims to Keep Cursive in Schools
description: Except when you sign a check  if you even do that anymore  you may hardly use the loops and swirls of cursive.

title: A Muslim Father, a Soldiers Ultimate Sacrifice
description: Like millions of people watching the Democratic National Convention last week, Janine Altongy was reduced to tears by the emotional  and forceful  remarks of Khizr Khan, a Muslim immigrant from Pakistan whose son, a United States Army captain, died in Iraq in 2004. Moved by his testimony, she urged her husband, Eugene Richards, to watch the speech.

title: Tesla-SolarCity Deal Could Distract the Carmaker
description: Tesla Motors deal to buy SolarCity, officially unveiled on Monday, is still perplexing. But at least Teslas boss, the electric-car pioneer Elon Musk, is making the best of the terms and process. At $2.6 billion, the price for the solar-panel installer where he is chairman is lower than expected, and the two boards have done the right things. But it still risks distracting Tesla, valued at $35 billion, at a critical time.

title: Trump Faces Backlash Over Khan Remarks
description: Donald Trump is facing criticism from Democrats and Republicans over his comments to Khizr Khan and his wife after a speech at the Democratic convention. Their son, an Army captain, died in Iraq.

title: Setting the Bodys Serial Killers Loose on Cancer
description: BETHESDA, Md.  The young surgeon was mystified. A fist-size tumor had been removed from the stomach of his patient 12 years earlier, but his doctors had not been able to cut out many smaller growths in his liver. The cancer should have killed him, yet here he lay on the table for a routine gallbladder operation.

title: A Muslim Father, a Soldiers Ultimate Sacrifice
description: When Eugene Richards heard the emotional remarks of Khizr Khan, whose son died in action in Iraq, he realized their paths had crossed during a moment of grief at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: British Decision on Nuclear Plant Angers China and France
description: LONDON  The decision of the new British government to postpone a deal on a nuclear power station, to be built by France with major Chinese investment, has shocked both of those countries and is a potentially major step away from the policies of former Prime Minister David Cameron.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Are All the Fireflies?
description: Q. In 1980, when I moved to Brooklyn, I saw many fireflies in my garden, but at some point, they disappeared. Are they in trouble, or is it just in my microenvironment?

title: Schuberts Final Acceptance, Rueful as Always
description: The British pianist Paul Lewis, 44, is one of todays finest exponents of Schubert, noted for his clarity of tone and simplicity of interpretation. I asked him to talk about a single page of Schuberts piano music; he chose the final page of the slow movement from the Sonata in B flat (D. 960), Schuberts last. Here are edited excerpts from the conversation.

title: Islands Mammoths May Have Been Thirsty at Their Extinction
description: About 6,000 years ago, St. Paul Island, a tiny spot of land in the middle of the Bering Sea, must have been a strange place. Hundreds of miles away from the mainland, it was uninhabited except for a few species of small mammals, like arctic foxes, and one big one: woolly mammoths.

title: She Swam to Escape Syria. Now Shell Swim in Rio.
description: BERLIN  Yusra Mardini, an Olympic swimmer, was an hour and a half into her first training session of the day, butterfly-kicking down the length of a pool with a yellow rubber duck balanced on her head.

title: Supreme Court Could Redefine Insider Trading Law
description: There are longstanding differences between Boston and New York, like the rivalry between the Red Sox and the Yankees. Adding a new one, the federal appeals courts in each city have taken different approaches to the type of benefit a tipper must receive in exchange for inside information to make trading on it a violation of the securities laws.

title: Guilty Plea in 07 Murder Ends New Yorks Longest Unresolved Case
description: After nine years in jail and three trials without a verdict, a Bronx man pleaded guilty to manslaughter on Monday in a 2007 murder, a move that closes New York Citys longest unresolved case.

title: Five Products for a Perfect Summer Shower
description: The seasons new body cleansers dont just smell nice  they very seriously detox, scrub and lather.

title: In London, Back-Stabbing and Conniving (Onstage and Off)
description: LONDON  You know these are scary times when Richard III starts to look like real life.

title: Mets Acquire Jay Bruce and Jon Niese in Trades at Deadline
description: The Cincinnati Reds did not have a game on Monday, so Jay Bruce was home with his wife, Hannah, and their 3-month-old son, Carter. Bruce had been on the trading block since last year, so he knew a change was likely.

title: Scientists Ponder an Evolutionary Mystery: The Female Orgasm
description: An eye is for seeing, a nose is for smelling. Many aspects of the human body have obvious purposes.

title: Cats Returns to Broadway With a Roaring Party
description: Leona Lewis, Andrew Lloyd Webber, Tituss Burgess and Tommy Tune attend opening night and the after-party at Gotham Hall.

title: Maryland Flash Flood Kills 2
description: Ellicott City, Md., was devastated by flooding on Saturday night, which left two people dead.

title: Benjamin Netanyahus Spokesman, on Press Freedom in Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Fathers of 1994 Bombing Victims in Argentina Keep Pushing for Justice
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Relatives of victims of the 1994 attack of a Jewish center in Buenos Aires sought Monday to reopen a criminal complaint against former President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner accusing her of trying to derail an investigation into the bombing, which killed 85 people.

title: Officer Responding to Queens Burglary Call Shoots Man
description: A 38-year-old man was shot on Monday by a New York City police officer who was responding to a burglary call in Queens, the authorities said.

title: Yankees Continue to Deal, Trading Carlos Beltran and Ivan Nova
description: The newest Yankee sat at his locker Monday, moments after the nonwaiver trade deadline, and declared himself thrilled to be there.

title: Donald Trump, Under Heavy Fire
description: To the Editor:

title: Thousands of Indian Workers Are Stuck in Saudi Arabia as Kingdoms Economy Sags
description: NEW DELHI  The Indian government is struggling to support thousands of its citizens who have lost their jobs in Saudi Arabia, Indias minister of external affairs said on Monday, a new indication of how the drop in global oil prices has affected the Arab worlds largest economy and those who rely on it for their livelihoods.

title: A Homecoming for Hellbenders, the Biggest Salamanders in North America
description: Take a two-foot-long muscle with a skeleton and coat it in multiple layers of snot. Now squish the muscle down so its flat. Add four short legs, eighteen toes, a big, wide mouth and beady eyes. Forget about eyelids. Stretch some skin out along the slimy muscle and wrinkle it on the sides. This is how it will breath. Now stick that creature under a big rock in a fast river or stream and leave it alone. Youve just made an adult eastern hellbender, the biggest salamander in North America.

title: Obama Says V.A. Has Made Progress on Veterans Health Care
description: ATLANTA  President Obama said on Monday that his administration had made strides in turning around the veterans health care system, highlighting a decline in the number of veterans facing long waits for doctor visits.

title: China Frees Wang Yu, Human Rights Lawyer, After Videotaped Confession
description: BEIJING  A prominent lawyer jailed as part of a crackdown on human rights lawyers in China has been released from detention, according to news reports on Monday, even as her colleagues suggested that a videotaped confession she had offered had probably been coerced.

title: Nick Denton Files for Bankruptcy, Just Weeks After Gawker Did
description: Nick Denton, the founder and chief executive of Gawker Media, filed for personal bankruptcy on Monday to protect himself from a legal judgment awarded in March to the former professional wrestler Hulk Hogan in an invasion-of-privacy lawsuit.

title: Gloria DeHaven, Sweetheart in Many a Movie Musical, Dies at 91
description: Gloria DeHaven, the perky daughter of vaudeville stars who grew up to sing, dance and play vulnerable, pouty-lipped ingnues in movie musicals of the 1940s and 50s, died on Saturday in Las Vegas. She was 91.

title: Ghazala Khan Is a Gold Star Mother. Heres What That Means.
description: Its a distinction no family wants.

title: Under Pressure, Big Banks Vie for Instant Payment Market
description: In this digital age when almost anything can be had in an instant, the movement of money can seem glaringly slow.

title: In Las Vegas, All You Need Is Love and Eight Million Beatles Fans
description: LAS VEGAS  When asked about the possibility of a Beatles reunion, John Lennon sometimes demurred by evoking what he considered the most depressing prospect facing rock musicians who cling to stardom too long: Going to Vegas and singing your great hits, as he put it in an interview shortly before his death in 1980.

title: Cats Is Back, Whether You Like It or Not
description: Thirty-four years and 7,485 performances after its original Broadway debut, Cats reopened Sunday afternoon at the Neil Simon Theater on West 52nd Street, where the red carpet filled with Broadway types and TV personalities.

title: Frank Oceans Long-Awaited Boys Dont Cry Is Due on Friday
description: The long wait for a new Frank Ocean album may nearly be over.

title: The Poet Kevin Young Is Named New Director of Schomburg Center
description: The poet and scholar Kevin Young has been named director of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem, a division of the New York Public Library and a leading repository for archival materials relating to African and African-American life, history and culture.

title: Seymour Papert, 88, Dies; Saw Educations Future in Computers
description: Seymour Papert, a visionary educator and mathematician who well before the advent of the personal computer foresaw children using computers as instruments for learning and enhancing creativity, died on Sunday at his home in Blue Hill, Me. He was 88.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Bad Moms
description: The directors Jon Lucas and Scott Moore narrate a scene from Bad Moms, featuring Mila Kunis, Kathryn Hahn and Kristen Bell.

title: Warren Buffett Is Latest Billionaire to Excoriate Donald Trump
description: OMAHA  The investor and philanthropist Warren Buffett unleashed a withering attack on Donald J. Trump on Monday for refusing to release his tax returns, asserting he had something to hide, and for misleading voters about his success as a businessman and ability to improve the American economy.

title: Panel Calls for Prosecution of Nigerian Soldiers in Killings of Hundreds of Shiites
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Nigerian soldiers should be prosecuted for killing more than 300 people last year in battles with a sect of Shiite Muslims, according to a report issued Monday by a Nigerian judicial panel.

title: Jon Lucas and Scott Moore Narrate a Scene From Bad Moms
description: In one scene from the comedy Bad Moms, three mothers (played by Mila Kunis, Kathryn Hahn and Kristen Bell) cut loose and go wild in a supermarket. The directors Jon Lucas and Scott Moore discussed the scene in a recent interview. Below are edited excerpts from that conversation.

title: March Graphic Novel Revisits Civil Rights Movement in Rich Detail
description: The third book of March, United States Representative John Lewiss graphic novel trilogy about the civil rights movement, comes out on Tuesday. But Mr. Lewis, Democrat of Georgia, said he hoped that his firsthand account of the struggle for equality and the power of nonviolent civil disobedience would continue to inspire a new generation of activists.

title: McDonalds Tweaks Its Recipes: Now, Real Butter in the McMuffin
description: OAK BROOK, Ill.  McDonalds long shied away from talking about how it makes the food on its menu and what is in that food. The company is now being open and loud about it.

title: For de Blasio, Another Grim Poll Offers Better News About 2017 Race
description: A majority of New York City voters continue to disapprove of Mayor Bill de Blasios job performance, according to a Quinnipiac University poll released on Monday, but he would still probably fare well in a matchup against at least two of his potential Democratic primary rivals.

title: In Gowanus, a Peoples Housing Plan to Challenge the Mayors
description: Last week, Mayor Bill de Blasio took an early victory lap on his campaign pledge to build and preserve 200,000 units of affordable housing by 2024. City Hall announced that nearly 53,000 affordable apartments were saved or put in the pipeline for construction during the past two and a half years.

title: For San Franciscos Queen of Philanthropy, No Quiet Exits
description: SAN FRANCISCO  No other city in America mixes high society and cultural philanthropy quite like San Francisco, and Diane Wilsey, known as Dede, has long been the indomitable queen of both.

title: Over (Organic) Dinner, These Fitness Studio Competitors Work It Out
description: When Vanessa Packer, the founder of the fitness studio ModelFIT, gets together for a monthly dinner with her fellow fitness-studio-owning friends Alexandra Bonetti Prez (of the cardio-dance Bari studio) and Sarah Larson-Levey (of the yoga chain Y7), they indulge.

title: Review: New York Musical Festival Is a Smorgasbord
description: The offerings at the annual, three-week-long smorgasbord of new musicals known as the New York Musical Festival are so wide-ranging  they vary drastically in subject and quality  that careless scheduling could cause whiplash among audience members. One moment, you might encounter a drama-club-level show; the next, a production more than ready for prime time.

title: Donald Trump, Hillary Clinton, Harry Potter: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Looking, Quickly, for the Fingerprints of Climate Change
description: When days of heavy rain in late May caused deadly river flooding in France and Germany, Geert Jan van Oldenborgh got to work.

title: Arm Warmers, Whiskers and Warm-Ups: A Ballerina Becomes a Jellicle Cat
description: A look behind the scenes during Georgina Pazcoguins first opening night on Broadway.

title: Rare Show of Discord Between I.O.C. and World Anti-Doping Agency Over Russian Scandal
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Fallout from the Russian doping scandal has provoked a public dispute among global sports officials, further fueling a controversy that has threatened to overshadow the start of the Rio Games this week.

title: Irans Top Leader Distances Himself from Nuclear Pact, Which He Once Supported
description: Irans top leader distanced himself on Monday from the nuclear agreement reached with major powers a year ago, accusing the United States of failing to honor pledges in the accord and citing the futility of negotiations with the Americans.

title: Federal Judge Bars North Dakota From Enforcing Restrictive Voter ID Law
description: A federal judge on Monday barred North Dakota from enforcing the states strict voter identification-card law, adding to several recent federal court rulings that such laws may disenfranchise minority voters.

title: Muslims and Christians in French Town Pray Old Bonds Survive Priests Murder
description: ST.-TIENNE-DU-ROUVRAY, France  It was the first time since a childhood school trip that Anissa Latroche had set foot in a church.

title: De Palma and De Niro in Our Apartment
description: Dear Diary:

title: Theranos, Embattled Laboratory, Shifts to Medical Machines
description: PHILADELPHIA  Elizabeth Holmes tried to salvage the reputation of her embattled blood-testing company here on Monday, discussing its technology and data at a scientific meeting for the first time. Instead of focusing on sins of the past, she made promises for the future.

title: New York State Aiding Nuclear Plants With Millions in Subsidies
description: Utility customers in New York State will pay nearly $500 million a year in subsidies aimed at keeping some upstate nuclear power plants operating, regulators in Albany decided on Monday.

title: Four Fresh Major Champions, but Still No Golf Savior
description: Spotted in the gallery at the P.G.A. Championship this weekend was a spectator wearing a bright red T-shirt  as boldly red as Donald J. Trumps favorite baseball cap. Across the chest of the T-shirt were four words, written in white capital letters: Make Tiger Great Again.

title: 2 Former Venezuelan Antidrug Officials Charged With Aiding Cocaine Ring
description: Two former officials of Venezuelas federal antidrug agency have been charged in New York with taking part in an international narcotics ring that worked with traffickers to ship cocaine into the United States, federal prosecutors in Brooklyn said.

title: Georgina Pazcoguin on Her First Broadway Opening Night, in Cats
description: The cats in Cats are a diverse group. Victoria, the most elegant of the Jellicle tribe, wears white from head to paw, symbolizing purity and innocence. For Georgina Pazcoguin, the New York City Ballet soloist who plays Victoria in the current Broadway revival of that Andrew Lloyd Webber musical, the role fulfills a childhood dream. She grew up obsessed with a videotape of the Broadway production. Catholic school ended at 2 p.m., and my dance classes started at 4:30 or 5 p.m., she said. In between, she watched Cats.

title: Why Corporate America Is Leaving the Suburbs for the City
description: WILMINGTON, Del.  For decades, many of the nations biggest companies staked their futures far from the fraying downtowns of aging East Coast and Midwestern cities. One after another, they decamped for sprawling campuses in the suburbs and exurbs.

title: Review: How Everything Became War and the Military Became Everything
description: In 2009, Rosa Brooks, a newly appointed civilian adviser at the Pentagon, had a dispiriting conversation with Samantha Power, then on the National Security staff. Ms. Brooks had solemn doubts about the prisoners living in indefinite detention at Guantnamo Bay. This was her field of expertise  human rights, international law. Yet her new colleagues wouldnt give her a proper hearing.

title: Donald Trumps Selective Service Records
description: For many years, Donald J. Trump, asserted that it was ultimately a high draft lottery number that kept him out of the Vietnam War, rather than a medical condition. But his Selective Service records, obtained from the National Archives, suggest otherwise.

title: Donald Trumps Registration Card
description: After his 18th birthday in June 1964, Donald J. Trump registered with the Selective Service, as did all men his age. It was the summer after his graduation from New York Military Academy and Mr. Trump recalled filling out his papers with his father, Fred Trump, at the local draft office on Jamaica Avenue in Queens.

title: Donald Trumps Draft Deferments: Four for College, One for Bad Feet
description: Back in 1968, at the age of 22, Donald J. Trump seemed the picture of health.

title: Donald Trump Finds a Russian Policy He Wont Defend
description: WASHINGTON  Donald J. Trumps statements on Russia tend to follow a pattern. He will say something in support of the country, praising its leader or promising to realign some aspect of American policy to its benefit. Foreign policy experts will express outrage, and Mr. Trump, ever defiant, will refuse to budge.

title: Even Uber Couldnt Bridge the China Divide
description: Travis Kalanick, the co-founder and chief executive of the ride-hailing giant Uber, often defended his eagerness to risk billions on winning the Chinese market with a simple question: If you have a chance to become Amazon and Alibaba at the same time, why not try?

title: Suzanne Wright, a Founder of Autism Speaks, Dies at 69
description: Suzanne Wright, a co-founder of Autism Speaks, a charity that fights for the autistic and teaches people how to spot and deal with the disorder, died on Friday at her home in Fairfield, Conn. She was 69.

title: Again, Assembly of Indias Doubles Tennis Teams Reveals Fissures
description: India loves Bollywood, and its Olympic tennis team has inadvertently provided a sequel suitable for the countrys renowned film industry.

title: The Activist and Herbalife: Just Maybe Ackmans Right
description: Bill Ackman, the activist investor, has been painted as a loser in his yearslong quest to shut down Herbalife, the nutritional supplement company that he bet against, contending it defrauded customers and was a pyramid scheme.

title: Tracking Bill Ackmans Bets
description: Mr. Ackman specializes in making big, concentrated bets. Sometimes his investments score big, but thats not always the case. Heres how some of his ideas have fared.

title: The Mets Look to October. The Yankees, Far Beyond.
description: The Mets and the Yankees collide this week, two games in Queens and two more in the Bronx. Really, though, they are headed in opposite directions. Their records are similar, but their missions are not.

title: Donald Trump Reaffirms Support for Warmer Relations With Putin
description: MECHANICSBURG, Pa.  Donald J. Trump unabashedly trumpeted his support for warmer relations with Russia at a campaign rally here on Monday night, acidly mocking opponents who say he is too friendly to Vladimir V. Putin, the countrys strongman president.

title: Body Camera Failed to Record Chicago Police Shooting of Black Teenager
description: CHICAGO  A Chicago officer whose police powers were suspended after the officer shot an African-American teenager in the back last week was wearing a body camera, but the device was not operating and did not record the fatal encounter, officials said on Monday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: The Americans are playing a key role in homing in on areas that we need to examine. I dont know how the F.B.I. got their intelligence, but it turned out to be a very valuable lead.

title: Plan Seeks to Aid Rugbys Growth With a Global Event on U.S. Soil
description: When an Australian sports promoter named Jason Moore gazes across the vast and increasingly varied American sports landscape, he sees room to grow for yet another international sport: rugby league.

title: Marta Marzotto, Italian Designer and Socialite, Dies at 85
description: ROME  Marta Marzotto, a fashion and jewelry designer, former model, countess and hostess to the famous, died on Friday in Milan. She was 85.

title: Tip for Players
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  Aspiring to greatness is a wonderful thing, but where you wind up depends quite a bit on how high or low you set the proverbial bar. You can aim for glory or you can say, At the very least, I dont want to be ___ .

title: U.N. Deadlocked Over Draft Agreement on Refugees and Migrants
description: UNITED NATIONS  More people are forcibly displaced from their homes today than at any time since the end of the Second World War.

title: No Indictment for Mississippi Officer in Fatal Shooting of Black Man
description: ATLANTA  A Mississippi grand jury found on Monday that a white police officer had committed no crime when he fatally shot a black man he had been chasing after the man was pulled over in Tupelo.

title: Comptrollers Report on Nursing Home Deal Cites Breakdowns in Communication
description: Memos went unread. The mayor said he was in the dark. But one person understood how New Yorks bureaucracy could allow for a Manhattan nursing home to be sold to luxury condominium developers: Joel Landau, the man whose company flipped it for a $72 million profit.

title: Elio Guaitolini, Restaurateur to New Yorks Elite, Dies at 83
description: Elio Guaitolini, whose namesake restaurant on the Upper East Side, Elios, has served as an informal clubhouse for Manhattans social and media elite since opening in 1981, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83.

title: Christine Quinn and Corey Lewandowski Bicker Over Trumps Khan Remarks
description: Many of New Yorks public figures remember the first time they incurred the wrath of Christine C. Quinn, the former City Council speaker known for her unapologetically forceful style.

title: Yankees Pare Their Roster, but Its Mets Who Wind Up Short
description: The Mets and the Yankees met Monday night at Citi Field with starkly different outlooks. The Yankees had completed five trades over the previous week, exchanging key veterans for prospects and the hope of a new future. The Mets, on the other hand, had worked to shore up weaknesses  namely, their offense and their pitching depth  in hopes of a playoff push similar to last seasons.

title: Danny Duffy Strikes Out a Team-Record 16 as Royals Defeat the Rays
description: Danny Duffy pitched eight innings of one-hit ball and had a team-record 16 strikeouts to lead the Kansas City Royals to a 3-0 road win over the Tampa Bay Rays on Monday night.

title: Corrections: August 2, 2016
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Whats on TV Tuesday
description: PBS gears up for Rio with The Boys of 36, about the working-class American rowers who took the gold at the 1936 Berlin Olympics. Sliding Doors, starring Gwyneth Paltrow in her It Girl prime, comes to Netflix. And Season 3 of Silks, the BBC series in which barristers fight for the right to wear big wigs, has its debut on Hulu.

title: South Korea Bans Volkswagen From Selling 80 Models in Country
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea on Tuesday stripped Volkswagen of its right to sell 80 models in the country, part of the global fallout from the carmakers emission deception.

title: As Homes and Cars Go, So Goes the Economy
description: Purchases of homes and cars are the twin pillars of the consumer economy  the starting point for other major economic activity, including taking out loans, buying insurance, paying taxes and spending on goods and services. As such, they are key measures of the depth of a recession and the strength of a recovery.

title: How Did a Nursing Home Become a Luxury Condo?
description: Another day, another investigation into Mayor Bill de Blasios administration. While the mayor likes to boast that his administration is competent, transparent and accountable, the facts occasionally suggest an entirely different set of adjectives.

title: Barriers to Reforming Police Practices
description: Second of two articles.

title: Mr. Trump and Spineless Republicans
description: Just when it seems that Donald Trump could not display more ignorance and bad judgment or less of a moral compass, he comes up with another ignominy or two. This weekend he denigrated the parents of a fallen American military hero and suggested that if elected he might recognize Russias claims to Ukraine and end sanctions.

title: How Artists Change the World
description: As usual, there were a ton of artists and musicians at the political conventions this year. And that raises some questions. How much should artists get involved in politics? How can artists best promote social change?

title: Turning the Tide on Voting Rights
description: Studio City, Calif.  Has the tide against restrictive voting laws turned?

title: Homeownership at 50-Year Low  So What?
David Muir on How to Break Into Broadcast News
description: At 42, David Muir is the youngest person to anchor a network evening newscast since Peter Jennings in the 1960s. In nearly two years in the chair at ABCs World News Tonight, Mr. Muir has overseen a ratings rise and scored high-profile sit-downs with President Obama, Tim Cook of Apple and Pope Francis. But it all began at the Roy H. Park School of Communication at Ithaca College in upstate New York, where Mr. Muir, class of 95, landed an anchor seat on the student newscast as a freshman.

title: In France, a Recipe Squabble over Marseille Soap
description: Marseille soap, or Savon de Marseille, is as French as wine and cheese, with a history that dates from the Middle Ages. Frenchwomen swear by the crude square blocks, which they use as a natural skin cleanser and, in a pinch, as anything from a toothpaste substitute to a moth repellent.

title: Harley Quinn, Just the Nice, Fun-Loving Psycho Next Door
description: The world of superhero comics is filled with tortured souls. One guy, grief-stricken after the vicious murder of his parents, dresses up as a bat to fight crime. Another similarly grief-stricken fellow dresses up as a spider. And those are the heroes.

title: A Gloomy Egypt Sees Its International Influence Wither Away
description: CAIRO  In a televised speech, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, a general turned president, warned Egyptians that they lived in a broken country surrounded by enemies who would never leave them alone.

title: Turkish Gold Trader Builds a Dream Team of Defense Lawyers
description: When Reza Zarrab, a wealthy gold trader from Turkey, was in need of a top-flight lawyer after his arrest in March, he hired Benjamin Brafman, one of New Yorks most prominent defense lawyers.

title: After Dallas Attack, Hundreds of Applicants Answer a Call for Backup
description: DALLAS  For two years, Dakota Leierer has worked two-week shifts in the oil fields of West Texas, sleeping in trailers and driving four hours to see his wife and two young children. But on July 7, when a gunman killed five police officers in Dallas, Mr. Leierer decided he needed to make a change. He wanted to become a Dallas officer.

title: Are Final Clubs Too Exclusive for Harvard?
description: One midnight near semesters end on the skirts of Harvard Yard, music thumped and laughs rang out from a colonnaded, Greek-revival mansion, the sort usually seen in Hollywood fantasies about fraternal campus life. But it was the scene outside that suggested something other than a frat party. This was the headquarters of the Fly, an exclusive mens fellowship known here as a final club. At its side door stood a silver-haired man in tuxedo, checking names against a list of the lucky invited. Eager young women in micro-minis queued up.

title: In Hot Milk, a Woman Struggles to Break Free of Her Hypochondriacal Mother
description: HOT MILKBy Deborah Levy218 pp. Bloomsbury. $26.

title: In Delia Ephrons Siracusa, Relationships Fall Apart Under the Sicilian Sun
description: SIRACUSABy Delia Ephron288 pp. Blue Rider Press. $26.

title: Donald Trump, Hillary Clinton, Zika Virus: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: G.O.P. Congressional Primary in Kansas Threatens Former Foil to Boehner
description: Congressional primaries are on the agenda throughout August, and a big one takes place on Tuesday in a sprawling House district in Kansas.

title: Are You Ready to Eat Your Natto?
description: Does a stinky, fermented soybean condiment belong on your plate? Ann Yonetani, a microbiologist turned food entrepreneur, thinks so.

title: New York Today: The Race to Recycle
description: Updated, 10:34 a.m.

title: Japan Announces More Stimulus Measures as Economy Struggles
description: TOKYO  In the three and a half years since he won the Japanese prime ministers office on a pledge to rekindle economic growth, Shinzo Abe has tried many tactics to coax the economy into expanding.

title: Morning Agenda: Herbalife vs. Activist: Just Maybe Hes Right
description: HERBALIFE VS. ACTIVIST: JUST MAYBE HES RIGHT Bill Ackman, the activist investor, has been painted as a loser in his quest to shut down Herbalife, the nutritional supplement company, but a Federal Trade Commissions complaint has vindicated his claims, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes.

title: Why Do So Many Contemporary American Authors Send Their Characters Abroad?
description: In Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Siddhartha Deb and Charles McGrath discuss the impulse for fiction writers to send their characters to distant places.

title: Has Wall Street Been Tamed?
description: Before the financial crisis, bankers were often regarded as greedy and self-interested. The mortgage melt down ratcheted that reputation into something much scarier: an existential threat to the global economy. Since 2008, the banks have seemed to many people like an active volcano does to the villagers below. Americans dont really understand banks, or know what causes them to blow up, but theyve seen enough to be afraid.

title: Why Calls for a National Conversation Are Futile
description: The bad news never seems to cease: death, discrimination, discrimination that culminates in death. Within days in early July, police officers shot and killed Alton Sterling in Baton Rouge, La., then Philando Castile near St. Paul, Minn., both of them black men. On July 7, a sniper murdered five cops during an otherwise peaceful protest in Dallas. Ten days later a different gunman killed three officers in Baton Rouge. This all took place not long after the June massacre at the Pulse nightclub in Orlando, Fla., and just before the campaign conventions of the countrys two political parties, during an election year that feels historically nasty. When things get this fractious and this tragic, we inevitably hear calls for a national conversation. But during Barack Obamas presidency, news organizations, politicians and academics have scarcely had to do any calling. Whatever it is we need to talk about is simply added to the mounting agenda.

title: I Have No Choice but to Keep Looking
description: Yuko Takamatsu was somewhere in the sea off the coast of Japan. Two and a half years had passed since the tsunami, and no one had found her; but no one was really looking, either, except her husband, Yasuo Takamatsu, who loved her very much. Takamatsu first searched on land, at the bank where she vanished, and along the beaches of Onagawa, and in the forests in the mountains. After two and half years, in September 2013, when he still hadnt found her, he turned to the sea.

title: Trump Seems More the Result of a Shift Among White Men Than the Cause of It
description: Many people believe that Donald Trump is about to remake the Republican Party.

title: For Party Elites, Appeal of Populism Shouldnt Be a Surprise
description: That rising populism comes as a surprise to those in charge lends credence to populisms intuition: Elites arent listening; we need to shout louder.

title: Not Forgotten: Alexander Graham Bell, Who Sparked a New Era of Communication
description: Alexander Graham Bells contraption of receivers connected to a series of wires forever changed the way people communicated.

title: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 5 | On How the Government Supports Your Junk Food Habit
description: Week 5 of our Summer Reading Contest ran during the Republican convention, and many of the 807 entries reflected that. Over and over, students weighed in on Donald J. Trump and his message, Melania Trumps speech, Ted Cruzs refusal to endorse Mr. Trump, and what the convention said to them about the Republican party in general.

title: Review: Underground Railroad Lays Bare Horrors of Slavery and Its Toxic Legacy
description: In his dynamic new novel, Colson Whitehead takes the Underground Railroad  the loosely interlocking network of black and white activists who helped slaves escape to freedom in the decades before the Civil War  and turns it from a metaphor into an actual train that ferries fugitives northward.

title: Dylann Roofs Lawyers Argue Against Death Penalty
description: Lawyers representing Dylann Roof, the white man accused of killing nine black members of a historic Charleston, S.C., church last year, filed a motion challenging the constitutionality of the death penalty after federal prosecutors declined his offer to serve life without parole.

title: Paradise, the New Muslim Utopia
description: ORAN, Algeria  Future writing project: a topography of paradise in the medieval Muslim imagination. But not only medieval, for among Muslims today paradise is also at the center of political discourse, sermons and the contemporary imagination. Paradise as a goal for the individual or the group has gradually replaced the dreams of development, stability and wealth promised by postwar decolonization in the so-called Arab world. These days, one imagines happy tomorrows only after death, not before.

title: Le paradis musulman, nouvelle utopie politique
description: ORAN, Algrie  A crire un jour : une topographie du paradis dans limaginaire mdival musulman. Pas seulement limaginaire mdival dailleurs, puisque pour beaucoup de musulmans le paradis est aussi au centre du discours politique, du prche et de limaginaire actuels. Le paradis comme but pour lindividu ou le groupe a remplac peu  peu les rves de dveloppement, de stabilit et de richesse quavaient promis les dcolonisations daprs-guerre dans le monde arabe. Dsormais on ne parle des lendemains qui chantent que pour aprs la mort, pas avant.

title: Zhai Yanmin, Chinese Rights Activist, Gets Suspended Prison Term
description: BEIJING  A Chinese court on Tuesday sentenced a human rights activist who had criticized the government to a suspended three-year term in prison, in the first of several trials apparently intended to showcase the Communist Partys hard-line attitude toward dissent.

title: Florida Is Most Likely to Be the Election Tipping Point
description: A reader, Phil from Virginia, wondered if there was a way to indicate more clearly on The Upshots presidential forecasting model which states were likely to be the tipping point ones.

title: Vice Media to Begin Nightly HBO News Program on Sept. 26
description: Vice Media announced on Tuesday that it will begin broadcasting its daily HBO half-hour newscast on Sept. 26.

title: 1891: At Trouville on the Sea
description: TROUVILLE-SUR-MER  Everyone here says that Trouville thus far is having its worst season in years as regards the weather. The rain goes away and comes again until visitors are quite discouraged. Bathing is not agreeable with a northeast wind and a dun sky. Even the Regatta failed to bring a crowd. But Trouville has other delights than bathing and dancing  the magnificent drives along well-kept roads, with the distant views of the sea, and the ungainly attempts of a few courageous bathers to take a dip in spite of the inclement weather.

title: Hillary Clintons Campaign Raised $63 Million in July, Its Best Mark So Far
description: Hillary Clinton raised $63 million in the month culminating in the Democratic National Convention last week, her campaign announced on Tuesday, her most successful fund-raising month to date.

title: Instagram Takes a Page From Snapchat, and Takes Aim at It, Too
description: MENLO PARK, Calif.  For nearly four years, Snapchat has been Facebooks white whale.

title: The Case for More Government and Higher Taxes
description: It may be hard to remember, but Americans once appreciated the government that serves them. Thats long gone.

title: House Republican Backs Hillary Clinton, Calling Donald Trump Unfit to Serve
description: Representative Richard Hanna, Republican of New York, broke ranks with his party to endorse Hillary Clinton for president on Tuesday, denouncing Donald J. Trumps attacks on the Muslim parents of a soldier killed in Iraq and calling Mr. Trump unfit to serve.

title: Raiding an Illegal Gold-Mining Ring in Perus Amazon Jungle? Easy. Getting There? Next to Impossible.
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Suzanne Daley, an associate editor for international print, describes the unexpected perils of her recent reporting adventure in the Amazon: Surprising an illegal gold-mining ring turned out to be the least of her worries.

title: 1966:  Johnson Urges Gun Control
description: WASHINGTON  President Johnson today [Aug. 2] called on Congress to pass a gun-control law in the wake of the mass murder of 15 persons by a crazed sniper in the capital of Mr. Johnsons native state of Texas.
