title: Outstanding Issues: A Yemeni Teenagers Trip to Estonia, by Way of Guantnamo
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, the reporter Charlie Savage describe the impact of an article he wrote about an ex-Guantnamo detainee  on readers, the subject and the writer.

title: Review: Dim All the Lights, Again: Will You Dance With Me?
description: In 1984 the director Ron Peck asked a friend and colleague, Derek Jarman, to record test footage for a proposed feature project. About 100 nightclubbers of all stripes, many of them regular patrons of the East London disco where the test was to be shot, were invited, and presumably instructed to act naturally. For that reason, the material that Mr. Jarman captured  recently rediscovered by Mr. Peck and being shown now as a short feature titled Will You Dance With Me?  feels like, well, a night out at a tackily appointed, friendly dance club, documented by a regular whos not intruding on anybodys fun.

title: Review: Richard Linklater: Dream Is Destiny Lionizes a Maverick Talent
description: If youre not already in the bag for its subject, then Richard Linklater: Dream Is Destiny wants to give your arm an extra twist. Maybe its makers, Louis Black and Karen Bernstein, found neither of the two film profiles from 2014 sufficiently enthusiastic about Mr. Linklaters resolutely outsider talents; whatever the case, theyve decided to dive deeper into the kudos and the mind that inspired them.

title: Bettors Can Seek Gold of Their Own During the Olympics
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  When the Olympics open up in earnest on Saturday, you can marvel at the athletic prowess on display, cheer for your favorite country, or just enjoy the spectacle.

title: Review: The Lobster Scene in Multiple Maniacs? It Still Startles
description: Ah, those stodgy Nixon-era minders of the national morality. Surely they didnt need to get as worked up as they did about the early John Waters film Multiple Maniacs. Or did they? It does, after all, feature rosary beads as a sex toy. And theres the rape scene involving a giant lobster.

title: Martin Frost Explores the Soul of the Clarinet
description: Think of musical virtuosity, and the qualities that most likely come to mind are speed, rhythmic complexity, and extremes of volume and pitch. Long, placid lines sound as if they should be as restful for the player as they are to the listener.

title: Review: Five Nights in Maine Probes the Pain of Loss
description: Maris Curran had plenty of opportunities to insert a cheesy plot twist into Five Nights in Maine, her delicate drama about loss and its aftermath. Yet she stayed true to her intentions, and the result is a believable character study that may not draw crowds but certainly challenges its two lead actors.

title: Advocacy Groups Allege Abuses on Nauru
description: A report by Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International said Australia appeared to be subjecting migrants to abuses at an offshore processing site as "a deliberate policy to deter further asylum seekers from arriving in the country by boat."

title: Review: collective:unconscious, the Stuff of Dreams Reinterpreted
description: A throwback to the Surrealists and exquisite corpse games, the omnibus film collective:unconscious began from a simple premise: Five filmmakers transcribed their dreams; each description was then given at random to one of the others to direct as a short. (The film bears no relationship to the theater organization Collective:Unconscious.)

title: Seven Female Furniture Designers
description: The designer Rachel Comey and the artist Leanne Shapton have collaborated on an exhibition featuring Shaptons abstractions of chairs, lights and tables designed by women.

title: Rediscovering Great Female Furniture Designers
description: One day this spring, Rachel Comey and Leanne Shapton were having lunch when it occurred to them that there was a blind spot in their knowledge of midcentury furniture designers: women. Comey, a fashion designer, was looking for chairs for her new store in L.A. She wanted something designed by a woman  which turned out to be a tall order. On a whim, they went to a few nearby furniture dealers in NoLIta. We were like, What have you got by women? Shapton recalls. And they were like: nothing.

title: An Analyst of Gothic Monsters Explores Trumps Appeal
description: Its all the rage in the news media at the moment to dig into Donald J. Trumps psyche. What mix of narcissism, psychosis and the like could possibly generate such a nonstop series of seeming miscalculations? In The Guardian, thankfully, Dean Burnett, a neuroscientist, standup comic and author of The Idiot Brain, has tried to tamp things down, explaining why diagnosing Trump is likely to do more harm than good.

title: Ta-Nehisi Coates to Curate French-American Festival
description: The writer Ta-Nehisi Coates, fresh from a year living in Paris, will be the curator of the third annual Festival Albertine, a free five-day event in New York in November bringing together French and American artists and thinkers.

title: Arthritis Drug May Have Benefits Against Alzheimers
description: A drug used to treat rheumatoid arthritis may have benefits against Alzheimers disease, researchers report.

title: Syrians Burn Tires to Prevent Airstrikes
description: Syrian children burned tires in Aleppo, Syria, in hopes of creating a smoke curtain to deter airstrikes.

title: Review: A Journey Through Uncharted Waters in Men on Boats
description: The Clubbed Thumb Summerworks production of Men on Boats played through the summer of 2015. Following are excerpts from Ben Brantleys review, which appeared in The New York Times on June 24, 2015. The full text is here. The play opened on Monday at Playwrights Horizons Peter Jay Sharp Theater, 416 West 42nd Street, Manhattan; 212-279-4200, ticketcentral.com.

title: Review: War Made Terrifyingly Palpable in Citizen Soldier
description: The tension in Citizen Soldier is enough to make you gnaw through your fingernails. This documentary, which follows a group of American G.I.s in Afghanistan in 2011, uses footage taken during their missions, sometimes via their own helmet cams. The sense of danger is palpable, as is the sense of misery after the most dreadful scenes.

title: Turkey Issues a Warrant for Fethullah Gulen, Cleric Accused in Coup
description: ISTANBUL  Turkey issued an arrest warrant on Thursday for Fethullah Gulen, a Muslim cleric based in the United States, who was accused last month of orchestrating a failed coup against the government of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

title: Review: In The Brooklyn Banker, Troy Garity Shows Promise (With the Mob)
description: Its 1973 in Brooklyn, and Santo (Troy Garity) is in a tough spot. A young man with a head for numbers, hes married with two kids and a third on the way, and has a bright future as a vice president for a local bank. He has stayed in the neighborhood and away from the mob ties that entangle his friends and family. At least until his father-in-law, Benny (Paul Sorvino), a lieutenant for the neighborhood don, brings him to the boss, Manny, who needs a favor. This is good for us, Benny promises.

title: Theater Listings for Aug. 5-11
description: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.

title: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
description: City Hall Park Broadway and Chambers Street Through Sept. 29

title: Review: War and Turpentine, a Grandfathers Painful Life
description: Some soldiers return home and are unable or unwilling to talk about their wartime experience. Others speak about little else.

title: Review: In Front Cover, Struggling for Self-Acceptance
description: Though too slight to be memorable, the gay romance Front Cover takes a gentle, thoughtful look at the intersection of ethnicity and sexuality.

title: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, Aug. 6 Through 14
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Colored Conventions, a Rallying Point for Black Americans Before the Civil War
description: Long before they could take any actual roles in government, black political activists sent thousands of delegates to advocacy events called colored conventions that were held starting in the 1830s. The activists drafted legislative petitions demanding better schools and job opportunities and legal protections from bigotry and violence.

title: Review: Soul of Calypso Elevates the Bollywood-Flavored Bazodee
description: Advertised as a sort of Bollywood goes Caribbean, Bazodee does indeed borrow cultural conventions from both, and it plays out in the perfect setting, Trinidad and Tobago, which has a heritage rich in Afro-Caribbean and Indian traditions.

title: Obama Writes Feminist Essay in Glamour
description: In his most extensive remarks about feminism, President Obama wrote an essay for Glamour magazine in which he reflected on American womens long fight for equality and called on men to fight sexism and create equal relationships.

title: Hanging Out on Pierre Paulins Recliner
description: Something happened to midcentury modernism in the last couple of years: It got boring. Once, the furniture of the Eameses, Eero Saarinen or a clutch of Danes still stood for design innovation; now you can order a tulip chair with one click from Design Within Reach, or head to Overstock.com for a knockoff. Maybe thats why were seeing a revived interest in flashier design from the 1960s and especially the 1970s  the geometric patterns, the shag carpeting, the brass and Lucite. Heck, even Match Game is back.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, Aug. 6 Through 14
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Review: Neither Heaven Nor Earth Engages the Horrors of War
description: Capt. Antars Bonassieu, the hero of Clment Cogitores debut feature, Neither Heaven Nor Earth, seems like a guy weve met before, at least in other war movies. Lean and muscular, with a thoughtful countenance under his blond brush cut, he is a seasoned soldier and a natural commander, tough on his men but capable of sensitivity when circumstances require it. (He is played by Jrmie Renier, a graceful chameleon who you may not recognize from Olivier Assayass Summer Hours or Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardennes LEnfant.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, Aug. 6 Through 14
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Antitrust Lawyer Who Handled Tech Collusion Case to Join Private Firm
description: James J. Tierney, the government antitrust lawyer who oversaw the complaint accusing six major Silicon Valley companies of colluding not to recruit competitors employees, is leaving the federal job to join the law firm Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe.

title: Review: Fanciful Classic The Little Prince Is Turned Into Modernist Fable
description: The masterstroke of The Little Prince, Mark Osbornes reimagining of Antoine de Saint-Exuprys 1943 childrens classic, is its side-by-side use of two styles of animation. Todays cold, corporate world, in which gray-faced, hunched-over adults grimly slog through life, is depicted in severe, rectilinear computer-generated animation. The magical universe of Saint-Exuprys wistful, poetic novella is rendered in stop-motion animation, with pastel shades that evoke his original watercolor illustrations.

title: Hillary Clinton to Animal Rights Protesters: Trumps Have Killed a Lot of Animals
description: LAS VEGAS  Hillary Clinton came here on Thursday to talk jobs, debt-free college, renewable energy and other planks of the Democratic platform.

title: U.S. Presidential Race, Rio Olympics, London: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Things to Do on Long Island, Aug. 6 Through 14
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Review: In Final Season of Inspector Lewis, Solving Mysteries While Navigating a New Boss
description: When Inspector Morse ended  15 years ago!  the Oxford detective Endeavour Morse keeled over in the middle of campus, his dramatic collapse and subsequent death the appropriate capstone for a series about a self-centered snob. When its spinoff Inspector Lewis ends in a few weeks, no one of importance will die. Call that a spoiler, but if youve watched Morses onetime sergeant, Robbie Lewis, over his nearly 30 years on television, you know that hed find being killed off far too immodest, too attention-grabbing a fate.

title: Comedy Listings for Aug. 5-11
description: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.

title: How Sunflowers Follow the Sun, Day After Day
description: At dawn, whole fields of sunflowers stand at attention, all facing east, and begin their romance with the rising sun. As that special star appears to move across the sky, young flowers follow its light, looking up, then over and westward, catching one final glance as the sun disappears over the horizon.

title: Review: In Little Men, Boys Develop a Bond That Is Threatened by Money
description: There is hardly a shortage of buddy movies about mismatched men bonding under duress, but films that chart the emotional weather of everyday male friendship are rare. Literature has more to offer, at least as far as boys are concerned. Tom Sawyer and Huckleberry Finn have a rich and renewable legacy. And it may be that association that imparts a novelistic vibe to Ira Sachss Little Men, beyond the Louisa May Alcott echo in the title. Its a subtle movie, alert to the almost imperceptible currents of feeling that pass between its title characters.

title: Bar Association Considers Striking Honeys From the Courtroom
description: When Lori Rifkin asked the opposing lawyer to stop interrupting her while she questioned a potential witness, he replied: Dont raise your voice at me. Its not becoming of a woman.

title: Pilot of Vanished Malaysian Flight Had Deviant Route on His Simulator, Minister Says
description: The pilot of the Malaysia Airlines jetliner that mysteriously vanished more than two years ago had used his personal flight simulator to practice a path over the remote southern Indian Ocean, where the aircraft is believed to have crashed, the countrys transport minister said on Thursday.

title: Olympic Officials Set Russias Roster; More Than 100 Are Barred for Doping
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Olympic officials announced on Thursday night that 271 Russian athletes had been approved to compete in the Rio Games  118 fewer than the country had hoped to enter.

title: Another Airbag Maker Is Under Scrutiny After Fatal Rupture
description: Airbags made by a Tennessee supplier came under heightened scrutiny on Thursday after a rupture in one of its bags was linked to the death of a driver in Canada last month.

title: Arrested Protester of Baton Rouge Police Shooting Files Suit
description: NEW ORLEANS  DeRay Mckesson is a prominent voice of the Black Lives Matter movement who was arrested in July while protesting the fatal police shooting of a Baton Rouge man selling CDs outside a convenience store. On Thursday, he filed a proposed class-action lawsuit against the city of Baton Rouge and several law enforcement agencies.

title: Movie Listings for Aug. 5-11
description: Read reviews of new releases and search our full database of thousands of films at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

title: A Peace Is Broken
description: In an ordinary summer, a season in which we were not preoccupied by recurring instances of terrorism, police violence and a raucously operatic presidential election threatening the fate of the republic, an incident of the kind that took place in the marshlands surrounding Jamaica Bay, in Queens, on an atypically cool evening might have easily ignited collective tensions.

title: Fred Tomlinson, Singer Who Led a Monty Python Troupe, Dies at 88
description: Fred Tomlinson, a singer and arranger who led a troupe of vocalists on Monty Pythons Flying Circus and other British television shows, died on July 17. He was 88.

title: Robert Rosencrans, Who Helped Propel C-Span, Dies at 89
description: Robert Rosencrans, a daring cable television industry pioneer who was instrumental in creating C-Span, the unfiltered public affairs network that faithfully covers government proceedings and civic events, died on Wednesday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 89.

title: Classical Music Listings for Aug. 5-11
description: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.

title: Looking Back (and Learning From) The Mary Tyler Moore Show
description: If Hillary Rodham had gone home and flipped on the TV after she delivered her Wellesley commencement address in the spring of 1969, how might she have seen the changing roles of American women reflected in popular entertainment? She could have watched Mary Tyler Moore  but it would have been in reruns of The Dick Van Dyke Show, where Rose Marie was the wisecracking career woman and Ms. Moore still the TV housewife, albeit the first to swap her aproned skirt for capri pants. It was not until a year after Mrs. Clintons classmates tossed their mortarboards that Mary Richards first tossed her tam in The Mary Tyler Moore Show.

title: $400 Million to Iran Was Not a Ransom, Obama Says
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday flatly denied that a $400 million pallet of cash delivered to the Iranian government in January, on the same day that four American citizens who had been detained by Iran were released, was a ransom payment, calling the latest uproar over the landmark nuclear pact with Tehran the manufacturing of outrage.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for Aug. 5-11
description: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.

title: Tax-Avoiding Mergers Find Champion in U.S. Chamber of Commerce
description: The U.S. Chamber of Commerce filed a lawsuit on Thursday to block new rules issued by the Obama administration that prevent American corporations from merging with foreign-based companies and moving their headquarters abroad to save on taxes.

title: Jazz Listings for Aug. 5-11
description: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.

title: Dance Listings for Aug. 5-11
description: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.

title: Paul Massey, Real Estate Executive, to Run for Mayor of New York City
description: Paul J. Massey Jr., a millionaire real estate executive, took steps on Thursday toward running for mayor of New York City  styling himself in the mold of former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, as a wealthy businessman and an outsider to politics with the management chops needed to run the nations biggest city.

title: What Is the #PalletsOfCash Debate?
description: WASHINGTON  The summer political season has been suddenly seized by a fierce debate about #PalletsOfCash delivered to Iran on an unmarked cargo plane.

title: Betting Billions on Rio, Comcast Hopes to Win the Future of Television
description: Five years ago, the Comcast chief executive Brian Roberts faced his first challenge as the new majority owner of NBC. On the eve of the bidding for the rights to show the 2014 and 2016 Olympic Games, he lost his top sports executive, Dick Ebersol, when talks for a new contract for Mr. Ebersol failed.

title: A Dollar for a Cigarette
description: Dear Diary:

title: Dynasty, the Nicaragua Version
description: A decade ago, President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua made a startling comeback by persuading voters to give him a second shot at running the country. It was a hard-fought victory for the former guerrilla leader, coming after three electoral defeats.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Aug. 5-11
description: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.

title: On a Bridge, a Quick-Thinking Cyclist Saves a Life on the Ledge
description: In a cellphone picture, a young man stands on a ledge of the George Washington Bridge. He is wearing blue gym shorts with white piping, a gray T-shirt, a beige baseball cap. His arms rest on the rail. Behind and below him is 200 feet of sky, then the Hudson River. The picture was taken an instant or two before Julio De Leon reached midspan on his weekly ride across the bridge.

title: Paul Ryans Rival, a Long Shot, Tries to Gain an Edge From Donald Trumps Praise
description: JANESVILLE, Wis.  Paul Nehlen has never spoken to Donald J. Trump. His bid to unseat Speaker Paul D. Ryan was not inspired by the Republican nominee. But when his campaign learned Monday night that Mr. Trump had just sent words praising Mr. Nehlen to his 10.6 million Twitter followers, they knew they had to run with it.

title: Around Town for Aug. 5-11
description: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.

title: Vexing Question on Patient Surveys: Did We Ease Your Pain?
description: The questionnaire arrives in the mail a few days after a patients discharge from the hospital.

title: Spare Times for Children Listings for Aug. 5-11
description: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.

title: 36 Hours in Nantucket, Mass.
description: Glorious public beaches, untouched moors and dunes, and sophisticated dining and shopping on this island off Cape Cod.

title: Grieving and Hunting for an Evil Person After a Jogger Is Killed
description: Karina Vetrano liked to post photos online of her night life, and spend the morning afterward unpacking her pain and passion as a writer.

title: I.O.C. Chief Thomas Bach Supports a Peculiar Form of Justice on Doping
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Finally, after a week of the most impertinent questions possible, Thomas Bach, the embattled International Olympic Committee president, was about to field a friendly one on Thursday.

title: Fatah Makes Incendiary Facebook Claim of Killing 11,000 Israelis
description: JERUSALEM  In an effort to appeal to Palestinians ahead of hotly contested elections, the party of President Mahmoud Abbas listed one of its main achievements as having killed 11,000 Israelis.

title: Lowell Goddard, Leader of Britains Child Sex Abuse Inquiry, Quits
description: LONDON  In an embarrassment to Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain, the chairwoman of a major inquiry into the sexual abuse of children resigned late Thursday, the third person to leave the post since the inquiry was announced two years ago.

title: Celebrating a Lesser-Known Role of Hamilton: Father of the Coast Guard
description: It was the morning rush in New York Harbor on Thursday when the Eagle, a majestic, 295-foot, three-masted Coast Guard ship, set sail from beneath the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. On the Eagles starboard side, a Staten Island Ferry chugged toward Lower Manhattan, while on its port side, a Fire Department fireboat shot plumes of water in front of the Statue of Liberty.

title: This Years Subway Series Is Ending Just in Time
description: The Mets and the Yankees now go their separate ways, and it is just as well. They split their four-game series, two victories apiece, meaning nobody won. How fitting. The season has discouraged both teams, and their shared angst can be suffocating.

title: Debate Over Trumps Fitness Raises Issue of Checks on Nuclear Power
description: Hillary Clinton has fueled a debate over whether her rival for the presidency, Donald J. Trump, is fit to command Americas atomic forces. Imagine him in the Oval Office facing a real crisis, she said in her address at the Democratic convention last week. A man you can bait with a tweet is not a man we can trust with nuclear weapons.

title: Leon Hall Signs a One-Year Pact With the Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  During each of their three previous losing seasons, the Giants have paid the price when multiple defensive backs have been sidelined with injuries. In a pass-happy league, not having enough depth in the secondary can be the biggest roster mistake of all.

title: Spraying Begins in Miami to Combat the Zika Virus
description: MIAMI  Aerial spraying of insecticide began Thursday in the one-mile-square area of Miami where mosquitoes have infected people with the Zika virus, and officials reported some glimmers of progress.

title: Steven LaTourette, Congressman Who Despised Gridlock, Dies at 62
description: Steven C. LaTourette, a centrist Ohio Republican who retired after nine terms in Congress saying he was disgusted with partisan gridlock, died on Wednesday at his home in McLean, Va. He was 62.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Madam Tegla gives us a chance for other people to know the history of our lives. And we can forget what happened before.

title: Review: In Engagements, Meet Me in the Gazebo for Spite and Hauteur
description: If theres anyone you definitely do not want at a party celebrating your coming wedding, its the mean-girl central character in Engagements, a bitingly funny but overly sour comedy by Lucy Teitler that opened on Thursday at the McGinn/Cazale Theater as part of Second Stage Theaters Uptown summer series.

title: The Way the World Moves
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  I think of Friday crosswords as an opportunity for the constructor to show off. Without any constrictions set by a theme (although we have seen some themed Fridays), puzzle makers can seed their Friday grids with all sorts of outrageous entries, puff up the crossings and sprinkle lots of questions marks in the clues. You get the idea. You should leave a Friday puzzle slightly bruised, but with a goofy grin on your face.

title: 46 Charged in Mafia Racketeering Conspiracy
description: Forty-six members of an organized crime network that included four of New Yorks five Mafia families were charged in a large-scale racketeering conspiracy, according to an indictment unsealed on Thursday.

title: Dylann Roof Attacked by a Fellow Inmate, Officials Say
description: Dylann Roof, the white man charged in the shooting massacre of nine black parishioners at a church in Charleston, S.C., was assaulted in jail on Thursday by a black inmate, officials said.

title: Judge Lets Dean Skelos and Son Remain Free While Appealing Convictions
description: Dean G. Skelos, the once-powerful New York state senator, and his son, Adam B. Skelos, may remain free on bail as they appeal their corruption convictions, a federal judge ruled on Thursday.

title: Mets Earn Split of Four-Game Series as Jay Bruce Ends Slump
description: The Mets outfielders have a ritual after each victory. They get together and exchange congratulations, leaping in the air and punctuating the celebration by swinging their arms for a low-five.

title: 9 Thrillers (One True) That Times Editors Think You Should Read This Summer
description: In my future life, I will spend entire weekends lying in a hammock by some idyllic lakeside, coolly reading thriller after thriller. As it is, I sacrificed two entire days of my Dominican Republic vacation this spring to Noah Hawleys Before the Fall, and have marked Kate Summerscales The Wicked Boy (a true murderous mystery) for my vacation later this month.

title: Apple Will Pay a Bug Bounty to Hackers Who Report Flaws
description: LAS VEGAS  Apple, which has been criticized in recent years for failing to pay outside hackers who report bugs in its products, said on Thursday that it would begin offering a so-called bug bounty to technologists who alert the company to flaws.

title: Cowboys Search Far and Wide for Backup Quarterback
description: The Dallas Cowboys are in no rush to get a veteran quarterback behind Tony Romo, even though Stephen Jones, the Cowboys executive vice president of personnel, said the team wanted to add one after Kellen Moore broke his right ankle in training camp this week.

title: Who Will Light the Olympic Caldron in Rio? It Wont Be Pel
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Sometimes it is one of the most famous athletes in the world, like Muhammad Ali in 1996. Other times it is an archer or a cross-country skier whose name you will never hear again. But whoever it is, the person who lights the caldron at the opening ceremony is given one of the highest honors at an Olympics.

title: How Do You Add to Versailles? Bravely
description: PARIS  Louis XIV waged architecture as he waged war  with total commitment, huge resources and soldiers from his army  and his greatest architectural campaign was, of course, Versailles, the sprawling baroque palace he wrapped around his fathers original hunting chateau outside Paris. When his army wasnt at war, he enlisted soldiers to help build the palace, moving in with his court in 1682.

title: Corrections: August 5, 2016
description: NATIONAL

title: Whats on TV Friday: Rio Olympics Opening Ceremony and The Little Prince
description: The first Olympic Games to be held in South America officially open in Rio de Janeiro. Rambunctious fur balls test their own athletic prowess in Kitten Summer Games. And Mark Osborne puts his spin on Antoine de Saint-Exuprys universe in The Little Prince.

title: The Week in Pictures: Aug. 5, 2016
description: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

title: (Parma) 36
The Week in Pictures: Aug. 5, 2016
description: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

title: Moderation Rears Its Head in Kansas
description: Moderate Republicans who have been fighting off extinction ventured onto the primary ballot this week in the deeply red state of Kansas and scored a dozen impressive victories. The insurgents knocked off conservative loyalists of Gov. Sam Brownback, whose disastrous experiment in trickle-down economics has busted the state budget and angered voters suffering from slashed services.

title: I Ran the C.I.A. Now Im Endorsing Hillary Clinton.
description: During a 33-year career at the Central Intelligence Agency, I served presidents of both parties  three Republicans and three Democrats. I was at President George W. Bushs side when we were attacked on Sept. 11; as deputy director of the agency, I was with President Obama when we killed Osama bin Laden in 2011.

title: The Perils of Writing Off Mr. Trump
description: Donald Trump seemed to do everything wrong this week. But what if, to his supporters, hes done everything right?

title: No Right Turn
description: All the experts tell us not to pay too much attention to polls for another week or two. Still, it does look as if Hillary Clinton got a big bounce from her convention, swamping her opponents bounce a week earlier. Better still, from the Democrats point of view, the swing in the polls appears to be doing what some of us thought it might: sending Donald Trump into a derp spiral, in which his ugly nonsense gets even uglier and more nonsensical as his electoral prospects sink.

title: Trumps Enablers Will Finally Have to Take a Stand
description: Up through the convention there were all sorts of Republican officeholders who werent really for Trump, but they werent really against him. They sort of endorsed him implicitly, while trying to change the subject.

title: The Sore Loser Uprising
description: After a week in which Donald Trump insulted babies and their mothers and war heroes and their families, and threw in fire marshals for good measure, the scariest thing to come out of his team of thugs and political mercenaries is this: the suggestion that civil unrest could follow if hes denied the presidency.

title: Protect the West From a Black-Gold Rush
description: Eldorado Springs, Colo.  In northeastern Utah, just across the border from my home state, Colorado, the Estonian-owned company Enefit American Oil is trying to make good on a promise that the federal government and private industry have been making in the American West for almost a century: squeezing oil from a stone.

title: Summer of Anxiety Eclipses the Silly Season of Years Past
description: LONDON  Almost to the day, in August 2009, an article appeared in this space saying: You know the silly season has arrived when The Times of London devotes a front-page obituary to the death of a fish called Benson.

title: The Fine Line: What Makes Simone Biles the Worlds Best Gymnast
description: Mary Lou Retton has described her as the top gymnast in history.

title: The Fine Line: What Makes Derek Drouin a World-Class High Jumper
description: If running faster means jumping higher, why does the world champion run so slow?

title: The Fine Line: What Makes Ryan Lochte a World-Class Swimmer
description: Has Ryan Lochte discovered the next big thing in swimming?

title: The Fine Line: What Makes Christian Taylor a World-Class Triple Jumper
description: By 22, Taylor had a world championship and Olympic gold.

title: R.B.S. Posts $1.43 Billion Loss in 2nd Quarter, as Litigation Costs Balloon
description: LONDON  The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Friday that it posted a large loss in the second quarter on ballooning litigation costs, as it grappled with restructuring to shift away from being a lender with global ambitions.

title: Clinton Released Her Taxes. Will Trump Follow This Tradition?
description: Almost all presidential nominees since 1976 have made their tax returns public, most around Tax Day in April   about 200 days before the election.

title: Wasting Time on the Internet? Not Really
description: Two years ago, Kenneth Goldsmith, the University of Pennsylvania poet and conceptual artist, taught a creative writing course he called Wasting Time on the Internet. Students would do just that, probing the tedium of the internet. But thanks to in-class use of social media, the class also became a creative ferment of improvised dance, trust experiments and inquiries into the modern nature of the self and the crowd.

title: The Shirt Stays On
description: Arent you going to take your clothes off? she asked, her fingers pulling at the edges of my T-shirt. It wasnt sexy the way she said it; no wry smile or soft coo came with the words, just frustration.

title: New Yorks Stalled Residential Construction
description: At first blush, it seems as if times are good for the real estate industry in New York.

title: The Elections: A Precedential Primer
description: We hear the word unprecedented a lot in respect to the 2016 campaign. In what ways has it set precedent? Test your knowledge.

title: They Want Trump to Make the G.O.P. a Workers Party
description: WASHINGTON  By riding his appeal among working-class whites to the top of the Republican Party, Donald J. Trump has emboldened conservative thinkers to press their party of business and the privileged to reshape its economic canon to more directly benefit poorer workers it has often taken for granted.

title: Leftover Meal Plan Swipes: No Waste Here
description: To Asia Suarez, a computer science major, the math hit like an error message: With less than three weeks left in the spring term, she would need to eat seven meals a day to use up the remaining 131 swipes on her food plan at New York University. A soccer player who works out furiously and eats a lot, Ms. Suarez still found that 300 meals a semester (for $2,541) were too many.

title: Mark Kirk in Electoral Vise as Republican in Illinois Senate Race
description: CHICAGO  Senator Mark S. Kirk of Illinois, among the nations most imperiled Republican incumbents, sat before a small audience in the basement of a public library here recently, intent on proving his bipartisan bona fides  perhaps his only hope of defusing the wrath of voters in a state with little love for Donald J. Trump.

title: Strong Job Gains, for Second Month, Reframe Economic Outlook
description: The American jobs machine has moved back into high gear.

title: How to Give a Better Speech: Talk to a Dog
description: The two undergraduates were acing their presentation. Good cadence. Sharp slides. Sunny dispositions. But it was a tough crowd.

title: A Young Syrian Torchbearer Highlights Brazils Embrace of Refugees
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  The Olympic torch relay certainly endured its share of indignities this summer as it wended across this vast country on its way to Rio de Janeiro.

title: Afghanistan Is in Chaos. Is That What Hamid Karzai Wants?
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Hamid Karzai, the former Afghan president and current antagonist to his successors government, likes to describe Afghan politics as a marathon.

title: For Anne Holton, Tim Kaines Wife, Elite Circles Are Old Turf
description: This weekend, Tim Kaine and his wife, Anne Holton, are expected to step off the campaign trail for a beach vacation with their extended family at the Virginia shore.

title: Transgender on the Force
description: After years of focused preparation, Aiden Budd was well on his way to fulfilling his lifelong dream of becoming an officer in the New York Police Department. He had served in the United States Army and had worked for years as an agent in the departments School Safety division. He studied for the exam to be promoted and he passed.

title: The Face of Taiwans Past Is Slowly Fading From View
description: You used to see Chiang Kai-sheks image everywhere in Taiwan. But lately, the man who led the Republic of China for nearly half a century has gradually been disappearing from view.

title: How Much Does Living Off-Campus Cost? Who Knows?
description: Location. Location. Location. That adage about real estate pricing takes on new meaning  and some bewildering logic  in the hands of college administrators.

title: Weighing the Strengths and Shortcomings of Chinas Education System
description: Nothing stirs passions quite like the debate over the Chinese school system. Critics say it is a test-obsessed bureaucracy that produces students who excel at reciting facts but not much else. Others argue that it is equipping children with exceptionally strong skills, particularly in math and science. Scott Rozelle, a Stanford University economist who runs a rural education program in China, is an author of a new study that challenges popular conceptions of Chinese schools. In a recent conversation, he discussed the strengths and weaknesses of the Chinese education system, as well as the advice he would offer the countrys leaders.

title: In Colson Whiteheads Latest, the Underground Railroad Is More Than a Metaphor
description: THE UNDERGROUND RAILROADBy Colson Whitehead306 pp. Doubleday. $26.95.

title: The Advance Man Who Didnt See Marriage Coming
description: When Helaine Blatt and Mort Engelberg started dating 26 years ago, they agreed marriage wasnt for them. But they had a change of heart, and on July 27, they wed at the Beverly Hills Courthouse.

title: A Match Made in Hollywood (and Endorsed by Bill Clinton)
description: When Helaine Blatt began dating Mort Engelberg in 1990, she soon found herself competing with his two other loves: producing big-budget movies, and traveling the world as an advance man for former President Bill Clinton.

description: Question:

title: Rio Olympics, Jobs Report, Suicide Squad: Your Friday Briefing

title: A Short-Circuit on F.B.I. Inquiry? Hillary Clinton Seeks to Explain
description: WASHINGTON  Hillary Clinton on Friday sought to explain her recent mischaracterization of the F.B.I. investigation into her private email server, saying she may have short-circuited in her remarks during a television interview on Sunday when she asserted that the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, had called her statements about her private email servers truthful.

title: Smoke, Fire and Human Evolution
description: When early humans discovered how to build fires, life became much easier in many regards. They huddled around fire for warmth, light and protection. They used it to cook, which afforded them more calories than eating raw foods that were hard to chew and digest. They could socialize into the night, which possibly gave rise to storytelling and other cultural traditions.

title: Keeping the Darlings Out of the Courtroom
description: "Dont raise your voice at me. Its not becoming of a woman. Honey. Darling. You either run with the nannies or you run with the wolves. A pat on the head. An arm around the shoulder.

title: My Brother, the Hospice Graduate
description: When I was a college sophomore living in a sorority house at the University of California at Santa Barbara, my parents called to tell me that my baby brother, Gavin, was dying. He had been given a diagnosis of a very rare disease, AicardiGoutieres Syndrome.

title: New York Today: Lingering Little Brazil
description: Updated, 9:57 a.m.

title: Hitler Opens the Berlin Olympic Games in 1936
description: TheOlympic Games in Rio de Janeiro will open on Friday, bringingthe Games to South America for the first time. Eighty years ago, the Olympics opened in a very different climate, as Hitler hosted the 1936 Games in Berlin. Below are excerpts from the New York Herald report on the opening ceremonythere.

title: For Putin, Disinformation Is Power
description: MOSCOW  Fifteen years ago, a few months into his presidency, Vladimir V. Putin told Larry King on CNN that his previous job as a K.G.B. officer had been like that of a journalist. They have the same purpose of gathering information, synthesizing it and presenting it for the consumption of decision makers, he said. Since then, he has excelled at using the media to consolidate power inside Russia and, increasingly, to wage an information war against the West.

description: Take the Quiz

description: RE: ROOSEVELT INSTITUTE

title: Why a Meaningful Shift in the Trump-Clinton Race May Be at Hand
description: Hillary Clinton has a large and perhaps growing lead in the nation and in many of the predominantly white battleground states where Donald Trump was thought to have his best shot, according to a wave of new surveys released in the last two days.

title: Cory Booker, After Touring a Prison, Renews Call for Criminal Justice Overhaul
description: After touring a federal prison on Thursday, Senator Cory Booker, Democrat of New Jersey, said he was more determined than ever to push through comprehensive criminal justice legislation that would cut mandatory minimum sentences and create new programs to ease prisoners re-entry into their communities.

title: Looking for Legal Status
description: When I first came to Israel from Eritrea four years ago, I went to a hospital and told them that I was a midwife, and that I had come to apply for a job. But they told me that I didnt have the papers needed to do that job in their country, so I went to work in a shawarma restaurant instead. I started out cleaning dishes and washing the place. It was not easy. The money was small, and four of us lived in two rooms. I had to go every two months to renew my asylum papers. For four years, I could never be permanent. Waiting in those queues, I could think only: I have to leave here. I cannot stay.

title: War Rug
description: Selected by Matthew Zapruder.

title: Hide and Seek in Chihuahua
description: Looking for Pancho Villa in a rugged and beautiful Mexican state.

title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 8 | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
description: Update: Winners for this week have been announced.

title: How to Read Lips
description: It is possible to listen with your eyes. Neuroimaging studies show that even when tested in silence, lip readers primary auditory cortex, the part of the brain that processes sound, is active. If you have lost some or all of your hearing, Molly Berry, a lip-reading tutor and chair of Britains Association of Teachers of Lipreading to Adults, suggests you start by announcing you have what she calls the invisible disability. No one will know youre deaf unless you tell them, says Berry, who, like most of her students, lost her hearing after childhood: She began going deaf in her 30s and now has a cochlear implant.

title: Kevin Warren of the Minnesota Vikings: Championships Are Won in the Details
description: This interview with Kevin Warren, chief operating officer of the Minnesota Vikings, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: How Not to Gain Weight on Vacation
description: Are extra pounds an inevitable consequence of a fun-filled vacation? They dont have to be, according to Harley Pasternak, an exercise physiologist, nutritionist and personal trainer in Los Angeles. Gaining weight on vacation is common, but its possible to go away, enjoy yourself and not come home heavier, he said. Here, he shares his tips on how to do just that.

title: When Get Out! Is Just a Game
description: When does an entertainment reach critical mass? Arguably, when its found on a cruise ship. That is the case with escape rooms, in which players in a locked room filled with clues try to escape before time runs out, usually in 60 minutes.

title: A Birmingham Restaurant With Fire in Its Belly
description: Youll find high ceilings, a long marble bar and large glass doors that open onto an inviting patio at OvenBird, the convivial restaurant that the chef Chris Hastings and his wife, Idie, opened in Birminghams Lakeview neighborhood last October. What you wont find is a gas line.

title: In Zurich, a Hawaiian-Themed Hotel With Kitsch to Spare
description: Rooms from 240 Swiss francs (about the same in dollars).

title: Help for a Colleague Who Has Talent, and Isnt Afraid to Scream It
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: Not Forgotten: Adam Yauch, Who, With His Bandmates the Beastie Boys, Made Hip-Hop Mainstream
description: The New York City rapper Adam Yauch, one of the Beastie Boys, helped make hip-hop the musical force that it has become today.

title: The Untouchables TV Series: Old-School Gangster Trapping
description: The Untouchables  the period crime show that ran on ABC from October 1959 through May 1963  was widely and with good reason considered the most violent dramatic series of its day. It was also, as demonstrated by a new DVD box (CBS/Paramount), one of the best.

title: Kashmiri Faces Sedition Charges Over Facebook Activity
description: NEW DELHI  The police in central India have charged a man with sedition, a colonial-era offense that can result in life imprisonment, based on Facebook content he shared or posted calling for India to withdraw from the Himalayan region of Kashmir.

title: How Donald Trumps Rigged Claim Chips Away at Democracy
description: As public support turns against him, Donald Trump is suggesting without evidence that the election could be rigged by Democrats using vote fraud. This claim threatens the norms of American elections and could provoke a damaging reaction among his supporters.

title: Trump, the Bad, Bad Businessman
description: The greatest scoop of my journalism career started at a poker table with a tip from an agitated banker.

title: Show Trials in China
description: On Thursday it was Zhou Shifengs turn to take the stage in the Chinese inquisition. A lawyer who worked with people who challenged the Communist Party, he was charged with spreading subversive thoughts under the influence of anti-China forces and sentenced to seven years in prison.

title: Confused by Chip Credit Cards? Get in Line
description: Youre at the checkout counter. Your items have been bagged. Your credit card is in your hand.

title: The Presidents Killing Spree in the Philippines
description: During his campaign, Rodrigo Duterte promised, in so many words, that he would launch a killing spree aimed at ridding the Philippines of drug-related crime as soon as he became president. He offered bounties to the police, the military, indeed anyone who wanted to help him with the job of assassinating 100,000 criminals during his first six months in office. He bragged there would be so many bodies in Manila Bay that the fish will grow fat.

title: 1891: China on the Brink of Rebellion
description: Our Shanghai correspondent, in a letter which we publish today [Aug. 6], sends us news of the gravest importance. China is on the brink of a rebellion permeating every corner of the Empire.

title: A.N.C. Suffers Major Election Setback in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG  The African National Congress, the party that helped liberate black South Africans from white-minority rule but has become mired in corruption, endured its worst election since taking power after the end of apartheid, according to results released on Friday.

title: Closets as Big as Some Apartments
Rumblings in the Auction World
description: A year or two ago, in less unsettled times, it was relatively easy for the wealthy to enhance their social status, and maybe make some money, by collecting art. Auction houses courted sellers with lavish guarantees; buyers, even at the top of the market, could be reasonably certain that quality works by blue-chip names would hold their value.

title: By the Numbers: Preparing for the Olympics
description: How did The New York Times prepare for its Olympics coverage? Heres a quantitative look.

title: This Is a Jobs Report That Democrats Can Boast About
description: Theres not much to say about the July jobs numbers beyond this: Theyre good news across the board.

title: 1966: Rock Hits Dr. King in Chicago Riot
description: Martin Luther King was hit on the head with a stone today [Aug. 5] as he stepped from his car in an all-white neighborhood to organize a demonstration against discrimination in housing.

title: Zen and the Art of 401(k) Maintenance
description: Heres how to get better returns in your retirement account: Pay as little attention to it as possible.

title: Do Oil Companies Really Need $4 Billion Per Year of Taxpayers Money?
description: What would happen if the federal government ended its subsidies to companies that drill for oil and gas?

title: Jeff Bridges Muses on Guns, Trump and Adoration for the Dude
description: In the contemporary western Hell or High Water, which generated buzz at Cannes, Jeff Bridges comes full circle in his portrayal of a steely, wisecracking Texas Ranger whose final mission is to track down two brothers who are robbing banks to pay off the lien on their deceased mothers property.

title: Waking the Spirit of a Disco Innovator
description: On Oct. 9, 1982, the songwriter and producer Patrick Cowley observed the release event for his third solo album, Mind Warp, from the mezzanine of the glamorous Galleria event space at the San Francisco Design Center. Mr. Cowley, the disco innovator who spawned hi-NRG  an up-tempo, mechanized strain of dance music calibrated for the peak of the party  wore black patent-leather pants and a matching jacket. The sickly-sweet smell of the inhalant club drug known as poppers wafted up from the dance floor, where gay men dressed in jeans and white T-shirts churned to the albums breathless pulse. But the revelry belied the grim content of Mind Warp, a meditation on the body besieged that Mr. Cowley created while withering from the effects of a mysterious affliction.

title: Back-to-School Sales Tax Holidays May Be Skimpier This Year
description: MANY states are holding annual back to school sales tax holidays in the coming weeks, but some are cutting back on the potential savings offered.

title: Single, 54, and a New Dad: Why Some Start Families Late
description: [The topics new parents are talking about. Evidence-based guidance. Personal stories that matter. Sign up now to get NYT Parenting in your inbox every week.]

title: Black Lives Matter Activists Stage Protests Across Britain
description: LONDON  Black activists, responding to calls for a nationwide protest against racial injustice, staged demonstrations in London and several other cities across Britain on Friday, in their boldest show of support to date for the emerging Black Lives Matter movement here.

title: A Soprano Finds a New Voice: Conducting
description: AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France  Barbara Hannigan was lying on her back onstage a few weeks ago during a performance of Debussys Pellas et Mlisande, a dreamlike, demanding production at the Aix Festival here, in which Ms. Hannigan, playing Mlisande, barely left the audiences sight.

title: Boxed In, Freaked Out: A Claustrophobe Navigates a Crowded City
description: Every claustrophobe will tell you that its the elevator riders who are the crazy ones. Thats what I am muttering as I haul myself up the winding staircase to the Grand Ballroom on the third floor of the Plaza Hotel in a gown on my way to a black-tie wedding. A few minutes earlier, I had taken one look at the elevator in the lobby and determined: No way. If there was an alternate route up, I would find it. My husband shot a knowing look my way and piled into the metal box with too many other guests  an image, even as I write this, that makes me uneasy  riding what The New York Times in 1891 called the vertical railway.

title: Design Thinking for Media That Matters
description: At the end of May, eight New York Times product managers and engineers participated in Matters media startup accelerator bootcamp. Over four strenuous days, we learned the process of design thinking: a human-centered, prototype-driven approach to creating something that fills a meaningful need in someones life.

title: Boston Police Chief on Defusing Tensions: Relationships Matter
description: BOSTON  The violent confrontations between the police and minorities that have erupted in many cities over the last couple of years have created new pressures on police commanders across the country. Many of them were already dealing with issues of morale, recruitment and retention, and community relations. But Boston, a city with a history of racial tensions, has been comparatively calm.

title: Ben Brantleys No. 1 Tip for Interviewing Barbra Streisand: Get Her to Show You the House
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Ben Brantley, the Timess chief theater critic, lets his inner fan boy peek out as he describes what it was like to spend a recent afternoon in Malibu, Calif., chez Streisand.

title: Why This Is Fine Is the Meme This Year Deserves
description: During the Democratic National Convention, the Republican Party shared a popular meme to Twitter: a two-frame comic of a dog sitting at a table with a cup of coffee. The room is on fire.

title: A Ballet Teacher Changes the Rules
description: Ashley Tuttle watched as her students sweated through their barre exercises with diligence but little spirit.

title: Did Obamas Bill Fix Veterans Health Care? Still Waiting.
description: When President Obama signed a sweeping $15 billion bill to end delays at Department of Veterans Affairs hospitals two years ago, lawmakers standing with him applauded the legislation as a bold response that would finally break the logjam.

title: Week of TV Trials in China Signals New Phase in Attack on Rights
description: BEIJING  Chinese lawyers and rights activists appeared in televised trials throughout this week in what seemed to be a new, more public phase of President Xi Jinpings campaign to cleanse the country of liberal ideas and activism.

title: Philanthropic Group Asks Rich Women for Work as Well as Money
description: PAM SCOTT, a marketing consultant, has worked with global brands like American Express, Nike and Levis to help them connect better with their customers.

description: Mr. Ratliff, a music critic at The Times since 1996, discusses his tenure.

description: NINETY-NINE STORIES OF GODBy Joy Williams151 pp. Tin House Books. $19.95.

title: Southern Fiction
description: THE ADVENTURISTBy J. Bradford Hipps276 pp. St. Martins, $25.99.

title: Paperback Row
description: Seven new paperbacks to check out this week.

title: The Poisoning of Children Around the World
description: Since the disaster in Flint, Mich., it seems each day there is a new report of lead exposure being rediscovered in American cities, towns and schools. Blood lead levels are tripling in some places and children with growing brains are at risk of reduced intelligence and developmental disabilities. These events have put the lead threat back on the front burner of U.S. public health priorities.

title: Heres a Solution
description: Sometimes a forceful tone is useful in disrupting someones dominant narrative of whats going wrong in their life, the journalist and advice columnist Heather Havrilesky recently told me. But I think my tone is far more compassionate and open than it was a few years ago. I made so many big mistakes when I was younger, and I still mess up regularly. Navigating this life is not simple or easy.

title: Syrian Girl Born Without an Eye Undergoes Surgery in Barcelona
description: MADRID  A refugee infant from Syria who was born without an eye and with a seriously disfigured face successfully underwent eye surgery at a Barcelona hospital on Friday, after being granted a special visa from Spain to receive free treatment.

title: How to Keep an Atomic Bomb From Being Smuggled Into New York City? Open Every Suitcase With a Screwdriver.
description: ALMIGHTYCourage, Resistance, and Existential Peril in the Nuclear AgeBy Dan ZakIllustrated. 402 pp. Blue Rider Press. $27.

title: The Latest and Best in Crime Fiction
description: Irish sons are brought up to honor their mothers. To Jimmy Phelan, the most feared gangster in the city of Cork, that means cleaning up his mothers kitchen after she bashes an intruder to a bloody pulp with a gaudy religious artifact she calls her holy stone. This tragicomic scene captures the wonderfully offbeat voice of Lisa McInerney, whose irreverent first novel, THE GLORIOUS HERESIES (Tim Duggan, $27), descends into the citys seedy underworld and finds a community of alcoholics, prostitutes, drug dealers and their customers, who live like rats but speak like street poets. Ireland is gripped in a recession, and a lot of people have no jobs  but not down here, where everyones working in the shadow economy, selling drugs or sex or someone elses stuff.

title: A Novels Abandoned Baby Links the Lives of Two Women
description: LEAVING LUCY PEARBy Anna Solomon319 pp. Viking. $26.

title: A Thriller Constructed From the Frustrations of a Long Marriage

title: A New Book Defends Irans Last Shah

description: LISTEN TO MEBy Hannah Pittard194 pp. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt. $25.

description: THIS MUST BE THE PLACEBy Maggie OFarrellIllustrated. 382 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $26.95.

title: Dementia Dims a Fathers Brilliance in a Novel Plumbing Family Mysteries
description: THE UNSEEN WORLDBy Liz Moore451 pp. W.W. Norton & Company. $26.95.

title: A Womans Love Affair With the North Is Both Travelogue and Memoir
description: WELCOME TO THE GODDAMN ICE CUBEChasing Fear and Finding Home in the Great White NorthBy Blair Braverman274 pp. Ecco/HarperCollins Publishers. $25.99.

description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | RSS | Stitcher| Audioboom

title: Review: Midsummer, an Urban Fairy Tale, Comes to Hartford
description: Yes, I thought during the last moments of Midsummer (a Play With Songs), I like these people together; they should be in love.

title: Inside the List
description: Moving On Up: Any way you look at it, J. D. Vance is a member of the elite  a Yale Law graduate and former biotech executive who is now, in his early 30s, a principal at a San Francisco investment firm. But it wasnt always thus. In the memoir Hillbilly Elegy, new at No.9 on the hardcover nonfiction list, Vance details his childhood in a poor Ohio town among a chaotic extended family with a mother who turned to drugs and a string of unstable relationships. Along the way, he takes a cleareyed look at some vexing and intractable problems facing the white underclass, which in my reading makes his book a kind of Appalachian version of Ta-Nehisi Coatess Between the World and Me (at No.6 after 55 weeks on the list) and a more intimate companion volume to Nancy Isenbergs cultural study White Trash (at No.10 after six weeks).

title: Adding Old Movies to an Old-Fashioned iPod
description: Q. I found some free old movies in the Internet Archive to download, but how can I copy the files to my iPod Nano, which does not have internet access?

title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: Home for Sale in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include a six-bedroom in Tenafly, N.J., and a four-bedroom in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: Scrutiny of Incoming Police Commissioner Begins. With His Suits.
description: Shortly after Chief James P. ONeill was announced as New Yorks next police commissioner, a city official took a look at him, still dressed in the uniform he has worn for most of his 33 years on the job. Youre going to go out and get some more suits, fella, the official said.

title: Daily Report: Facebook Bars Cheesy Headlines That Let Readers Down
description: Facebook isnt ending spam. It just wants better labeling on the can.

title: At Westchester Broadway, Suede Shoes and Prison Blues
description: Silence makes for one of the best moments in Million Dollar Quartet, the jukebox musical now cranking out the entertainment at Westchester Broadway Theater in Elmsford.

title: Inside Repossis New Paris Flagship Boutique
description: Gaia Repossi worked with the architect Rem Koolhaas to create a space as modern and architectural as her own haute jewelry designs.

title: The Most Stunning New Store in Pariss Haute Jewelry Mecca
description: Micro architectures. That is how Gaia Repossi describes the fine jewelry she designs. Not as multi-carat baubles. Or haute fantasias  the provenance of most high-end jewelers. But strict architectural works conceived as human adornment. A series of segmented rings joined by a simple line across the phalanx references the Brutalist lines of Le Corbusier. Delicately looping squiggles suggest, simultaneously, the world of Calder and the spectral images of radio waves.

title: The Modern Games
description: Travel through time to some of the most unforgettable moments in Olympic history.

title: The S.S. United States Wont Take to the Seas Again After All
description: The S.S. United States, the worlds fastest ocean liner, wont be sailing the seas again after all.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are in Greenwich Village, the East Village and Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: Yankees Mark Teixeira Will Retire After This Season
description: If the decision to announce his retirement at the end of the season was an obvious one, as Mark Teixeira proclaimed, it was not an easy one.

title: 3 Quick and Savory Recipes for Peak-of-the-Season Tomatoes
description: Were in tomato thrall. Real tomatoes are back, in all their tomatoey glory. The cherry tomatoes at the greenmarket are so riotously colorful  bright little spheres in yellow, red, burgundy, orange and green  that I keep a big bowl of them on the kitchen table. Its hard to pass by without grabbing a couple, as if I were reaching for a few juicy grapes or berries.

title: Immunotherapy Drug Opdivo Fails Clinical Trial to Expand Use
description: The hot new field of immunotherapy got a shock on Friday when a best-selling new drug failed as an initial treatment for lung cancer in a clinical trial.

title: The Particle That Wasnt
description: A great might have been for the universe, or at least for the people who study it, disappeared Friday.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: How to Be a Person in the World
description: Heather Havrilesky discusses her new collection of advice columns, and Jessica Winter talks about her debut novel, Break in Case of Emergency.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: How to Be a Person in the World
description: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

title: Preparing for a Surfing Safari on a Do-It-Yourself Board
description: When I took up surfing last summer after a 20-year hiatus, I immediately realized that this would be not a casual hobby but a year-round obsession.

title: Moroccan Olympic Boxer Arrested on Sexual Assault Charges
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The Brazilian police arrested the Moroccan Olympic boxer Hassan Saada on Friday morning on charges of sexually assaulting two workers at the Olympic Village. He is to be held for 15 days, according to a court statement, making it likely that he will miss his fight scheduled for Saturday.

title: Flying With Shrieking Children? Give Your Neighbors a Goody Bag
description: Some of the worlds rudest and most obnoxious people can be found on airplanes: the line jumpers, the overhead-bin hogs, the incessant talkers, the seat recliners and the armrest appropriators. And dont forget the shrieking children and the parents who cant or wont keep them quiet.

title: For Fall Coats, Bigger is Better
description: This season, voluminous outerwear has emerged as the apex of au courant style.

title: Newcomer to the Old Ball Game
description: Its not Cooperstown. But the people who come upon, or seek out, the baseball cards in a dimly lighted corridor of the American Wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art display behavior similar to the people, mostly men, you see poring over artifacts at the Baseball Hall of Fame nearly 200 miles upstate.

title: Syrians Seeking Asylum in South Korea Find Only a Cold Shoulder
description: YANGJU, South Korea  Surrounded by salvaged used-cars parts bound for Syria, Ahmad Khalifa has worked 12 hours a day for three years in one country that does not really want him while longing for another that war has destroyed.

title: Review: Marleys Cafe Is a Sweet Spot With a Reggae Soundtrack
description: Ill wager that most of us have enjoyed at least one memorable meal in our lives that had very little to do with food. I know Ive been lucky enough to attend several such occasions  all of which left me with only a vague recollection of what I ate, but an indelible impression of the experience: the company I kept, the environment we shared.

title: Embarrassing Photos of Me, Thanks to My Right-Wing Stalkers
description: MIDDLEBURY, Vt.  THERE are shameful photos of me on the internet.

title: What You Should Watch: The Little Prince and the Olympics
description: Welcome to Watching, The New York Timess what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. You can browse previous guides here, and to receive recommendations straight to your inbox, sign up here. Stay tuned for our coming website.

title: Photo Firehose: Rio Olympics
description: A real-time stream of images from the Rio 2016 Olympics by photographers for The New York Times, The Associated Press, Reuters, Getty Images, European Pressphoto Agency, and Agence France-Presse.

title: Review: At Limani Seafood Grill in Westfield, Bringing Greece Home
description: As I sat at Limani Seafood Grill in Westfield on one of the warmest days of the year and devoured a salad of sweet watermelon, tangy feta cheese and fresh mint, I was certain that there was no better antidote to the oppressive heat.

title: Review: At Pax Romana in White Plains, Eating as the Romans (Mostly) Do
description: Pax Romana, an eating emporium that opened last February in White Plains, is a smart salute to the culinary traditions of Rome. In a city where Bloomingdales must stand in for the Coliseum, and the gushing water feature in front of Trump Tower at City Center is as close as youll get to anything remotely like the Trevi Fountain, the team at Pax Romana is valiantly turning out plates of cacio e pepe and spaghetti carbonara for an appreciative pubblico (public).

title: Review: Dopo La Spiaggias Chef Brings Lighter Fare to Sag Harbor
description: It must have been quite a surprise for some residents of Sag Harbor this summer when they wandered over to their beloved Bay Street restaurant, Tutto Il Giorno, only to discover it was now called Dopo La Spiaggia (After the beach). Was it possible that the immensely popular Tutto had fallen victim to the Hamptons restaurant scenes revolving-door epidemic?

title: Great Wine Is Not Enough on the North Fork
description: SOUTHOLD, N.Y.  Southold Farm & Cellar produces some of the most interesting, creative and exciting wines on the North Fork of Long Island.

title: Stunning Photos, New and Old, of Rio de Janeiro
description: Just in time for the Olympics, a new book showcases the vibrant and diverse history of their host city.

title: Chicago Releases Videos From Police Officers Killing of 18-Year-Old
description: CHICAGO  An agency that investigates Chicago police conduct released dramatic videos on Friday showing two officers firing their guns at a fleeing stolen car in a fast-paced, chaotic clash last week that led to another officer fatally shooting an unarmed 18-year-old black man in the back.

title: Deliveroo, an On-Demand Food Delivery Service, Raises $275 Million
description: How much money does it take to compete with Uber?

title: $32 Million Sale on Fifth Avenue
description: The chief executive of the Loews Corporation, James S. Tisch, purchased through a trust a sprawling apartment at 1040 Fifth Avenue, an exclusive prewar co-op building designed by Rosario Candela and home to a host of prominent residents over the years, including Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis.

title: Gullivers Gate, a Huge Miniature World, Will Rise Near Times Square
description: Near the Brooklyn Navy Yard, the Seagrams building is nearly complete, its bottom swathed in green plastic. A few steps away, at the Whitney Museum of American Art, construction has just begun, its bottom floors being measured with a ruler. And downstairs, the Roosevelt Island tram is slowly making its way through a test run.

title: Accounting Error May Not Derail Deal, but Ex-Director Bails Early Anyway
description: When a company delays the release of its financial results because of an accounting error, spooked investors typically flee, and shares plummet.

title: The Dapper and Dignified Newspaper Salesman in Chelsea
description: Each day, no matter the weather, Steeve Mackaya dons a bright suit, with coordinating shirt, tie and hat, to sell newspapers in Chelsea.

title: My 10 Favorite Books: Andrew Solomon
description: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the writer and National Book Award winner Andrew Solomon, who shares his list exclusively with T.

title: The Ever-So-Stylish Newspaper Salesman
description: Steeve Mackaya arrives each morning before rush hour with three stacks of newspapers, two milk crates and, rain or shine, a different boldly colored suit. The photographer Moshe Katvan noticed him sitting in his wheelchair and was mesmerized. He was like a piece of New York street art, totally unbelievable and amazing, the photographer said. You wont see it anywhere else in the world. I asked him what he wanted, if he wanted money. He said he wanted nothing. He just wanted to say his piece.

title: When New York, Leery of Losing Business, Leaned Dixie
description: Because of cotton, no city in the North was more pro-South, anti-abolition or anti-Lincoln, John Strausbaugh writes in justifying the title of his new book, City of Sedition: The History of New York City During the Civil War (Twelve Books, $30).

title: Snowy Egrets, Once Fashion Victims, Always Elegant Predators
description: There is nothing as white as a snowy egret, and few things are as graceful. Watching one hunt in the shallow waters of Hamilton Beach, Queens, one early morning, I was held rapt for almost an hour by the birds search for prey. Its image reflected perfectly in the dark mirror of the Hawtree Creek, it was as if two birds hunted. The scene was like a masterful Japanese print; minimal, carefully rendered and capturing an ancient truth. I pitied the school of killifish the bird had targeted.

title: Indian Textiles Sold for Happy Money
description: On a recent afternoon, Katie Novello laid a pile of clothes on the counter of Dress Shoppe II in the East Village: cotton tunics, billowy drawstring pants, an embroidered jacket.

title: Daymond Johns Sunday Activity
description: Mr. John, an investor on the ABC reality series Shark Tank, throws knives during his downtime. The exercise can be really tiring, he said.

title: The Playlist: Britney Spears Puts on a Show and Tove Lo Plays It Cool
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos  and anything else that strikes them as intriguing  in the Playlist. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this format? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com.

title: How Daymond John, a Shark Tank Investor, Spends His Sundays
description: Daymond John, an investor on the ABC reality series Shark Tank, travels roughly 280 days a year. When he is in New York, chances are he is in Midtown. From the Empire State Building, Mr. John, 47, runs Fubu, an apparel company he founded with three friends in Queens nearly a quarter-century ago. After work, he simply crosses the street to get home, where he lives with his partner, Heather Taras, and their 5-month-old daughter, Minka, in a high-rise. It is a convenient setup for work, but when it is time to play he prefers woodpeckers and grass to concrete and pigeons. On weekends, he sometimes skips town and drives north to his cabin in Dutchess County, which sits on several hundred acres.

title: After Brexit Vote, a Burst of Interest in Travel to Britain
description: It has not been even two months since Britain voted to leave the European Union, and already, the travel industry is seeing the effects of the decision. While its too soon to determine how travel to Britain will be affected in the long term, for the time being, with the exchange rate of the pound at a more than 30-year low  compared with the dollar, the region seems to be a more appealing destination for travelers from the United States.

title: Transgender Acceptance
description: To the Editor:

title: Safety at the Panama Canal
description: To the Editor:

title: Thomas Ads on His Tricky Opera Adaptation of a Buuel Film
description: SALZBURG, Austria  Thomas Adss new opera, The Exterminating Angel, based on the surreal 1962 Luis Buuel film, had its premiere at the Salzburg Festival on July 28; it arrives at the Metropolitan Opera next year. One of the great composers of his generation, Mr. Ads, 45, has written only two previous operas  Powder Her Face (1995) and The Tempest (2003)  so this was a major event.

title: A Dubious Sale in Manhattan
description: To the Editor:

title: The One That Got Away: How an Elusive Fish Captured a New York Town
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y.  It began, as so many eyebrow-raising stories do, with a tale about a fish.

title: Incitement by Fatah
description: To the Editor:

title: Bristol-Myers Squibbs Hubris Cost It $21 Billion
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb has suffered a $21 billion self-inflicted wound.

title: New York Buildings With Communal Gardens
description: Joining a community garden or growing herbs on your kitchen windowsill are two tried-and-true methods for New York apartment dwellers to keep their green thumbs active. Now some new developments are offering residents space in on-site gardens, and at least one has created a farm on the buildings property.

title: Ways to Get More Voters to the Polls
description: To the Editor:

title: Profanity, Vitriol, Slurs: Why The Times Published Trump Rally Video
description: David M. Halbfinger, a presidential campaign editor, and Erica Berenstein, a video journalist, talk about the decision to publish Unfiltered Voices From Donald Trumps Crowds.

title: On the Trail: The Week of July 31
description: Both campaigns headed into Rust Belt states that could be decisive in the election, while also making stops in places like Florida, Virginia and Colorado.

title: Chris Costner Sizemore, Patient Behind The Three Faces of Eve, Dies at 89
description: At the start of the 1957 movie The Three Faces of Eve, the British-born journalist Alistair Cooke, who narrates the film, appears on camera to tell viewers that the incredible tale they are about to see is a true story  not suggested by or based on something that happened, but a facsimile of actual events.

title: The U.S. Olympic Swim Team Does Car Pool Karaoke
description: The opening ceremony for the Olympics will be held in Rio on Friday, and the first goofy video of the event has arrived just in time.

title: 10 Things to Do Now in NYC
description: A guide to cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And there's much more where these came from.

title: Chicago Releases Clip of Police Shooting
description: Officials released footage on Friday of the moments before a deadly police shooting of an 18-year-old, Paul ONeal, in Chicago last week. The video shows the police firing into an allegedly stolen car.

title: Can G.O.P. Tell Donald Trump, Youre Fired? Probably Not
description: We are in the midst of yet another of Donald J. Trumps self-inflicted spirals of terrible news. And with prominent Republicans saying they will back Hillary Clinton and others announcing this week that they wont endorse Mr. Trump, there has been yet another round of speculation about how the party could get rid of him.

title: 2 Muslim American Women Ordered Off American Airlines Flight
description: Two Muslim American women were ordered off an American Airlines plane in Miami this week after a flight attendant said that overhearing them talking with other passengers about the lack of food and water on the flight made him uncomfortable, one of the women said.

title: Profanity, Vitriol, Slurs: Why The Times Published Unfiltered Trump Rally Video
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

title: Where a Queens Jogger Died, Residents Warn: Dont Go There Alone
description: Local residents call it the Weeds. Or the Baja, because it is a dirt-filled peninsula. It is the reed-choked interior of Spring Creek Park in Howard Beach, Queens, where Karina Vetrano, 30, went alone for an evening jog on Tuesday and never came out.

title: Why Frank Ocean and Other Big Names Prefer the Sudden Digital Drop
