description: MEXICO CITY  At least 39 people have died in Mexico after a series of landslides caused by torrential rains from Tropical Storm Earl, government officials said, as the country braced for the arrival of another tropical storm.

title: 5 Things to Know About Japans Emperor and Imperial Family
description: Emperor Akihito of Japan indicated in a rare public address on Monday that he wants to abdicate the throne, which would make him the first Japanese monarch in 200 years to step down. Here are five essential facts about one of the worlds oldest and most cloistered royal families.

title: Listening to Voices From 'Hijabi World'
description: On what is likely the most diverse college campus in the United States, Muslim women who wear a hijab talk about their lives.

description: To the Editor:

title: To Floss, or Not?

title: Moving Beyond Bratton
description: WITH the impending departure of William J. Bratton as commissioner of the New York Police Department, an important chapter in American policing is about to close. Mr. Bratton  with whom I have collaborated in a Harvard program on police reform  has served with distinction as commissioner in Boston, Los Angeles and twice in New York, the nations largest department and a trendsetter in the profession. Not surprisingly, police chiefs across the country are watching the Police Department closely to see whether, and how, it moves beyond Mr. Brattons policies.

title: A Message to a Stingy Governor
description: Considering the hard-pressed criminal justice system of Missouri  a crisis laid bare by the police shooting and civil unrest in Ferguson in 2014  the last thing Gov. Jay Nixon should be doing is stinting on support of the state public defender system, which provides counsel to indigent defendants.

title: Can Clinton or Trump Recapture Robust American Growth?
description: The party conventions were rightly characterized as either relentlessly downbeat (Republican) or fervently optimistic (Democratic). The Republican view rests in part on poll numbers that show a solid majority of Americans think that the country is headed in the wrong direction. What has caused this malaise?

title: Time to Borrow
description: The campaign still has three ugly months to go, but the odds  83 percent odds, according to the New York Timess model  are that it will end with the election of a sane, sensible president. So what should she do to boost Americas economy, which is doing better than most of the world but is still falling far short of where it should be?

title: Many Countries Will Need Help Adapting to Climate Change
description: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration reported last week that global temperatures last year were the highest on record  and that this year is likely to be hotter still. That is a powerful reason for rich countries to begin making good on their promises to help low-lying island nations, some of the poorest countries in the world, build their defenses against the disastrous effects of climate change, which some are already experiencing.

title: Trumps Troubles in the Black Belt
description: There has been much talk this election about the fundamental transformation of voters in the Rust Belt and what that portends for Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump.

title: Can We Trust Julian Assange and WikiLeaks?
description: The release of a cache of emails from the Democratic National Committee by WikiLeaks last month has raised a great many questions  about the role of the D.N.C. in trying to influence the primary and about the alleged interference of Russian intelligence in an American election.

title: New Approaches to Fighting Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: Against Sustainability
description: Among the many stories that can be told about the origins of the environmental movement in the West, perhaps the most common is that it began with the emergence of Romanticism in the late 18th century. In this version, environmentalism was born as the good twin to evil industrialization. Today, when we talk about ecological sustainability and environmental preservation, we typically still understand them in terms of a battle between nature and industry.

title: Listening to the Voices From Hijabi World
description: To set foot on the campus of Rutgers University, Newark, is to witness a majority-minority census in three dimensions. Brown, black, beige and every shade in between, the universitys population is robust with first-generation Americans redefining attitudes about race, interfaith dialogue and national identity. Those features have led it to be ranked by U.S. News and World Report as the most diverse campus in the United States.

title: Kenya Angers Taiwan by Deporting More Fraud Suspects to China
description: HONG KONG  Taiwan protested on Monday after five of its people were deported from Kenya to China, where they are wanted on suspicion of telecommunications fraud.

title: Transcript of Emperor Akihitos Speech
description: Following is a translation of Emperor Akihitos televised address to the Japanese public on Monday, as prepared by the Imperial Household Agency. In the speech, Akihito, 82, spoke publicly for the first time about retiring.

title: Picture Prompt | Children and Cell Phones
description: A Times article says that, on average, children are getting their first smartphones around age 10.

title: Put One Foot Wrong in This Town and Youve Left the Country
description: At De Biergrens beer shop, you can walk in from the Netherlands through one door and walk out into Belgium through another. There are two telephones, one connected to the Belgian telecom system and one plugged into the Dutch. There are even two cash registers, at opposite ends of the shop  one in each country.

title: Criminal Defendants Sometimes Left Behind at Supreme Court, Study Shows
description: WASHINGTON  The quality of advocacy at the Supreme Court these days is quite high. We have an extraordinary group of lawyers who appear very regularly before us, Justice Elena Kagan said in 2014 at a Justice Department event.

title: Donald Trumps Diet: Hell Have Fries With That
description: President Obama is so disciplined that his wife has teased that he eats precisely seven lightly salted almonds each night.

title: Suing a New Jersey Commissioner Over Rules for Fertility Treatment
description: The plaintiffs claim a state mandate discriminates against their sexual orientation by essentially forcing them into costly treatments.

title: 4 Lesbians Sue Over New Jersey Rules on Fertility Treatment
description: Five years ago, Erin and Marianne Krupa chose to start a family. They moved to Montclair, N.J., from a more conservative environment in North Carolina, and decided that Erin would carry their first child.

title: Under Pier 57 in Manhattan
description: Pier 57 is supported on three buoyant concrete boxes anchored permanently below the water line. Being inside them feels simultaneously claustrophobic and limitless.

title: Pier 57 Goes Down in History as a Place Where Concrete Floats
description: Youll have an easier time reading this column if you accept that colossal concrete boxes  one and a half blocks long and three stories high  can float in water.

title: Reconstructing Taoisms Transformation in China
description: Terry F. Kleeman is a leading scholar of the early texts and history of Chinas only indigenous religion, Taoism. A professor of religious studies at the University of Colorado, Boulder, he is the author of the recently published Celestial Masters: History and Ritual in Early Daoist Communities. This is the first work in any Western language on the founding of Taoism as a formal religious movement, rooted in earlier philosophical teachings like the Tao Te Ching, also known as the Daodejing and sometimes translated as The Way and Its Power.

title: Michael Ian Black Reviews 2 Books About the Male Physique
description: THE HEROS BODYBy William GiraldiIllustrated. 265 pp. Liveright Publishing. $25.95.

title: Nina Stibbes New Novel Sets a Moody Teenage Heroine in a Sketchy Nursing Home
description: PARADISE LODGEBy Nina Stibbe274 pp. Little, Brown & Company. $26.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills Dozens at Pakistani Hospital in Quetta
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A suicide bomber struck a hospital in the southwestern Pakistani city of Quetta on Monday, officials said, killing at least 74 people in another devastating attack on civilians in a city that has become a byword for massacre and struggle over the past decade.

title: Anna Wintours Wild Garden
description: A stroll through the editors romantic and meandering 40 acres  cultivated over the last 20 years by her friend, the landscape designer Miranda Brooks.

title: Alzheimers Patients Keep the Spark Alive by Sharing Stories
description: Can you keep the love light shining after your partners brain has begun to dim? Just ask Denise Tompkins of Naperville, Ill., married 36 years to John, now 69, who has Alzheimers disease.

description: Hillary Clinton will begin a two-day campaign swing through Florida on Monday, seeking to keep Donald J. Trump on his heels in a state viewed as central to his electoral fortunes.

title: Video Software Maker Kaltura Raises $50 Million From Goldman
description: Kaltura, which makes software that allows users such as companies and universities to upload and share video over the web, has raised $50 million from Goldman Sachss private capital investing group.

title: The Merits of Reading Real Books to Your Children
description: A new Harry Potter book and a new round of stories about midnight book release parties reminded me of the persistent power of words printed on a page to shape childrens lives.

title: As Peat Bogs Burn, a Climate Threat Rises
description: RED EARTH CREEK, Alberta  Kristyn Housman grabbed the end of a sampling auger, a steel tube that two colleagues had just drilled into a moss-covered hummock in a peat bog, and poked through a damp, fibrous plug of partly decomposed peat.

title: Think Tanks Become Vehicles for Corporate Influence
description: Think Tanks Become Vehicles for Corporate Influence They are regarded as research centers independent of moneyed interest, but think tanks have to chase funds, too and, in the process, have pushed the agendas of corporate donors.

title: 6 South Korean Lawmakers Accused of Taking Chinas Side Against Antimissile System
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A political split in South Korea over the deployment of a United States missile defense system sharpened on Monday, as six opposition lawmakers began a three-day visit to China and President Park Geun-hye accused them of siding with Beijing in a dispute of major national import.

title: Thousands in Eastern Chinese City Protest Nuclear Waste Project
description: BEIJING  Chinas efforts to expand its nuclear power sector suffered a backlash in one eastern seaboard city over the weekend, as thousands of residents took to the streets to oppose any decision to build a reprocessing plant in the area for spent nuclear fuel.

title: Donald Trump Adopts G.O.P. Tax Cuts, but Balks at Trade Pacts
description: Donald J. Trump sought on Monday to move beyond a week of turmoil, using a major policy address to cast himself as a president who could bring new jobs and prosperity and warning that his rival, Hillary Clinton, would be a steward of stagnation.

title: A Favorable Poll for Donald Trump Seems to Have a Problem
description: Theres an interesting new entry in political polling: the U.S.C. Dornsife/Los Angeles Times Daybreak poll. Its different from other surveys because its a panel, which means it recontacts the same voters over and over. In 2012, a similar panel study done by RAND was considered a big success.

title: Whoops! When Museum Visitors Get Touchy-Feely With the Exhibits and Unleash Mayhem
description: A man walked into the National Watch and Clock Museum in Columbia, Pa., in May. A video showed him admiring a sculptural wall clock on display, touching and pulling on it at least five times to see how it works.

title: Thailands Divisions on Display in Vote Approving New Constitution
description: HONG KONG  Although a proposed constitution drafted by Thailands military government has been endorsed by a majority of voters, regional returns show that deep political divides remain, analysts said on Monday.

title: 4 Great Fly-Fishing Destinations
description: From Upstate New York to Montana, four rivers to fly-fish your way to paradise.

title: 1966: U.S. Space Accord with Russia
description: NEW YORK  Ambassador Arthur J. Goldberg said today [Aug. 8] that the Soviet Union will sign a treaty with the United States on the peaceful uses of outer space despite tensions between the two countries over war in Vietnam. Mr. Goldberg said this was his personal assessment at the month-long meeting in Geneva, where representatives of 28 countries met to draft the treaty.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 9, 1966

title: White Nights and Cheap Days in St. Petersburg
description: No. Is not you.

title: How Common Procedures Became 20 Percent Cheaper for Many Californians
description: At a time when health care spending seems only to go up, an initiative in California has slashed the prices of many common procedures.

title: As Peace Talks in Yemen Crumble, Civilians End Up in Cross Hairs Again
description: SANA, Yemen  A pharmacist, Sadam al-Othari, had a firsthand look at the results of the collapse in peace talks in Yemen between the Saudi-led military coalition and Yemeni militias over the weekend when a bomb exploded outside his drugstore, killing a customer and his young son and wounding Mr. Othari.

title: What Are the Purple Dots on Michael Phelps? Cupping Has an Olympic Moment
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Olympics trivia: What has 19 gold medals and a bunch of purple circles?

title: Not Forgotten: Jesse Owenss Chilly Reception in Nazi Germany, Then Olympic Glory
description: Owens faced a moral tug of war and ultimately decided to participate in the 1936 Games in Hitlers Berlin. He won four gold medals.

title: Amid Softening, Sothebys Posts Gain in Latest Quarter
description: Sothebys latest earnings report amounts to a microcosm of the art market.

title: Tracy Morgan to Return to the New York Comedy Festival
description: Tracy Morgan, recovered from the 2014 car crash that nearly killed him and having earned an Emmy nomination for the Saturday Night Live episode he hosted last fall, will return to the New York Comedy Festival for the first time since 2011.

title: Edward Daly, Peace-Seeking Bishop in Northern Irelands Troubles, Dies at 82
description: Edward Daly, who as the Roman Catholic bishop of Northern Irelands second-largest city argued relentlessly for peace during the three decades of sectarian violence known as the Troubles, died on Monday in Londonderry. He was 82.

title: Scores Killed in Pakistan Hospital Blast
description: Dozens of people died in Quetta, Pakistan, on Monday as an explosion, apparently caused by a suicide bomber, rocked a hospital.

title: Rio Olympics: Drama in the Pool and a Super Tuesday
description: Womens 100-meter Breaststroke: In the days leading up to this race, the American Lilly King criticized her Russian opponent, reigning world champion Yulia Efimova, for her drug cheating, a reference to Efimovas 16-month doping suspension which ended in early 2015. During qualifying the two rivals exchanged finger-wagging taunts, which led to a tense final.

title: Walmart Rewrites Its E-Commerce Strategy With $3.3 Billion Deal for Jet.com
description: Traditional retailers have spent more than a decade and billions of dollars trying to transform their brick-and-mortar businesses for the online shopper. Yet Amazon and other digital upstarts continue to lap them.

title: Views From the Pulpit Tend to Favor Hillary Clinton, Survey Finds
description: Few American churchgoers have heard endorsements from the pulpit in the past few months of this contentious presidential race, but when clergy members did speak out in church, far more favored Hillary Clinton than Donald J. Trump, according to a survey released on Monday by the Pew Research Center.

title: Americas Dangerous Putin Panic
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria  WILL Vladimir V. Putin, the president of Russia, elect the next president of the United States? My guess is not. But reading the avalanche of commentary about Russias alleged interference in American politics, one might think otherwise.

title: Rural Electrical Cooperatives Turn to the Internet
description: By the 1930s, 90 percent of urban residents in the United States had electricity. Not so in rural areas, where only 10 percent of the population had easy access to electricity. Electrical companies argued that it was too difficult to provide service to those areas and, even if they did, there was little money to be made.

title: Taking the Windows 10 Express
description: Q.  When I downloaded the new Windows 10 update, I just clicked the Use Express Settings button during the installation. But what exactly are Express settings, and can I change them after the fact?

title: And the Rio Crowd Goes Crazy! For Whatever!
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The same shouts can be heard throughout the Summer Olympics, from table tennis and fencing to swimming and beach volleyball events: Silncio! Shh!

title: Sneaking Into a Chinese Village Where Floodwater and Unrest Linger
description: LONGCAO, China  The hardest part about getting into Longcao was not the floodwater, or the debris blocking the roads. The biggest obstacle was the cluster of police officers standing guard under the archway at the villages main entrance, peering into cars as they passed by.

title: For Italians, Donald Trumps Act Is Familiar
description: PORTOFERRAIO, Italy  Hes a prominent billionaire politician with a reputation for provocative comments, vulgar insults and sexual innuendo, to say nothing of a hairstyle that cant be ignored.

title: Fencer Is First American Olympian to Compete in a Head Scarf
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Drawn to fencing as a teenager because the athletes compete while fully covered, Ibtihaj Muhammad on Monday became the first United States Olympian in any sport to compete at a Games while wearing a hijab.

title: The Import of the Antinori Wine Family in a Terra Cotta Relief
description: The Antinoris of Florence, Italy, have been in the wine business in Tuscany since the 14th century and can trace their lineage back even further. As testimony to their importance during the Renaissance, a massive glazed terra-cotta relief, The Resurrection of Christ, by Giovanni della Robbia, dating from around 1524 and commissioned by the Antinoris, is a highlight of an exhibition of della Robbia works at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston. The relief, in a half-moon shape, was created for the entrance to one of the familys properties and includes the Antinori crest, designed by della Robbia. Since 1898 it has been in the Brooklyn Museum. The Antinoris contributed to the restoration of the work: Della Robbia: Sculpting With Color in Renaissance Florence, Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, to Dec. 4; National Gallery of Art, Washington, Feb. 4 to June 4, 2017.

title: Gold Medal Recipes
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Those Poststorm Spectacular Sunsets, Explained
description: Q. Why does a spectacular sunset so often follow a late-afternoon thunderstorm?

title: Painted Dinnerware From a Master Chef and Renaissance Man
description: Not only has the chef Jacques Ppin mastered skillet and stove, but he also has a way with paint and brush. His whimsical, often clever paintings of chickens and vegetables now decorate a line of ceramic dinnerware, kitchen and serving utensils, dish towels and accessories. The chickens he paints look harried, but consider whats next for them: Jacques Ppin Collection, $7 to $499, Sur La Table stores, surlatable.com.

title: Deciphering the English Language
description: To the Editor:

title: A Restaurant With a Terrace Off the Saks Shoe Department
description: Theres a terrace on the eighth floor of the Saks Fifth Avenue store with a classic balustrade and sweeping views of Fifth Avenue and Rockefeller Center. It has been fixed up and is open to the public for the first time, as a seasonal extension of the stores Caf SFA restaurant, just outside the shoe department. The views are stunning; the menu is simple: hummus, spring rolls, a lobster roll or a chicken sandwich, with wine, cocktails, beer and iced tea: The Terrace, Saks Fifth Avenue, eighth floor, 212-940-4080, cafesfa.com.

title: Questioning Authors Revisionism
description: To the Editor:

title: From the Halal Street Carts, That White Sauce Drizzled on Everything
description: The condiment of choice for chicken or meat at halal street carts is a thick drizzle thats simply called white sauce. Jamal Rasoully, whose parents fled Afghanistan about 30 years ago and opened a restaurant in New York, said that they made such a sauce based on an old Pashtun recipe. Now, Mr. Rasoully has bottled the condiment, calling it Spin Sauce. The traditional sauce is yogurt-based, but this one has mayonnaise written all over it and certainly delivers all-purpose potential. Theres a spicier version and a fierce cayenne hot sauce, too: Spin Sauce, $11.99 for three 12-ounce bottles, spinsauce.com.

title: Israel and Free Press Debated
description: To the Editor:

title: Evan McMullin, Anti-Trump Republican, Mounts Independent Presidential Bid
description: Evan McMullin, a former C.I.A. official and a Republican who passionately opposes Donald J. Trump, announced Monday that he would run for president as an independent candidate.

title: What $100 Can Buy, State by State
description: Spend enough time traveling around the United States and youre bound to notice a dramatic variation in what a dollar can buy.

title: Cured Roe From Gray Mullet Caught in the Gulf of Mexico
description: The delicacy bottarga is cured roe, usually from fish like mullet. In thin slices or grated, its used to season and bring umami to pasta and other dishes. Most bottarga is a fishermans afterthought, coming from parts of the catch that otherwise may be discarded. But Marc Slakmon, who learned to make it from his Tunisian grandmothers, has teamed up with a Florida fisherman who is catching gray mullet in the Gulf of Mexico. Their company, DellIsola Foods, produces Bottarga DellIsola, and chefs are praising its quality. It is rich, briny and pleasantly funky with an excellent consistency for slicing, shaving or grating: Bottarga DellIsola, $32 to $118 whole, depending on the size; $25 for a two-ounce jar of grated; bottargadellisola.com.

title: Medicine and Preventing War
description: To the Editor:

title: Harry Potter Films to Be Shown on Syfy and USA Network
description: Harry Potter is coming to NBCs cable stations.

title: For Fall, a Strange Harmony of Clashing Prints
description: The season brings a study in contrasts with stripes, plaids, florals  and everything in between.

title: 5 Best in Show Winners From the American Cheese Society
description: At the recent annual meeting of the American Cheese Society in Des Moines, five best-in-show winners were named. First place went to Little Mountain, a mild yet complex Swiss-style Alpine cheese from the Roelli Cheese Company in Shullsburg, Wis. Second was a tie: St. Malachi Reserve, another Alpine cheese, with deep, almost caramel notes from the Farm at Doe Run in Coatesville, Pa., and Buff Blue, a deliciously buttery water-buffalo-milk blue cheese from Bleating Heart Cheese in Tomales, Calif. In third place was another tie, this one between Greensward, a silky, intense Vacherin-style cheese made by the Cellars at Jasper Hill and cave-finished by Murrays Cheese in New York, and Jeffs Select Gouda, a well-made classic from the Caves of Faribault in Faribault, Minn.: roellicheese.com, facebook.com/thefarmatdoerun, bleatingheart.com, murrayscheese.com, faribaultdairy.com.

title: The Science of Humming to Draw Snails From Their Shells
description: People who grew up in coastal New England know this trick: To coax a periwinkle snail out of its shell, hum to it.

title: 1891: Bank of England Reassures
description: The Governor of the Bank of England, Sir William Lidderdale, has consented to make a statement to the public through the Herald, in consequence of the alarming stories in America and on the Continent, to the effect that a general financial crash is near at hand, and that the British banks are afraid to let the full situation be known, for fear it would precipitate a panic throughout the world.

title: Olympic Strategies, Part 1
description: The 2016 Rio Olympics have begun, unleashingHungarian swimmer Katinka Hosszu, American shooter Ginny Thrasher, and a whole pack of Brazilian gymnasts. Ive enjoyed the Times coverage, including theInteractive Stories series and the SMS experiment. It was alsoa nice surpriseto findKaren Crousesstory aboutBruce Gemmell, an old college teammate of mine and current coach of swimmerKatie Ledecky. Ive spent as much time immersed in water as enveloped by math problems, and its good to see so many friends andfast swims down in Rio. (Well done with the flag, MP!)

title: DJ Khaled Finds the Key to a No. 1 Album
description: Drake helped to dethrone himself on the Billboard album chart this week: DJ Khaleds Major Key (We the Best/Epic Records), which features Drake on its current hit single, For Free, reached No. 1 on the strength of 59,000 all-digital albums sold and 42 million streams, according to Nielsen Music data.

title: Brooklyn Bridge, the Times Square in the Sky, May Get an Expansion
description: Peter Cardillo cannot lose himself in the panoramic views on his walks home across the Brooklyn Bridge from Wall Street. He is too busy trying to stay in one piece.

title: Bride Is Walked Down Aisle by the Man Who Got Her Fathers Donated Heart
description: Its a bittersweet wedding story a decade in the making: Nearly 10 years after Jeni Stepiens father was killed, the man who received her fathers donated heart traveled from New Jersey to Pennsylvania to walk her down the aisle.

title: Bespoke This, Bespoke That. Enough Already.
description: Last summer, the director Paul Riccio made a satirical video short about a groundbreaking new product referred to as bespoke water.

title: Pretty Girls Are Supposed to Smile
description: There is no one who has not smiled at least once, writes Marianne LaFrance, a Yale University psychology professor, in her 2011 book Lip Service: Smiles in Life, Death, Trust, Lies, Work, Memory, Sex and Politics. Her book explores how smiling unifies us. Like breath, the smile is universal. We smile to connect, to forgive, to love. A smile is beauty, human.

title: Delta Malfunction on Land Keeps a Fleet of Planes From the Sky
description: Delta Air Lines is working to reset its operations on Tuesday morning, after a power failure grounded flights and led to cancellations and delays a day earlier. As of 12:30 p.m. Eastern time, Delta had canceled more than 500 flights scheduled for Tuesday.

title: Jeffrey Eisenach: Tech Industry Consultant and Think Tank Scholar
description: Scholar, consultant, expert witness  Jeffrey A. Eisenach has worn all these hats while playing a leading role in the debate over telecommunications policy in the United States. Here is a look at the potential conflicts that this situation creates for Mr. Eiensach, a scholar at the American Enterprise Institute.

title: States Vie to Shield the Wealth of the 1 Percent
description: LAS VEGAS  Steven J. Oshins, a Nevada lawyer who specializes in estate planning, has never met the wealthy software entrepreneur Dan Kloiber, but he is nonetheless intensely interested in Mr. Kloibers contentious divorce.

title: Think Tank Scholar or Corporate Consultant? It Depends on the Day
description: WASHINGTON  Over the many months that officials in Washington debated sweeping new regulations for internet providers, Jeffrey A. Eisenach, a scholar at the conservative American Enterprise Institute, was hard to miss.

title: What You Should Watch: Iris and Halt and Catch Fire
description: Welcome to Watching, The New York Timess what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. You can browse previous guides here, and to receive recommendations straight to your inbox, sign up here. Stay tuned for our coming website.

title: A Vote for Change in South Africa
description: In municipal elections last Wednesday, South African voters handed the African National Congress, the party of Nelson Mandela, its worst setback since the end of apartheid in 1994. The vote could presage major political change when South Africans go to the polls in national elections in 2019.

title: Soccer Gold? At This Point, Brazil Might Settle for a Goal
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  They love basketball and volleyball in Brazil. Formula One racing and martial arts have produced many of the countrys sports heroes.

title: Goldman Sachss Fight to Avoid Paying Employees Legal Fees
description: We know that paying for a lawyer can be an expensive proposition. The New York Times reported recently that a Turkish gold trader, Reza Zarrab, has hired a veritable whos who of white-collar defense firms to defend him against charges of violating United States sanctions laws in dealings with businesses in Iran. Costs could rise to the tens of millions of dollars if the case goes to trial.

title: Ahmed Mohamed, Boy Handcuffed for Making Clock, Is Suing

title: Mike Pence Should Get Donald Trump to Withdraw
description: For the past year, every effort by Republican leaders to topple Donald J. Trump has met with embarrassing failure. Yet, according to published reports, jittery insiders have been considering still other ways of detaching the Trump brand from the party of Lincoln. The best option is one that can avoid an ugly, and likely futile, confrontation and help both Mr. Trump and his party save face. All eyes must now turn to his running mate, Mike Pence, to do what must be done.

title: A Letter From G.O.P. National Security Officials Opposing Donald Trump
description: Dozens of the nations most senior Republican national security officials, many of them former top aides or cabinet members for President George W. Bush, have signed a letter saying they will not vote for Mr. Trump, the Republican nominee.

title: 50 G.O.P. Officials Warn Donald Trump Would Put Nations Security at Risk
description: Fifty of the nations most senior Republican national security officials, many of them former top aides or cabinet members for President George W. Bush, have signed a letter declaring that Donald J. Trump lacks the character, values and experience to be president and would put at risk our countrys national security and well-being.

title: Times Insider Photo Challenge: Caption This!
description: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. Occasionally we have some fun.

title: Brand to Know: Traditional Soap, Made Modern
description: A Korean body scrub is a spa experience not easily forgotten  the intensely exfoliating rubdown requires a certain amount of grit and courage. For the Toronto native Karen Kim, 36, the memory of her Korean grandmother buffing her body when she was 5 years old left a lasting impression: The vigor and determination! she says of the sloughing technique. It was painful but effective. Years later, when she was in her 20s, Kim traveled to Seok Mo Do, a fishing island off the coast of South Korea, with her mother and five aunts. Most days revolved around trips to the public baths and cleansing rituals. Every morning, wed take our sponges and buckets, and sit in the bath all day, she says. My Korean isnt very good, so it was hard to communicate, but this was an intimate bonding moment.

title: Stranded Syrians Receive Aid by Crane
description: Aid groups used cranes to drop supplies to thousands stranded at Jordans northern border. Nearly 75,000 Syrians are camped in the desert there, in deteriorating conditions, after the border closed.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Review: A Musical Tale of the Cosmos, Birth and Death
description: Within the life span of our galaxy, the premiere of Paola Prestinis The Hubble Cantata at the Prospect Park Bandshell on Saturday night barely registers as a blip. And yet its 50 minutes of ponderous texts set to fluffy nebulae of diatonic music sometimes felt endless.

title: Review: Powerhouse Lifts Veil on Secretive Hollywood Agency
description: With the fall of the studio system, when actors labored under long-term employment contracts, came the rise of the talent agents, those mysterious professionals whose job is to procure employment for artists. The mystery extends from what agents actually do to the economics of the agencies where they work, as all the major industry players are private and notoriously secretive. In Powerhouse: The Untold Story of Hollywoods Creative Artists Agency, James Andrew Miller has taken on the formidable task of lifting the veil on the sector.

title: Review: A Spirit of Charity Probes Struggle of Public Hospitals
description: All hospitals deliver an endless loop of drama. In Americas great public hospitals, the show is nothing short of operatic.

title: Monkeys That Smile the Way We Do
description: Need a laugh? Get online and take a look at videos of baby Japanese macaques smiling as they sleep.

title: Making the Harpsichord Modern Again
description: Playing the harpsichord is my best expression of me liking my life, said Mahan Esfahani, 32, sipping peppermint tea at a restaurant near Lincoln Center before his stimulating late-night appearance at the Mostly Mozart Festival on Friday. I am a harpsichordist because I have to make a living, but if anything its a tool to look at everything else.

title: A Brain Surgeons Legacy Through a Grandsons Eyes
description: As a boy growing up in Massachusetts, Luke Dittrich revered his grandfather, a brain surgeon whose home was full of exotic instruments. Later, he learned that he was not only a prominent doctor but had played a significant role in modern medical history.

title: The Opening Ceremony Founders on the Importance of 1993
description: The Opening Ceremony founders Humberto Leon and Carol Lim agree that 1993 was a formative year. For one, they both graduated from suburban Los Angeles high schools. That summer was pivotal, Lim says. I could really enjoy myself because Id gotten into college, so I backpacked through Europe for four months. And that fall, they enrolled at University of California, Berkeley, where they met and, Leon recalls, quickly bonded over their shared affinity for polyester outfits. At the time, we looked to magazines and what our favorite actors and musicians were wearing, he remembers. As an 18-year-old kid, youre trying to emulate the people you admire. In the pre-internet era, the pair had to conduct nondigital research, as Lim calls it  queuing for the latest issue of Interview or the Face, or scrutinizing 10,000 Maniacs music videos.

title: Review: War Porn Widens the Field of Vision About the Costs in Iraq
description: In a controversial essay published in the Los Angeles Review of Books in 2015, Roy Scranton, a United States Army veteran who served in Iraq, argued that our perception of war has been warped by modern war literatures preoccupation with what he called the trauma hero myth.

title: Putin and Erdogan, Both Isolated, Reach Out to Each Other
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and his Turkish counterpart, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, are expected to reconsider their dispute over Syria at a meeting on Tuesday in St. Petersburg, with both leaders interested in a public display of affection to show the West that strained ties have not left them isolated.

title: An Alternative Form of Mental Health Care Gains a Foothold
description: HOLYOKE, Mass.  Some of the voices inside Caroline Whites head have been a lifelong comfort, as protective as a favorite aunt. It was the others  youre nothing, theyre out to get you, to kill you  that led her down a rabbit hole of failed treatments and over a decade of hospitalizations, therapy and medications, all aimed at silencing those internal threats.

title: Swimming Geek/Sports Reporter Sizes Up the Scene at the Olympic Pool in Rio
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, the deputy sports editor Jay Schreiber introduces readers to the scene inside the Olympic pool on the eve of swimming competitions.

title: Review: A Mostly Mozart Milestone, and an Immersive Lineup
description: This summer, in celebration of its 50th anniversary, the Mostly Mozart Festival has been offering game audience members opportunities for immersion experiences: single evenings with three very contrasting programs in different locations at Lincoln Center. The latest one was on Saturday.

title: Johnny Nicholson, Whose Midtown Cafe Drew the New Bohemians, Dies at 99
description: Johnny Nicholson, whose tiny Midtown Manhattan restaurant, the Caf Nicholson, served as a gathering place for the artists and celebrities known as the New Bohemians in the 1950s and 60s, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 99.

title: A Big Week for Cats on Broadway
description: Audiences made a beeline for felines last week, as the Broadway revival of the musical Cats had its biggest week at the box office since performances started in mid-July.

title: Review: The Gently Funny Newtons Cradle at New York Musical Festival
description: The student sitting to my left at Thursday afternoons performance of Newtons Cradle had never been to the New York Musical Festival before. At intermission, as the crowd socialized around us, she turned to me and asked, Does everyone know each other?

title: On the London Stage, Love Doesnt Just Hurt, It Kills
description: LONDON  A partial list of the onstage casualties amassed during a mere three days of theatergoing here: attempted suicides: four; successful suicides: five; accidental death by reckless use of a firearm: one; death by natural causes, hastened by the cruelty of a spouse: one; loss of trust in others: immense and incalculable; happy endings: one, and that one highly suspect.

title: Exhibition to Celebrate Harry Potter Series Turning 20
description: LONDON  You could pop in after youve seen the children off on the Hogwarts Express.

title: A Visual History of Which Countries Have Dominated the Summer Olympics
description: The account of which countries have dominated the Summer Olympics is also a snapshot of modern history.

title: Airstrikes Barely Holding Off Taliban in Helmand, Afghan Officials Say
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan security forces are struggling to head off an intensified Taliban offensive in Helmand Province in recent weeks, heavily relying on American airstrikes as the insurgents have again tightened the noose around Lashkar Gah, the provincial capital, according to officials and residents.

title: The Wonderfully Sleazy 1970s Fashion of Ben Cobb
description: Wherever mens fashion goes, Ben Cobb is there. This summer, in London, Milan, Paris and New York, there he was, seated in the front row at almost every runway show. And when hes on the street outside the venues, the street-style photographers cant resist taking his picture.

title: TIAA-EverBank Deal Offers a Lesson on Acquisitions
description: An unorthodox American bank deal has provided the industry with a timely reminder on mergers and acquisitions. TIAA, the giant pension fund, is acquiring EverBank, a small bank that does business primarily online, for $2.5 billion.

title: Kohei Uchimura Leads Japan to Gymnastics Gold, Dethroning China
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Japan returned to the top of the mens gymnastics world, beating Russia and China in the team event at the Olympics.

title: Why Usher Shaves His Sneakers (and 4 Other Style Insights)
description: Although he has had a career punctuated by multiplatinum album sales and Grammys, Usher Raymond IV, 37, favors an understated style. The musician, actor and entrepreneur, who plays Sugar Ray Leonard in the boxing film Hands of Stone, opening Aug. 26, took some time during a recent stop in New York to discuss his closet favorites and why he dreams of designing the perfect dance shoe.

title: Donald Trump, Delta Air Lines, Michael Phelps: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Artist Accused of Disowning a Painting Testifies
description: CHICAGO  The artist Peter Doig took the stand here Monday in an odd federal court case in which the owner of a landscape painting is accusing Mr. Doig of falsely denying that he created the work while a young man in Canada.

title: Sorry, Ms. Jackson: Youre Underrated. Control at 30
description: The standard for planet-stopping artistic statements in pop music is now so high that you need a pilots license to compete with the Beyoncs, Kanyes and Kendricks of the world. But when Janet Jackson craved ascent, she didnt go to flight school. She went to Flyte Tyme. That was the Minneapolis production company Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis operated and where the three came up with Control, Ms. Jacksons third record and the first of their subtly strange, sonically complex thematic carnivals. The album turned 30 in February, peaked in popularity right about this time that year (hitting No. 1 in July) and still sounds today as much like 1986 as it does 2056. Some producers make hooks. These three made wedgies.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Louis Vuitton and Christian Dior Follow the Scent of Opportunity
description: Perfume today has lost its soul. It is far too mass and too marketed, lacking in personality.

title: Fact-Checking Donald Trumps Economic Speech
description: WASHINGTON  In laying out his economic platform on Monday, Donald J. Trump made several assertions that glossed over the complexities of the domestic and international economy. Here are a few we checked out.

title: Epic Records Whips Up Hit Album Out of Thin Air (and Online Streams)
description: You technically cant buy the digital compilation album from Epic Records featuring hits by French Montana and DJ Khaled that has been a steady presence on the Billboard chart this summer. In fact, the album has sold a total of zero copies since its quiet release seven weeks ago.

title: Sexual Harassment Suit Against Roger Ailes Stays in New Jersey
description: Lawyers for the former Fox News chairman Roger Ailes have agreed to keep the sexual harassment lawsuit brought against him by the former anchor Gretchen Carlson in New Jersey, according to a court filing on Monday.

title: Colorado Activists Submit Petitions for Referendums on Fracking
description: In an effort to halt the advance of the oil industry in Colorado, environmental activists said they submitted enough signatures on Monday to place on Novembers ballot two initiatives aimed at severely limiting hydraulic fracturing.

title: New Photos Cast Doubt on Chinas Vow Not to Militarize Disputed Islands
description: When President Xi Jinping of China visited President Obama at the White House last September, he startled many with reassuring words about his intentions for the Spratly Islands, a contested area where the Chinese government has been piling dredged sand and concrete atop reefs for the past few years and building housing and runways on them.

title: Donald Trumps Economic Team Is Far From Typical
description: Donald Trump, laying out his economic plan on Monday in Detroit, said that the nation must stop relying on the tired voices of the past. In what would seem to be yet another jab at Hillary Clinton, he added, We cant fix a rigged system by relying on the people who rigged it in the first place.

title: A Difficult Winter Cellphone Call
description: Dear Diary:

title: Legislators Take Aim at New Jersey Student Loan Programs Tough Tactics
description: Almost a dozen people with harrowing experiences with New Jerseys controversial student loan program testified on Monday before state lawmakers, detailing its aggressive collection tactics and onerous terms that some said had ruined them financially.

title: Mr. Trumps Losing Economic Game Plan
description: Donald Trump said on Monday that he wanted to usher in economic renewal, but most of his proposals would hurt the economy, rack up huge deficits, accelerate climate change and leave the country isolated from the world.

title: Brooklyn Rapper, Charged in Shooting, Sues Club and Promoter
description: Troy Ave, the Brooklyn rapper charged with attempted murder after a shooting at a rap concert in which he was also wounded, is now suing the Manhattan club where the incident occurred, saying security was lax there.

title: Sudden Rainfall Left Little Time to Flee Mudslides in Mexico
description: XALTEPEC, Mexico  When the rain came harder than anyone in this mountain village could remember, Tefila Prez Francisco and her relatives gathered on the second floor of her fathers house, thinking they would be safe there. It was late Saturday night and the dirt roads outside had turned into streams.

title: Michael Jordan Endows a Hall in African American Museum Gallery
description: Michael Jordan is donating $5 million, and a basketball jersey from the 1996 N.B.A. Finals, to the Smithsonians new National Museum of African American History and Culture, the museum said Monday.

title: Patch of Miami Is Ground Zero for the Zika Virus
description: Around July 4, a patient entered an emergency room in Miami-Dade County with a fever, a rash and joint pain  three of the four classic symptoms of the Zika virus. By this point, there had already been about 1,600 other Zika cases in the continental United States, but it soon became clear that this one was different.

title: Copacabanas Natural Sand Is Just Right for Olympic Beach Volleyball
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  It was midmorning on Copacabana Beach, six months before the Olympics, and Brazils most famous volleyball player, Giovane Gvio, stepped barefoot onto the sand.

title: Judge Reopens Complaint Against Argentine Ex-President in 1994 Bombing
description: BUENOS AIRES  A federal judge in Argentina has ordered the reopening of a criminal complaint against former President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner in which she had been accused of conspiring to derail an investigation into the bombing of a Jewish center here in 1994 in which 85 people were killed.

title: With a Trick Play, U.S. Womens Field Hockey Pulls Off a Second Upset
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Corners in field hockey are similar to corner kicks in soccer but certainly more elaborate and perhaps more interesting.

title: Rodriguezs Exit: A Chance for Boston Fans to Deliver a Final Verdict
description: When Mariano Rivera bade farewell to Fenway Park, he was saluted with a video montage and the Boston Cello Quartets rendition of Enter Sandman, the song that had long accompanied his entrance from the bullpen.

title: Why, in One Case, the de Blasio Administration Opposes Affordable Housing
description: A small parking lot between 17th and 18th Streets, just off Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan, has become an unlikely focal point in a battle over the future of Mayor Bill de Blasios affordable housing plan.

title: What Generals Keep Up Their Sleevies
description: TUESDAY  No, that headline is not a TYPO. Its a clue from todays puzzle that made me snort because it was such an unexpected bit of silliness, so Im commemorating it.

title: Susan Collins of Maine Says She Will Not Vote for Donald Trump
description: Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, announced Monday that she would not vote for Donald J. Trump in the presidential election, dealing another blow to Mr. Trump as he tries to unite his party and win more support from women.

title: Teacher Out at Fordham Prep After School Says 84 Sexual Abuse Claim Is Credible
description: The gathering, in June 1984, was like many others involving recent graduates of Fordham Preparatory School, a Jesuit all-boys secondary school in the Bronx. It took place at a home in Westchester County, where many of Fordhams students lived. Most of those at the party drank and several ended up spending the night, according to a former Fordham Prep student, Michael Meenan.

title: Parents of 2 Americans Killed in Benghazi Attack Sue Hillary Clinton
description: The parents of two Americans killed in the 2012 attack on a United States diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya, filed a lawsuit on Monday against Hillary Clinton, saying that her extreme carelessness in handling confidential and classified information while secretary of state contributed to the conditions that led to their sons deaths.

title: UnREAL Season 2 Finale: Trust Me
description: A show as meta as UnREAL faces the problem that often confronts satire: if you skewer a genre well enough, you might eventually become it. This season has struggled, partly by aiming for network-drama polish rather than self-aware pulp. Everlasting is a show about people seeking triumph amid inescapable falsity; everything in UnREAL echoes that, with an edge. Adding tertiary love interests and subplots just provided the season with stumbling blocks. This finale, more than anything, needed to put what mattered  Rachel, Quinn, behind-the-scenes satire, occasional heartbreak  back in the center and trust it to hold.

title: American Lilly King Makes Statement With Olympic Record in 100-Meter Breaststroke
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  A movement that has been gathering steam at the Olympic Aquatics Stadium was ready for its hashtag on Monday night. The Clean Athletes Matter brigade found a ready, able and ardent leader: Lilly King of the United States, who entered the Rio Games with the top time in the world in the womens 100-meter breaststroke.

title: Bryan Clauson, Champion Sprint Car Racer, Dies at 27 After Crash
description: Bryan Clauson, who raced practically anything with four wheels but was most accomplished as a champion driver of light, powerful cars on treacherous dirt tracks, died Sunday in Lincoln, Neb., after having been severely injured in a crash the night before. He was 27.

title: The Landslide Odds
description: We explore whether Hillary Clinton, the most distrusted Democratic presidential nominee in a generation, could be heading for an old-fashioned, legitimate landslide. Our guests: Newt Gingrich, Amy Chozick and Nate Cohn.

title: Brazils First Gold Medal of Rio Olympics Comes in Judo
U.S. Mortality Rate Declines, and Researchers Breathe a Sigh of Relief
description: WASHINGTON  The death rate in the United States declined in the first quarter of this year, preliminary data show, a return to normal for a crucial health measure that showed a rare increase in 2015.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | captious
description: captious  \kap-shs\  adjective

title: Taran Killam and Jay Pharoah Leaving Saturday Night Live
description: As it heads into its 42nd season and an autumn that is teeming with potential for political satire, Saturday Night Live is undergoing some visible changes and shedding three performers from its ensemble.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: We are not used to this in table tennis. It was just weird.

title: U.S. Asks Judge to Deny Turkish Gold Traders Motion to Dismiss Charges
description: United States prosecutors asked a federal judge in New York on Monday to deny a motion by a Turkish gold trader to dismiss charges that he conspired to violate the United States sanctions on Iran.

title: Another Big Day in Brazil
description: The Rio Olympics continued Monday with gymnastics, water polo and fencing among the featured sports. Athletes also competed on Guanabara Bay in sailing and wind surfing.

title: Corrections: August 9, 2016
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Whats on TV Tuesday: The Rams in Hard Knocks and U.S. Swimmers at the Rio Olympics
description: The Rams return to Los Angeles  and go Hollywood  in the latest installment of HBO Sportss Hard Knocks. The swimmers Michael Phelps and Katie Ledecky try to rack up the golds at the Rio Olympics. And three summery films by French directors heat things up.

title: Erroll Garner Recordings Unearthed for a New Album
description: Last fall the pianist Erroll Garner achieved a rare posthumous distinction when The Complete Concert by the Sea entered the Billboard Jazz Albums chart at No. 1. A restored and expanded version of Concert by the Sea  the 1956 release that solidified Garners popular image, and one of the best-selling jazz albums in history  it featured 11 previously unissued tracks and a greatly improved sound mix in a three-CD boxed set.

title: Cancer-Drug Ads vs. Cancer-Drug Reality
description: TOWSON, Md.  Two days into a long-dreamed-of family vacation to Italy in August 2013, my wife, Ronna, became nauseated, unusually tired and short of breath. One of the great non-complainers in American history, she insisted that it was no big deal and valiantly tried to join in on various outings in the Italian countryside. But, after a few increasingly difficult days, even Ronna knew that it was time to go to the emergency room.

title: What the Military Owes Rape Survivors Like My Daughter
description: LA CROSSE, Wis.  When my daughter, Carri Leigh Goodwin, joined the Marine Corps in July 2007, she was a shy, quiet 18-year-old who loved reading and writing poetry. She joined the Marines to make me proud  Im a former Marine  and to her surprise, she turned out to be good with a gun.

title: Time to Get Serious With South Sudan
description: Since the founding of the nation of South Sudan five years ago, its citizens have gone from a brief moment of exhilaration and promise to the cruel reality of tribal violence, depredation and despair. Their leaders have failed them, and so has the United Nations Security Council, which is once again scrambling for a solution to end rampant killing and other abuses. One move the Council could make immediately is to impose a long-overdue embargo on arms shipments, especially to the government forces that have been largely responsible for the bloodshed.

title: The Great Affluence Fallacy
description: In 18th-century America, colonial society and Native American society sat side by side. The former was buddingly commercial; the latter was communal and tribal. As time went by, the settlers from Europe noticed something: No Indians were defecting to join colonial society, but many whites were defecting to live in the Native American one.

title: Ichiros Glory, and the End of A-Rod
description: The two ballplayers started as major leaguers in Seattle, each carrying the glow of a future Hall of Famer  that mix of confidence and ambition and off-the-charts talent. On Sunday, in the twilights of long careers, they reached vastly different milestones.

title: Gary Johnson to the Rescue
description: Gary Johnson knows a thing or two about virtual reality.

title: What Is With Those Crowds at Trump Rallies?
Obamacare Appears to Be Making People Healthier
description: Obamacare has provided health insurance to some 20 million people. But are they any better off?

title: Picking Tobacco Under an Unforgiving Sun in Mexico
description: Csar Rodrguez has been documenting the plight of Huichol tobacco workers in Mexico, who have toiled for years exposed to the elements and chemicals.

title: Picture Prompt | In the Park
description: Whats the best thing youve ever seen or done in a public park?

title: Picture Prompt | Simone Biles
description: Simone Biles is the best gymnast in the world. In fact, many say she is the best in history.

title: Article of the Day | Emperor Akihito of Japan Raises Possibility of Leaving Throne
description: Article: Emperor Akihito of Japan Raises Possibility of Leaving Throne

title: Donors for Bush, Kasich and Christie Are Turning to Clinton More Than to Trump
description: People who donated to establishment Republican candidates in the primary season are more likely to give money to Hillary Clinton than to Donald J. Trump.

title: Picking Tobacco Under an Unforgiving Sun in Mexico
description: Leer en Espaol.

title: In Japan, an Emperor Constrained by History and a National Identity Crisis
description: The hint by Emperor Akihito of Japan that he would like to abdicate challenges something bigger than the laws requiring him to serve until his death and questions over succession.

title: They Will Kill Us: Afghan Translators Plead for Delayed U.S. Visas
description: WASHINGTON  Zar Mohammad Stanikzai remembers the promise made to him when he became a translator supporting the United States military in 2012: Help us, and we will keep you safe. Four years later, his fear of Taliban reprisals has made him a prisoner in his Afghan home, he said, and he is still waiting for the Americans to honor their commitment.

title: Finding Good Pain Treatment Is Hard. If Youre Not White, Its Even Harder.
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  Roslyn Lewis was at work at a dollar store here, pushing a heavy cart of dog food, when something popped in her back: an explosion of pain. At the emergency room the next day, doctors gave her Motrin and sent her home.

title: Mormons Distaste for Donald Trump Puts Utah Up for Grabs
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Donald J. Trump has vowed to turn blue states red in November, but as he continues to rattle Republicans with his combative style and provocative proposals, voters in some of the countrys most conservative strongholds are considering a radical idea: supporting Hillary Clinton.

title: Gymnastics Team Final: Simone Biles and the U.S. Women Go for Gold
description: In womens gymnastics, there is a consensus about the Olympic team event: It is a battle for second place between China and Russia.

title: Mexicos Richest Man Confronts a New Foe: The State That Helped Make Him Rich
description: MEXICO CITY  All is not well in the kingdom of Carlos Slim.

title: In Still Here, Four Russian Friends Confront Middle Age in New York City
description: STILL HEREBy Lara Vapnyar310 pp. Hogarth. $26.

title: Teju Coles Essays Build Connections Between African and Western Art
description: KNOWN AND STRANGE THINGSEssaysBy Teju ColeIllustrated. 393 pp. Random House. Paper, $17.

title: Power, Ambition and Betrayal in Hollywood: James B. Stewart on Powerhouse
description: POWERHOUSEThe Untold Story of Hollywoods Creative Artists AgencyBy James Andrew Miller707 pp. Custom House/William Morrow. $32.50.

title: Need a Babysitter? Dont Count On Grandma
description: Susan Glickman, a second-grade teacher, was among the first of her friends to be a grandparent. At 56, Ms. Glickman, of East Rockaway, N.Y., said she and her husband are thrilled about their daughters 8-month-old, Lilah, who lives less than an hour away, in Manhattan.

title: Delta Air Lines, Quetta, Olympic Games: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Trumps Economic Agenda and the Team Behind It
description: Donald J. Trump has laid out his economic vision, and it included deep tax cuts for the wealthy, tearing up climate change agreements and abandoning trade deals. He insisted, We cant fix a rigged system by relying on the people who rigged it in the first place, highlighting the fine line that he has to tread between between being anti-elite and yet absolutely elite. Its tough to be seen as a successful billionaire businessman who is also an outsider trying to work for the little guy.

title: One Secret to Cutting Spending: Wait 72 Hours Before You Buy
description: Im going to assume for a minute that youre one of the millions of people who have a recurrently frustrating relationship with spending. It probably starts with a commitment to sticking to your budget, and you do for a few days. Then, despite your resolve, you break down, pull out the credit card and do something that you promised you wouldnt. You wake up in the morning ashamed and resolve never to do it again.

title: Speculation Ends: Date and Venue Set for World Chess Championship in New York
description: Back in February, the company that runs the World Chess Championship announced some big news: the tournament would return to New York City this fall, for the first time in more than two decades. The company promised to reveal a venue shortly.

title: New York Today: The Greenest Street
description: Updated, 9:02 a.m.

title: A Seismic Shock for Jacob Zuma
description: CAPE TOWN  Jesus is back! This tweet was widely shared in South Africa as voters in last weeks local government elections delivered a body blow to the ruling African National Congress party.

title: Paul Ryan Expected to Easily Defeat Primary Opponent, Despite Ugly Fight
description: Memo to those wondering if Speaker Paul D. Ryan could be the next politician on the precipice of an embarrassing primary defeat to a no-name challenger: Dont bet on it.

title: These Days of Rage
description: LONDON  On July 14, Bastille Day, in Nice, France, 85 people died after being mowed down on the promenade by a man driving a truck. Four days later, a 17-year-old man attacked passengers with an ax on a train near Wrzburg, Germany. Four days after that, an 18-year-old man shot dead nine people in a Munich shopping mall.

title: Heres Lucy! Scary Statue Is Replaced With One That Looks Like Her
description: It was the Lucy that nobody loved.

title: When Your Child Is the Travel Agent
description: Last February, when my sister-in-law, Katrina, was struggling to put together a six-person, three-generation family trip for spring break, she turned to a nontraditional travel agent: Leo Kugel of Silver Spring, Md.

title: London Bookstores Go Rogue as No Wi-Fi Zones
description: What do literary tourists look for when they visit the British Isles? Often its the quaint, old-fashioned bookshops that provide the perfect excuse to browse uninterrupted and to disconnect from the world. Until recently, the trend for barista-made coffee and high-speed Wi-Fi was considered by some in the citys bookish crowd to be ruining Londons centuries-old tradition of disconnected browsing.

title: Glamping Adds a Touch of Luxe to the National Parks
description: The notion of nodding off under the stars to the crackle of a fire in the shadow of ancient ponderosa pines sounds dreamy. Heres the catch. Though I love communing with nature, I detest discomfort. This includes interacting with moist soil and insects as well as partaking in tiresome camp chores like tent pitching, fire making, food schlepping and foraging for makeshift, leave-no-trace toilets.

title: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 6 | On N.B.A. to Move All-Star Game From North Carolina
description: Every week this contest gets harder to judge and harder to win, as more and more students post picks to fulfill summer reading assignments before the start of school.

title: Summer 2016 News Quiz | June 7-Sept. 5, 2016
description: The 13 weeks since our last News Quiz have produced dramatic headlines around the globe, from the Brexit decision to the Republican and Democratic National Conventions to the Olympics in Rio de Janeiro  as well, sadly, as a rash of massacres so relentless that The Times published a health piece in July on what a constant cycle of violent news is doing to us.

title: Saudi-Led Coalition Resumes Bombing of Yemeni Capital After Talks Collapse
description: SANA, Yemen  The military coalition led by Saudi Arabia significantly stepped up its bombing campaign in Yemen on Tuesday, striking the capital, Sana, and killing 21 people across the country, most of them civilians, according to medical and security officials in three provinces.

title: Introducing The Run-Up, Our New Election Podcast
description: Its three months until Election Day. To guide you through this final, delirious phase of the presidential campaign, The New York Times is drawing on our all-star team of reporters, columnists, magazine writers and analysts to create a new podcast. Its called The Run-Up.

title: 1916: A School for War Victims
description: PARIS  M. Justin Godart, Under-Secretary of State for the Military Health Service, inaugurated yesterday afternoon [Aug. 8] at the Maison-Blanche, Neuilly-sur-Marne, a new institution for re-educating maimed soldiers. Its organization is due to the initiative of the Union des Colonies Etrangres en France, which comprises eighteen groups of friendly foreign colonies. The school is divided into two sections, one for teaching French, English, book-keeping, shorthand, typewriting, etc., and the other for manual labor, with workrooms devoted to a large variety of trades and occupations.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Aug. 10, 1916

title: Whos Got a Carrier to Rival the U.S. Navys? (Hint: Not Russia.)
description: An aircraft carrier can be a very handy tool, especially when trouble flares up far from a friendly military base. Just ask the Pentagon, which has 10 big Nimitz-class supercarriers that it uses around the world to protect air and sea lanes and to mount airstrikes. Theres generally at least one of them stationed near the Middle East at all times.

title: The Girl From Ipanema Goes Walking Again, With Gisele Bndchens Help
description: For about a week in 1964, a bossa nova tune was bigger than songs by the Beatles.

title: Facebook Blocks Ad Blockers, but It Strives to Make Ads More Relevant
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Digital ads pop up online so frequently and ubiquitously that many people are using software to block them.

title: M.I.T., N.Y.U. and Yale Are Sued Over Retirement Plan Fees
description: Three prominent universities were sued on Tuesday, accused of allowing their employees to be charged excessive fees on their retirement savings.

title: How the U.S. Crushed the Competition in the Womens Gymnastics Team Final
description: The American womens gymnastics team won the gold with 184.897 points,  an 8-point lead over second-best Russia.

title: Downtown St. Paul Makes Room for New Settlers
description: ST. PAUL  On a bluff overlooking the Mississippi River, where pioneers disembarked from steamships in the 1800s to settle the Northwest Territory, developers are transforming another piece of history.

title: Brazilians Speak Portuguese, but the Olympics Must Use French

title: Summer Intern Report: Prototyping an Improved Search Query With Machine Learning
description: I was thrilled when I was offered the summer internship for two specific reasons. First, it was with The New York Times and second, I was going to join the Search team. I was looking for an opportunity that intersected with my interests in information retrieval and machine learning. More importantly, I would have a chance to use what I had been learning in grad school.

title: Restoring Old Churches Inspires a New Philanthropy in Russia

title: 1966: Collusion in the Suez Crisis
description: LONDON  A British prime minister confirmed for the first time today [Aug. 9] what has long been alleged  that the evidence points to collusion between Britain, France and Israel during the Suez crisis ten years ago. In response to a question in Parliament, Harold Wilson said that far from the British entering the fight only to separate the Egyptians and Israelis, the whole thing was a put-up job. Mr. Wilsons comments this afternoon followed the recent disclosure by Christian Pineau that a secret agreement was reached prior to Suez among the three countries.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 10, 1966

The hard-hitting upstart has been making waves with her baseline game since she turned pro at 14 and has been hailed as the face of the next generation of American womens tennis.

And I realized something not too flattering about myself: Im feeling nostalgic for 2011 or so.

In this piece, the Times reporter Rukmini Callimachi recounts the first time  after four years of covering Al Qaeda and the Islamic State  that she met face to face with a former terrorist whose proof of identity and affiliation were solid enough that she could quote him in a story.

title: What Happened on Wall St. Ahead of the Crisis? We May Yet Find Out
description: The eighth anniversary of the 2008 financial crisis is almost upon us, making this as good a moment as any to take stock of how little we know still about the bad behavior and deception that occurred inside the big Wall Street banks that helped to cause it  and how little we may ever know.

Nathan Kalwicki and Will Cook also lost limbs in battle: Mr. Kalwicki in Afghanistan, when an Afghan soldier turned on his training corps; Mr. Cook in Iraq, after stepping on an improvised bomb at age 18.

title: In the Olympic Pool, Contempt for Drug Cheats Rises to the Surface

But that hope is fraying as a growing number of athletes are openly criticizing competitors who have a history of using performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Inside Queen Elizabeth IIs Wardrobe

title: The Slow-Game App Is the New Smoke Break
description: All around the world, millions of smartphone users are preparing for war. Pokmon Go has sent players scurrying outside their homes to hunt cartoon critters, chuck virtual balls at them, and then groom their captured characters into a digital army. Advance far enough in the game, and players are invited to join a Pokmon team and stage face-offs at designated gyms  basically, virtual forts  where battle-ready competitors descend to hold their phones with a white-knuckle grip, stare unblinkingly at the screen and tap furiously on one anothers Pokmon in a bid to seize control of the territory.

description: Collectors and artists gather at the Parrish Art Museums annual fund-raiser in Water Mill, N.Y.

title: Transporting the Dead: A Booming but Lightly Regulated Industry
description: Even when the dead bodies Zachary Smeltz lifts for a living are hefty, he makes sure to handle even the burliest corpse in a gentle manner, masking any exertion. Treat every case like thats your mom that youre transferring, is the motto Mr. Smeltz imparts on the staff of the mortuary transport business he owns that sends him all over New Jersey and Pennsylvania and to other locales, picking up bodies.

title: The Return of the Gothic Lip
description: Insensitive to red, a heartbreaking phrase, is technically a description of early black-and-white film, which converted the colors of blood and red lipstick to black. Elsa Lanchesters lips were painted redder than her auburn hair for 1935s The Bride of Frankenstein; the makeup artist on the film based her look on a 3,300-year-old bust of Nefertiti, who announced her power by blackening her eyes, reddening her lips and dyeing her nails with dark henna. But when Lanchester appeared on screen as the Bride  Shes alive!  her overdrawn mouth looked dark as hell: Et voil, the modern gothic lip was born. Robert Smith of the Cure, whose lipstick emphasized not the Cupids bow but the corners of his mouth, giving him the moue of a dissatisfied cannibal, was said to inspire the almost-black goth lip of the 1990s; he only, in fact, wore the 60s designer Mary Quants Crimson Scorcher. But what are facts when it comes to what we see? Color depends on perception, and our perception, so dependent on lighting, changes over the years the way light does over the course of a day. Sometimes were desensitized to red, and so to get a look as fresh as red lipstick used to give, we turn to shades that look more like ink.

title: Why Poets Can Make Better Search Engines
description: Daniel Nadler spends most of his waking hours running the technology start-up Kensho, which has become a darling of the financial industry, attracting big investments from Goldman Sachs and venture capitalists.

title: The Innkeepers Widow
description: Months after her husbands death in a freak ski accident, Mary Celeste Beall steps into a new role as the president of the Blackberry Farm resort.

title: A Widow Takes the Helm at Blackberry Farm
description: WALLAND, Tenn.  For someone who could ski as well as Sam Beall, his first run down a Colorado slope that February afternoon was supposed to be easy.

title: What Made Two Republican Women Back Hillary Clinton
description: This Republican is voting for Hillary Clinton, Jennifer Pierotti Lim proclaimed at the Democratic convention last month. Thats becoming a more common refrain lately, with high-profile Republicans like Meg Whitman throwing their support behind Mrs. Clinton. Ms. Lim, the founder of the volunteer group Republican Women for Hillary, and Meghan Milloy, the groups chair, spoke in a recent interview about where they agree with the Democratic nominee, where they disagree and what the Republican Party would have to do to win them back.

title: Rio Olympics: Diving Pool Turns Green, and U.S. Swimmers Find Gold
description: An unsettling thing happened at the Olympic diving pool on Tuesday: the water inexplicably turned green, just in time for the womens synchronized 10-meter platform diving competition.

title: Israel Accuses U.N. Worker of Aiding Hamas in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli prosecutors on Tuesday charged a Palestinian employee of the United Nations in the Gaza Strip with providing material assistance to Hamas, the Islamist group that controls the territory, including helping to build a jetty for its military wing.

title: A Warning for Dogs, and Their Best Friends, in Study of Fertility
description: For decades, generations of dogs have been bred, raised and trained as service animals for disabled people at a center in England: Labrador retrievers, golden retrievers, curly coat retrievers, Border collies and German shepherds. Scientists at the University of Nottingham realized that they had an ideal opportunity to study dog fertility  five types of purebreds, uniform conditions, one location, systematic record-keeping. So in 1988, they started annually testing the sires sperm.

title: Federal Court Blocks New Jersey Plan to Legalize Sports Betting
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit on Tuesday stymied New Jerseys attempts to offer sports betting again, ruling against the states plan to operate sports books in its casinos and racetracks.

title: A Little Food With Your Tequila at Casa Neta
description: CASA NETA MEZCALERIA AND TEQUILERIA Nothing says Mexico like bright wall murals pulsing with energy. Those by Tracy Ahumada, a graphic designer, add spice to this Flatiron-district setting for classic Mexican fare on small plates and agave-based spirits. The list of dishes, including tacos, quesadillas, ceviche and salads, is as brief as the selection of tequilas and mezcals stretches long, to more than 100. The chef, Joel Zaragoza, a native of Mexico City, seeks ingredients from local farms. The space, which once housed the Champagne bar Flte, has a downstairs lounge, the Sugar Skull Room, a year-round nod to the Day of the Dead with a mural by Derrick Turner, the bartender: 40 East 20th Street, 212-529-7870, casanetanyc.com.

title: Tim Tebow Will Attempt Another Comeback, This Time in Baseball
description: If at first you dont succeed, try a different sport.

But choreographers on the same level are a rarer species. During much of the Now: Premieres program on Monday, an evening of mostly new works, living choreographers were overshadowed by the dead.

description: MOSCOW  Against a backdrop of rising tensions between Turkey and the West, Presidents Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey pledged on Tuesday to repair relations after nine months of open antagonism.

description: Jennifer Mankins took over the boutique Bird in 2004 and has since expanded it to include three Brooklyn outposts. When she opened her Williamsburg shop in 2009, she included mens wear to complement her womens selection. I felt like the male counterpart to my female customers didnt have any place to go, she said.

description: RIO DE JANEIRO  One of New Zealands most famous and versatile athletes was knocked out of the Olympics on Tuesday, rocking a nation accustomed to outsize success at the Games.

description: RIO DE JANEIRO  There will be plenty of drama at the pool Tuesday night as some of the biggest names in swimming, including Katie Ledecky, Michael Phelps and Katinka Hosszu, are set to compete. Here is what to expect:

title: My Deadly, Beautiful City
description: The arctic mining city of Norilsk is one of the most polluted in the world  but many residents are still proud to call it home.

title: My Deadly, Beautiful City
description: Not many people have heard of Norilsk, an industrial cityin an isolated part of Arctic Russia. No roads or trains lead there; internet is severely limited; and it is it closed to foreigners. Getting there, I would find out, is very difficult. Yet despite its obscurity, Norilsk has one of the largest mining and metallurgical complexes in the world and produces most of the earths palladium, an essential mineral in electronics and automobiles. Most of us probably have a bit of Norilsk in our pockets, bags or homes.

title: Judge Rejects Rod Blagojevichs Plea for Reduced Sentence
description: CHICAGO  Rod R. Blagojevich, a former governor of Illinois, sat in a federal prison in Colorado on Tuesday as his image streamed into a courtroom in Chicago. His famous mane of Elvis-like dark hair has gone white. He squirmed, studied his cuticles and wiped away tears. And he pleaded with a federal judge via the live video feed to reduce his sentence for corruption charges and let him go home to his family.
