title: Inside the List
description: Step Right Up: David Cay Johnston, whose The Making of Donald Trump enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No.15, had just started a job as a reporter for The Philadelphia Inquirer in June 1988 when he first met Trump in Atlantic City. I almost immediately recognized Donald as the P.T. Barnum of our age, Johnston said in a phone interview. During one of their meetings, Johnston deliberately said something wrong (about craps, natch) to see how his subject might respond. He embraced my false fact in his answer, which taught Johnston, formerly a reporter at The Times and a Pulitzer Prize winner, something he hopes his readers will learn too: Donald doesnt know anything.

title: Literature of the Forever War
description: When a man is plunged up to his neck into the caldron of war, Vasily Grossman writes in Life and Fate, his epic novel of the Russian experience during World War II, he is quite unable to look at his life and understand anything; he needs to take a step back. Then, like someone who has just reached the bank of a river, he can look round: Was he really, only a moment ago, in the midst of those swirling waters?

title: Cannes, Citing Security Risks, Bans Full-Body Burkinis From Its Beaches
description: PARIS  The mayor of the French resort city of Cannes has barred women from bathing on public beaches in swimsuits that reveal too little skin.

title: Food Delivered to Your Beach Towel
description: Justin Harter made an important discovery a few years ago while hawking ice pops on Rockaway Beach in Queens: Once people get to the beach, they dont want to move.

title: The First Hipster of New York
description: Q. Did the hipster originate in New York? Or did hipsters migrate here from some other bastion of cool?

title: In Fight for Horse Health, the Battleground Can Be a Mares Body
description: There are six female horses that live in Ithaca, N.Y., and their job is to have sex over and over again. The mares  Millie, Lynx, Sophie, Recruit, Beautiful and Belle  are at the front lines of safeguarding the countrys lucrative horse-breeding industry from a potentially devastating sexually transmitted disease brought into the United States.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include a five-bedroom in North Stamford, Conn., and a four-bedroom in Bayville, N.Y.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are on the Upper East Side, the Lower East Side, and in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: As the World Grows More Slowly
description: To the Editor:

title: Summer Cooking, Summer Eating
description: The best summer meal? The perfect dessert? The meal to make if youre looking to impress someone?

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: The Playlist: Barack Obamas Summery Playlists and Green Days Fiery Return
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos  and anything else that strikes them as intriguing  in the Playlist. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this format? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com.

title: Violent Protests in Ethiopia
description: Demonstrators demanding political change in Ethiopia have been met with violent resistance by the government. Witnesses say that scores of protesters have been fatally shot during clashes with police.

title: Fox News Names 2 Insiders to Top Posts
description: In assuming the leadership of Fox News last month, Rupert Murdoch pledged a fresh start at a network reeling from accusations that its longtime chairman, Roger Ailes, had overseen a culture of harassment and intimidation.

title: Executive Director Is Leaving El Museo del Barrio
description: Just two years after becoming the executive director of El Museo del Barrio, Jorge Daniel Veneciano announced on Friday that he would step down at the end of the month to pursue new opportunities.

title: The Banana Man of Lower Manhattan
description: Abdulhamed Kharma, a sidewalk fruit vendor in Lower Manhattan, says he always tries to live up to his last name.

title: Once Priced Out, a Cafe Returns in Greenpoint
description: Verb Cafe was a shabby, cash-only space in Williamsburg that had no Wi-Fi but served good coffee for 15 years. Naturally, it got priced out of its Bedford Avenue storefront. The store that replaced the Verb in the summer of 2014, Soap Cherie, sells soaps in the shape of cupcakes. Locals bemoaned it as the latest loss in a gentrifying city. The artist Molly Crabapple wrote on Twitter,  New York is change, I know, but still, cant believe CBGBs is dead and the Chelsea Hotel is gutted and Verb is now a soap shop.

title: What Synchronized Divers Say to Each Other Before the Plunge
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Poised far above a swimming pool, about to somersault four and a half times into the water  that is no moment for a philosophical discussion, even if there is a person standing right next to you. But practitioners of the curiously mesmerizing sport of synchronized diving, who aim for dives that are not only perfect but also perfectly in sync, tend to have their own last-minute communication rituals.

title: Marco Rubio Warns Christian Conservatives of the Costs of Gay Intolerance
description: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, who has faced widespread condemnation for agreeing to speak at a conference alongside Christian conservatives who have denounced homosexuality and gay rights, used his speech to the group on Friday to warn of the costs of intolerance.

title: A $7.4 Million Heist Made for Hollywood
description: To his neighbors in Jackson Heights in the early 1990s, Sam Millar was known as a stoic family man who drove an old minivan and ran a comic book store near the familys apartment on 24th Avenue, near La Guardia Airport in Queens.

title: As New York Fights Zika Virus, Officials Turn Their Focus to Sex
description: One by one, the women paraded into the research center in Midtown Manhattan. There were about 40 of them, pregnant or of reproductive age, brought together by New York City health officials for focus-group sessions in English and Spanish.

title: Thomas Gibson Is Fired From Criminal Minds
description: Thomas Gibson, a star of Criminal Minds on CBS, has been fired from the show after an altercation with a producer.

title: Hope Solo Takes Aim at Sweden After U.S. Women Are Ousted
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Hope Solo stood in front of the American net on Friday afternoon, desperately needing to block a shot.

title: Why We Should All Digest Our Data
description: The shift from reading news in print to reading news online has dramatically increased the data available about our products. With print, user engagement is opaque  if you recycle your Sunday paper without reading it, well never know. With digital products, its increasingly easy to collect data on how users interact with online articles, smartphone apps, or email newsletters.

title: How David Maupin, an Art Dealer, Spends His Sundays
description: The art dealer David Maupin, who, with Rachel Lehmann, founded Lehmann Maupin in 1996, is in for a busy time. On Sept. 3, the Perfect Earth Project  an environmental nonprofit on whose board Mr. Maupin sits  will hold a benefit at the home of his friend, the photographer Cindy Sherman. Five days later, Lehmann Maupins Hong Kong gallery will open an exhibition of David Salles new paintings. And plans are underway for Lehmann Maupin to open its third Manhattan gallery. Mr. Maupin, 55, spends summer weekends in Bridgehampton with his husband, Stefano Tonchi, 56, the editor in chief of W magazine and a former New York Times editor, and their 5-year-old twin daughters, Maura and Isabella.

title: Cirque du Soleil Bends Broadway Norms to Revamp Paramour
description: And now for Cirque du Soleils latest daring trick: Paramour, the companys foray into Broadway musicals, will go dark later this month so the creative team can rework the shows story and acrobatics.

title: Torrential Rains Strand Wayward Indian Elephant in Bangladesh
description: NEW DELHI  Plenty of back-and-forth intermingling happens along the 2,500-mile zigzag border shared by India and Bangladesh. But the Bangladeshis are having trouble returning a four-and-a-half-ton Indian visitor to its home.

title: Cost, Not Choice, Is Top Concern of Health Insurance Customers
description: It is all about the price.

title: Shah Rukh Khan, King of Bollywood, Was Detained at a U.S. Airport for the Third Time
description: Shah Rukh Khan, the Indian actor known as the King of Bollywood, said he was detained for a few hours at an American airport on Thursday. Again.

title: Thai Leader Links Attacks on Tourist Sites to Constitution Change
description: MANILA  The head of the Thai junta urged his countrymen on Friday to have patience while investigators determine who was behind a wave of deadly bombings in Thailand this week.

title: Whats Universal in All of Us
description: Using her iPhone, Amy Touchette seeks to capture the diversity of the places she has lived in Brooklyn  Williamsburg and Bedford-Stuyvesant.

title: Eye Contact: Embracing the Spontaneity of Instagram
description: I wait for people to look my way or notice me, Amy Touchette says. Thats when I take the picture  to capture when we see each other.

title: Who Decides Where Each Country Lives in the Athletes Village?
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Vivian Kong, an Olympic fencer representing Hong Kong, pointed toward the tower where she and the rest of her contingent were staying at the Olympic Village.

title: Never Too Hot to Wear Black
description: Heat, humidity and a fashion stalwart.

title: Dont Throw Out Your Organ Donor Card After 65
description: Take my kidneys. Please.

title: Fact Check: Trump, Clinton on the Economy
description: The Republican presidential nominee Donald J. Trump and his Democratic rival, Hillary Clinton, offered widely different economic proposals in Michigan this week. We fact-checked both of their speeches.

title: Craig Robinsons Turtles Give Him Guilt Trips
description: On a recent evening, Craig Robinson, the actor and stand-up comedian known from the TV show The Office and the movies Hot Tub Time Machine and Knocked Up, sat in Zum Schneider, a Bavarian beer garden in the East Village, practicing his German.

title: Doctor Calls Aleppo Situation Catastrophic
description: Civilians were trapped in Aleppo, Syria's most populated city, as fighting escalated. Samer Attar, a Chicago doctor who recently volunteered in a hospital there, says conditions are deteriorating.

title: Look of Summer: The Little Black Sundress
description: These New Yorkers stayed with black uniforms on some of the seasons hottest days.

title: The Lochte Turn
description: Ryan Lochte's revolutionary turns have changed the sport of freestyle swimming.

title: Simone Biles Is the Worlds Best Gymnast
description: At this point in time, nobody can beat Simone Biles, Nastia Liukin, 2008 Olympic gold medalist, said.

title: Review: Gauzy Clichs Swaddle Chesapeake Shores
description: Here in Clich Shores, you can live a quiet, sanitized life surrounded by all those hackneyed themes and characters you expect from lightweight escapist paperbacks. Scruffily handsome ex-boyfriend from your high school days? Yeah, he and his three-day beard are here. Father who wasnt home often enough when you were a kid? Hes here, too. So is the grandma who spouts bland maxims. Practically everyone is fashion-shoot attractive, and practically everyone is white.

title: On the Way to the Met, a Meistersinger Is Stranded in Europe
description: It seemed like an unbeatable formula: a brilliant concept, dazzling designs, rave reviews and a plan to share the costs. Stefan Herheims acclaimed staging of Wagners Die Meistersinger von Nrnberg, which wowed audiences at the Salzburg Festival in 2013, was headed to the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Mothers to Homeland Security: We Wont Eat Until We Are Released
description: Dear Jeh Johnson,

title: The Fight to Protect L.G.B.T. Students in Colombia
description: Two years ago, 16-year-old Sergio Urrego jumped to his death from a shopping center in Bogot, leaving as his suicide note a Facebook post quoting Pink Floyds Goodbye Cruel World. His death was the genesis of a controversy that roiled Colombia this week, as the effort to expand L.G.B.T. rights was drawn into a broader political fight that has polarized the nation.

title: Foot-Dragging on Volcker Rule Gives Banks Critics Ammunition
description: Wall Streets procrastination only gives opponents another reason to act. Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, Morgan Stanley and other banks want the Federal Reserve to give them until 2022 to offload investments banned by the Volcker Rule. They have already had six years to do so, during which time the stock market has doubled. Asking for such a long delay may lead to unwanted consequences.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: A Winning Look (Outside the Pool) for Michael Phelps
description: By now, half the planet knows the meme #PhelpsFace, the viral image of the Olympian Michael Phelps furiously glowering as he prepped in the team room on Monday for his semifinal in the 200-meter butterfly. While his rival, Chad le Clos of South Africa, attempted to Jedi mind-trick the decorated swimmer by shuffling and shadowboxing feet away from him, Mr. Phelps hunkered down beneath the hood of his swim parka emanating death rays.

title: The Decline of Unions and the Rise of Trump
description: THE white working-class men who are planning to vote for Donald J. Trump this November have been called many things: xenophobic, racist, misogynist, dangerously nave. But even if those descriptions are true, it doesnt mean these men were fated to be Trump supporters. Recent research in social science and history suggests that they might have been out front in the fight against Mr. Trump  if only the American labor movement werent a shell of its former self.

title: JRs Monumental Artworks Have an Olympic Moment in Rio
description: Michael Phelps has nothing on her: The French triathlete Lonie Periault, rising out of Guanabara Bay in Rio, is caught mid-lap, looming over the water, her wingspan stretching more than 98 feet.

title: The Billion-Dollar Jackpot: Engineered to Drain Your Wallet
description: If youve noticed that colossal lottery winnings are becoming almost common this year, its no accident. Four of the 10 biggest jackpots in United States history have already occurred in 2016, an engineered outcome intended to generate mind-bogglingly big winners.

title: Review: Herbie Hancock, Basking in a Boundless Legacy of Fusion
description: Herbie Hancocks current project can be understood as both a progression and a reclamation. On Thursday night at the Prospect Park Bandshell, in a marquee concert at the BRIC Celebrate Brooklyn! Festival, he tucked some eagerly anticipated new music into a set list otherwise devoted to reframed hits. From behind his grand piano and a bank of synthesizers  or sometimes standing out front, with a keytar  he held magnanimous court, presiding over an evening that reaffirmed his legacy in the realm of vanguardist pop, jazz-funk and R&B.

title: Conviction Against Brendan Dassey of Making a Murderer Is Overturned
description: A federal judge on Friday overturned the murder and sexual assault convictions of Brendan Dassey, one of the defendants whose case was the subject of the wildly popular Netflix documentary series, Making a Murderer.

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Operations Against ISIS
description: The Department of Defense has identified 18 American service members who have died supporting the operation to eliminate the Islamic State militant group. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: In Syria, Battles for Aleppo Seem as Endless as the War Itself
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The battle for Aleppo  Syrias most populous city  is once again raging, once again trapping hundreds of thousands of civilians, once again rallying fighters seeking an advantage in the five-year-old civil war.

title: Hillary Clinton, Donald Trump, Vladimir Putin: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Partying for a Good Cause With Gwyneth Paltrow
description: Recent benefits included the Southampton Hospital Summer Party and the Paddle & Party for Pink, which raised $1.75 million for the Breast Cancer Research Foundation.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: A Simple Test to Dispel the Illusion Behind Stock Buybacks
description: Stock investors have had one sweet summer so far watching the markets edge higher. With the Standard & Poors 500-stock index at record highs and nearing 2,200, whats not to like?

title: Decoding Donald Trumps Sarcasm
description: Donald Trump claimed on Friday that when he said President Obama was the founder of ISIS, he was being sarcastic. He tweeted:

title: Benefits in the Hamptons and Cocktails at Saks
description: The past weeks party circuit included stops in Bridgehampton, N.Y., for Paddle & Party for Pink, where guests mingled with the actress Gwyneth Paltrow and the surfer Laird Hamilton; in nearby Southampton for a fund-raiser for that towns hospital; and in Midtown Manhattan, for after-work cocktails on the newly opened eighth-floor terrace of Saks Fifth Avenue.

title: Hillary Clinton Releases Tax Returns
description: The Times reporter Steve Eder discusses the tax returns released by the Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton  and her running mate, Tim Kaine  and what it means for her Republican rival, Donald J. Trump.

title: An American Fencing Medal in Foil, 84 Years in the Making
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The American mens foil fencing team won a bronze medal on Friday, the first medal for the United States in the event since 1932.

title: Colorado Towns Work to Preserve a Diminishing Resource: Darkness
description: WESTCLIFFE, Colo.  As people around the world stepped into their backyards or onto rooftops to peer up at the annual spectacle of the Perseid meteor shower early on Friday morning, few of them had a view like Wilson Jarvis and Steve Linderer.

title: Is God Transgender?
description: In the 1970s a cousin of mine, Paula Grossman, became one of the first people in America to undergo sex-reassignment surgery. As Paul Monroe Grossman, Cousin Paula had been a beloved music teacher in New Jersey. She was fired after her surgery, and she subsequently lost her lawsuit for wrongful termination based on sex discrimination (though a court did rule that she could receive a disability pension). The story was all over the news back then; Id like to think it would have ended differently today.

title: Lightning Strike in Poughkeepsie Kills One and Injures 4
description: A lightning bolt that struck during a fast-moving storm killed one person and injured four, two critically, at a park in the center of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., on Friday afternoon, the police and the mayor of the Hudson Valley city said.

title: Alex Rodriguez Is at Peace as He Walks Away
description: On a typical game day, Alex Rodriguez would ride to work up Broadway, through Harlem and Washington Heights  where he was born  and into the South Bronx. It was a quiet time when he could sit in the back, stare out the window at the city passing by him, and formulate a game plan.

title: The Upside to A-Rod
description: Alex Rodriguez has played his last game as a New York Yankee. Unceremoniously releasing him from his $275 million contract, which was supposed to run through the 2017 season, the Yankees have elected to speak now and not hold their peace: They will pay him the remaining $27 million of his contract and bring him on in an advisory capacity.

title: A Changing of the Guard on the Front Lawn
description: Where are the lawn Madonnas of yesteryear? One of the charms of wandering the outer-circle neighborhoods of New York, far from the towering commercialism of Manhattan, has been the statues of the Blessed Mother staring out serenely from the postage-stamp lawns of rowhouses.

title: Subway Rider Arrested on Lewdness Charges Had a Giveaway: A Team U.S.A. Tattoo
description: Hes the kind of man you should be able to pick out in a crowd, even amid the Olympic furor: His forehead is emblazoned with a Team U.S.A. tattoo.

title: Trumps Misguided Embrace of Tax Cuts
description: In a speech in Detroit on Monday, Donald J. Trump put forward a huge tax cut as the centerpiece of his economic program. He compared his plan to Ronald Reagans 1981 tax cut, saying his proposal would be the biggest tax revolution since the Reagan tax reform, which unleashed years of continued economic growth and job creation.

title: Green Water Lingers in Olympic Pools as the Excuses Pile Up
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Why cant they fix the swimming pools at the Rio Olympics?

title: Thailands Power-Hungry Generals
description: Voters in Thailand on Sunday approved a new Constitution that vests extraordinary powers in the military and treats electoral politics like a dangerous game that requires close supervision by the countrys generals. That outcome was hardly surprising. The Thai military, which took control of the country in 2014 in a coup, stifled debate about the Constitution by harassing journalists and charging critics with sedition.

title: Stop Treating Marijuana Like Heroin
description: Supporters of a saner marijuana policy scored a small victory this week when the Obama administration said it would authorize more institutions to grow marijuana for medical research. But the government passed up an opportunity to make a more significant change.

title: Polio Response in Africa to Be Fast, Difficult and Possibly Dangerous
description: The counterattack against resurgent polio in Africa will be rapid, logistically difficult and potentially dangerous, involving millions of doses of vaccine, thousands of vaccinators and the health ministries and militaries of five countries, experts from the World Health Organization and other groups say.

title: Donald Trump Fine With Prosecuting U.S. Citizens at Guantnamo
description: Donald J. Trump said this week that he was fine with prosecuting American citizens accused of terrorism offenses before a military commission at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, rather than a civilian court on domestic soil.

title: U.S. Strike Said to Kill ISIS Chief of Afghanistan-Pakistan Region
description: The leader of the Islamic State branch that operates in Afghanistan and Pakistan was killed in an American airstrike on July 26 in eastern Afghanistan, the Pentagon said Friday. It was the United States militarys second killing of an anti-American Islamist militant leader in the region in the past three months.

title: House Measure Protecting Embryos Threatens Veterans Fertility Treatments
description: WASHINGTON  This spring, after a yearslong push in Congress, a measure to provide fertility treatments for veterans with catastrophic reproductive injuries finally secured bipartisan support and seemed headed to becoming law.

title: Military Base Near Newburgh Is Made a Superfund Site Over Tainted Water
description: ALBANY  State environmental officials took action on Friday to hold the federal Defense Department accountable for water contamination in Newburgh, N.Y., saying that firefighting foam containing a dangerous chemical, used at a local military base, polluted the citys water supply.

title: Glenn Yarbrough, Folk Singer With the Limeliters, Dies at 86
description: Glenn Yarbrough, a folk singer who at midcentury found fame and fortune with the popular trio the Limeliters but who walked away from it all for a life at sea, died on Thursday at his daughters home in Nashville. He was 86.

title: Usain Bolt and Michael Phelps: Twin Titans of the Modern Olympics
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Over to you, Usain Bolt, and the bar is even higher than usual.

title: Maya DiRado, Exiting the Sport, Catches Katinka Hosszu and Grabs Gold
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Maya DiRado saved her best race for last, winning the 200-meter backstroke in her final race before retiring to start a job with a management consulting firm in Atlanta.

title: The Gray Ladle: Summer Produce
description: At 2 p.m. on Thursday, Aug. 18, Julia Moskin and Kim Severson were on hand for the second installment of Times Insiders cooking club, The Gray Ladle.

title: 1.28 Billion Minutes Streamed (and NBC Is Still Counting)
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  NBC Sports promise to stream every sport live at the Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro is fulfilled here at its headquarters  a former Clairol factory  where the digital feeds from every event are sent to tablets, computers, smartphones and other connected devices. They are visible on flat screens throughout the vast broadcast operations center  mosaics of sports that are being played simultaneously.

title: Somebody (His Names Joseph Schooling) Finally Beats Michael Phelps
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  What the vault is to the United States gymnast Simone Biles, the 100-meter butterfly is to the five-time Olympian Michael Phelps. The shortest individual race in Phelpss Olympic program has always been his toughest. His three consecutive victories, starting at the 2004 Games in Athens, came by a total margin of 28-hundredths of a second.

title: Louis Herman, Who Talked With Dolphins, Dies at 86
description: Louis M. Herman, whose seminal research demonstrated that dolphins could understand and respond to language transmitted by sound and visual signals, and whose research survived the criminal release of two trained dolphins by disgruntled former employees, died on Aug. 3 in Honolulu. He was 86.

title: Katie Ledecky Smashes World Record in the 800-Meter Freestyle
description: In 1968, a teenager in North Dakota watched transfixed as Debbie Meyer won the 200-, 400- and 800-meter freestyle races at the Mexico City Olympics. The next time the teenager, already a competitive swimmer, got in the pool, she cut through the water repeating to herself, I am Debbie Meyer.

title: For Simone Manuel, Gold Ripples Beyond the Pool
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Simone Manuel woke up Friday morning to confirmation that her victory in the 100-meter freestyle a few hours earlier had not been a dream. The proof was perhaps more surreal than Thursday nights payoff: Instagram posts from LeBron James and Serena Williams.

title: Thomas Steinbeck, Novelist and Son of John Steinbeck, Dies at 72
description: Thomas Steinbeck, the eldest son of the novelist John Steinbeck and, later in life, a fiction writer who fought bitterly in a family dispute over his fathers estate, died on Thursday at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 72.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: He does not need advice, he needs people who will carry out his orders with as little fuss as possible.

title: Susan M. Baer, Transportation Pioneer Who Ran New Yorks Airports, Dies at 65
description: Susan M. Baer, the first person to run all three major airports in the New York metropolitan area for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the first woman to be named its aviation director, died on Aug. 9 at her home in Upper Montclair, N.J. She was 65.

title: Device Used by Anubis
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  It might sound counterintuitive, but I think of the difficult Saturday puzzles as a way to metaphorically loosen my belt. For one thing, theres no theme to think about. I know a wide variety of topics will be covered, so I can put my mind into neutral and let it coast, because eventually I will pick up on something. As difficult as the puzzle itself might be, I actually find it relaxing.

title: U.S. Declares Zika an Emergency in Puerto Rico
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration declared a public health emergency in Puerto Rico on Friday because of the Zika virus, sending a message to the island that the virus, which has infected more than 10,000 residents, should be taken seriously.

title: Katie Ledecky and the Eternity of 11 Seconds
description: Katie Ledecky crushed the field and broke her own world record in the 800-meter freestyle, winning by more than 11 seconds.

title: Hacker Releases More Democratic Party Documents
description: WASHINGTON  A hacker believed to be tied to the Russian intelligence services made public another set of internal Democratic Party documents on Friday, including the personal cellphone numbers and email addresses of nearly 200 lawmakers.

title: Alex Rodriguez Departs, but Not as a Deity
description: The view across the field into the Tampa Bay Rays dugout from the first-base side revealed a handful of players present and accounted for when Alex Rodriguez was called to the area near home plate. Two or three Rays were perched on the steps, applauding the newsmaker nicknamed A-Rod for his 22 extraordinary major league years.

title: Ticket Prices Soar, and Plummet, for A-Rods Last Game
description: It was a boom befitting the career of a player who has hit 696 home runs. Prices soared for tickets to Alex Rodriguezs last game, on Friday at Yankee Stadium in the Bronx, after he abruptly announced his retirement on Sunday.

title: Egyptian Judo Athlete Refuses Handshake After Losing to Israeli
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  An Egyptian judoka declined to shake hands with his Israeli opponent after their match on Friday, eliciting jeers from the crowd.

title: Ryan Nassib Flubs Audition for the Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Eli Manning sat out the Giants first preseason game Friday night because Coach Ben McAdoo wanted the little-used reserve quarterback Ryan Nassib to get a lengthy audition with the starting unit. In Nassibs three seasons with the Giants, he has thrown only 10 passes and his rookie contract expires at the end of this season.

title: Under Dark Skies, Alex Rodriguez Ends Complicated Career as a Yankee
description: The pinstriped odyssey of Alex Rodriguez was an action-packed thriller, a cautionary tale, a pathetic farce and a story of redemption, all in one. The postscript  starting as a coach and adviser, leading to places unknown  must still be written. But a dozen uproarious volumes closed for good on Friday.

title: Jamie Liu and Leyan Lo: A Rubiks Cube Whiz Finds Love, Quickly
description: Jamie Liu, a daughter of Susan Hsiou-chang Liu and George Ke-hsiung Liu of Irvington, N.Y., was married Aug. 13 to Leyan Andrew Lo, a son of Jan Jy-Yean Lo and Chi-Yuan Lo of Basking Ridge, N.J. Maxine Lee, a college friend of the bride who was temporarily appointed a deputy commissioner of civil marriages by San Diego County, officiated at Viansa Sonoma, a vineyard in Sonoma, Calif.

title: Amy Lewis and Douglas Sweetman: Finding Love on a Dairy Farm
description: Amy Elizabeth Lewis, the daughter of Mary M. Lewis and Alan R. Lewis of Cornwall, N.Y., was married at her parents house Aug. 12 to Douglas Peter Sweetman, a son of Jennie E. Sweetman of Warwick, N.Y., and the late Tunis Sweetman. The Rev. Dr. Elwood E. Mather III, a Lutheran minister, officiated.

title: Susanna Griffith and Kenneth Schuemann: Fellow Debaters, Back in Agreement on Love
description: Susanna Kathryn Griffith and First Lt. Kenneth Bert Schuemann were married Aug. 13 at the United States Air Force Academy Cadet Chapel in Colorado Springs. The Rev. Bryan Counts, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Padres Batter Logan Verrett and Drop Mets Under .500
description: At some point, something about this Mets season has to change if they have any thought of making the postseason. After an 8-6 loss to the rebuilding San Diego Padres on Friday, the Mets have lost four straight games, dropping under .500 for the first time since April 17.

title: A Day of Finals Won and Records Broken
description: Great Britain set a team world record in cycling, while several athletes set records for speed and one set a record for his age.

title: In a Year of Injuries, Rafael Nadal Finds Joy by Winning Doubles Gold
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Remember that look in Paris? It was late May and Rafael Nadal was sitting in a news conference with his lips pursed, his eyes full of gloom and his left wrist in a brace as he announced his withdrawal from the French Open, the Grand Slam tournament that he had won a record nine times.

title: Corrections: August 13, 2016
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Whats on TV Saturday: Brooklyn and The Wine Show
description: Brooklyn, John Crowleys best-picture Oscar nominee, tries to answer the question Where do we come from? Michael Phelps swims his last race in Rio. Matthew Goode and Matthew Rhys go on a drinking binge in The Wine Show.

title: Joe Girardi and Alex Rodriguez Part on a Poignant Note
description: On a night overflowing with good will, affection and even some joy, Joe Girardi broke down in tears on Friday following Alex Rodriguezs final game as a Yankee.

title: What Is Best About America
description: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

title: Why Some Life Insurance Premiums Are Skyrocketing
description: Like clockwork, Sara and James Cook paid $452 a month for life insurance. That is, until a letter arrived last year telling the elderly Georgia couple the premiums on the policy theyd had for 25 years were rising sharply.

title: A Sex and the City for African Viewers
description: Lets get this out of the way up front: An African City, the steamy Ghanaian web series about five young women looking for love in Accra, is an unabashed rip-off of Sex and the City. There are the ubiquitous five-inch strappy sandals, the scene-stealing dresses made of Fanti fabric and the bevy of men who hop in and out of the beds of Nana Yaa, Makena, Zainab and Sade. The women are as free and liberal about sex as their American HBO foremothers, with the exception of the fifth character, Ngozi, who is such a Charlotte.

title: Q: Why Do Gay Men Love the Olympics? A: Isnt It Obvious?
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Since before the 2000 Summer Olympics in Sydney, Outsports.com has been covering gay issues in sports. The site is filled largely with coming-out stories, news analysis and slide shows of good-looking athletes.

title: He Likes Trump. She Doesnt. Can This Marriage Be Saved?
description: In early May, when Dr. Thomas Stossel told his wife, Dr. Kerry Maguire, of his plan to vote for Donald J. Trump in the general election, she hit him with an ultimatum.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from Rio de Janeiro to a lodge in East Tennessee.

title: Aid and Attention Dwindling, Migrant Crisis Intensifies in Greece
description: NEA KAVALA, Greece  As her young children played near heaps of garbage, picking through burned corn cobs and crushed plastic bottles to fashion new toys, Shiraz Madran, a 28-year-old mother of four, turned with tear-rimmed eyes to survey the desolate encampment that has become her home.

title: Reshaping Lives, Without Congress
description: The Obama White House has issued hundreds of major regulations in an effort to reshape aspects of American life. Here are some of the most important:

title: Reshaping Lives, Without Congress
description: The Obama White House has issued hundreds of major regulations in an effort to reshape aspects of American life.

title: Once Skeptical of Executive Power, Obama Has Come to Embrace It
description: WASHINGTON  In nearly eight years in office, President Obama has sought to reshape the nation with a sweeping assertion of executive authority and a canon of regulations that have inserted the United States government more deeply into American life.

title: A Little Variety
description: VARIETY PUZZLES  Please note that the A Little Variety suite of puzzles is not running in the Magazine this week because of the special Middle East coverage. However, we are offering this weeks A.L.V. puzzles online and they are free to everyone today. You can download and print out a copy of the PDF here.

title: Farhads and Mikes Week in Tech: Betting on Jet and Diverse Work Forces
description: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

title: Brown Water in a Rental
description: I live in a rent-stabilized apartment in a building that opened in 2009. Since October, brown water has occasionally come out of the kitchen faucet. Since March, it has happened every other day. Initially, management ignored my requests to fix the problem, even questioning the validity of my concerns. I sent them date-stamped pictures of the brown water and saved a water sample. They finally agreed to buy a water-filtration system, but are charging me to install it. Can they legally charge me for installation? And am I entitled to a rent abatement?

title: Rio Olympics: Green Pools Caused by Hydrogen Peroxide Dump
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Olympics officials on Saturday gave what they said was a definitive explanation why the water in two competition pools turned green this week. Someone, the officials said, mistakenly added 160 liters of hydrogen peroxide on Aug. 5, neutralizing the chlorine and allowing the growth of organic compounds that might have included algae.

title: How Producing Clean Power Turned Out to Be a Messy Business
description: On the edge of a bucolic field in Princeton, N.J., an eco-friendly office building recently opened its doors. Plants festoon the roof, a living wall is planned for the lobby, and rainwater storage tanks supply the buildings needs. In the parking lot there are wind turbines, solar panels and electric vehicle charging stations.

title: Is That Real Tuna in Your Sushi? Now, a Way to Track That Fish
description: Most people dont think data management is sexy, says Jared Auerbach, owner of Reds Best, a seafood distributor in Boston. Most dont associate it with fishing, either. But Mr. Auerbach and a few other seafood entrepreneurs are using technology to lift the curtain on the murky details surrounding where and how fish are caught in American waters.

title: Clouds of Dust Hang Over Arkansas Program to Fight Blight
description: PINE BLUFF, Ark.  It was a win-win proposition, a redemption for wayward men in a city in need of redeeming. Inmates and parolees would get training and job skills for a new start; in turn, this blight-plagued city in the Arkansas Delta would be freed of hundreds of abandoned homes, the unwanted souvenirs of decline.

title: Sisterhood Is Not Enough: Why Workplace Equality Needs Men, Too
description: Ill never forget how exciting it was to attend my first womens conference. The convention center was pulsing with estrogen, and it was exhilarating to be a part of a like-minded sisterhood. Sprinting from workshops to motivational keynotes featuring famous faces and wannabes, I came away inspired and armed with information so that I too could succeed in business while being female. I was woman, hear me roar!

title: A Caregiver for New Books About Nursing
description: Margaret Zuccarini, 74, is a publisher at Springer Publishing.

title: Solar Snare: Spend Thousands and Cut Power Bills by $9 a Month
description: Does this seem like a red flag?

title: The Soviet Doping Plan: Document Reveals Illicit Approach to 84 Olympics
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Late in 1983, months before they announced a boycott of the Los Angeles Olympics, sports officials of the Soviet Union sent detailed instructions to the head of the nations track and field team.

title: Inside the Failing Mission to Tame Donald Trumps Tongue
description: Donald J. Trump was in a state of shock: He had just fired his campaign manager and was watching the man discuss his dismissal at length on CNN. The rattled candidates advisers and family seized the moment for an intervention.

title: Variety Puzzle: Diagramless Crossword
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Administrivial Diagramless Hint Alert! If you do not want to use the starting square hint for the August 14 Diagramless puzzle, please look away now.

title: Another Puerto Rico
description: To the Editor:

title: Police in South Africa Struggle to Gain Trust After Apartheid
description: ALEXANDRA, South Africa  During apartheid, the government wielded the police like a club, using them to keep black South Africans in check and brutally extinguish any dissent.

title: Olympic Pilgrims Cloak Themselves in National Pride
description: Fans pulled out all the stops in expressing their adoration for their homelands at the Games. They even worked flags into their wardrobes.

title: How a Priest Made the Case for Mother Teresas Sainthood
description: Mother Teresa will be formally canonized on Sept. 4 by Pope Francis in Rome. Widely known as the Saint of Calcutta, she founded religious orders of women and men that serve the poor in more than 130 countries. Even for a woman who is an icon of modern saintliness, the Roman Catholic Church requires that someone must gather evidence of miracles and present a case that she is worthy to be admitted to the pantheon of saints.

title: Flowers a Thing of the Past at the Olympic Medal Ceremonies
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Something is different about the medal ceremonies at the Olympics this year: The flowers are gone.

title: Rios Carnival for the Senses Ends at the Food Line
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Ask Milton Ponce to describe the flavor of the round, little, baked snack that he has been producing for more than 50 years, and he sounds a bit stumped.

title: A Congressman Slighted Immigrants, Then Embraced Them. Now He Runs From Trump.
description: DENVER  Representative Mike Coffman watches telenovelas. He admits this with a laugh that doubles him over, his hand clamping on a nearby shoulder for support, but the Colorado Republican has serious reasons for his immersion in Spanish-language soap operas.

title: A Super Pac Targets Hillary Clintons Wealthy Connections
description: As Donald J. Trump assails Hillary Clinton, calling her corrupt and crooked, a super PAC aiding his campaign, Rebuilding America Now, has begun trying to marshal evidence, with nearly $7 million spent so far on this ad, Dead Broke, according to Kantar Media/CMAG.

title: A Long History of Heartbreak Shadows the Cubs Dominant Season
description: CHICAGO  As Chicago Cubs outfielder Chris Coghlan dug in for a full-count, two-out, bases-loaded pitch from St. Louis Cardinals pitcher Carlos Martinez, he was concerned that Martinez would try to quick-pitch him.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: How to End the Stigma of Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON  The Guantnamo Bay prison may soon reach a milestone. The Obama administration appears close to resettling the remaining detainees recommended for transfer, some of whom have been stranded on that list for years. That prospect raises a question: What more, if anything, should the United States do to help them, and hundreds of other people who were previously released after being detained without charges for years, most of whom are not suspected of engaging in new militant activities?

title: Obit for the Obits
description: No sense in burying the lede. This week, after more than eight years of lively habitation in one of journalisms more obscure corners, Im making a final egress, passing on. Starting after Fridays deadline (ha!) I am an ex-obit writer.

title: How to Write About Trauma
description: One summer afternoon, when I was 4 or 5 years old, I was raped by a next-door neighbor. If the act itself was gruesome, the aftermath was surprisingly uneventful, beginning with the fact that my mother, despite knowing what had transpired, did nothing. As for me, I did what everyone tries to do under similar circumstances: move on and be normal. With the exception of the occasional nightmare that visited me in the years that followed, I was convinced that there had been no lasting damage. How miraculous it was that I had emerged unscathed.

title: Chinas Defiance in the South China Sea
description: No one expected last months international arbitration court decision to be the last word on the tug-of-war over the South China Sea and its many islands, rocks and reefs. The waterway is too strategically important and the disputes too complex for the competing claims by China and five other countries in the region to be quickly resolved. Yet provocations continue, raising questions about Chinas commitment to the rule of law and heightening fears of a wider conflict.

title: Brenda Martinez
description: Brenda Martinez is a track and field athlete specializing in middle distances who is competing in the 1,500 meters at the Rio Olympics.

title: To Get to Harvard, Go to Haiti?
description: This summer, as last, Dylan Hernandez, 17, noticed a theme on the social media accounts of fellow students at his private Catholic high school in Flint, Mich.

title: Donald Trump Is Making America Meaner
description: FOREST GROVE, Ore.  ALL across America, in little towns like this one, Donald Trump is mainstreaming hate.

title: A Mideast Rift in College
description: On campuses around the country, a debate over Israel and the B.D.S. movement.

title: The Secret of Jamaicas Runners
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Among the most enigmatic features of Jamaica, an island of only 2.8 million people, is its astonishing supremacy in running. Currently, the worlds fastest man and woman are both Jamaicans. Nineteen of the 26 fastest times ever recorded in 100 meter races were by Jamaicans. The list goes on.

title: Echoes of Jim Crow for Sparta Voters
description: The disastrous Supreme Court ruling that crippled the Voting Rights Act three years ago has emboldened aggressive new attempts at voter suppression by local officials in jurisdictions that have been freed from federal oversight.

title: The Perfect G.O.P. Nominee
description: WASHINGTON  SPEAKING of crazy

title: Watching My Beloved Aleppo Rip Itself Apart
description: In June 2011, the last time I was in Aleppo, I visited my grandmothers home every day. I obsessively photographed the apartment where my father grew up and where I spent much of my youth. I snapped shots of her wooden doors and balcony, our familys antiques arranged in the glass vitrine, her organized kitchen cabinets and my grandfathers proud portrait in the dining room. I took only a few sentimental pieces with me when I left to go back to my home in America. I wish I had taken everything.

title: Donald Trump Courts the Gun Zealots
description: The mutual embrace of Donald Trump and the National Rifle Association grew tighter last week with Mr. Trumps incendiary suggestion that Second Amendment advocates could maybe find a way to deal with Hillary Clinton and her gun safety agenda if she reached the White House.

title: A Playboy for President
description: IN a different campaign or era, it would have been a race-altering moment; in this one, it was barely a scandal. There was Melania Trump, the potential first lady of the United States, posing stark naked in 90s-era photos published by the New York Post  and then in the next days edition, canoodling lipstick-lesbian style in bed. Yet the press yawned, her husbands latest outrage overshadowed it, and it only stayed a story because the date of the photos raised questions about the future Mrs. Trumps immigration status.

title: Indonesias Push to Execute Drug Convicts Underlines Flaws in Justice System
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Sixteen years ago, Zulfiqar Ali left his native Pakistan for Indonesia in search of a new life. Last month, that life was on the verge of ending in front of a firing squad.

title: Champion of Human Rights in China Leaves a Tarnished Legacy
description: WASHINGTON  Harry Wu, who spent 19 years in Chinese labor camps, was a familiar figure on Capitol Hill, delivering searing broadsides against Chinas authoritarian government that drew admiration from American politicians condemning the countrys human rights abuses.

title: Appreciating Prince Fielders Swing
description: To the untrained eye, Prince Fielder appeared to have one of the most aggressive all-or-nothing swings in modern history. But Fielder, who was forced to end his career Wednesday because of herniated disks in his neck, was more of an artist than he seemed.

title: Mike Pence May Break With Donald Trump, Again, Over Tax Returns
description: COLUMBUS, Ind.  Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, suggested Saturday that he might release his tax returns before Election Day, even as his running mate has shown no inclination of doing the same.

title: Saudi Coalition Airstrikes in Yemen Kill at Least 19, Mostly Children
description: SANA, Yemen  Airstrikes carried out by warplanes from a military coalition led by Saudi Arabia killed at least 19 people, mostly children, on Saturday in a residential area and a school in northern Yemen, witnesses and hospital officials said.

title: Olympic Revelry Distracts Brazil (Momentarily) From Its Woes
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Brazil is in a terrible way: There is a Zika epidemic, the economy is in the toilet and a bare-knuckle brawl for the presidency has paralyzed the nation.

title: Kenny Baker, the R2-D2 Robot in Star Wars, Dies at 81
description: Kenny Baker, the British actor best known for playing the robot R2-D2 in six Star Wars films, died on Saturday at his home in northwest England. He was 81.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paint and Switch? Did Alec Baldwin Pay $190,000 for the Wrong Picture?
description: Ten years or so ago, as the actor Alec Baldwin remembers it, the gallery owner Mary Boone sent him an invitation to a show of work by the painter Ross Bleckner, an artist whom she represented and he had befriended.

title: Philip Bialowitz, Who Escaped a Nazi Death Camp and Testified in Court, Dies at 90
description: Philip Bialowitz, a Polish Jew who escaped Sobibor, a secret Nazi extermination camp, in the aftermath of a dramatic prisoner uprising and bore witness to the horrors of the Holocaust in a powerful memoir and in courtroom testimony, died on Aug. 6 in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 90.

title: Running, Rowing and Riding
description: Scenes from the Rio Games on Saturday.

title: Imam and His Assistant Killed in a Shooting Near a Mosque in Queens
description: A gunman shot and killed an imam and his assistant on the street near their mosque in a working-class corner of Queens on Saturday afternoon, the police said.

title: U.S. Drones Record ISIS Fighters Fleeing Manbij in Northern Syria
description: CAIRO  American military drones monitored Islamic State militants loading up hundreds of cars, buses and trucks with fighters and civilians and fleeing the city of Manbij, Syria, on Friday, as Syrian rebels advanced and the extremists lost yet another stronghold.

title: Moral Thinking
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  Sometimes you need more cowbell, and sometimes you just need more L. Ian Livengood returns with a Sunday puzzle that adds more L (hence the title Moral Thinking) to our puzzle.

title: Bilingual Invitation to Arizona Mayor Draws an Angry Reply, in English
description: PHOENIX  The invitations to the border mayors meeting landed in inboxes in the United States and Mexico in English and in Spanish, standard for any type of official communication about binational events.

title: American Womens Fencing Team Earns a Bronze in Saber
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The American womens saber team won a bronze medal on Saturday with a 45-30 victory over Italy, thereby atoning for some disappointing finishes in the individual event.

title: Yankees Tyler Austin and Aaron Judge Hit Back-to-Back Homers in Debuts
description: Aaron Judge had just sat down to dinner with his parents at Dinosaur BBQ when Al Pedrique, his manager at Scranton-Wilkes/Barre, the Yankees Class AAA affiliate, walked up to their table.

title: On Day to Honor Past Glory, the Yankees Show the Power of the Future
description: If it all works the way they plan, Saturday will stand as a fulcrum for the Yankees, the pivot point from past to future glory. They formally released Alex Rodriguez. They promoted two new right-handed sluggers. And they honored the champions of 1996, the group that set a rigid and sometimes suffocating standard for every team to follow.

title: A Simple Yell Helps a Dynasty Pull Together
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Just when the United States womens eight needed it the most on Saturday, when other crews threatened to pull away and win the Olympic gold medal, coxswain Katelin Snyder shouted something special into her headset. Her voice echoed through the Americans boat.

title: Mo Farah Falls but Hardly Misses a Step in 10,000-Meter Victory
description: Mo Farah of Britain, who won gold in the 5,000 and 10,000 meters at the 2012 London Games, won the 10,000 on Saturday night at the Rio Olympics after falling to the track about midway through the race.

title: Puerto Rico Gets First Olympic Gold as Mnica Puig Surprises in Tennis
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The Puerto Rican anthem had just been played for the first time at an Olympic medal ceremony. Mnica Puig was still wiping away the tears when the two women she had defeated in her final surge to her gold medal stepped up to the top step of the podium to join her for photos.

title: Jamaicas Elaine Thompson Is the Fastest Woman in the World
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  A little smile appeared to form on Elaine Thompsons face as she took her final steps across the finish line. Soon, it expanded into a look of full incredulity, her mouth agape. And seconds later, as she began to process that she had won the gold medal in the womens 100-meter dash, she began hopping up and down on both feet, arms out at her sides.

title: Michael Phelps Wins 23rd and Final Olympic Gold
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The United States had never failed to take the gold in the mens 4x100-meter medley relay at a non-boycotted Summer Games, and it was not about to end the streak on Saturday, not in the competitive farewell of the greatest Olympian.

title: Eli Apple to Undergo M.R.I. After Preseason Knee Injury
description: Eli Apple, the Giants 2016 first-round draft pick, will have a magnetic resonance imaging examination of his left knee, which he injured in Friday nights preseason loss to the Miami Dolphins. The veteran wide receiver Victor Cruz, who has a groin strain and did not play Friday, should return to practice Sunday on a limited basis.

title: It Wasnt a Life or Death Game, but It Looked Like One
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  When the American and British women squared off on Saturday night in the Olympic field hockey tournament, there was a modest amount at stake, but nothing more.

title: Sumgong Gives Kenya Its First Womens Marathon Gold
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Kenya has long dominated distance running, but not until Sunday did it have a gold medal in the womens Olympic marathon.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: If we knew it would be like this, we would not have left Syria.

title: Lacey Drucker, Alexander Clifford
description: Lacey Helen Drucker, a daughter of Robin I. Reibel and Bruce H. Drucker of Boston, was married Aug. 13 to Alexander Garrett Clifford, a son of Nancy C. Gucker of New York and Garrett J. Clifford of Huntington, N.Y. Cantor Kate Judd officiated at the Woodstock Inn & Resort in Woodstock, Vt.

title: Lindsay Sargent, Matthew Miller
description: Lindsay Janine Sargent and Matthew John Miller were married Aug. 13 at Pine Hollow Country Club in East Norwich, N.Y. Msgr. Jim Lisante, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

description: Grace Marie Silk, the daughter of Jan M. Silk and Kevin B. Silk of Carpinteria, Calif., was married Aug. 13 to William Elliot Tisch, the son of Patsy A. Tisch of Santa Barbara, Calif., and Steve Tisch of Los Angeles. Lee Lakso, a friend of the couple who was ordained by the Unity Church of Santa Monica, officiated at Hotel Bel-Air in Los Angeles.

description: Anne Craig Shoemaker, a daughter of Susanne L. Shoemaker and Paul T. Shoemaker of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married Aug. 13 to Robert Paul Kirkham, a son of Ann L. Kirkham and D. Collier Kirkham of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Cari Pattison, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Reformed Church of Bronxville in Bronxville, N.Y.

description: Jordan Fraser Bock, a daughter of Dawn W. Bock and Steven L. Bock of Lexington, Mass., was married Aug. 13 to Geoffrey Alexander Smith, the son of Mary M. Menino and John E. Smith Jr. of Weston, Mass., at the Boston Harbor Hotel. James Murphy, the grooms high school debate team coach, received permission from the state to officiate.

title: Laura Zatz, Benjamin Shaffer
description: Laura Yaremchuk Zatz and Benjamin Louis Shaffer were married Aug. 13 in Dearborn, Mich. Rabbi Tamara Kolton officiated at Lovett Hall, a ballroom on the Henry Ford property.

title: Ivy Lukacs, Sebastian Castro-Malaspina
description: Ivy Ann Lukacs and Sebastian Hugo Castro-Malaspina were married Aug. 12 at Pleasantdale Chateau in West Orange, N.J. The officiant was Dev Gopalan, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event.

title: Karen Boosalis, Ross McHugh
description: Karen Elisabeth Boosalis, a daughter of Wendy B. Boosalis and Christopher J. Boosalis of Maple Grove, Minn., was married Aug. 13 to Christopher Ross Albert McHugh, the son of Cheryl Smetana McHugh and Christopher T. McHugh of Pine City, Minn. The Rev. Jeffrey T. Foels, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the House of Hope Presbyterian Church in St. Paul.

title: Jean Woroniecki, Alan Roberts
description: Jean Lauren Woroniecki, the daughter of Colleen M. Woroniecki of Wall, N.J., was married Aug. 13 to Alan Paul Roberts, a son of Mary P. Roberts and Bruce I. Roberts of Knoxville, Tenn. The Rev. Theodore J. Roman, a priest affiliated with CITI Ministries, officiated at Doolan's Shore Club in Spring Lake, N.J.

title: Elizabeth Arkema, Karl Hakansson
description: Elizabeth Ventress Arkema, a daughter of Christine E. Bishop and Dr. Paul H. Arkema of Weston, Mass., was married Aug. 13 to Karl Mikael Olof Hakansson, a son of Caroline A. Sjoberg and Sven Mikael A. Hakansson, both of Gothenburg, Sweden.

title: Katherine Philip, Andrew Kaufman
description: Katherine FitzGibbon Philip, a daughter of Jennifer Brainard Philip and William Van Ness Philip of Simsbury, Conn., was married Aug. 13 to Andrew Kaufman, the son of Susan Kaufman and David B. Kaufman of New York. Cynthia A. Kilburn, a justice of the peace, officiated at Ekwanok Country Club in Manchester, Vt.

title: Jessica Singer, Jordan McLean
description: Jessica Marie Singer and Jordan Matthew McLean were married Aug. 11 at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau, where Edwina Townes, a staff member in the New York City clerks office officiated.

title: Sofia Vargas, Noah Nielsen
description: Sofia Elizabeth Vargas, a daughter of Elizabeth R. Weiner and Heriberto Vargas Jr. of Manhattan, was married Aug. 13 to Noah Gabriel Nielsen, a son of Isabel Weinger Nielsen and Lars Nielsen of Northfield, Vt. Rabbi Benjamin H. Spratt officiated at the West Mountain Inn in Arlington, Vt.

title: Heidi Kim, Jared Brown
description: Heidi Kathleen Kim, the daughter of Hayesook Kim and Chongmoo Kim of Perrineville, N.J., was married Aug. 13 to Jared Matthew Brown, a son of Sylvia Rabinowitz Brown and Dr. Michael R. Brown of Tucson. Rabbi Steven J. Kirschner officiated at the Haw River Ballroom in Saxapahaw, N.C.

title: Melissa DeChillo, Stephen Meahl
description: Melissa Lynn DeChillo and Stephen William Meahl were married Aug. 13 at St. Patrick's Old Cathedral in Manhattan. Msgr. Donald Sakano, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Katherine Liu, Joshua Heller
description: Dr. Katherine Liu, a daughter of Yan Liu of Flushing, Queens, was married Aug. 13 to Dr. Joshua Adam Heller, a son of Dr. Debra S. Heller of Closter, N.J., and Dr. Allen N. Heller of Tenafly, N.J. Susanna Macomb, a minister ordained by the New Seminary for Interfaith Studies, officiated at the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Jenna Pace, Scott Terry
description: Jenna Lynn Pace and Scott Andrew Terry were married Aug. 10 at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau by Angel L. Lopez, a staff member in the office of the New York City Clerk.

title: Carley Freese, Robert Waters III
description: Carley Elizabeth Freese, the daughter of Susan H. Freese and John E. Freese of Virginia Beach, was married Aug. 13 to Robert Lee Waters III, the son of Carol H. Waters and Mr. Waters II of Beaufort, S.C. The Rev. Dr. Terrance Lindvall, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at All Saints-by-the-Sea, a chapel in Southport, Me.

title: Anna Della Subin, Hussein Omar
description: Anna Della Subin and Hussein Ahmed Hussein Omar were married on Aug. 10 at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Angel L. Lopez, a staff member in the Office of the City Clerk, officiated.

title: Claire Hankin, Taylor Wray
description: Claire Marie Hankin, the daughter of Lynn M. Gaudioso Hankin and Errol P. Hankin of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married Aug. 13 at the Castle Hotel & Spa in Tarrytown, N.Y., to Taylor Curtice Wray, the son of Cyndi G. Wray and Mark D. Wray of Orlando, Fla. Justice O. Peter Sherwood of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated a ceremony led by Matthew Wray, an uncle of the groom who became a Universal Life minister for the event.

title: Amy Beamer, Charles Korschun
description: Amy Michelle Beamer, the daughter of Patricia M. Beamer and Dr. Andrew D. Beamer of Summit, N.J., was married Aug. 13 to Charles Salem Korschun, the son of Holly W. Korschun and H. Marshall Korschun of Atlanta. Robert Gurske, a Roman Catholic deacon, officiated, with assistance from Cantor Lee Coopersmith, at Fiddlers Elbow Country Club in Bedminster, N.J.

title: Deja Butts, Nicholson Blaise
description: Deja Nelfiria Butts, a daughter of Linda Forrest and Richard M. Butts, both of Jamaica, Queens, is to be married Aug. 14 to Nicholson Pierre Blaise, a son of Hermine M. Blaise and Nicholson Blaise of Brockton, Mass. Pastor Omar Jarvis, a Seventh-day Adventist minister, is to perform the ceremony at the Wadsworth Mansion in Middletown, Conn.

title: An Errant Throw Gives the Mets Enough for a Much-Needed Win
description: After a four-game losing streak, a spirited team meeting and a mini news conference tirade, Manager Terry Collins desperately needed a potent weapon to change the Mets fortunes, and his own.

title: Emma Gleason, Jeffrey Aser
description: Emma Wilder Boyd Gleason, a daughter of Jennifer N. Boyd and Wilder G. Gleason of Norwalk, Conn., was married Aug. 13 to Jeffrey Scott Aser, the son of Patricia Clark Aser of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Thomas M. Aser, at Hildene, a museum in Manchester, Vt., that was once the summer home of Robert Todd Lincoln.

title: Eliza Hernandez, Christian Nuccio
description: Eliza Jasmine Hernandez, a daughter of Elba and Oscar L. Hernandez of Chapel Hill, N.C., was married Aug. 13 to Capt. James Christian Nuccio, a son of Jo A. and James T. Nuccio of Charlotte, N.C. Msgr. John McSweeney, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Matthew Catholic Church in Charlotte.

title: Emma Hanson, Joshua Puritz
description: Emma Meadows Hanson, a daughter of Virginia W. Hanson and Grant W. Hanson of Lake Oswego, Ore., was married Aug. 13 to Joshua Everett Puritz, the son of Carole L. Kerner and Arthur M. Puritz, both of New York. Peter Landis, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the Maysara Winery in McMinnville, Ore.

title: National Guard Deployed in Milwaukee Amid Unrest Over Fatal Police Shooting
description: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin activated the Wisconsin National Guard on Sunday to assist local law enforcement following a night of violence in Milwaukee that began hours after a police officer fatally shot a fleeing armed man there.

title: Whats on TV: Black Orpheus and The Walking Dead Marathon
description: Supplement your Olympics viewing with Black Orpheus, Marcel Camuss intoxicating adaptation of the Greek myth, set during Carnival in Rio. Cinderella and Four Knights puts a South Korean spin on the fairy tale. And wake up before dawn, if you dare, for an all-day marathon of The Walking Dead.

title: Corrections: August 14, 2016
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Homes That Sold for $700,000 to $899,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.

title: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know about the weeks top stories.

title: Rio Olympics, U.S. Presidential Race, Brendan Dassey: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here are the weeks top stories, and a look ahead.

title: Athletes Who Were Denied Their Olympic Medal Moments Because Others Were Doping
description: When an Olympic medalist is caught doping, any medals he or she has won are usually ordered returned, to be awarded to the next finisher in line.

title: Hard Times in Venezuela Breed Malaria as Desperate Flock to Mines
description: THE ALBINO MINE, Venezuela  The 12th time Reinaldo Balocha got malaria, he hardly rested at all. With the fever still rattling his body, he threw a pick ax over his shoulder and got back to work  smashing stones in an illegal gold mine.

title: 1966: Chinese Communists to Make New Leap Forward
description: HONG KONG  Communist China announced yesterday [Aug. 13] it was making a new leap forward. The Central Committee of the Chinese Communist party, in its first plenary session in nearly four years, strongly reaffirmed the nations hard line at home and abroad, said a Radio Peking broadcast monitored here. The committee, which ended its 12-day meeting in Peking Friday, announced its decisions on the domestic service of Radio Peking yesterday.

title: For Trump, Pennsylvania Is a Crucial Battleground
description: The lunch group in Monessen, Pa., is evenly divided between Donald J. Trump supporters and Trump opponents. But the dark mood across the whole room suggests why this working-class town might end up favoring him in November.

title: Network Led by One Individual Carried Out Bombings, Thai Official Says
description: BANGKOK  A series of bombings that killed four and injured dozens in Thailand at the end of last week was committed by a widespread network that followed the instructions of a single person, a police official said on Sunday, although he declined to identify the perpetrators.

title: Rio Olympics Roundup: Simone Biles, Usain Bolt and Ryan Lochte
description: Simone Biles picked up her third gold medal of the Olympics on Sunday by winning the vault competition.

title: What to Cook This Week
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Deal Aims to Keep a Former Welfare Hotel in Manhattan Affordable
description: Two chapters in two lives are being lived out in the tidy room on East 28th Street that Andrew Byrnes now calls home  two chapters that are different but entwined. One is the latest chapter in Mr. Byrness life. His previous chapter was troubled, and troubling.

title: Officials Spent Big on Olympics, but Rio Natives Are Paying the Price
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  A thousand metaphysical miles from the well-heeled Olympic zone, a couple of activists and I entered the Favela do Mandela, a ramshackle collection of brick-and-tar-paper buildings. We walked a narrow road ringed by wary-eyed young men, which led to a narrower one, which led to a five-foot-wide alleyway. We found the home of 64-year-old Marie Auxiliadora.

title: Boko Haram Video Appears to Show Bodies of Kidnapped Girls
description: The militant group Boko Haram released a video on Sunday purporting to show the bodies of several kidnapped schoolgirls who fighters claim were killed by Nigerian airstrikes.

title: Can You Beat Usain Bolt Out of the Blocks?
description: Usain Bolts reaction time out of the starting blocks in the 100-meter final at the London Olympics was 0.155 of a second. Try to beat it.

title: Fighting Rages in Aleppo, Syria, Killing Dozens of Civilians
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Fighting in Aleppo, Syria, killed dozens of civilians over the weekend, a high toll even for a city that has been the scene of intense fighting recently, a monitoring group said on Sunday.

title: 1916: Food Grows Scarce in Bulgaria
description: LONDON  The economical situation of Bulgaria is rapidly becoming as critical as that of Germany and Austria-Hungary. According to information from various reliable sources bread is everywhere extremely scarce. In Sofia, white bread is unobtainable and black bread is given out sparingly. In some parts of the country only two pounds a week is allowed to each householder. Sugar, butter, eggs and salt are among the necessaries sold at exorbitant prices, and even then only in very small quantities.

title: Ryan Lochte and Three Teammates Robbed at Gunpoint
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Ryan Lochte, an Olympic gold medalist in swimming, and three of his United States teammates were held up at gunpoint here early Sunday, according to the United States Olympic Committee, heightening anxiety over violent crime in the host city of the Summer Games.

title: Hillary Clintons Edge in a Donald Trump-Centric Race Has Liberals Wary
description: Liberal Democrats and progressive activists have grown wary of the state of the 2016 presidential race, chafing at Hillary Clintons big-tent courtship of Republican leaders they have long opposed and fearing the consequences of shaping the contest as a referendum on Donald J. Trump.

title: French Music Festival to Come to Central Park SummerStage
description: The French music festival Vieilles Charrues will come to Central Park SummerStage on Oct. 1 for its 25th anniversary. The Avener, Matthieu Chedid, and the Celtic Social Club will perform.

title: Review: The Disappearance Has a Missing Mademoiselle and a Gallic Gumshoe
description: The Disappearance is a European missing-child mystery, and if youve seen the pillars of the genre (The Killing, The Missing) you know what to expect. It has some regional flavor  with much of the action centered on a corner cafe in Lyon, France, run by the family of the disappeared girl  but its mostly menu typique.

title: Suicide Squad Tops Box Office for Second Weekend
description: LOS ANGELES  Sex-starved anthropomorphic food. Meryl Streep as a clueless opera singer. A furry, folksy Disney dragon. Bank robbers in poverty-stricken West Texas.

title: Afghanistan Forces Struggle to Hold Firm Against Taliban in South
description: CHAH-I-ANJIR, Afghanistan  As Taliban fighters push toward the southern city of Lashkar Gah, members of Afghanistans elite forces are trying to hold their ground here, about 10 miles from the city, the capital of Helmand Province and a critical link in the defense of the entire region.

title: An American Stands on the Shoulders of a Gladiator
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  About the same time that the future United States Olympic volleyball player Carli Lloyd was born 27 years ago, her uncle was discovered by a talent scout in a Southern California gym.

title: Mets Neil Walker Prepares to Depart and Meet His New Arrival
description: The date has been marked for months. Neil Walkers wife, Niki, was expected to give birth to the couples first child, a girl, on Tuesday.

title: Justin Rose Outduels Henrik Stenson for Golf Gold Medal
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The lives of the worlds top golfers revolve around a village much smaller than the facilities in and around Olympic Park, where they received a warm reception in the sports return to the Olympic program after a 112-year absence.

title: Not Forgotten: The Tryst With Destiny Speech That Divided India and Pakistan
description: The roles of Mohandas Gandhi, Jawaharlal Nehru and Muhammad Ali Jinnah on Aug. 15, 1947, when power over one-fifth of humanity was transferred from Britain.

title: In Olympic Dressage, an Effortless Performance Takes Hard Work
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  You think human athletes are high-maintenance? Meet Legolas 92, a 1,300-pound, 14-year-old gelding from Westphalia, Germany.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Aug. 15
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: U.S. Field Hockey Has a Backup Goalie, but Shes in the Stands
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Alesha Widdall, the backup goalie for the United States womens field hockey team, was getting ready for the teams final game of Olympic group play, against Britain on Saturday at the Olympic Hockey Center.

title: A Writers Quest to Unearth the Roots of Tibets Unrest
description: Generations of Chinese have been taught that the Tibetan people are grateful to China for having liberated them from feudalism and serfdom, and yet Tibetan protests, including self-immolations, continue to erupt against Chinese rule. In Tibet in Agony: Lhasa 1959, to be published in October by Harvard University Press, the Chinese-born writer Jianglin Li explores the roots of Tibetan unrest in Chinas occupation of Tibet in the 1950s, culminating in March 1959 with the Peoples Liberation Armys shelling of Lhasa and the Dalai Lamas flight to India. In an interview, she shared her findings.

title: Steven Matzs No-Hit Bid Is Broken Up, to Terry Collinss Relief
description: Steven Matz, a rookie left-hander for the Mets, came within four outs of the second no-hitter in club history on Sunday, with a base hit in the eighth inning ruining his bid.

title: Review: Mohenjo Daro Depicts a Go-To Heros Exertions in Antiquity
description: Before the action starts, the Bollywood movie Mohenjo Daro assures us that no animals were harmed during its making. More unusual, a note tells us that the film doesnt support or dispute any specific interpretation of ancient Indian civilization. This disclaimer probably isnt necessary. From its first scenes, the movie, set in 2016 B.C., makes its intentions known: This is a heros tale, not history.

title: Yankees Luis Severino Returns to Minors After Savaging by Rays
description: Mariano Riveras plaque is the newest addition to Yankee Stadiums Monument Park, where the inscription credits his signature cut fastball with leading to 652 saves, the major league record.

title: Review: The public domain Beats the Heat and Humidity
description: Though the actual temperature hovered in the mid-90s late Saturday afternoon in New York, the feels like indicator on weather sites put the figure at 105 degrees. Even so, the premiere of David Langs the public domain, his new work for 1,000 voices, went on as planned in the main plaza of Lincoln Center. Arriving for the performance, I was certain that the volunteer choristers who had rehearsed the piece so thoroughly would show up. But would anyone else?

title: Review: Emotional Rescue Ruminates on Life and Music
description: They strode upon the land like gods. They had formidable egos and captivating prose styles and strong, often unpredictable opinions. They had influence, too, at least for a while, and maybe even a modicum of power. I speak here of the rock critics  writers like Lester Bangs, Robert Christgau, Ellen Willis and Dave Marsh  who rose to prominence in the 1960s and 70s, and I mention them as a way of providing a contrast to Ben Greenmans new book, Emotional Rescue.

title: Its Thrilling. Its Chilling. Its a 30-Minute Commercial.
description: Lifeline is a half-hour thriller directed by an Academy Award winner about a mans search for his missing girlfriend. In the film, set in Shanghai with a plot driven by corporate malfeasance, punches are thrown, shots are fired and people are killed. At one point, the actress Olivia Munn stands over a dead woman, blood on her hands.

title: Arms, and Legs, Aloft
description: Usain Bolt strode to glory again, and synchronized swimmers flipped through a preliminary round on a day when athletes at a variety of venues had reason to celebrate.

title: How Mark Rylance Became Olivia Onstage
description: LONDON  When you live with a woman for more than a decade  as Mark Rylance did, on and off, with a certain countess famed for her beauty and her severity  you come to know her well. I liked her enormously, Mr. Rylance said recently, in a rush of respectful warmth. I guess I liked the struggle between the form she felt she had to maintain and the great force within her. He also came to realize that she was both funnier and sadder than he had at first suspected.

title: Hey Ho, Its Old: England Embraces Punk Rock 40 Years Later
description: BLACKPOOL, England  Ramones forever! C. J. Ramone yelled to a tightly packed crowd at the Rebellion Festival here earlier this month, and a little roar rippled through a sea of bright-pink mohawks, bleached-blond spikes  and more than a few balding heads.

title: Forty Years On, What Does Punk Rock Mean?
description: LONDON  The origins of punk rock are somewhat hazy, but by 1976 it had emerged as a genre of loud, fast, rebellious music, with style and attitude to match. Forty years later, we asked punk rockers and those who know their music what it means to them.

title: Someones Gonna Pay
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  Todays crossword by Sam Trabucco solved almost like a Tuesday to me because the theme was a bit less straightforward than I was expecting for a Monday. Committing a puzzle to a specific day of the week is a fine line to walk.

title: Sale of Federal Mortgages to Investors Puts Greater Burden on Blacks, Suit Says
description: For years, the federal government avoided insuring mortgages in black neighborhoods, a practice known as redlining that exacerbated racial divides throughout Americas cities.

title: Intels New Mission: Find Fresh Uses for Its Famous Paranoia
description: Andy Grove, the renowned chief executive of Intel, who died in March, coined a phrase beloved in Silicon Valley: Only the paranoid survive.

title: President Obamas Emotional Spotify Playlist Is a Hit
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass.  Some full-time music critics spend their lives curating playlists they hope become popular. President Obama outdid them all last week in between briefings by senior aides and rounds of golf with friends on vacation here.

title: Mysterious Scribbling on the Subway
description: Dear Diary:

title: A Vote on the Tyco Merger and Earnings Reports From Target and Walmart
description: Heres what to expect in the week ahead.

title: Celebrity Chefs Turn Wasted Olympics Food Into Meals for Homeless
