description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Consider what it takes to keep all those Olympian machines nourished and hydrated for one meal at the Rio Games: 250 tons of raw ingredients to fill the bellies of 18,000 athletes, coaches and officials in the Olympic Village.

title: Secret Ledger in Ukraine Lists Cash for Donald Trumps Campaign Chief
description: KIEV, Ukraine  On a leafy side street off Independence Square in Kiev is an office used for years by Donald J. Trumps campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, when he consulted for Ukraines ruling political party. His furniture and personal items were still there as recently as May.

title: Fyvush Finkel, Pillar of Yiddish Theater Who Crossed Into TV, Dies at 93
description: Fyvush Finkel, whose homespun moniker and putty face  comic statements all their own  helped him become a mainstay of what remained of Yiddish entertainment, and who later crossed over into television as the cantankerous lawyer on the 1990s series Picket Fences, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

title: Usain Bolt Is Still the Worlds Fastest Man
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  As the king of sprinting and the biggest global star at the Rio Games, Usain Bolt of Jamaica held aloft his index finger, signaling that he was No. 1, during introductions Sunday night as a smitten crowd chanted his name.

title: Thousands Displaced in Storm-Drenched Louisiana
description: After days of ruinously heavy storms in southern Louisiana, rain-swollen rivers and creeks continued wreaking damage across the state, inundating neighborhoods and submerging roads and highways.

title: Pitching, and Injuries to Rivals, Keep the Mets in the Wild-Card Race
description: Terry Collins was off by one day. When Collins, the Mets manager, delivered a blistering tirade about his sluggish team last Thursday, he did it with the struggling Logan Verrett scheduled to pitch the next game. Verrett promptly gave up five runs in the first inning on Friday.

title: Mark Sanford: I Support You, Donald Trump. Now Release Your Tax Returns.
description: Among Donald J. Trumps traits is his penchant for internalizing and personalizing things  insults, rejections and even policy disagreements. Trading slights seems essential to his personality, or at least something he feels is necessary for his presidential campaign.

title: Andy Murrays Big Year Now Has Olympic Gold
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Andy Murray of Britain put a brighter shine on his finest tennis season by winning his second straight Olympic gold medal in singles on Sunday night, but surely Juan Martn del Potro of Argentina deserves something more precious than silver.

title: End the First-Use Policy for Nuclear Weapons
description: Throughout the nuclear age, presidents have allowed their senior commanders to plan for the first use of nuclear weapons. Contingency plans were drawn to initiate first strikes to repel an invasion of Europe by the Soviet Union, defeat China and North Korea, take out chemical and biological weapons and conduct other missions.

title: Milwaukee Shaken by Eruption of Violence After Shooting by Police
description: MILWAUKEE  Like many of his neighbors, Dominic A. Lebourgeois was in disbelief on Sunday at the level of violence that descended on his Sherman Park neighborhood the previous evening.

title: Our Community Lost Its Heart: Queens Imam Is Recalled as Peacemaker
description: Imam Alauddin Akonjee delivered his weekly sermon on Friday in his quietly powerful manner, drawing, as usual, nearly 200 people to a two-story house-turned-mosque in Ozone Park, Queens. He spoke in Bengali, his native language.

title: A Tech Moguls Fight to Keep Control of a Newspaper Empire
description: In early summer, after the company formerly called Tribune Publishing had rejected two takeover offers from Gannett, two of its biggest investors found themselves in an escalating dispute. The investment firm Oaktree Capital Management was publicly questioning the motives of Michael W. Ferro Jr., an investor and the new chairman of the publishing company, in his decision to rebuff Gannett.

title: Unlikely Facebook Friendship Saves Afghan Baby With Heart Defect
description: HOLON, Israel  They had never met, but they were Facebook friends connected across thousands of miles. Together the two digital acquaintances  a young English teacher in Jalalabad, Afghanistan, and a retired State Department official living in Haifa, Israel  collaborated to save a baby in Pakistan with life-threatening congenital heart problems.

title: Who Might Buy Gawker Media? Here Are Some Possibilities
description: The end of Gawker Media as an independent company is near.

title: With N.F.L. Deal, Twitter Live-Streams Its Ambitions
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Last March, Twitter and Facebook, along with other tech companies, faced off over which of them would get the rights to live-stream National Football League games on Thursday nights.

title: Fox News Turmoil Recalls News Corp. Phone Hacking Scandal
description: Settlements for alleged inappropriate behavior that continued unabated.

title: Health Insurers Use Process Intended to Curb Rate Increases to Justify Them
description: WASHINGTON  After the Affordable Care Act took effect in 2010, it created a review mechanism intended to prevent exorbitant increases in health insurance rates by shaming companies that sought them.

title: Heng on Japans Emperor and the Constitution
description: Emperor Akihito indicated in a rare public address that he wants to abdicate the throne, which would make him the first Japanese monarch in 200 years to step down.

title: 2 Killings Near Mosque Plunge a Queens Neighborhood Into Fear
description: On Sunday afternoon, Nurul Khan changed clothes after working around his house on a sweltering day and set off on a short walk, just around the corner, to his mosque to pray. It is a stroll he takes five times a day, he said, starting each morning before the sun has risen.

title: How Millennials Became Spooked by Credit Cards
description: Kids these days: They just arent pulling out the plastic like they did in the past.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: It is a situation of national shame. I was seeing this kind of thing when I was a medical student a half-century ago. It hurts me. The disease had disappeared.

title: The Night Of Season 1, Episode 6: The Cat or the Yarn?
description: In the recap for last weeks episode, I wrote about how Nazs acclimation to prison life mirrored that of the lead character in the French drama A Prophet, which tracks a young convicts rise from helpless naf to jailhouse kingpin. Yet, I also noted a crucial difference between the two: A Prophet is about how a system predicated on reform turns a petty criminal into violent monster, but we dont know if the same is true of Naz. There are suggestions, based on his behavior and based on the real possibility that he murdered Andrea Cornish, that prison hasnt changed Naz so much as revealed the coarsened soul that his good-guy demeanor has hidden so effectively.

title: On Power, an Unholy Trinity Reaches a Breaking Point
description: This interview contains spoilers for last Sundays episode of Power.

title: The Numbers Behind Japans Sputtering Economy
description: NAGOYA, Japan  Japan on Monday reported that its economy had expanded by the smallest of margins in the second quarter. The country has been struggling to ignite growth after years of slumping wages and prices. The currency has shot up this year, hurting crucial export industries. Its the worlds third-largest economy. So what does it mean when it grows only a fraction of a percent in one quarter?

title: Gymnasts Specialty: Returning to the Olympics. (Shes 41. Its Her 7th Trip.)
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Now that the marquee gymnastics events are over at the Rio Games  with the Japanese men and the American women proving to be the best in the team and all-around competitions  the sports apparatus finals have begun.

title: Racial Violence in Milwaukee Was Decades in the Making, Residents Say
description: The burning buildings, smashed police cars and scuffles between police officers and angry protesters on Milwaukees north side over the weekend might have seemed like a spontaneous eruption.

title: Making the Old New Again
description: In Brooklyn Heights, a team of architects will give a second life to a dilapidated 19th-century mansion.

title: Tattered Brooklyn Mansion Has a Blueprint for Rebirth
description: Once upon a time, a mansion stood at the corner of Clark Street and Monroe Place in Brooklyn Heights. Built in 1872, it was stately and corniced, bedecked in stone scrollwork and intricate ironwork, a credit to its architect.

title: On Survivors Remorse, a Fight Over Visibility for Black Women of All Complexions
description: This interview contains spoilers for Sundays episode of Survivors Remorse.

title: Reports of Gunfire at J.F.K. Airport Prompt Evacuation
description: Panicked travelers stampeded through Kennedy International Airport on Sunday night after unconfirmed reports of gunfire there, leading the police to evacuate two terminals and close part of a major highway that runs near the airport, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said.

title: No Corrections: August 15, 2016
description: No corrections appeared in print.

title: Hong Kong Protest Leaders Sentenced to Community Service
description: HONG KONG  Two Hong Kong activists were sentenced to community service on Monday and another was given a suspended jail term for their involvement in a demonstration that led to large pro-democracy street protests two years ago.

title: Whats on TV Monday: The Disappearance and True Life: We Are Orlando
description: A teenager goes missing after a night of revelry in The Disappearance, a sudsy French thriller with hints of The Missing and Broadchurch. The Olympic sprinter Allyson Felix chases her seventh medal. And survivors of the Orlando, Fla., massacre talk about life after the attack.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | debauch
description: debauch  \di-boch, -bch, de-\  noun and verb

title: Sole Russian Track and Field Athlete Cleared for Rio
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  An appeals court ruled early Monday morning that the Russian long jumper Darya Klishina should be allowed to compete in the Rio Games, overturning an 11th-hour decision by track and fields world governing body.

title: Picture Prompt | $100
description: If someone gave you $100, what would you do with it? Why?

title: Usain Bolt and the Fastest Men in the World Since 1896  on the Same Track
description: Every Olympic medalist in the 100-meter sprint  on the same track.

title: Comparing Test Scores of Public and Charter Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: STEM Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Gunshots and Anguish Near a Mosque in Queens
description: An imam and his assistant were gunned down on a street in Ozone Park, Queens, on Saturday, minutes after finishing afternoon prayers, two blocks from their mosque. A man got out of car, ran up behind them, shot each in the head, and fled.

title: For Music, Smaller Is Better
description: To the Editor:

title: A Looming Clash in Venezuela
description: Venezuelas electoral commission signaled last week that a referendum that could oust President Nicols Maduro will not be held before the end of the year. That was hardly a surprise, but it puts Venezuela on a dangerous  and avoidable  collision course.

title: Wisdom, Courage and the Economy
description: Its fantasy football time in political punditry, as commentators try to dismiss Hillary Clintons dominance in the polls  yes, Clinton Derangement Syndrome is alive and well  by insisting that she would be losing badly if only the G.O.P. had nominated someone else. We will, of course, never know. But one thing we do know is that none of Donald Trumps actual rivals for the nomination bore any resemblance to their imaginary candidate, a sensible, moderate conservative with good ideas.

title: When Police Are Poor Role Models for One Another
description: The drug trade is so insidious in some neighborhoods of Baltimore that when I was a detective there I sometimes had to arrest children for selling narcotics. Sad as that was, a drug counselor told me, they learned to do it from the people around them.

title: What Two Years of Negative Interest Rates in Europe Tell Us
description: Hoping to kick-start European economies, the European Central Bank took the extraordinary step two years ago of lowering one of its key interest rates to below zero. The idea was to discourage banks from stashing their money in the central bank by charging them a modest rate for doing so. Since the banks would lose money rather than earn interest on their deposits, it was hoped they would be prompted instead to make more loans at lower rates to businesses and consumers.

title: Questions About Americas Nuclear Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Women Who Love Women Arent Tragic
description: The first time I fell in love, I did nothing about it. She seemed out of reach, unattainable, impossible. There was fear and doubt, naturally, but beneath all that, I had been conditioned to believe that if anything was certain, my happiness wasnt. It was a time-honored tradition: My queerness was inherently tragic. Thats how I had been told our stories end. Women who loved women couldnt live happily ever after.

title: How to Reduce the Gender Pay Gap
Article of the Day | How to Live Wisely
description: Article: How to Live Wisely

title: You Cant Just Walk Away: Why Paula Bronstein Keeps Photographing Afghanistan
description: Her new book features her photographs taken in Afghanistan, showing both the beautiful and the horrific in a visual compendium of what has happened on the ground during Americas longest war.

title: New Yorkers in Subway Deserts Have Advice for L Train Riders: Suck It Up
description: Waiting at a bus stop in a cascade of snow. Inching along in stop-and-go traffic. Cramming into a commuter van alongside other passengers.

title: Pro Boxers at the Olympics: An Opportunity, or a Dangerous Power Grab?
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The International Olympic Committee has been ripping down the vestiges of amateurism for decades, paving the way for professionals like Michael Jordan, Serena Williams and Sidney Crosby to win gold medals.

title: Flocking to Robben Island: Tourists by Day, Poachers by Night
description: Robben Island in South Africa is getting to be notorious again  and this time its not for racial oppression.

title: You Cant Just Walk Away': Why Paula Bronstein Keeps Photographing Afghanistan
description: Once in Kabul, the photographer Paula Bronstein and I went to visit a mother and her two children as they smoked heroin in the tiny storage room where they lived. Their fingers black with tar, Zaher, 14, and Gulpari, 12, inhaled the drug out of a canoe-shaped piece of foil heated from below, a skill learned from their mother.

title: G.O.P. Urges Donald Trump to Broaden Outreach to Black Voters
description: When Donald J. Trump went to Detroit last week to deliver a speech on his economic proposals, he laid the chronic problems of the heavily black city at the feet of his opponents, saying Democrats had a stranglehold on power, and unless we change policies, we will not change results.

title: Fading Signs
description: Medallions with national coats of arms were hung on 300 lampposts along Avenue of the Americas in 1959. But only around 22 remain.

title: On Avenue of Americas, No Brazil or Mexico. Panama or Peru, Either.
description: There is no Brazil.

title: How Usain Bolt Came From Behind Again to Win Gold
description: Usain Bolt of Jamaica became the first runner to win the 100 meters at three Olympics.

title: Caleb Carrs New Thriller Takes On Fancy Forensics. Michael Connelly Reviews.
description: SURRENDER, NEW YORKBy Caleb Carr598 pp. Random House. $30.

title: Human Cells Make Up Only Half Our Bodies. A New Book Explains Why.
description: I CONTAIN MULTITUDESThe Microbes Within Us and a Grander View of Life By Ed YongIllustrated. 355 pp. Ecco/HarperCollins Publishers. $27.99.

title: Taking Sports to the Extreme
description: Mountain biking, helicopter skiing, river surfing, BASE jumping, waterfall kayaking, ice climbing and other extreme sports that put participants at risk of serious injury, even death, grow annually in popularity.

title: Milwaukee, Louisiana, Usain Bolt: Your Monday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: The Art of Vulgarity
description: What is bad taste? How much is too much? Why do we say yes? On the eve of their London exhibition, the fashion curator Judith Clark and the psychoanalyst Adam Phillips pry open the excessive and the ugly for interpretation.

title: New York Today: Mourning in Queens
description: Updated, 8:19 a.m.

title: Donald Trump to Lay Out 3 Pillars of Terrorism Plan, Aides Say
description: As he continues to face a backlash for calling President Obama and Hillary Clinton the founders of ISIS, Donald J. Trump will travel to the battleground state of Ohio on Monday to discuss his plans to fight terrorism and shore up national security.

title: Hacks Can Ease the Trials of Aging
description: When Barbara Beskind, 92, had trouble reaching foods in the back of her refrigerator, she installed a lazy susan on an inside shelf. The revolving tray makes items much easier to reach. Ms. Beskind, a former occupational therapist in the Army who has age-related macular degeneration, a disease that reduces her central vision, also attached small tactile bumps to the Answer button and the 2 and 8 keys on her phone, making it easier for her to respond to and make calls.

title: The State of the Clinton-Trump Race: Is It Over?
description: It has been three weeks since Democrats gathered for their convention, and Hillary Clinton still holds a large and consistent lead in national and battleground state polls.

title: Morning Agenda: Millennials Are Wary of Debt
description: Credit card debt among Americans under 35 has fallen to its lowest level since 1989. Having racked up a pile of student loans, young people want to avoid the kind of pressure that they saw their family and friends under during the financial crisis. And laws passed after that crisis make it harder for them to secure credit cards anyway.

title: Brazils Uplifting Olympics
description: When I was a correspondent in Brazil 30 years ago, inflation was rampant. It ran at an average of 707.4 percent a year from 1985 to 1989. The salaries of the poor were wiped out within hours of being paid. The country went through three currencies  cruzeiro, cruzado and cruzado novo  while I lived in Rio. The only way out for Brazilians, people joked, was Galeo, the international airport.

title: Women Have Been Boxing in the Shadows for Too Long
description: Theres a scene in T-Rex  a documentary that follows the middleweight phenom Claressa Shields from her hometown of Flint, Mich., to the 2012 Olympic Games in London and back again  that perfectly illustrates the biggest problem faced by womens boxing. Shields is sitting with two Team U.S.A. representatives and her coach, Jason Crutchfield, in a nondescript lobby after glory and fanfare have receded into a post-Olympic haze. She has returned home after four decisive victories, having won the first American gold medal in womens boxing. Shes 17. The reps from Team U.S.A. are discussing her sponsorship opportunities. Names like Ryan Lochte and Gabby Douglas are tossed out as the sort of Olympians to whom sponsors flock. Team U.S.A.s public-relations consultant, a woman named Julie Goldsticker, goes into an incomprehensible description of why sponsors are attracted to certain people. Then she looks at Shields and says: I would love for you to stop saying that you like beating people up and making them cry.

title: Death by Medical Error: Adding Context to Scary Headlines
description: When I started out as a doctor in 1999, the Institute of Medicine published a blockbuster report that declared that up to 98,000 people were dying in United States hospitals each year as a result of preventable medical errors. Just a few months ago, a study in the BMJ declared that number has now risen to more than 250,000, making preventable medical errors in hospitals the third-largest cause of death in the country in 2013.

title: Why Clone Sheep  Dont They All Look Alike Anyway?
description: Ask The Times, a Times Insider feature, draws on New York Times expertise to answer questions about current events, science, sports, culture and whatever else is making headlines.

title: Finding India in a Sweet Corner of Houston
description: HOUSTON  For one humid week in high summer, Santas workshop is a Texas storefront. The holiday is not Christmas; it is Raksha Bandhan, and the gifts in production arent toys but a colorful array of sweet mithai, the Indian version of pastries.

title: Chinese Court Upholds Ruling Against Historian Who Questioned Tale of Wartime Heroes
description: BEIJING  In a tale taught to generations of Chinese schoolchildren and celebrated in film, theater and paintings, five Communist soldiers who had fought off the Japanese invaders in World War II, killing dozens, chose to leap off Langya Mountain, shouting Long live the Chinese Communist Party! rather than surrender.

title: Summer Vegetable Gratin
description: Put tomatoes, zucchini and squash to good use in this summer gratin.

title: Building a Better Vegetable Gratin
description: A gratin of summer vegetables should be the easiest thing in the world to make in August: a no-recipe breeze for the carefree summer cook. Slice up squash, tomatoes, etc.; arrange attractively; bake.

title: Angry After Milwaukee Police Shooting, Protesters Turn Against Media, Too
description: MILWAUKEE  Demonstrators upset over an officer-involved shooting here took out their frustration on the police and property during street demonstrations over the weekend, but they also directed their anger at the news media.

title: 1966: Newspaper Ends Publication
description: NEW YORK  The New York Herald Tribune, one of Americas oldest and most influential newspapers, went out of existence today [Aug. 15]. The newspaper, which sent Stanley to find Livingstone in Africa, fell victim to rising costs, strong competition and a series of prolonged strikes. The owners of the World Journal Tribune, a corporation formed by the merger of the morning Herald Tribune and the afternoon Journal American and the World Telegram and the Sun, announced the Herald Tribunes death.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 16, 1966

title: Reports of Shooter at J.F.K. Airport
description: Unconfirmed reports of gunfire at Kennedy Airport on Sunday night left travelers panicked as the police worked to evacuate two terminals.

title: How Czech Wine Got Its Terroir Back
description: VALTICE, Czech Republic  A dozen years ago, Mike Mazey was making wines in his native Australia when he received an unexpected job offer from Europe: Come to the Czech Republic and teach us your craft.

title: Olympians Mother Leaves a Suitcase at Check-In, and It Is Destroyed
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Running late after arriving for the Olympics last week, the mother of the United States volleyball player Carli Lloyd dropped her suitcase at the cruise ship where she is staying during the Games. She and her family then rushed to see her daughters first match.

title: Hesitant to Make That Big Life Change? Permission Granted
description: Sixteen days from now, my family and I will board a plane for New Zealand. Not for a vacation  but to live and work for the next 12 months or so. Its spontaneous, its exciting, its new, and its something Ive always wanted to do. Sounds awesome, right? Yes!

title: Which Co-Pilot to Choose: Google Maps or Waze?
description: Q. Since Google hasnt integrated the two apps it owns, should a driver use Google Maps or Waze for traffic and navigation? And can you use Waze safely to report road conditions while driving?

title: Daily Report: Live Video Is Where the Advertising Bucks Are
description: Online video  and especially live video  has become a promised land for a bevy of internet companies.

title: Usain Bolts Showdown With Justin Gatlin Carries a Sense of Historys Passing
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  King Bolt, narrow of hip and wide of shoulder, with that ambling gait, came sauntering out of the tunnel into the Olympic Stadium with arms spread wide, as if he were embracing all the love from the crowd.

title: 1916: St. Marys Day Loses Splendor
description: St. Marys Day was shorn of much of its customary splendor yesterday [Aug. 15]. In normal times on August 15, the Feast of the Assumption, every Marie in France  there are hundreds of thousands of them, mostly pretty, or have been pretty  is fairly certain to receive a bouquet, or a flowering plant in blossom, or a humble little nosegay, from some relative, or suppliant, or friend. But the wars baleful effect has touched even la Sainte-Marie. Husbands, suppliants, brothers and friends are in the trenches, and for countless Maries yesterday, instead of being a day of rejoicing, was one of sad memories.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Aug. 16, 1916

title: The Emperor and the Prime Minister
description: TOKYO  August is always a solemn time in Japan. It is the month when we remember the double destruction of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, and Japans defeat in World War II. This year, however, we find ourselves not only remembering history, but witnessing it: The nation has been shaken by a recent video message from Emperor Akihito in which he hinted that he wished to abdicate.

title: Rio Olympics: Shaunae Miller Dives to Gold in 400 Meters
description: In a desperate lunge at the finish line, Shaunae Miller of the Bahamas won the womens 400 meters at the Rio Olympics on Monday night, defeating Allyson Felix of the United States.

title: Brand to Know: A Voluminous Line, Brought Back From the Past
description: Today, it is possible to purchase a pair of pants online and have those pants hand-delivered to you  neatly folded in a gift box  within the hour. But in the 1920s, when the Czechoslovakian businessman Jan Nehera founded his eponymous brand, if you wanted pants you had to make them yourself, or have a tailor make them for you. Nehera thought shopping should be easy, so he started producing ready-to-wear clothing made from sturdy, practical material that you could buy straight off the rack. The result was a new model that revolutionized the industry and shot Nehera to success. His brand flourished throughout the 1930s  at its height, there were 130 stores across Europe  until World War II brought things to a halt.

title: National Sawdust Announces Second Season
description: National Sawdust, the experimental performance space that opened in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, last fall and quickly became a vital part of New Yorks new music scene, said Monday that its second season would feature a roster of guest programmers, 30 newly commissioned works and the start of an online arts journal.

title: The Top News Events That Got America Talking About Race
description: Every day last year, Twitter users turned to social media to talk about race.

title: Comedy Central Cancels Larry Wilmores Late-Night Show
description: For almost a decade, the combination of Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert made Comedy Central destination viewing for fans of late-night comedy and barbed political commentary.

title: Chlos Muse, Anne-France Dautheville
description: In the 70s, she became the first woman to ride a motorcycle around the world solo.

title: Fall for Dance to Offer Premieres by Wayne McGregor and Elizabeth Streb
description: Premieres by the British choreographer Wayne McGregor and the MacArthur grant recipient Elizabeth Streb are coming to the Fall for Dance Festival at New York City Center.

title: Which Olympic Sport Would You Compete In?
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  During downtime at the Rio Games, staff members from The New York Times keep mulling over a question:

title: Whats for Breakfast?
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Brooklyn Youth Chorus Announces 25th Season
description: The Brooklyn Youth Chorus will celebrate its 25th season with newly commissioned pieces from acclaimed composers, including Nico Muhly, Caroline Shaw and Rhiannon Giddens.

title: Nan Goldin Wants You to Know She Didnt Invent Instagram
description: Im not responsible for anything like social media, am I? Tell me Im not.

title: Donald Trumps Terrorism Plan Mixes Cold War Concepts and Limits on Immigrants
description: Donald J. Trump on Monday invoked comparisons to the Cold War era in arguing that the United States must wage an unrelenting ideological fight if it is to defeat the Islamic State. He said he would temporarily suspend immigration from the most dangerous and volatile regions of the world and judge allies solely on their participation in Americas mission to root out Islamic terrorism.

title: Louisiana Deals With Severe Flooding
description: Severe flooding across Louisiana has turned deadly, forcing thousands to evacuate their homes and leaving many in need of rescue.

title: Plan to Let Barges Park on the Hudson Meets Resistance in River Towns
description: YONKERS  This citys mayor, Mike Spano, likes to stroll along the Hudson River waterfront and marvel at the changes since the 1980s. Hundreds of millions of dollars in public and private investment have transformed a once forlorn riverfront marred by abandoned industry into a vibrant place where people live and play.

title: When Theyre Gone, Theyre Gone
description: Kyle Shanahan lives in Sag Harbor, N.Y., where he thought there was a shortage of coffee shops like the ones he recalled in his native Cleveland. And nothing goes better with coffee than doughnuts, he said. So he has opened his own coffee and doughnut shop, with help from his stepfather, the chef Michael Symon. Mr. Shanahans doughnuts are yeasted, but made from brioche dough, so they have a denser, more caky consistency than most. Each day he produces four classics and four special doughnuts, like one gleaming with chocolate glaze and a popcorn topping and another with lemon-poppy seed icing. The honey-glazed variety, one of his classics, is my favorite. He makes 1,300 on weekdays, 2,200 on weekends, and when theyre gone, theyre gone: Grindstone Coffee and Donuts, 7A Main Street (Bay Street), Sag Harbor, N.Y., 631-808-3370, grindstonecoffeeanddonuts.com.

title: Give Them the Old Bronx Grape
description: Bronx grapes have arrived. Some 90 years after the Cornell Agricultural Experiment Station in Geneva, N.Y., and the New York Botanical Garden developed the Bronx Seedless table grape, Lagier Ranches in Escalon, Calif., has enough of a crop of these lovely translucent pale green-to-pink grapes (with thin skins and a lush, almost candied flavor) to ship them to New York. The organic grapes have been sold on a limited basis in Northern California, but the grape never grew well in the Northeast. They will be available for about three weeks: Bronx Seedless Table Grapes from Lagier Ranches, $6.99 for a one-pound box at Agata & Valentina and Eataly stores.

title: Canned Tomatoes and So Much More
description: In summer, books about canning and preserving are as common as apple cookbooks in the fall. But Domenica Marchettis book caught my eye for its uncommon point of view: preserving food the Italian way. Pack artichokes, peppers and mushrooms in oil. Make deliciously spicy pickles from melon. Even limoncello, mostarda and confections like torrone can come straight from your kitchen. There are simple cheeses and cured meats, along with a useful section covering tomatoes, but the option of freezing for preservation is not included. At the end of each chapter are some easy recipes for using your homemade creations. Its a cautious book that stresses safety over shortcuts. The techniques may have been passed down by generations of nonnas, but they knew what they were doing: Preserving Italy by Domenica Marchetti (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $23).

title: In U.S. Jails, a Constitutional Clash Over Air-Conditioning
description: JENNINGS, La.  The air inside the Jefferson Davis Parish jail was hot and musty. Prisoners, often awakened by the morning heat, hoped for cooling rain after nightfall. And ice, one inmate recalled, brought fleeting relief in the cell she called a sweatbox.

title: The Risks of Unfettered Capitalism
description: Capitalism may be the best economic system ever devised, but one of its drawbacks is that it provides financial incentives to harm and even kill people. Just ask those people who say they have been victimized by cigarettes, predatory lenders, Volkswagen diesel emissions, Takata airbags, General Motors ignition switches, Trump University, Vioxx, asbestos or other products.

title: Ros All Day, but at Night, Grab the Gin
description: This season of ros now includes a gin. Pink gin, a Victorian-era throwback said to have been first concocted by the Royal Navy, achieves its pale salmon color from the botanicals and bitters used to mellow the spirits strong juniper profile. This English gin, made in pot stills in small batches, gets its name from the Gin Act of 1751, legislation designed to restrict the sale of demon gin to the poor. Consider it for a blushing martini or gimlet, or simply serve it on the rocks with a spritz of lime and just a splash of good tonic: Gin Lane 1751 Victoria Pink Gin, $27.99 from ginlane1751.com.

title: Numberplay: Olympic Strategies, Part 2
description: Great spirits have always encountered violent opposition from mediocre minds, wrote Albert Einstein in 1940. The expression is a terrible clich at this point, but its always intrigued me. What does violent opposition look like? Are only mediocre minds susceptible? And how do these great spirits respond?

title: Belgian Chocolate in a Pudding Cup
description: There has to be a chocolate mousse thats fresh, not frozen, said Johan Halsberghe, who was the chef for the Belgian ambassador in New York. So he decided to do something about it. He uses organic Belgian chocolate for his white- and dark-chocolate mousses, made in Brooklyn and sold fresh in food shops. The dark variety is light-textured and creamy with an excellent balance of bitter and sweet. The white chocolate version, made with gelatin, is a trifle spongier in texture, but also not too sweet. Both are sold in small plastic containers. The mousses can be unmolded for more elegant service by running a knife around the inside of the cup and inverting it with a bit of force onto a plate: Johan Fresh Chocolate Mousse, dark, 2.47 ounces; white, 2.82 ounces, each $3.99 at Brooklyn Fare, 431 West 37th Street, 212-216-9700, brooklynfare.com.

title: Airbnb for Business Travelers: More Wi-Fi, Fewer Hosts in Towels
description: Whether traveling for business or pleasure, Tad Milbourn, chief executive of the San Francisco technology start-up Payable, stays at an Airbnb property whenever possible.

title: Cracking Eggs and Taking Names
description: The chef Eric Ripert will discuss his childhood in the south of France and his early years working in Paris as recounted in his new memoir, 32 Yolks: From My Mothers Table to Working the Line, at the Museum of Food and Drink. Signed copies of the book will be sold afterward: 32 Yolks, a Conversation With Eric Ripert, Aug. 30, 6:30 to 8 p.m., $35, Museum of Food and Drink, 62 Bayard Street (Lorimer Street), Williamsburg, Brooklyn, mofad.org.

title: Gabby Douglas Defends Herself Against the Wrath of Social Media
description: Gabby Douglas is a decorated Olympic gymnast who will bring home a gold medal from Rio. But her performance has not been enough to appease some observers on the internet.

title: President of Zambia, Edgar Lungu, Wins Narrow Victory as Rival Demands Recount
description: JOHANNESBURG  President Edgar Lungu of Zambia eked out a victory in last Thursdays elections, according to official results announced Monday afternoon. But his main rival disputed the impartiality of election officials and demanded a recount.

title: What You Should Watch: Brooklyn and Olympic Highlights
description: Welcome to Watching, The New York Timess what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. You can browse previous guides here, and to receive recommendations straight to your inbox, sign up here. Stay tuned for our coming website.

title: Blurred Lines in Pursuing Insider Trading Cases
description: Insider trading can be prosecuted by the Justice Department, and it can be pursued in a civil enforcement action by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The S.E.C. used to handle the bulk of these cases, but lately it seems that more cases result in criminal charges along with a parallel lawsuit.

title: Matches or Lighter Fluid: Which Is Better for the Environment?
description: Q. Is it environmentally better to use safety matches or a fuel-filled lighter to start a fire while camping?

title: Suicide Squad Soundtrack, Like the Movie, Opens at No. 1
description: Suicide Squad, the latest gang-of-superheroes blockbuster film, has been ruling the box office since it came out two weekends ago. Now its soundtrack is a hit as well, opening at No. 1 on Billboards album chart with 128,000 album sales and 32.6 million streams in the United States, according to Nielsen.

title: Showtime at the Muse dOrsay: Watching Varnish Dry
description: PARIS  Its showtime at the Muse dOrsay  the electric moment when visitors pause in the grand public art galleries here, all to watch varnish dry.

title: Louisiana Floods Lead to 8 Deaths
description: Rescuers navigated submerged streets and neighborhoods in parts of southern Louisiana on Monday, plucking people to safer ground and trying to stay ahead of the rain-swollen waterways spilling over into new areas.

title: Rio Has Never Felt So Safe. But What Happens After the Games?
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Portugals education minister was robbed at knife point. So was the chief of security for the opening ceremony as he left Olympic Stadium. A police officer was killed when his vehicle was sprayed with gunfire, and an Olympics bus carrying journalists was attacked by people throwing rocks.

title: Times Insider Photo Challenge: Caption This!
description: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. Occasionally we have some fun.

title: The 90s-Minimalist Revival to End Them All
description: No matter where you look, the 90s, suddenly, are back  with slip dresses, crop tops and dark lipstick. Now comes Calvin Kleins new all-cashmere offering, a 23-style range of sumptous fabric in black, white and stone gray. There are ribbed turtlenecks and blanket scarves, simple pullovers, leggings and lightweight T-shirts. Best of all, the pieces come in a variety of cashmere weights  so they will take you from early fall straight through to the depths of winter.

title: Their Hair Fell Out. Should the F.D.A. Have the Power to Act?
description: WASHINGTON  When the Los Angeles hairstylist Chaz Dean pitched his almond mint and lavender-scented hair care products  endorsed by celebrities like Brooke Shields and Alyssa Milano  he sold millions. But his formula got an unexpected result: itching, rashes, even hair loss in large clumps, in both adults and children.

title: China Faces a Surge in Cardiovascular Disease, Study Finds
description: BEIJING  High blood pressure and obesity are becoming increasingly common in China, contributing to an epidemic of cardiovascular disease that will probably worsen over the next two decades, according to a study published on Monday.

title: Times Readers Recommend Their Favorite Thrillers
description: When we published our special Summer Thrills issue last month, we asked you to name your favorite thrillers on our Facebook page. Here are just some of the most enthusiastic and considered answers you gave us:

title: Usain Bolt: Faster Than a Camera Shot, Almost
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, the Times sports reporter Ken Belson chats with the Times photographers Doug Mills and Chang W. Lee about the mechanics of photographing Usain Bolt and the 100-meter dash.

title: Russia and Ukraine Tensions Rise Over a Raid That May Not Have Happened
description: MOSCOW  Germanys foreign minister, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, urged Moscow on Monday to reduce tensions with Ukraine after what Russian officials said was a border skirmish with Ukrainian forces in which two Russian soldiers died.

title: Upset by Brexit, Some British Jews Look to Germany
description: LONDON  Until Britain voted to leave the European Union, Philip Levine never thought deeply about his Jewish heritage.

title: Yes, Medicine Can Use Virtual Reality, Emphasis on Reality
description: Youd think medicine would be the last holdout against virtual reality. After all, the body is the body  solid flesh, no faking it, no escaping it. We may turn books into bytes, create driverless cars and soldierless wars; but even patched with plastic and titanium and attached to external electric circuits, the body is still where medicine does business.

title: In the U.S., VW Owners Get Cash. In Europe, They Get Plastic Tubes.
description: FRANKFURT  Volkswagen owners in the United States will receive about $20,000 per car as compensation for the companys diesel deception. Volkswagen owners in Europe at most get a software update and a short length of plastic tubing.

title: In the 70s, She Motorcycled Around the World. Today, Shes Fashions Unlikely New Muse.
description: Anne-France Dautheville is 28 in 1972, astride a Moto Guzzi 750 motorcycle on the way to Tehran, traveling alone cross-continent. Shes flagged down by a car, and three children get out to ask Dautheville about herself, her life and her eye makeup. (I always made up my eyes, she recalls.) Then they start driving faster than me. Ten kilometers later, they stop on the side of the road, and they stop me again. I ask, Is there something you forgot? And they say, Well, we were wondering, are you a girl or are you a boy? Dautheville throws back her head and roars with laughter.

title: Biden Warns Trump Is Risk to U.S. Security
description: SCRANTON, Pa.  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. warned on Monday that Donald J. Trump, even as a candidate, had elevated the dangers confronting American allies and military personnel overseas.

title: How Elections Are Rigged
description: To the Editor:

title: Zika and the Military
description: To the Editor:

title: Bombing of Doctors Without Borders Hospital in Yemen Kills at Least 15
description: SANA, Yemen  At least 15 people were killed on Monday in northern Yemen when warplanes bombed a hospital supported by Doctors Without Borders, according to hospital and local health ministry officials.

title: Puerto Rico Celebrates First Gold Medal
description: The tennis player Mnica Puig became a hero for Puerto Rico when she took home the commonwealths first gold medal in womens singles on Saturday. The win spurred celebrations across the island.

title: Letters to the Editor and Online Comments
description: To the Editor:

title: Nancy Pelosi, on G.O.P. Protecting the Rich
description: To the Editor:

title: When Judges, Not Juries, Decide Guilt
description: To the Editor:

title: Peter Thiel: The Online Privacy Debate Wont End With Gawker
description: Last month, I spoke at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland because I believe our country is on the wrong track, and we need to solve real problems instead of fighting fake culture wars. Im glad that an arena full of Republicans stood up to applaud when I said I was proud to be gay, because gay pride shouldnt be a partisan issue. All people deserve respect, and nobodys sexuality should be made a public fixation.

title: Bill Shine Steps Out From Behind the Scenes to Lead Fox News
description: Bill Shine, the newly appointed co-president of Fox News, commutes two hours every morning from Long Island to Midtown Manhattan, leaving his house so early that, as he tells colleagues, the other guys on the train all have Sheetrock on their boots.

title: Lyft Declined G.M. Takeover Effort, but Rivals Could Force Its Hand
description: Lyft, the No. 2 American ride-hailing service, recently rebuffed takeover interest from General Motors, its 9 percent owner, according to the news service The Information. There are reasons for Lyft to steer clear of Detroit, despite a shared vision for autonomous cars. But cash-flush rivals could still force the Silicon Valley start-up into G.M.s lane.

title: Trump Campaign and Its Chief, Paul Manafort, Try to Move Past Ukraine Report
description: The Trump campaign was on the defensive on Monday after a New York Times report revealed that its chairman, Paul Manafort, was designated to receive $12.7 million in undisclosed and potentially illegal cash payments from a pro-Russian political party in Ukraine.

title: Lies, Lying Liars, and Donald Trump
description: So, theres a new conservative take on whos to blame for Donald Trump  and the answer, it turns out, is liberal commentators, and me in particular. Yep, by denouncing the dishonesty of people like Mitt Romney, I was crying wolf, so that voters paid no attention to warnings about Trump.

title: From Bare Knuckles to Idealism in Bobby Kennedy: The Making of a Liberal Icon
description: Reading about the life and death of Robert F. Kennedy, the reader cant help but be reminded of the striking parallels between the late 1960s and today  polarized politics, racial tensions and growing social anxiety and tumult. Its also impossible not to think about the vast gulf between the idealistic hopes Kennedy inspired among his young followers, and the fear and cynicism that have marked this years presidential campaign.

title: From False Alarm to Panic: Inside Kennedy Airports Chaotic Night
description: Jennifer Rosen was scheduled to depart Kennedy International Airport on an 8:55 p.m. flight to San Francisco but instead found herself stuck at Gate C62 in Terminal 2. It was the typical misery of summer airline travel  or so it seemed.

title: Under Pressure Over Aleppo Siege, Russia Hints at Seeking Deal With U.S.
description: Acknowledging an unfolding disaster in Syrias besieged city of Aleppo, where roughly two million people are trapped, Russia conceded on Monday that daily three-hour halts in fighting that it had proposed last week were insufficient, possibly opening the door to longer pauses.

title: Not Forgotten: Tefilo Stevenson, Boxer Who Chose Country Over Wealth
description: Even after three gold medals, country came before glory for Tefilo Stevenson.

title: Genetics and Running
description: To the Editor:

title: Pippa Middleton Goes Out on Her Own. But Shes Not Alone.
description: At first glance, it seemed to have the all the makings of a Jane Austen novel: wholesome second daughter of a country family that has come up in the world gets swept away by wealthy, dashing suitor after whirlwind romance and years of enduring idle gossip around her broken courtships and social aspirations, not to mention poisonous comparisons with a dazzling older sister.

title: Review: Elvis Lives! (And Not Just in Your Head)
description: Thinking people everywhere know that Elvis Presley is alive. We just disagree on the details, like where and how, and what his hair looks like these days. All of us, though, are probably going to be disappointed in the rather bland possibility presented in Elvis Lives!, a Tuesday night movie on AXS TV.

title: Devotion to the Stage, and to a Newborn
description: Recently, I went a whole month without seeing a play. Five weeks, actually. For most people, this is a profound nonevent. For me, it was a marvel. And also sort of a problem. I was a drama-besotted adolescent who became a college actress who became a theater critic. I dont really know what to do with myself if Im not spending a lot of my week sitting in a creaking plush seat, staring up at a stage.

title: Review: In Quiet, Comfort, a Mattress Becomes the Audiences Magic Carpet
description: New York may be a world capital, but it can feel provincial when it comes to non-English-speaking theater. Oh, we see Chekhov and Ibsen and indulge in the occasional French comedy, but those works tend to be decades or centuries old. The situation is dire for playwrights who happen to be alive.

title: Giant Coral Reef in Protected Area Shows New Signs of Life
description: In 2003, researchers declared Coral Castles dead.

title: A Better (Smelly) Mosquito Trap, but With Caveats
description: A new type of mosquito trap running on solar electricity and using human odor as bait has cut mosquito populations by 70 percent in a test on a malaria-ridden island in Kenya, according to a new study.

title: Introducing Little-Known High Jewelry Designers
description: With rare stones, exquisite craftsmanship and one-of-a-kind settings, these three talents excel in strong statements that are deeply personal.

title: The Psychiatric Question: Is It Fair to Analyze Donald Trump From Afar?
description: In the midst of a deeply divisive presidential campaign, more than 1,000 psychiatrists declared the Republican candidate unfit for the office, citing severe personality defects, including paranoia, a grandiose manner and a Godlike self-image. One doctor called him a dangerous lunatic.

title: U.S. Presidential Race, Rio Olympics, Milwaukee: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Scientists Just Say No to Chemtrails Conspiracy Theory
description: Conspiracy theories can be stubborn, particularly in the echo chamber of the internet.

title: Higher Fees Increase Law Firm Revenue by 4.1 Percent
description: An increase in revenue for law firms in the first half of this year came largely from higher lawyer billing rates rather than greater demand for services, according to Citi Private Banks quarterly report on the legal industry.

title: For Olympic Diving, Green Water Is Gone, if Not the Mystery
description: To the bafflement of Olympic athletes and watchers, the water in the pool used for diving competitions, azure blue on Monday last week, mysteriously turned emerald green and stayed that way for days.

title: Abenomics and the Single Arrow
description: Some disappointing numbers on Japanese GDP, and the usual suspects are out there denouncing Abenomics and calling for structural reform, the universal elixir. And the evidence that structural reform is the answer is

title: Waiting 8 Days in the Heat for a Career in Carpentry
description: Dawn on Monday began the eighth consecutive day that Glenn Hobbesland stood on the baking sidewalk in the West Village of Manhattan. There, for the past week of searing heat, he had slept in a pup tent pitched on the pavement to be among the first in a line of several hundred people seeking to join the carpenters union.

title: As Canada Moves to Legalize Marijuana, Shop Owners Ask: Why Wait?
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The Cannabis Culture Lounge has everything a pothead might need to feel right at home: $3 marijuana buds, bongs for rent, bags of Skittles and Doritos for sale, and black leather couches where customers can recline in zoned-out contemplation in a pungent haze. Never mind that it is all technically prohibited by Canadian law.

title: Michel Richard, Acclaimed Chef at Citronelle, Dies at 68
description: Michel Richard, a French-born chef whose French-Californian hybrid Citrus was one of the top restaurants in Los Angeles for more than a decade, and who gave Washington a major claim to be a serious dining city after he opened Citronelle there in 1993, died on Saturday in Washington. He was 68.

title: Pennsylvanias Attorney General Is Convicted on All Counts
description: NORRISTOWN, Pa.  She was a rising Democratic star. She was the first in her party to be elected state attorney general. She was one of the most powerful women in Pennsylvania.

title: Choo Choo Coleman, a Catcher With the Original, Woeful Mets, Dies
description: Choo Choo Coleman, a catcher for the Mets during their comically dismal early seasons  and a fond, chuckle-inducing memory for Mets fans  died on Monday in Orangeburg, S.C.

title: This Great-Grandmother Coaches an Olympic Champion. Now Let Her By.
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The great-grandmother who could pass as Barbara Bushs kid sister waded through the stands at Olympic Stadium on Sunday night, trying to get close enough to congratulate the South African runner Wayde van Niekerk, who had just captured the gold medal in the 400 meters and broken one of the oldest world records in mens track and field.

title: 15 Guantnamo Detainees Are Sent to Emirates in Largest Obama-Era Transfer
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon said on Monday that it had sent 15 Guantnamo detainees to the United Arab Emirates in the largest single transfer of the Obama administration. The move eliminated a fifth of the wartime prisons remaining population, which dropped to 61.

title: The Triangle
Will Simone Manuel Inspire More Black Children to Swim?
description: When Kendall Williams let her daughter, Bailey, paddle happily in a swimming class on the South Side of Chicago as a preschooler, she noticed the other parents seemed anxious.

title: Concerns About Mayor de Blasios Response After Imam and Assistant Are Killed
description: In the hours after an imam and his assistant were shot dead on a Queens street on Saturday, several elected officials rushed to the scene.

title: An Olympic Event Where 1st Prize Is the Chance to Lose Billions
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Behind the scenes of the Olympic matchups and rivalries that draw large crowds here, there is stealth competition taking place in the hallways and hotels of this beach town worth tens of billions of dollars. It is a bidding war that could rival the most ferocious auction on Wall Street.

title: Memorial in Alabama Will Honor Victims of Lynching
description: One day in October 1910, a mob of white people in Montgomery, Ala., tried to seize and lynch several black men who were being held in a downtown jail on suspicion of interracial sexual relations.

title: Germany Eliminates U.S. Womens Field Hockey in a Quarterfinal
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  After one period of their field hockey quarterfinal on Monday, the United States women found themselves trailing, 2-0, to Germany in the searing heat and facing their first crisis in what had been a joy ride of a tournament.

title: Brooklyn Man Charged With Killing Imam and Assistant Near Mosque
description: Two days after an imam and his assistant were gunned down after afternoon prayers in Queens, the police said late Monday that a man they had in custody had been charged in the killings.

title: Delays Persist in Shuttering D.C. Homeless Shelter That Few Consider Livable
description: WASHINGTON  The homeless woman was shuffling down a faded yellow hallway in the D.C. General Family Shelter  a former city-run hospital where gurneys still sit askew, lights flicker and faded medical posters decorate the walls  when she caught the eye of a well-dressed official touring the building.

title: Affordable Housing Rules Apply to Bronx Complex, but Not One in Manhattan
description: The New York City Planning Commission on Monday declined to impose a key plank of Mayor Bill de Blasios affordable housing plan on a boutique condominium proposed for Manhattan.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Just as we won the Cold War, in part, by exposing the evils of communism and the virtues of free markets, so too must we take on the ideology of radical Islam.

title: Gerald Grosvenor, British Duke and Billionaire, Dies at 64
description: Gerald Grosvenor was a 16-year-old student at Harrow when reporters arrived at the school to inform him that his uncle had just died, which meant that Gerald was suddenly an honorary earl and that his father had unexpectedly inherited the title of Duke of Westminster.

title: Bisque or Gazpacho
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  Lynn Lempel has established herself as one of the queens of early-week crossword puzzle making as, with a few exceptions, she has focused her constructing on Monday and Tuesday themed puzzles. And, without exception, her puzzles are solid and fun to solve.

title: In Queens, Prayers for Killed Imam
description: Mourners at the funeral for Imam Alauddin Akonjee and his assistant, Thara Miah, described a "true leader."

title: N.F.L. Threatens to Suspend Four Players for Not Cooperating With Steroid Investigation
description: The N.F.L. has threatened to indefinitely suspend four players because they have declined to cooperate with an investigation into a news report that linked them to performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Rookies Chad Green and Aaron Judge Lead Yankees Over Blue Jays
description: The Yankees have swept out the old and welcomed the new, and they received another indication Monday that the future may indeed hold the sort of promise that has been missing most of the season.

title: Ask Well: Is Dementia the Same as Alzheimers Disease?
description: Question:

title: Vaccine Shortage Could Spread African Yellow Fever Outbreak Abroad, Charity Warns
description: A deadly yellow fever epidemic that has afflicted southern and central Africa this year could soon spread worldwide, exacerbated by a severe vaccine shortage, the charity Save the Children warned on Tuesday.

title: Google Duo Makes Video Calling Between Operating Systems Easier
description: Google and Apple have battled each other for years for primacy over mobile users. Apple has proferred its superior devices, like the iPhone. Google has fought back with its Android operating system and a series of mobile apps that are more flexible and compatible with a broader set of devices than Apples apps.

title: Aetna to Pull Back From Public Health Care Exchanges
description: WASHINGTON  In a blow to President Obamas health care law, Aetna, one of the nations major insurers, said Monday that it would sharply reduce its participation in the laws public marketplaces next year.

title: New York City to Pay $4.1 Million to Family of Akai Gurley
description: New York City has agreed to pay more than $4 million to the family of Akai Gurley, the unarmed man killed in a Brooklyn housing project in 2014 by a police officer on patrol, according to a lawyer for Mr. Gurleys family.

title: Corrections: August 16, 2016
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Whats on TV Tuesday: The Big Lebowski and Elvis Lives!
description: All hail His Dudeness: Jeff Bridges still resonates as the Coen brothers stoner bowler in The Big Lebowski. Simone Biles and Aly Raisman take to the floor at the Rio Olympics. And the Sharknado people imagine what might have been in Elvis Lives!

title: Mets Stumble Against Lowly Diamondbacks, Again
description: PHOENIX  Given their 59-59 record, the Mets have clearly had trouble winning this season. But theres a concerning trend in the manner in which they have been defeated: They struggle against losing teams.

title: Uninhibited Chinese Swimmer, Discussing Her Period, Shatters Another Barrier
description: BEIJING  The uninhibited Fu Yuanhui, the Chinese swimmer beloved for her over-the-top expressions, has made waves once again. On Saturday night in Rio, she freely discussed having her period while competing in the Olympics, breaking what has long been a taboo among female athletes. The video of her poolside interview quickly went viral.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | temperament
description: temperament  \tem-p(-)r-mnt, -pr-mnt\  noun

title: Uplifting, and Deflating
description: At the Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, another day of surprise victories, inspirational efforts and disheartening defeats.

title: Bobby Hutcherson, Vibraphonist With Coloristic Range of Sound, Dies at 75
description: Bobby Hutcherson, one of the most admired and accomplished vibraphonists in jazz, died on Monday at his home in Montara, Calif. He was 75.

title: Apples Emoji Gun Control
description: Cambridge, Mass.  This month, Apple previewed some changes to its next generation of iPhones and iPads with the promise that all the things you love to do are more expressive, more dynamic and more fun than ever. That especially includes emojis, those little icons that, according to one study, 92 percent of the online population now make part of their everyday communication.

title: From California, a Better Way to Retire
description: At any given moment, about half of the private-sector employees in the United States  some 60 million people  do not have any type of employer-sponsored retirement plan. The result is a growing American underclass, in which a third of current retirees live almost entirely on Social Security and fully half of future retirees will face reduced standards of living. Worse, the coverage gap has long proved intractable, with Congress and the financial industry unable or unwilling to design or support truly simple and low-cost retirement savings plans.

title: Mr. Trumps Foreign Policy Confusions
description: Donald Trumps speech on Monday was advertised as an attempt to redirect his campaign from a series of blunders to a more serious discussion of foreign policy, starting with combating global terrorism. As such, it marked another test of his readiness to lead. It did not go well.

title: Who Will Watch the Watch List?
description: New Haven  When a police officer pulled over Peter Santilli last December in Newtown, Ohio, it seemed like a routine traffic stop. But when the officer ran his data in the law enforcement database, Mr. Santillis name came up as a match on a terrorist watch list. The cop pulled out his weapon immediately, Mr. Santilli said, and told him to put his hands up.

title: The Shadow of Crime in City Parks
description: A blogger who writes about New York City parks looked at some crime statistics recently and found an uptick. For the nine months ending in March, there were 417 major crimes (like murder, rape, robbery and assault) in about 1,000 of the citys biggest parks. That is up 23 percent from the 340 crimes reported in the same period last year.

title: Picture Prompt | Self-Driving Cars
description: Do you think self-driving cars are a good idea?

title: Is Terrorism Getting Worse? In the West, Yes. In the World, No.
description: If it feels as if terrorism deaths are rising in the West, its because they are. Yet the numbers remain relatively small, and globally, deaths from terrorism appear to be declining, not rising.

title: How Do Olympians Stay So Driven?
Hearing Music in Photos of Jazz Giants
description: A new book features Ted Williamss photos of the jazz world, a record of a life spent listening through his camera.

title: Hearing Music in Photos of Jazz Giants
description: A good jazz photograph tells its story musically as much as visually. More than images of rock, classical or hip-hop musicians, jazz images, like those of Ted Williams, who studied saxophone and clarinet before picking up the camera after World War II, seem to capture the intangible essence of a thought being transformed into sound.

title: The Easiest Way to Get Rid of Racism? Just Redefine It.
description: On its face, inviting a former grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan onto your radio show is a risky proposition with very little upside. The situation gets even more precarious when youre inviting this ex-wizard to dole out opinions on race. But these are wild times were living in, which is why David Duke  who has emerged as a top cheerleader for the Republican presidential nominee, Donald J. Trump  appeared on N.P.R.s Morning Edition two weeks ago and defended the candidate from charges of racism.

title: On Delta, All-Suite Business Class Flights
description: Suites in the skies  airline seats with doors that slide shut to give passengers total privacy  have become de rigueur in international first class: Emirates and Singapore Airlines are two of the carriers that offer them on long-haul flights. But an all-suite business class? It has yet to be heard of, according to Delta Air Lines, and the carrier wants to be the first in the industry to change that with the fall 2017 debut of the Delta One suite in its Delta One business-class category.

title: Anthony Weiner Thinks Hes Pretty Good at Giving Advice
description: What is your job now? I dont have one, really. Ive got a consulting company with a handful of clients  a couple of nonprofits, a universe of businesses and executives whose instincts are good. Sometimes they just want to kibitz.

title: Flints Water Crisis and the Troublemaker Scientist
description: Near the railroad tracks on the outskirts of Flint, Mich., there is an old pump house, the walls of which have long served as a kind of communal billboard. The Block, people call it. People paint messages there  birthday wishes, memorials for the dead. In January, after Gov. Rick Snyder declared a state of emergency in response to Flints water crisis, a new message appeared, addressed implicitly to Snyder but also to the world: YOU WANT OUR TRUST??? WE WANT VA TECH!!! In the history of political graffiti, We want Va. Tech may sound like one of the least stirring demands ever spray-painted on a wall, but in the context of Flint, it was charged with the emotion and meaning of a rallying cry.

title: Summertime, and the Revivals in London are Breezy
description: LONDON  When youre approaching a monumental landmark, its usually a good idea to leave the awe at home. That would seem to be the attitude of the creative teams behind four disarmingly relaxed and very enjoyable revivals of watershed musicals here this summer. They are shows that in their original incarnations caused such excitement that ever after they have inspired trepidation, agitation and extreme self-consciousness among those who revisit them.

title: How to Get the Most out of Visiting World-Famous Sites
description: If youre visiting Florence, Italy, youve got to see the world-famous Uffizi Gallery. But why? Because thats what one does in Florence? Because you feel compelled to post a selfie in front of Botticellis Birth of Venus?

title: Early Voting Limits Donald Trumps Time to Turn Campaign Around
description: Advisers to Donald J. Trump keep reassuring Republicans that there is still plenty of time to rescue his candidacy  nearly three months to counter Hillary Clintons vast operation in swing states and get Mr. Trump on message.

title: Britains Church Bell Ringers Dont Limit Themselves to Sunday Services
description: Some Britons love ringing church bells so much that they think it ought to be an Olympic sport.

title: Feeling Cornered, Coal Industry Borrows From Tobacco Playbook, Activists Say
description: Greg Zimmerman, an environmental activist, was scrolling through the website of a coal industry association when he came across a presentation that startled him: Survival Is Victory: Lessons From the Tobacco Wars.

title: Taking Summer School to Get Ahead, Not Catch Up
description: GILL, Mass.  Chase Pellegrini de Paur didnt flunk math, and he is not trying to hone his study skills. The 15-year-old honor-roll student nevertheless spent six weeks this summer studying geometry at the prestigious Northfield Mount Hermon boarding school here.

title: Evictions by Armed Men Rattle a Mexican Tourist Paradise
description: TULUM, Mexico  By the time Renaud Jacquet arrived at his compound of rental beach villas, invaders were crawling all over the place.

title: MTV Classic Is Nostalgia for Millennials. But Do They Want TV?
description: VH1 Classic is dead. This month, it was reborn as MTV Classic, a channel focusing on music videos and shows from the 80s to the aughts. The nostalgia baton has officially been passed to the millennials.

title: In the Brazilian Rain Forest, a White Elephant, a Big One
description: MANAUS, Brazil  Our tale takes metaphorical root in the early 1880s and the fevered imaginings of rubber barons. Sitting by the vast Amazon River, bewitched by pink river dolphins and torrential downpours, surrounded by rain forest, these men hungered for a legacy worthy of kings.

title: Article of the Day | A Visual History of Which Countries Have Dominated the Summer Olympics
description: Article: A Visual History of Which CountriesHave Dominated the Summer Olympics

title: Nobel Laureate Joseph Stiglitz Says the Euro Needs Big Reform
description: THE EUROHow a Common Currency Threatens the Future of EuropeBy Joseph E. Stiglitz416 pp. W. W. Norton & Company. $28.95.

title: The E.U. Is in Crisis. Two Economists Disagree on Why.
description: SLIPPERY SLOPEEuropes Troubled FutureBy Giles Merritt270 pp. Oxford University Press. $29.95.

title: Inside My Head Im a Girl: Three Ways of Growing Up Gay
description: BOY ERASED (Riverhead, $27), a memoir by the debut author Garrard Conley, recounts a hellish tutelage under John Smid, the director of a so-called ex-gay therapy group called Love in Action. The son of a Baptist preacher in a small, evangelical Ozarks community, Conley is outed and at 19 enters treatment at the programs grim facility in Memphis, earnestly hoping to cure himself. With its penchant for whiteboards and workbooks, Love in Action has the flavor of a low-budget corporate retreat and all the hallmarks of a cult. We had to be willing to undergo extreme changes, Conley writes, leave people behind who were harmful to our development, who reminded us of the past.

title: Olympics, Donald Trump, Louisiana: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Somali Forces, Backed by U.S., Kill Shabab Militants in Raid
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  United States forces assisted Somali commandos in killing several members of the Shabab militant group in an attack last week, an American military spokesman said on Tuesday, but it was not clear whether any high-level operatives had been eliminated.

title: The Olympics, Where Winning Gold Can Mean Losing Billions
description: Why does anyone want the Olympics in their home city? The last time the Games were profitable was in Los Angeles in 1984  that is more than 30 years ago. But for whatever reason, government officials, businessmen and bankers are in a bidding war for the 2024 Summer Games that could rival anything seen on Wall Street. Some are competing on costs, but potential losses are a major concern  is it all a poisoned chalice?

title: What a Clinton Landslide Map Would Look Like, and How Trump Could Still Rally
description: Each week, Nate Cohn, The Upshots elections analyst, based in Washington, and Toni Monkovic, an Upshot editor in New York, discuss the 2016 race and post a lightly edited transcript of their written exchange.

title: Liz Cheney Faces Wyoming Primary in Bid to Return to Washington
description: Will a Cheney be returning to power in Washington? Liz Cheney, that is, a daughter of Dick Cheney, the former vice president, and the favorite in Tuesdays crowded Republican primary for Wyomings at-large House seat.

title: Uncovering Gay History in San Francisco
description: Osento, a Japanese bathhouse on Valencia Street in San Francisco, is long gone, closed now for nearly a decade. I could have used a soak, though: It was an uncommonly hot and muggy day in the city, and Id been walking its streets for hours.

title: Hoy en Nueva York: La Habana en Harlem
description: Actualizado, 11:25 a.m.

title: New York Today: Havana in Harlem
description: Updated, 11:24 a.m.

title: The Umbrella Movement Fights Back
description: HONG KONG  The run-up to the Sept. 4 election for Legislative Council is getting tense, and the governments of both Hong Kong and Beijing are watching with keen interest. For the first time, a crop of fresh-faced candidates who cut their political teeth during the pro-democracy Umbrella Movement in 2014 are hoping to bring to the lawmaking body their battle to emancipate Hong Kong from Beijings increasingly authoritarian control.

title: How Do You Tell a Better Story in Sports?
description: The modern N.B.A. era began in the 1980s with two made-to-order if only half-true narratives. The rivalry between Larry Bird and Magic Johnson was transmitted to the public through sportswriters who typecast Bird as the white country bumpkin who gritted his way to excellence and Johnson as the black, always-smiling savant who whipped up his God-given talents into the best show on the hardwood. The cities of Boston (parochial and solemn) and Los Angeles (flashy and morally suspect) were featured in supporting roles that echoed the best and worst traits of the main characters. The reality behind Bird versus Magic was mostly irrelevant. What mattered was that the choice you were supposed to make between them was laid out as simple-mindedly as possible.

title: After Lawsuit, New Jersey Allows Driver to Get 8THEIST License Plate
description: Drivers in New Jersey will be able to request vanity license plates that reference their belief in atheism after the states Motor Vehicle Commission settled a lawsuit this month filed by a woman whose request for a license plate that said 8THEIST was rejected almost three years ago.

title: Not Forgotten: Babe Ruth, the Slugger Who Went From Boyhood Chaos to Baseball Stardom
description: Before Babe Ruth tantalized fans with hundreds of home runs he had to survive a tough childhood in an orphanage.

title: Stranded Indian Elephant Dies of Heart Attack, Ending a Wretched Journey
description: NEW DELHI  A wild Indian elephant that attracted worldwide attention after being swept hundreds of miles down a flood-swollen river into Bangladesh died on Tuesday of a heart attack, Bangladeshi officials said.

title: Russia Sends Bombers to Syria Using Base in Iran
description: MOSCOW  Russia launched a fleet of bombers bound for Syria on Tuesday from an Iranian air base, becoming the first foreign military to operate from Irans soil since at least World War II.

title: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 7 | On In Hillary Clintons Nomination, Women See a Collective Step Up
description: As in every other week of this years Summer Reading Contest, Week 7 attracted a record number of entries  1,101  as teenagers around the world took on everything from Election 2016 and the role of the police in America to Snapchat, cursive, lionfish and flossing.

title: Why Shes Distrusted
description: How did Hillary Clinton lose Americans trust? Stanley Greenberg, a top Democratic campaign strategist, describes how he addressed the trust issue for another Clinton: Bill. We also speak with Lissa CQ Muscatine, a longtime adviser for Hillary Clinton, and Mark Landler, a White House correspondent for The Times.

title: Americans Dont Trust Her. But Why?
description: A Clinton with a trust problem. Weve seen that before. It was 1992, and doubts about Bill Clintons integrity, stoked by his marital infidelities and avoidance of the Vietnam War, were the biggest threat to his presidential campaign. Stanley Greenberg, a top Democratic campaign strategist, devised a secret plan to turn around the candidates reputation for dishonesty.

title: Yayoi Kusama to Be the Focus of a Touring Museum Show
description: Its strange to think about taking a room-sized, mirror-lined art installation designed to be a dazzlingly immersive and thoroughly self-contained aesthetic experience and putting it under the same roof as five other versions of the artwork. But thats the idea at the heart of a 2017 survey of the Japanese ultra-Pop artist Yayoi Kusama, which will host six of her attention-grabbing infinity mirror rooms alongside sculptures, paintings and drawings from her six-decade career.

title: How House Republicans May Survive Donald Trump
description: No presidential candidate in modern history has behaved like Donald J. Trump. And that distinction, paradoxically, might be enough for Republicans in the House of Representatives to keep their majority in November.

title: Capital Punishment Is Not Israels Answer to Terrorism
description: TEL AVIV  For decades, Israel has prided itself on its anti death-penalty stance. But in the past year, calls for the use of capital punishment have started to rise again, heightened by the trial of Elor Azaria, a sergeant in the Israel Defense Forces. Sergeant Azaria has been charged with manslaughter for killing Abdel Fattah al-Sharif, a Palestinian. Mr. Sharif had stabbed an Israeli soldier, and been shot and wounded by the soldiers colleagues. In a video of the event, he can be seen lying supine and still for several minutes before Sergeant Azaria calmly points the gun at his head and fires.

title: The Demise of a Prison Lord
description: On July 18, Guatemalas most infamous  and powerful  prisoner, Byron Lima Oliva, was shot to death in the Pavn prison outside Guatemala City. While it was a fellow prisoner who, the authorities said, put two bullets in Mr. Limas head, in all likelihood the intellectual authors of the killing hail from the highest echelons of the state and the moneyed elite. In Guatemala, it is often impossible to tell where the state ends and the underworld begins.

title: On Tenant Blacklist, Errors and Renters With Little Recourse
description: After two years of being homeless, napping in stores open all night and more recently staying in a convent in Harlem, Margot Miller found out in March that her luck was about to change: She had qualified for an apartment for low-income older adults.

title: I Tracked and Tried to Outsmart Hamilton Scalpers  With 341 Lines of Code
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Tiff Fehr, an assistant interactive editor and senior software engineer at The Times, describes how she estimated the astronomical profits made by those scalping tickets for the Broadway musical Hamilton.

title: After His Show Is Canceled, Larry Wilmore Thanks Fans and Comedy Central
description: In his first appearance on The Nightly Show since Comedy Central said that it had canceled the program, the host Larry Wilmore introduced himself to his viewers on Monday night and asked: Um, so, how was your day?

title: The Anatomy of a Dive Across the Finish Line
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Allyson Felix, a graceful and enduring American sprinter, has earned a lot of loyalty from track and field fans worldwide through the years.

title: Google Duo Challenges FaceTime
description: Google and Apple dominate the mobile world. Now the issue for those companies is how to get people to switch from Apples mobile ecosystem to Googles or vice versa.

title: How to Set Up a Mass Email System
description: Q. Are there any bulk-email programs that are free or low cost? I need a program to send messages to email lists containing 50 to 500 addresses.

title: Puerto Ricos Financial Woes Revive Calls for Independence
