description: Investigators said on Wednesday that they were certain the man charged with first-degree murder in the sidewalk killing of an imam and his assistant in Queens was the assailant, though they concede the motive for the attack remains a mystery.

title: More Big Banks Are Using Arbitration to Bar Customer Lawsuits
description: Big banks are increasingly using the fine print of checking account agreements to restrict their customers ability to settle disputes in court, even though most consumers want to keep their legal options open.

title: Hillary Clinton Twists the Knife in Donald Trumps Tax Proposals
description: Hillary Clinton leaned into her plans to raise taxes on the wealthiest Americans on Wednesday, denouncing Donald J. Trumps tax proposals as a boondoggle for billionaires.

title: Egypt Suspends 8 Female TV Anchors, Saying They Are Overweight
description: CAIRO  Most Egyptian journalists have had to watch their tongues and tone down their reporting over the past three years to keep their jobs under a military-dominated government. Now, the state is ordering some women working as television anchors to practice a similar restraint with their weight.

title: Hedge Funds Avoided Big Losses Despite Brexit Shock
description: LONDON  In late June, as Britons prepared to go to the polls to vote on the countrys membership in the European Union, about 800 hedge fund managers gathered at the opulent Cavalieri hotel on a hill overlooking Rome for an annual rite.

title: Syrian Government and Russia Are Accused of Using Napalm-Like Bombs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian government aircraft hit the rebel-held Damascus suburb of Daraya with incendiary bombs for the third straight day on Wednesday, according to local council members, who said the weapons were packed with substances akin to napalm.

title: Is Your Lipstick Bad for You?
description: You cant legally buy a drug in the United States that hasnt undergone rigorous testing, mandated by Congress, to prove that its safe and effective. By contrast, that lipstick, shampoo, or deodorant you use every day may have undergone no such testing.

title: South Korean Dream Team Begins Its Quest for a Sweep in Womens Golf
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  It looked like any other major tournament opener in womens golf, with volunteers barking at people to silence their cellphones and caddies lining up the players for their shots. Upon closer inspection, the stark expressions of the players on the practice range and the duct tape covering sponsors names on their clothing served as reminders that the stakes are even higher this week at Reserva de Marapendi.

title: Genetic Tests for a Heart Disorder Mistakenly Find Blacks at Risk
description: Genetic tests for an inherited heart disorder are more likely to have incorrect results in black Americans than in whites, according to a new study that is likely to have implications for other minorities and other diseases, including cancer.

title: Blue Jays J. A. Happ Having Career Year as Majors Top Winner
description: No pitcher has won as many games this season as J. A. Happ of the Toronto Blue Jays. A pitchers record can be misleading, of course, but a pattern emerges with time. For Happ, who improved to 17-3 by beating the Yankees on Wednesday, winning big had not been part of the pattern.

title: U.N. Admits Role in Cholera Epidemic in Haiti
description: For the first time since a cholera epidemic believed to be imported by United Nations peacekeepers began killing thousands of Haitians nearly six years ago, the office of Secretary General Ban Ki-moon has acknowledged that the United Nations played a role in the initial outbreak and that a significant new set of U.N. actions will be needed to respond to the crisis.

title: As Insurers Like Aetna Balk, U.S. Makes New Push to Bolster Health Care Act
description: WASHINGTON  Facing high-profile withdrawals from online insurance exchanges and surging premiums, the Obama administration is preparing a major push to enroll new participants into public marketplaces under the Affordable Care Act.

title: U.N. Wants to Know Why Peacekeepers Did Not Stop Violence in South Sudan
description: Alarmed over attacks that included the rapes and beatings of foreign aid workers by soldiers in South Sudans capital last month, the United Nations secretary general has ordered an inquiry into why the organizations peacekeepers failed to stop the violence, his spokesman said on Wednesday.

title: Community Policing Expands in New York, but Some Question if It Works
description: When Mayor Bill de Blasio introduced the next New York City police commissioner this month, he said he wanted someone who could make neighborhood policing a reality and help ease the distrust that persists between officers and residents in many predominately minority communities, like Far Rockaway in Queens.

title: The Birth of a Nation, Nate Parkers Heralded Film, Is Now Cloaked in Controversy
description: LOS ANGELES  It was supposed to be a corrective to #OscarsSoWhite. The blistering story of a slave revolt that was directed and written by a black artist, Nate Parker, who also stars in the lead role, The Birth of a Nation had been positioned as a balm for an industry long criticized for sidelining minorities.

title: Christie Orders Use of General Fund for Essential Transportation Work
description: With lawmakers in New Jersey at an impasse over transportation funding, Gov. Chris Christie on Wednesday ordered officials to use the states general fund to pay for essential transportation projects until the crisis is resolved.

title: Ernst Neizvestny, a Russian Sculptor Who Clashed With Khrushchev, Dies at 91
description: Ernst Neizvestny, a sculptor whose ventures into modernism put him at odds with the Soviet cultural authorities and led to a memorable confrontation with Nikita S. Khrushchev in 1962, died on Aug. 9 in Stony Brook, N.Y. He was 91.

title: U.S. Basketball Team Muffles Argentines, if Not Their Fervent Fans
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Argentine fans were irrepressible, bouncing up and down and back and forth across the stands, waving flags, imploring their compatriots to jump along, and singing that anyone who did not join the fun was Brazilian.

title: Elaine Thompson Adds the 200 to Her 100 Crown
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Elaine Thompson of Jamaica won the 200 meters to complete a sprint double at the Rio Games.

title: Harry Briggs Jr., a Catalyst for Brown v. Board of Education, Dies at 75
description: Harry Briggs Jr., whose parents originated the pivotal lawsuit that struck down public school segregation in 1954, but whose name was relegated by fate to a forgotten legal footnote, died on Aug. 9 in the Bronx. He was 75.

title: Its So Typical
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  Have you ever stared at a word for so long that it stops looking like that word and starts to look like a completely different word?

title: Coal Burning Causes the Most Air Pollution Deaths in China, Study Finds
description: BEIJING  Burning coal has the worst health impact of any source of air pollution in China and caused 366,000 premature deaths in 2013, Chinese and American researchers said on Thursday.

title: Blue Jay Dance Haiku
description: Dear Diary:

title: Cuomo Moves to Revive a Dormant Housing Aid Program
description: The administration of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has offered developers and union officials a wage subsidy for construction workers in the hopes of reviving a dormant program that has generated thousands of apartments for poor and moderate-income New Yorkers, and saved property owners tens of millions of dollars in property taxes.

title: Who Are the Swimmers Who Were With Ryan Lochte?
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Ryan Lochte is a familiar sports figure, second only to Michael Phelps in renown among American male swimmers.

title: Little Is Medal-Worthy About NBCs Coverage of Foreign Athletes
description: NBCs Summer Games broadcasts should be thought of as an Olympic edition of Americas Got Talent, a 17-day series about a rousingly successful American team tailored to an American audience that is probably happy to watch Americans do fantastically well in Rio de Janeiro.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Fear is a good thing. Fear is going to lead you to take action.

title: Mr. Robot Season 2, Episode 7: Escaping Reality
description: No canned laughter, no Full House theme song, no retro commercials, no ALF cameo  and yet somehow I dont think anyone will complain about a relative lack of narrative boldness in this weeks episode of Mr. Robot. Turns out its not just a 20-minute sojourn in sitcom land for which Elliot Alderson departed from reality this time around. Hes actually been living in a fantasy world all season.

title: Six Years Into Obamas Health Care Law, Who Are the Uninsured?
description: Roughly 20 million more Americans have health insurance now than when President Obamas health care law was passed in 2010. But as Mr. Obama prepares to leave office, there are still about 24 million adults with no coverage, according to a survey by the Commonwealth Fund, a health research group. That translates to an uninsured rate of about 13 percent, down from 20 percent in 2013. Who are the remaining uninsured?

title: Giants Kicker Josh Brown Suspended for Season Opener
description: The Giants Pro Bowl place-kicker Josh Brown was suspended Wednesday under the N.F.L.s personal conduct policy and will miss the opening game of the season against the Dallas Cowboys on Sept. 11. The cause of the one-game suspension, which is without pay, was not specified. Brown, in a statement issued by the team, said he disagreed with the decision by the league.

title: Corrections: August 18, 2016
description: FRONT PAGE

title: After an Injury Scare, Neymar Strikes Back Against Honduras
description: Neymar scored the fastest goal in Olympic history and then added a penalty kick in stoppage time on Wednesday as Brazil beat Honduras, 6-0, for a spot in the gold medal match. Brazil has never won Olympic gold in the sport.

title: Whats on TV Thursday: Unfaithful and Usain Bolt in Rio
description: Baby, its hot outside. Steam up your screen  while basking in air-conditioned comfort  with Unfaithful, Body Heat and Match Point. Usain Bolt, meanwhile, races for another gold in the 200-meter sprint. And Deliverance provides a late-night chill.

title: Bolt Is Back
description: Usain Bolt advanced to the 200-meter final in an effort to win his third straight gold medal in the event, and Brazilian teams had a busy day on the beach and the indoor volleyball courts.

title: Jon Niese Returns to Starting Role, and Mets Return to Losing
description: PHOENIX  There are many reasons the Mets have plodded through the past three weeks. They have endured more injuries. Their offense has remained inadequate. Their pitching has not been sharp, especially at the back end of the rotation.

title: New Miles Davis Boxed Set Features His Quintet at Its Peak
description: The Miles Davis Quintet of the 1960s has long been praised as one of the most advanced small groups in jazz history, and anyone seeking to test the claim can choose from an abundance of evidence: studio albums, concert and club recordings, multi-disc collections. This fall will bring a new addition: Freedom Jazz Dance  The Bootleg Series Vol. 5, a three-CD boxed set.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | superannuated
description: superannuated  \s-pr-an-y-wat-ed\  adjective

title: Highly Personal Portraiture by William Eggleston
description: The portraiture of William Eggleston, whose color photography helped shepherd the medium into the art world, is the exclusive feature of a new exhibit and book.

title: Voting Rights Success? Not So Fast
description: In Texas, Michigan, North Carolina and elsewhere, federal courts in recent months have struck down one discriminatory voting law after another in a series of major victories for voting-rights advocates. Millions of voters, especially minorities who might have otherwise been obstructed by voter-identification requirements or shortened early voting times, will now be able to cast their ballots in the presidential election.

title: What Trump Doesnt Know About Detroit
description: No shortage of critics unleashed their weaponry eight years ago as the federal government intervened to save General Motors and Chrysler when they teetered near bankruptcy. Among the more notable: Mitt Romney, whos well remembered for his 2008 New York Times Op-Ed article, Let Detroit Go Bankrupt.

title: The Courts Begin to Call Out Lawmakers
description: In 1962, in the midst of the civil rights movement, African-American residents of Jackson, Miss., went to court to challenge the racial segregation of the citys five municipal swimming pools, four of which were set aside for whites and one for blacks. When the plaintiffs won, the Jackson City Council responded by closing all the pools. It first claimed a minor water difficulty and later explained that integrated pools would present a safety problem and would be too expensive to operate. No pools, evidently, were preferable to integrated pools.

title: Breaking a Promise to Afghan Translators
description: The nations rancorous debate over immigration policy has greatly diminished the chances of citizenship for a small group of people who have done a great service to the United States and are as deserving as anyone to make it their new home. They are the Afghan interpreters who, at considerable risk to their lives and families, worked for the American government during the war and who remain in mortal danger.

title: A Life of Anxiety and Basketball
description: Just relax, my freshman high school basketball coach said when I forgot to remove my warm-up jacket. It was the middle of the third quarter, score tied. I nodded and bolted toward the court. He yanked my jersey and reminded me to report to the scorers table first.

title: Rare Chance for Mercy on Texas Death Row
description: When it comes to capital punishment, there is not much official mercy to be found in the state of Texas.

title: Do You Care More About a Dog Than a Refugee?
description: Last Thursday, our beloved family dog, Katie, died at the age of 12. She was a gentle giant who respectfully deferred even to any mite-size puppy with a prior claim to a bone. Katie might have won the Nobel Peace Prize if not for her weakness for squirrels.

title: More Older People Are Finding Work, but What Kind?
description: The rules of the job market arent the same for older workers.

title: For William Eggleston, People Are Like Parking Lots
description: Most portrait artists attempt to differentiate the emotional essence of each individual subject. But William Eggleston, a father of color photography whose 1976 Museum of Modern Art exhibit arranged by John Szarkowski helped shepherd the medium into the art world  much to the chagrin of critics  insists that he photographs a person the same way he photographs a parking lot. A new exhibition of his portraiture at the National Portrait Gallery in London, however, belies that assertion by displaying more than 100 highly personal images.

title: Picture Prompt | Policing
description: This is an illustration that went with a recent Opinion piece in The Times.

title: A Danish Wind Turbine Maker Harnesses Data in a Push to Stay Ahead
description: AARHUS, Denmark  A project to install hundreds of wind turbines in the Fosen peninsula area of Norway at one point was shelved as unfeasible. The strong breezes that whip off the sea can shift and swing unpredictably, while the soaring cliffs and steep drop-offs create turbulence that wears out expensive equipment.

title: Can Hillary Manage Her Unruly Coalition?
description: Two adjoining communities  Baltimore City and Baltimore County  show us how hard it is for the Democratic Party to reconcile the interests of its upscale wing with those of its lower-income wing.

title: An Artist Takes an Unflinching Look at the Fight Against Terror
description: LONDON  A new exhibition in London takes an unflinching look at American and British counterterrorism methods after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, with a display of stark photographs taken at the Guantnamo Bay prison in Cuba at its core.

title: One of Rio's Most Jaw-Dropping Athletes Isnt Part of the Olympics
description: Giovanna Petrucci, born and raised in Rio de Janeiro, is the slackline world champion and a regular fixture in Rio's lively beach sports scene.

title: This Rio Phenom Would Be a Lock for a Gold. If There Were One for Slacklining.
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Bouncing in the air above the sand of Ipanema Beach, not an Olympic venue in sight, is one of the most remarkable athletes in the world who has nothing to do with the Rio Games. Her name is Giovanna Petrucci, and her acrobatics rival those of the gymnasts and divers competing across this city.

title: Why Are New York Citys Streets Always Under Construction?
description: The answer, in large measure, lies in what's buried beneath.

title: An Unexpected Route to Williamsburg
description: As a graduate student at the Parsons School of Design, Kendall Huberman shared a small two-bedroom rental in the East Village with a friend, paying more than $1,800 a month.

title: Article of the Day | As Louisiana Floodwaters Recede, the Scope of Disaster Comes Into View
description: Article: As Louisiana Floodwaters Recede, the Scope of Disaster Comes Into View

title: Nazi Gold Train May Not Exist, but That Doesnt Stop Diggers
description: WALBRZYCH, Poland  A group of explorers has begun digging in southwestern Poland in a quixotic search for a buried Nazi train said to be filled with stolen gold, gems and artworks  despite experts doubts that the train even exists.

title: Nigeria Is Freeing Children From Boko Haram, Then Locking Them Up
description: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria  It had been more than a month, and Dije Ali was still locked in a military prison with her seven children.

title: Whats That on Your Bumper? A Hairy Kind of Car Insurance
description: In some parts of West Africa, ponytails arent just hairdos. They dress up taxis, too.

title: The Connoisseur of Pain
description: Within minutes of our first meeting, and more or less in response to my saying good morning, Justin Schmidt began lamenting our cultures lack of insect-based rites of passage. He told me about the Sater-Maw people in northwestern Brazil, who hold a ceremony in which young men slip their hands into large mitts filled with bullet ants, whose stings are so agonizing they can cause temporary paralysis; when initiates pass the test, theyre one step closer to becoming full members of society.

title: Debt. Terror. Politics. To Seattle Millennials, the Future Looks Scary.
description: SEATTLE  Part of Jillian Bosharts life plays out in tidy, ordered lines of JavaScript computer code, and part in a flamboyant whirl of corsets and crinoline. Shes a tech student by day, an enthusiastic burlesque artist and producer by night. Code-mode and show-mode, she calls those different guises.

title: Jacqueline Woodsons Adult Novel Captures 1970s Brooklyn
description: ANOTHER BROOKLYNBy Jacqueline Woodson175 pp. Amistad/HarperCollins Publishers. $22.99.

title: Theres a Little Bit of Narcissism in Us All. Kristin Dombek Explains Why.
description: THE SELFISHNESS OF OTHERSAn Essay on the Fear of NarcissismBy Kristin Dombek150 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. Paper, $13.

title: Terry McMillan: By the Book
description: The author of Waiting to Exhale and, most recently, I Almost Forgot About You doesnt like to read espionage, science fiction or romance novels. I either know how theyre going to end or dont care.

title: Louisiana, Ryan Lochte, Usain Bolt: Your Thursday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: New York Today: The Home of Hip-Hop
description: Updated, 10:12 a.m.

title: Morning Agenda: No Brexit Shock for Hedge Funds
description: Who made money off Britains vote to leave the European Union? Funds that bet on drops in stocks and currencies (particularly the pound), thats who. The rewards were high  for those willing to make a wager  and bets on the decision to leave, or Brexit, were dirt cheap.

title: Thomas Cholmondeley, Scion Implicated in Killings of 2 Kenyans, Dies at 48
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Conservationist? Adventurer? Aristocrat? Killer?

title: A Haitian Grandmothers Home-Cooked Porridge
description: In the hierarchy of enjoyable social interactions, chitchat in the dentists chair ranks barely higher than unbidden office talk in the mens room. But last month, the hygienist buzzing my teeth fascinated me with her vacation stories. She had taken her first trip to Haiti, where her family is from. We talked a bit about the hits of Haitian cuisine  the crisped chile-citrus pork called griot, the beautifully named black-mushroom rice called diri djon djon. But what struck me was her story about the man next to her on the plane. He was returning to his birthplace and was miserable about it. She tried to cheer him up, but when they landed, he turned his head from the window and said, Looks like I havent missed much.

title: Why Did This Boy Run a Fever Every Night?
description: He said he felt fine. His symptoms  high temperature, cough, fatigue  were commonplace. But he kept getting sicker and sicker.

title: Review: From Natalie Portman, Israels Birth Distilled in Mood and Memory
description: A Tale of Love and Darkness, Natalie Portmans directing debut, addresses a hugely complicated and consequential moment in 20th-century history: the founding of the state of Israel. There is no simple way to tell the story, and Ms. Portmans film, closely based on a memoir by the Israeli novelist Amos Oz, is full of mixed emotions and chronological tangles. But despite the geopolitical momentousness  and present-day potency  of its concerns, its an elegant and intimate movie, a thing of nostalgic whispers and sighs rather than polemical slogans and shouts.

title: Choice of Hong Kong for Organ Transplant Meeting Is Defended
description: HONG KONG  Organizers have defended the choice of Hong Kong as the site for a global conference on transplants, saying it did not signify international acceptance of Chinas transplant system, which long relied on organs from executed prisoners. Chinese officials say that they are overhauling the system, and that the use of prisoners organs has ended.

title: The Odd Olympics: Japans Prime Minister Dresses Up as Mario
description: Gold medals are great, but for many viewers of the Rio Olympics, the real high points were the odd, hilarious or unexpected moments beyond the competition, which were shared and amplified by social media.

title: Advice From a Former Olympic Hopeful: Set the Bar Low
description: Watching the Olympics, especially the track and field events, has long been somewhat fraught for me. Sixteen years ago this summer, I retired from my career as a professional runner and abandoned my dreams of becoming an Olympian. I had been a top-ranked American runner, represented the United States in international competition and was a World University Games gold medalist. So while viewing the Olympics brought joy, it was matched with an undercurrent of sadness and self-criticism. I missed my former life and lamented the lack of intensity in my physical fitness regime.

title: 2 Officials in Vietnam Are Killed in Rare Shooting
description: HONG KONG  Two provincial officials in Vietnams governing Communist Party died on Thursday after being shot in their offices by a forest ranger, who later shot himself, the countrys state-controlled news media reported.

title: 36 Hours in Boulder, Colo.
description: Who even needs the legal marijuana? Boulder is an exceptionally easygoing place to hang out.

title: South Sudans Opposition Leader Flees Country as Peace Deal Unravels
description: JUBA, South Sudan  The South Sudanese opposition leader Riek Machar has fled to the Democratic Republic of Congo after being targeted by government troops, his spokesmen said on Thursday, as a fragile peace deal to end more than two years of civil war unravels in the worlds youngest country.

title: Look Out! Playwright Leslye Headland Has Her Eye on You
description: For the playwright and film director Leslye Headland, people-watching is a favorite sport. Maybe its a blood sport. She loves to look at people and steal their souls, she said, scanning a Midtown bar on a recent weeknight. She sounded like she meant it.

title: Paris (and Beyond) by App
description: Tech-savvy entrepreneurs in France are offering apps to help visitors get the most out of Paris and many other cities.

title: You Can Save on Airfare (If You Know the Tricks)
description: The airfare for your family vacation to Orlando, Fla., cost you $500 a person. Your friend snagged tickets there during the same week for nearly half the price. What gives? It may not be pure luck, according to Rick Seaney, the founder of farecompare.com, an airline ticket comparison site. There are ways to save on airfare, but you have to know the tricks, he said. Here, he shares his top ones.

title: The Syrian Boy Pulled from the Rubble in Aleppo
description: Omran Daqneesh, 5, was rescued after an airstrike in the Syrian city of Aleppo. Within hours, a photo of his dust- and blood-covered face captured the world's attention. This is the story behind the image.

title: How Omran Daqneesh, 5, Became a Symbol of Aleppos Suffering
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  In the images, he sits alone, a small boy coated with gray dust and encrusted blood. His little feet barely extend beyond his seat. He stares, bewildered, shocked and, above all, weary, as if channeling the mood of Syria.

title: Nigerias Tragedy
description: The release of a video on Sunday by Boko Haram, claiming to show as many as 50 of the 276 girls the terrorist group kidnapped in April 2014 from their school in Chibok, Nigeria, has given new hope that some of the missing girls can be rescued. The kidnapping sparked an international outcry, and a #BringBackOurGirls Twitter campaign.

title: Before the Tour, the Store: In 21 Cities Around the World, Kanye West Sets Up Shop
description: Kanye Wests Saint Pablo tour, for his platinum Life of Pablo album, begins its course through North America on Thursday. But even before it begins, his Pablo merchandise  tied to and inspired by the album  will have had its own worldwide debut.

title: A Luxury Liner at War, a Submarine in Peril
description: The Queen Mary, put into service 80 years ago, was built as a passenger liner, but World War II altered its mission, a transformation explored in Mighty Ship at War: The Queen Mary, which airs Sunday, Aug. 21, as part of a daylong nautical theme on the Smithsonian Channel. As the situation in Europe darkened, the ship was increasingly used to ferry emigrants out of troubled areas, and once Britain declared war, it was turned into a troop transport. The program recounts a catastrophic incident in 1942 when the liner collided with one of its own escort ships, the Curacao, splitting it in half and killing more than 300. Sundays lineup also includes the final installment of Hell Below, a six-part series on submarine warfare in World War II. Part 6, Fatal Voyage, is about the U.S.S. Tang, which compiled a formidable record against Japanese ships until a fateful engagement in October 1944, when it was sunk by one of its own malfunctioning torpedoes.

title: Beach Cleanup and Dance, Together in Queens
description: Typically, dancers are barefoot, not their audiences. But at the Beach Sessions, at Rockaway Beach, spectators can wriggle their toes in the sand. Last year, the Rockaway resident Sasha Okshteyn started this free outdoor series to bring contemporary dance from city stages to the long shoreline of Queens. The effort is ecological as well as artistic: In pairing performance with beach cleanups and partnering with organizations like the Surfrider Foundation, Ms. Okshteyn is forging a dialogue between dance and its environs.

title: Rio Olympics: Ashton Eaton and Usain Bolt Defend Titles
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Ashton Eaton likes to view the decathlon as a competition with himself, not with others.

title: Delving Into the History and Beauty of Textiles at the Met
description: The Secret Life of Textiles: Animal Fibers at the Metropolitan Museum of Art delves deep into the history and beauty but also the often inscrutable facts of textiles. Its two dozen items range across several cultures and centuries, including Chinese textile fragments from the fourth century B.C., Indian and Russian shawls, mens hats from Tibet and Korea, and a 19th-century French Jacquard-weave portrait of George Washington. Building on natures genius, these often labor-intensive artifacts use fibers from yaks, sheep, goats, horses, cows and silkworms. One of the few intact garments in this show is a lavish ceremonial robe from 19th-century China discreetly trimmed in cat fur. Especially enlightening are the works labels, which parse the different fibers morphologies and the techniques that transformed them, aided by greatly magnified photographs. (Through Feb. 20; 212-535-7710, metmuseum.org.)

title: Charlie Parker Jazz Festival Has Free Shows for Many Tastes
description: The Charlie Parker Jazz Festival is one of the more generous rites of summer in the city: a weekends worth of free performances, uptown and downtown, with a lineup that cuts across age and style. Named after a peerless alto saxophonist and bebop lodestar, the festival usually spotlights one of his former contemporaries. This year, its the magisterial pianist Randy Weston, who recently turned 90; he is to perform on Saturday, Aug. 27, with his African Rhythms Sextet at Marcus Garvey Park.

title: A Note From the Editors of NYT Now
description: Dear NYT Now reader,

title: Exploring Jesus and Josephine Baker Through Music
description: In 1680, the Baroque composer and organist Dietrich Buxtehude wrote Membra Jesu Nostri, a cycle of seven cantatas reflecting on the body of Christ. Over two programs on Sunday, Aug. 21, at Merkin Concert Hall, the International Contemporary Ensemble (ICE), in residence this summer at the Mostly Mozart Festival, will perform the cantatas along with seven works written in response to them by a diverse group of composers. The new pieces will be introduced in two groups: The first, at 3 p.m., will feature works by David T. Little, Anna Thorvaldsdottir, Caroline Shaw and Hans Thomalla; for the second, at 7 p.m., Buxtehudes sacred cantatas will be heard along with pieces by Lewis Spratlan, Pelle Gudmundsen-Holmgreen and Santa Ratniece. The Crossing, an acclaimed chamber choir, joins ICE for these bold programs.

title: New York Times to Shelve NYT Now App
description: In early 2014, The New York Times introduced an app called NYT Now that would provide a curated list of stories  for a lower price than a full digital subscription  to what it hoped would be a younger, mobile-savvy audience. Jill Abramson, then the executive editor of The Times, unveiled the app at the South by Southwest conference in Austin, Tex.

title: An Angel Introduces Bats to Trojans
description: The Greek tragedians, the dramatist Ellen McLaughlin writes, ask the hardest questions. Perhaps best known for portraying the celestial messenger in the Broadway production of Tony Kushners Angels in America, Ms. McLaughlin continues to ask those questions from her own perspective, in her own language. Having refracted the Hellenic take on the nature of humanity and mortality, on war and its aftermath, in contemporary adaptations of works by Sophocles (Oedipus) and Aeschylus (The Persians), Ms. McLaughlin revisits the battle-ravaged plains and psyches of Euripides all too timely The Trojan Women, at the Flea Theater. Directed by Anne Cecelia Haney, with choreography by Joya Powell, the show begins performances on Wednesday, Aug. 24, featuring the Fleas resident acting company, the Bats. (Through Sept. 26; 866-811-4111, theflea.org.)

title: The Luxury Mall as Consumer Prison
description: At art school in London a decade or so ago, the Qatari-American artist, writer and filmmaker Sophia Al-Maria came up with a pithy term, Gulf Futurism, to describe the warp-speed transformations of Dubai and other oil-rich cities: the rise of hotels, malls and museums and the incorporation of the areas Bedouin tribes into an international consumer class. She has been elaborating on this catchphrase ever since, in videos and writings that combine sci-fi fantasies with dystopian musings on the human and environmental costs of hyperdevelopment.

title: A Week of Mel Brooks in Brooklyn
description: Whats moronic, tasteless and celebrating its 35th anniversary this year? History of the World, Part I, Mel Brookss 1981 cameo-filled collection of ersatz historical episodes. Janet Maslin, reviewing the film when it came out, complained that many of the jokes are either meanspirited or scatological, or both, and these days the best way to watch it may be with an accompaniment of grub and alcoholic beverages. Thats possible Monday, Aug. 22, at Syndicated, the theater and restaurant in Bushwick, Brooklyn, which begins a Brooks week with the movie that evening. Sample gag: Moses comes down from the mountain carrying three tablets and announces to his people, The Lord Jehovah has given unto you these 15 [drops one tablet, which shatters]  10! Ten Commandments. The rest of the weeks lineup: Blazing Saddles, Robin Hood: Men in Tights, Spaceballs, Young Frankenstein, The Producers and High Anxiety. (syndicatedbk.com.)

title: War and Pillaging Couldnt Break an Afghan Village, but a Tumbling Economy May
description: ISTALIF, Afghanistan  To survive the last catastrophe, when their town was sacked and burned by the Taliban, the potters of the northern Afghan town of Istalif buried the tools of their trade and fled, some enduring years of exile until the threat finally passed.

title: 1916: Britain Stops Exports to Sweden
description: LONDON, England  The King to-day [Aug. 18] signed the proclamation forbidding all exports from Great Britain to Sweden, except under special license. General satisfaction is expressed in the press at the energetic measures taken to prevent the re-exportation of merchandise from Sweden to enemy countries. It is fully realized here that the Government has been forced to action by sheer force of circumstances, of which the Swedish Trade Law of April 16, 1916, making it illegal for an importer in Sweden to furnish an exporter in the United Kingdom with information regarding the disposal of the goods, was the climax.

title: Daily Report: Intel and Cisco, Shifting With the Times
description: Technology companies have to adapt continually to shifting trends. That was abundantly clear this week when two longtime tech stalwarts made moves to change with the times.

title: White Rappers, Clear of a Black Planet
description: Last month, the white rapper G-Eazy  a handsome ectomorph sporting a motorcycle jacket and 1950s-slick hair  headlined a show at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, part of a weekslong tour. Over the last couple of years, this Oakland, Calif., musician has evolved from regional curio to legitimate pop contender: He appears on the lead single from the forthcoming Britney Spears album, and in March, his song Me, Myself & I with the guest singer Bebe Rexha  from his platinum album, When Its Dark Out  went to No. 7 on the Billboard Hot 100.

title: How Technology Can Help You Travel and Save
description: Technology has changed the way we travel, from lodging to flight information. But it can also save us money on planning and beyond.

title: Tika Sumpter on Playing the Future First Lady, Michelle Obama
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  Tika Sumpter knew the screenplay was something special. It was, at its core, a romance, with two charming leads slowly falling for each other over the course of a single Chicago day. They speak passionately  at some points, angrily  about moral courage and racial politics and the struggles of staying true to oneself. They take sides on Good Times versus The Brady Bunch, ice cream versus pie. They quote the poet Gwendolyn Brooks (We Real Cool) from memory, while sizing up Ernie Barness painting Sugar Shack. They watch Do the Right Thing.

title: 1896 | The Book Review Is Born
description: Times Insider shares historical insights from The New York Times. In this piece, David W. Dunlap, a Metro reporter, looks back at The Timess inaugural Book Review.

title: An Instantly Classic Womens Watch
description: It was women who pioneered wearing watches on the wrist. Queen Elizabeth was given an intricately bejeweled one by the Earl of Leicester in 1572; the Queen of Naples had a band made of hair and gold thread. While men continued to keep their watches in their pockets, sporty 19th-century ladies wore timepieces with leather straps while on horseback and bicycles. Ralph Lauren channels that intrepid spirit with his first collection of round watches for women, RL888, named for the address of his flagship Madison Avenue mansion. The selection features Breguet-style hands and a bold combination of Arabic and Roman numerals. Many have interchangeable straps, including this one made of slick black alligator.

title: Comparing Digital Video Recorders
description: Q. What are the pros and cons of getting a TiVo digital video recorder for the television instead of using the hardware pushed by my cable company?

title: Barware, by a Beloved Brooklyn Bartenders Dad
description: If youve been to Leyenda, the Brooklyn cocktail joint known for jalapeo-infused tequila tipples and tiki-inspired pisco potions, youve likely met Ivy Mix  or at least enjoyed her drinks. She runs the bar with her partner Julie Reiner (both are highly decorated in the world of mixology; last year, Mix won Best American Bartender at the Oscars of the spirits industry, Tales of the Cocktail); and despite Leyendas success, its just one aspect of Mixs resume. Much of her time is spent on the road managing Speed Rack, the femme-focused national cocktail competition she co-founded in 2011. And this month, she launches a new venture: a new line of barware created in partnership with her father, Robin Mix, a glassblowing artist based in rural Vermont.

title: When Women Fight ISIS
description: Two years ago this month, the Islamic State attacked the Yazidis, a Kurdish religious minority who live around Sinjar Mountain in Iraq. The militants came down on unprotected villages like Byrons wolf on the fold, slaughtering the men and taking away thousands of women and children to be sold as sex slaves.

title: Talking to Children When a Parent Is Dying
description: I closed the door quietly behind me and heard the voice of a young child.

title: Donald Trumps Crucial Pillar of Support, White Men, Shows Weakness
description: Donald J. Trumps support among white men, the linchpin of his presidential campaign, is showing surprising signs of weakness that could foreclose his only remaining path to victory in November.

title: 7 Chicago Officers Face Firing Over Laquan McDonald Cover-Up
description: CHICAGO  Chicagos police superintendent has called for the firing of seven officers for their response to a colleagues fatal shooting of Laquan McDonald in 2014, a case that roiled the city and laid bare longstanding tensions between the police and black Chicagoans.

title: In Provence, a Former Palace Exudes Luxury and Privilege
description: From 379 euros (about $423).

title: 20 Sports, 13 Hours: Schedule? Who Needs a Schedule? Or a Map?
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The challenge presented a sports fans dream and a logistical nightmare: Who can see the most Olympic events in one day? Victor Mather, our resident Olympics historian and master of many tasks, proposed such a competition to Sarah Lyall, a staff reporter who, shall we say, is allergic to checklists.

title: 20 Sports, 13 Hours: It Was All Planned Out (Now, Wheres That Bus?)
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The challenge presented a sports fans dream and a logistical nightmare: Who can see the most Olympic events in one day? Victor Mather, our resident Olympics historian and master of many tasks, proposed such a competition to Sarah Lyall, a staff reporter who, shall we say, is allergic to checklists.

title: 1966: Senate Passes Defense Bill
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate unanimously passed today a near-record $58.2 billion defense money bill providing about $10 billion and possibly thousands of men for the Vietnam war. The Senate bill, exceeded only by a 1944 World War II Army appropriation, included a controversial provision that would give President Johnson authority to call up individual reservists for duty in Vietnam. Reserve groups have expressed opposition to the amendment, which could, if Mr. Johnson exercised this authority, strip some Reserve units of personnel.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 19, 1966

title: Bolivian Llama Party
description: At the underground TurnStyle food hall at Columbus Circle, a Bolivian dumpling holds court.

title: Overstuffed (and Underground) Pastry at Bolivian Llama Party
description: Call a saltea an empanada at your own risk.

title: U.S. Swimmers Disputed Robbery Claim Fuels Tension in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Soon after the first news media reports surfaced Sunday morning of an armed assault on four American swimmers, the athletes were interviewed at the United States Olympic teams hospitality house by State Department officials, national swim team officials and Olympic officials. They all agreed that the swimmers should avoid further attention and that the United States Olympic Committee would soon put out a statement.

title: Rally Racing School: A Different Type of Defensive Driving
description: Team ONeil Rally School in New Hampshire teaches quick reactions and precise car control, techniques that can help drivers avoid mishaps off-road and on.

title: Rally Racing School Teaches the Basics of Controlled Mayhem
description: DALTON, N.H.  It would seem a parents nightmare.

title: U.S. Women Drop Baton, but Advance After a Second Chance
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Of all the strange things that have happened in womens track and field at the Rio Olympics, and there have been a handful of odd occurrences, this was perhaps the most bizarre.

title: Twitter Suspends 235,000 More Accounts Over Extremism
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Twitter suspended 235,000 accounts that promoted terrorism over the last six months, as part of a continuing effort to keep people from using the social network for extremist causes, the company said Thursday.

title: Cogolins Contemporary Rugs, From the Archives
description: A hidden gem of a textile company in the South of France unveils a new collection.

title: A Historically Minded Collection of Carpets
description: In a small village in Provence, the storied custom-rug maker Cogolin brings the magical designs of a Modernist artist back to life.

title: Good, Bad and Mad: Paul Krugman on the News
description: Opinion columnist Paul Krugman expresses his views on climate change, false moral equivalences, and Americas enduring goodness.

title: The Tribal Thrill of the Olympics
description: LONDON  When the calendar clicks around to global events, the Olympics in particular, it could almost be argued that all sport is tribal, at least from the vantage of the worlds couches and bars that provide the virtual stadium for those unable to finagle a ticket to Rio de Janeiro.

title: Times Insider Book Club: Sheri Fink
description: On Tuesday, Aug. 30, Sheri Fink, a New York Times correspondent, was on hand to discuss her latest book, Five Days at Memorial: Life and Death in a Storm-Ravaged Hospital.

title: The Evidence That Ryan Lochte Lied About an Armed Robbery in Rio
description: Brazilian investigators said video evidence and witnesses showed that American swimmers had fabricated their account of being held up at gunpoint in Rio.

title: Antipsychotics During Pregnancy Not Tied to Birth Defects
description: Taking antipsychotic medicines during pregnancy does not increase the risk for birth defects, a large new study has found.

title: Werner Herzog Says The Internet Has Its Glorious Side
description: Over a career spanning nearly 50 years, the German filmmaker Werner Herzog, 73, has managed to gracefully pivot from outrageous and eccentric narrative films (Aguirre: Wrath of God, Fitzcarraldo) to poignant and poetic documentaries (Cave of Forgotten Dreams). Now, Mr. Herzog has set his eye on the internet, or what he calls the thing.

title: Uber Aims for an Edge in the Race for a Self-Driving Future
description: A world in which cars drive themselves may come sooner than once thought.

title: Steven Avery, of Making a Murderer, Eyes Freedom After Co-Defendants Conviction Is Overturned
description: Will Steven Avery, featured in the Netflix series Making a Murderer, go free?

title: One of Bill Cosbys Lawyers Is No Longer Representing Him
description: In a legal reshuffle, Monique Pressley, a lawyer for Bill Cosby who became something of a public face for the entertainer in his battle against allegations of sexual assault made by many women, is no longer representing him in any pending legal cases, a spokesman for Mr. Cosby said.

title: Brazilian Judge Discusses Case Involving American Swimmers
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Judge Marcello Rubioli is the head of the special court handling the case involving four American swimmers  Gunnar Bentz, Jack Conger, Ryan Lochte and Jimmy Feigen  and their claim that they were held up at gunpoint here early Sunday morning. This interview has been condensed and edited.

title: Hillary Clinton and the Ghosts of MTV
description: I experienced eight years of weird celebrity life in the 90s as a political reporter for MTV News. Yes, MTV once had a Peabody Award-winning news department. An argument has been made that MTV got Bill Clinton elected president and sent Hillary Clinton to the White House in 1992 by coaxing young people to vote  as their vote tilted that first election his way.

title: Good, Bad and Mad: Paul Krugman on the News
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights the workings of and thinking at The New York Times. In this podcast, the Opinion columnist Paul Krugman talks about the news: the good, the bad and the most maddening.

title: Review: Morris From America: A 13-Year-Old Stranger in a Strange Land
description: Morris From America, Chad Hartigans charming new film, begins with a father-son discussion of hip-hop, an argument about beats, flows and hooks. Its partly an affectionate intergenerational dispute; 13-year-old Morris (Markees Christmas) is skeptical of his fathers old-school dogma, while his dad, Curtis (Craig Robinson), dismisses his sons taste as too pop. The conversation also provides a clue about the movies own strategies. Its a pop confection with a rough, honest texture, real but not raw and suffused with an infectious sweetness that lingers after the final shot.

title: Is Hayden a Boy or Girl? Both. Post-Gender Baby Names Are on the Rise.
description: When it came to naming their third son a few weeks ago, Megan Fox and Brian Austin Green sidestepped traditional boys names like Ethan and Jacob for the gender-agnostic name Journey, which may have been a subtle nod to the couples much-chronicled attempts to work their way back from the brink of divorce.

title: When Tart, Pungent and Funky Mean Its a Good Brew
description: Five years can be an eternity in the craft-beer business. What may begin as an experiment can accelerate into a fad, if not a furor. So it has seemed with American brewers and the range of styles collectively known as sour beers.

title: Review: In Little Reds Hood, Tweets, Sweets and a Wolf on the Way to Grandmas
description: Most audience members at the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theater politely turn off their cellphones before the curtain rises. But these days, at every performance, one all-too-typical Manhattan kid persists in texting, tweeting, posting, sharing, emailing and updating, completely oblivious to those around her.

title: Gawker.com to Shut Down Next Week
description: For nearly 14 years, Nick Denton and Gawker.com have defined Gawker Media.

title: Badmintons Shuttlecock: Sports Gears Rare Bird
description: It has 16 goose feathers, sits on a stump of Portuguese cork and flies at up to 300 miles per hour, which makes the badminton shuttlecock one of the more curious pieces of sports equipment to be found anywhere.

title: At Least 120 Athletes at the Rio Olympics Were Previously Suspended for Doping
description: Roughly one out of every 100 competitors at this years Games has served a suspension. So far, 25 have won medals in Rio.

title: Blood in the Water, a Gripping Account of the Attica Prison Uprising
description: Not all works of history have something to say so directly to the present, but Heather Ann Thompsons Blood in the Water: The Attica Prison Uprising of 1971 and Its Legacy, which deals with racial conflict, mass incarceration, police brutality and dissembling politicians, reads like it was special-ordered for the sweltering summer of 2016.

title: Toronto International Film Festival to Screen The Birth of a Nation as Planned
description: Despite the controversy clouding the new film The Birth of a Nation, the Toronto International Film Festival will screen it as planned in September, according to a festival spokeswoman.

title: The Art of Della Robbia: From Earth and Water, Pure Beauty
description: BOSTON  In Renaissance Italy, art was a form of advertising, pushing hopes and emotions as much as things. Allegorical images  Temperance, Justice, Charity  on urban facades promoted civic pride and obedience. In churches, sculptural angels offered getaway deals to heaven. Home icons of the Virgin and Child taught that salvation lay not in riches but in fruitfulness, patience and a good-night kiss.

title: Sure, These Women Are Winning Olympic Medals, but Are They Single?
description: When Corey Cogdell-Unrein of the U.S. Olympic team won a bronze medal in womens trap shooting, The Chicago Tribune left out a key detail when it shared the  news: her name. It described her only as the wife of a Bears lineman.

title: Volkswagen Supplier Played Key Role in Cheating, Court Papers Say
description: FRANKFURT  The German auto supplier Robert Bosch GmbH played a key role in developing the software that let Volkswagen cheat on clean air rules, according to new allegations filed in a San Francisco court on behalf of car owners.

title: Photos Offer Glimpse Inside Arizona Border Detention Centers
description: PHOENIX  In June 2015, legal and civil rights groups filed a class-action lawsuit in Federal District Court in Tucson accusing the Border Patrol of holding migrants in dirty and crowded cells at stations in southeastern Arizona, after they were caught illegally entering the United States.

title: Swimmings Racial Divide
description: To the Editor:

title: Champions of Our National Parks
description: To the Editor:

title: The California of the Caucasus
description: Back when Georgia  a country bordered by the Black Sea and the Caucasus Mountains  was behind the Iron Curtain, it was fancied the California of the U.S.S.R. Slightly smaller in size than South Carolina, but with impressively diverse terrain, this fertile country had a reputation for producing exceptional fruits and vegetables, superb wines and talented filmmakers. When I was studying in Leningrad in the 70s, says Ambassador Ian C. Kelly, currently stationed in Georgia, a group of us were taken to Tbilisi. Arriving there was like arriving in Oz  suddenly everything went from black and white to color.

title: Gender Identity in Olden Times: Interpreting the Torah
description: To the Editor:

title: Photographing Africas Fashion Elite
description: The Swedish photographer Per-Anders Pettersson has spent the last five years documenting the vibrant fashion scene across sub-Saharan African.

title: The New (Very Pink) NoLIta Restaurant Making Italian Healthy
description: In the middle of a quiet Elizabeth Street block, above an unmistakably pink subterranean stone entryway with flower boxes of mottled caladium leaves, a neon starburst with a smiley face announces a new arrival: the full-service healthy Italian restaurant Pietro Nolita. Its owners, Pietro Quaglia and Mina Soliman, met in 2003, when Soliman was working at Indochine as a matre d. At the time, Quaglia was interning at Dolce and Gabbana, whose team held ritual Friday night dinners there. The pair didnt talk restaurants until September of last year, when Quaglia was alerted the space was available by the restaurateur and designer Serge Becker  whose wife happens to be Solimans sister. The longtime friends becomes business partners soon thereafter.

title: A World Mr. Thiel Helped Create: Readers on Peter Thiel and Gawker
description: While many readers praised Peter Thiel for his support of a lawsuit against Gawker, some questioned whether he was really a defender of Americans privacy, in response to a recent Op-Ed.

title: Documenting Africas Rising Fashion Industry
description: With its own fashion weeks, along with homegrown talent making a splash abroad, the continent is establishing itself as an important design hub.

title: Photographing Africas Fashion Elite
description: Per-Anders Pettersson has spent the last five years documenting the vibrant fashion scene across sub-Saharan Africa. His new photography book, African Catwalk, is a visual survey of Africas emerging fashion industry, giving viewers an insiders perspective on a transcontinental spectacle that often goes unseen.

title: Africa Takes Its Turn on the Runway
description: It was a fashion show that stopped traffic.

title: Secrecy of Settlements at Fox News Hid Bad Behavior
description: Like many companies confronted with sexual harassment in their executive ranks, Fox News and its parent, 21st Century Fox, say they do not tolerate such behavior and have strict policies prohibiting it.

title: AIBA Reassigns Official Overseeing Olympic Boxing Judges
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The federation running the boxing tournament at the Olympics reassigned its executive director on Thursday, a day after a handful of judges were sent home for making questionable rulings in a few bouts.

title: Debate in New Jersey: Is Bear That Walks Upright Suffering, or Thriving?
description: OAK RIDGE, N.J.  The first time Greg Macgowans wife saw the bear near their home, the upper half of the animals body was obscured by a neighbors deck. She said, Come here  theres a guy in a bear suit, he recalled.

title: Truth, Lies and Chinese Art Inspire a Puzzle Box of a Play
description: The brouhaha over Mike Daisey, who admitted to fabricating details in his one-man play about Chinese factory workers, The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs, led to a humbling backlash against the acclaimed writer-performer and innumerable essays.

title: Hillary Clintons Campaign Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: Immune System and Spirit Kept Cancer at Bay for a Year
description: I recently chronicled the story of Jason Greenstein and his battle against cancer. He was at the vanguard of a new kind of treatment that unleashes the immune system to fight the disease as it does infections caused by viruses and bacteria.

title: Review: War Dogs, an Absurd (and True) Gunrunning Tale
description: Based on a true story, the movie War Dogs says, and indeed it is. Which proves conclusively that truth is stranger than fiction.

title: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
Frances Burkini Bans Are About More Than Religion or Clothing
description: WASHINGTON  There is something inherently head-spinning about the so-called burkini bans that are popping up in coastal France. The obviousness of the contradiction  imposing rules on what women can wear on the grounds that its wrong for women to have to obey rules about what women can wear  makes it clear that there must be something deeper going on.

title: Review: In Spaceman, a Pitcher Specializing in Brashness
description: Anyone going to Spaceman with the expectation of seeing a version of the major league career of Bill Lee, the pitcher known by that nickname, will be frustrated, maybe even annoyed. The film is interested not in the heart of Lees career  he pitched for Boston and Montreal from 1969 to 1982  but in the end of it, and the slow process of letting go of the glory days.

title: One Photographers Cotton-Candy View of Los Angeles
description: The pastel-hued landscapes in the Australian native Gina Neros Leaving Hampton series cast the city in a pretty, peaceful light.

title: How One Familys Deep Pockets Helped Reshape Donald Trumps Campaign
description: Last week, as Donald J. Trump endured one of the most tumultuous stretches of his presidential campaign, a few longtime allies in New York conservative circles met for dinner and a drink. As the evening progressed, the conversation turned to an inevitable topic: What would it take to give Mr. Trump his best shot at winning?

title: Social Security Retreats From Cellphone-Based Online Security
description: Never mind  at least, for now.

title: Review: In Kubo and the Two Strings, Origami Fuels an Animated Quest
description: If you must blink, do it now is the first line spoken in this stop-motion animated movie. Its apt advice. Kubo and the Two Strings was made by Laika Films, the outfit behind such quirky and visually arresting pictures as Coraline (2009) and ParaNorman (2012). The action in Kubo begins at night, with a desperate woman at sea fighting off waves with her small boat and a shamisen (a Japanese three-stringed lute) imbued with magic powers.

title: Outside the Bars
description: Musicians have written a nearly uncountable number of books in recent years. But unlike, say, Rod Stewart or Steven Tyler, Franz Nicolay refers to Montaigne, Tocqueville, V.S. Pritchett, Ford Madox Ford and Melville  and thats just in a two-page stretch of the introduction to his new travelogue, The Humorless Ladies of Border Control.

title: A Moral Imperative to Recover a Lost Art Legacy
description: The last time anyone is known to have heard from the Polish-Jewish artist Moshe Rynecki was in 1943, when his wife, Perla, received a postcard that he had sent from Majdanek, a concentration camp near Lublin, Poland. The Nazis had transported him there from the smoldering ruins of the Jewish ghetto in Warsaw. The rest of his family had stayed in Warsaw, posing as Christians. His scrawled message reassured his wife that he was well and painting in the camp, his son, George Rynecki, recalled in a memoir written decades after the war.

title: Review: Kingsglaive: Final Fantasy XV, Where the Bad Guys Sport Silly Hats
description: Theres a very real possibility that watching Kingsglaive: Final Fantasy XV could result in brain addlement. At least, thats what it might feel like if youve so far managed to resist the lure of the long-running (29 years, no less), rampantly successful Final Fantasy video game franchise. Suffice to say, this spinoff from the story of a magical kingdom besieged by an evil empire is too ludicrous for words.

title: One Titanic Survivor Goes on View: A Deck Chair
description: A century-old wooden deck chair from a sunken British ship might seem like an incongruous artifact to include in an exhibition of recently acquired objects by a New York history museum, except that this one was retrieved from the Titanic. New York, where the ship was to dock, was the final destination of about 200 of the 1,500 passengers who drowned in the disaster, and the first Senate hearings into the tragedy were held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

title: Review: Kampai! For the Love of Sake Celebrates Japans Best-Known Libation
description: The title Kampai! For the Love of Sake  kampai is a Japanese toast  captures the essence of this crisp if feather-light documentary. The film, directed by Mirai Konishi, is the latest in a mini-genre (including The Birth of Sake, released in March, and Wa-shoku, from 2015) extolling Japanese cuisine, here again focusing on Japans best-known libation and profiling its experts.

title: In the Rockaways, Dancing by the Surf and Sand
description: Anyone who has turned a cartwheel in the sand or sprinted along a shoreline can identify: Something about the beach feels invitingly kinetic.

title: Review: Ixcanul, From Luminous Ritual to Emotional Explosions
description: Ixcanul means volcano in the Kaqchikel language, and the title refers both to the peak that overlooks the Guatemalan coffee plantation where the film is set and to the eruptive emotions at the movies core. We see no hint of these, though, as we watch Mara (Mara Mercedes Coroy), a young Maya woman, and her parents work the land and care for their livestock. Their actions are languid and explicit; yet theres a ritualistic precision to the way they slit a pigs throat and scrape off its hair thats more hypnotic than repellent.

title: On Instagram, the Artist Ai Weiwei Focuses on Refugees
description: Ai Weiwei, the Chinese artist and dissident, is known for his films, sculptures and photography. Last July, the Chinese government returned Mr. Ai his passport after four years of detainment in Beijing. Since sharing the moment on his Instagram, Mr. Ai has been traveling  first moving to Germany, where he settled with his family, then to London in September for his single-artist show at the Royal Academy of Arts, and in January to Paris for an atrium and window display inside the Bon March department store.

title: Searching for Light in the Darkness of the 80s
description: For contemporary art in America, the 1980s was an exciting if not lovable decade. Arguably it was second only to the 1960s for ambitious innovations of style and thought. Consider Julian Schnabels brawny Neo-Expressionist paintings, Cindy Shermans canny, staged self-portraits, Jeff Koonss sumptuous sculptures of kitschy objects and Barbara Krugers suavely designed leftist agitprop: The 80s abounded in eye- and mind-grabbing work.

title: Review: Daniel Radcliffe Battles Homegrown Extremists in Imperium
description: Daniel Radcliffe might seem a long way from Hogwarts in Imperium, a bleak movie about an F.B.I. agents undercover foray into the world of neo-Nazis, but then again, maybe not. In the child-friendly Harry Potter films, Harry was perpetually doing battle against the wizarding worlds version of racism and a toxic hatred that seemed to grip those around him like a disease. The difference is that in Imperium his character, Nate Foster, doesnt have magic to fall back on.

title: Doctors Without Borders Is Pulling Staff After Hospital Bombings in Yemen
description: SANA, Yemen  Doctors Without Borders announced on Thursday that it would evacuate its staff from six hospitals in northern Yemen because it could not get assurances that its hospitals would not be bombed again.

title: Uber Speeds Toward a Driverless Future, Putting Jobs in Danger
description: Uber is steering its driverless vehicle technology toward a crash between robots and jobs. The private ride-hailing company, which was worth s $66 billion on Thursday, said that it had bought the autonomous big-rig start-up Otto and that it was unleashing driverless taxis in Pittsburgh. Putting computers instead of humans behind the wheel could save lives, but it would automate a task that employs millions of American workers. Americas safety net is ill-prepared for such a job-destroying juggernaut.

title: Miami Beach Zika Cases May Prompt Call to Avoid City
description: MIAMI BEACH  A cluster of Zika cases most likely transmitted by local mosquitoes has been identified in Miami Beach, and federal and state officials are considering whether to advise pregnant women to avoid traveling to the city and possibly even all of Miami-Dade County, a health official said Thursday.

title: A Writer for Inside Amy Schumer Becomes a Thorn for the Star
description: In recent years, Amy Schumer has emerged as one of comedys biggest stars, a performer and writer who has used her visibility and Emmy Award-winning sketch series, Inside Amy Schumer, to call attention to a wide range of social issues that were once considered too uncomfortable to joke about, be they the chauvinistic depiction and discussion of womens bodies in the media or the publics unwillingness to believe sexual assault charges made against Bill Cosby.

title: J.K. Rowling Announces E-Book Series, Pottermore Presents
description: At the recent premiere in London of the play Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, J. K. Rowling insisted that she is really, truly, done with writing about Harry Potter.

title: Review: In Making a Killing, Guns Do Slay People, Children Included
description: Try watching a 4-year-old recount the night when his enraged father shot the little boys mother and grandfather in front of him. If theres a stronger word than heartbreaking, it would be apt for that story and for the others told in Making a Killing: Guns, Greed and the N.R.A.

title: Israels New Man in New York
description: Dani Dayan is articulate and charming, a lively and provocative conversationalist. An immigrant from Argentina and a Spanish speaker, he is an Israeli settler from the West Bank, and the controversial former head of the settler movement.

title: Review: Treasonous Play for Justice in The People vs. Fritz Bauer
description: Fritz Bauer is a mass, and a mess, of contradictions: crafty yet principled, loyal yet friendless, brooding yet driven. Sometimes he charges ahead, other times he bumbles along, usually engulfed in a cloud of tobacco smoke. Burghart Klaussner, playing him in The People vs. Fritz Bauer, delivers a masterly performance as this complicated man.

title: Review: Wrestling With Gay Identity and Parental Wishes in Spa Night
description: Because David Cho (Joe Seo), the glum, bashful 18-year-old protagonist of Spa Night, is struggling with homosexual desire, it would be easy to categorize this cool, exquisitely observant first feature by the Korean-American filmmaker Andrew Ahn as a gay movie. But it is much more. The film is a contemplation of the loneliness, tension and anxiety of outsiders pursuing a piece of the American dream.

title: Review: Lo and Behold, the Danger, and Potential, of the Digital Revolution
description: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World is Werner Herzogs documentary about the internet. For some readers, that sentence will be sufficient. One of our most intellectually ambitious filmmakers  a self-professed seeker of ecstatic truths, a tireless foot soldier of cinema  tackles what he calls one of the greatest revolutions humanity has experienced. The combination of Mr. Herzogs doggedly curious sensibility and the mysteries of the digital universe seems both improbable and irresistible.

title: U.S. to Phase Out Use of Private Prisons for Federal Inmates
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said on Thursday that it would begin to phase out the use of private for-profit prisons to house federal inmates. The Bureau of Prisons had resorted to such prisons to ease overcrowding as the incarceration rate soared, but the number of federal inmates has been dropping since 2013.

title: Review: Womens Hard Choices, Cutting Deep at Williamstown Festival
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass.  A womans right to choose  how to live her life, or how to end it  provides an oblique theme linking the two plays that close the Williamstown Theater Festival season, which ends on Sunday.

title: Readers React: Should Air-Conditioning Be a Right for Prisoners?
description: For many Americans, the way prisoners are treated is a reflection of the national character.

title: Review: Ben-Hur Is a Savage Update for a New Generation
description: For any filmmaker foolhardy enough to embark on a remake of Ben-Hur, the kitschy 1959 sword-and-sandals epic that captured 11 Oscars and elevated Charlton Heston to Hollywood sainthood, the first order of business is to create a bigger and better version of that movies climactic chariot race.

title: Review: Netflixs Fearless Explores the Worlds Most Dangerous Sport
description: Superlatives fall like thudding hooves in the Netflix documentary series Fearless, available on Friday. Bull riding is definitely the most dangerous sport in the world. Its the fastest-growing sport in America. Professional Bull Riders, whose 2015 season the series chronicles, is a global phenomenon.

title: Lower Medal Count in Rio Rattles Chinas Olympics Obsession
description: BEIJING  Even before the Olympic flame is extinguished in Rio de Janeiro, China is deep in debate about its showing in the Summer Games. Many Chinese are asking if the nations once insatiable appetite for medals has hit a limit.

title: Swim Around Manhattan Is Saved From a Future as Murky as Its Waters
description: Just before 7 a.m. Monday, David Barra hopped onto a rock on the shoreline of the Hudson River to address an eager group of swimmers. Nearby, cars trickled across the George Washington Bridge, Amtrak trains rumbled past, and a faint breeze carried the sour scent of spilled beer from the patio of a waterfront bar.

title: Jill Soloway of Transparent Aims to Challenge With I Love Dick on Amazon
description: Amazon is posting three new comedy pilots on Friday. You know what they say in baseball  if you get a hit one out of every three at-bats, youre in the Hall of Fame.

title: Sexism in Olympics Coverage
description: The Olympics coverage has been criticized for sexism on almost a daily basis. Female Olympians are described as married or unmarried, while men are called the fastest or the strongest.

description: The New York Times film critics review Ben-Hur, A Tale of Love and Darkness and Morris from America.

title: Family of Man Charged in Killing of Queens Imam Insists He Is Innocent
description: They arrived early, an hour before the judge started hearing cases on Thursday, taking up much of a long bench in the Queens courtroom. They were family members of Oscar Morel, the man charged with first-degree murder in the execution-style attack on an imam and his assistant on a sidewalk on Saturday afternoon.

title: When Police Dont Live in the City They Serve
description: MILWAUKEE  The split-second law enforcement decision of when to pull the trigger often comes down to perception. Is that person acting suspiciously? Is he or she a threat?

title: Republicans Worry a Falling Donald Trump Tide Will Lower All Boats
description: Donald J. Trumps struggling candidacy has now become a direct threat to Republican control of Congress, significantly increasing the likelihood that Democrats will take control of the Senate and cut substantially into the House Republican majority next year.

title: Far-Right Party Trades on Merkels Refugee Policies in Her Home State
description: ROSTOCK, Germany  As Germany grapples with integrating refugees, it seemed like a good idea: Take 15 newly arrived, unaccompanied minors, mix them in with German teenagers and scatter them in groups of two or three through empty apartments in revamped Communist-era housing blocks on the edge of this Baltic port city.

title: Fight for Viacom Is Said to End With the Redstones in Control
description: The fight over Sumner M. Redstones $40 billion media empire is over, and the 93-year-old mogul has won.

description: Soon you will be able borrow money from a bank called Marcus.

title: Giants Kicker Josh Brown Says Domestic-Violence Arrest Led to Suspension
description: Giants kicker Josh Brown said Thursday he had been suspended for one game by the N.F.L. because of a domestic-violence arrest after an incident at home with his wife in 2015. Although the charges were dropped in the case, the N.F.L.s personal-conduct policy states that a conviction is not required for a player to be disciplined by the league.

description: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.

description: In Italy, where two decades of economic stagnation have created a long line of barely breathing companies, Feltrinelli, one of the countrys largest booksellers, stands out.

title: Judge Overturns Ubers Settlement With Drivers
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A federal judge on Thursday struck down a proposed class-action settlement between Uber and a group of its current and former drivers, potentially continuing a protracted lawsuit that questioned a key tenet of the ride-hailing companys business.

title: False Reports of Gunfire at J.F.K. Airport Offer a Real Case Study in Security
description: As a human stampede tore its way through a terminal at Kennedy International Airport, a Transportation Security Administration agent running along was heard screaming, Theres a bomb! Another agent yelled, Someones been shot!

title: Pop & Rock Listings for Aug. 19-25
description: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.

title: Frances Burkini Bigotry
description: After bans on full-face veils, head scarves in schools and rules about students skirt lengths, Frances perennial problem with Muslim womens attire has taken its most farcical turn yet with a new controversy over the burkini, body-covering swimwear whose name is an amalgam of burqa and bikini. As of Thursday, five French mayors had banned the burkini, calling it, variously, a threat to public order, hygiene, water safety and morality, tantamount to a new weapon of war against the French republic. Thierry Migoule, an official with the city of Cannes, the first to ban the burkini, declared the swimwear clothing that conveys an allegiance to the terrorist movements that are waging war against us.

title: Jazz Listings for Aug. 19-25
description: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.

title: Middle-Income Jobs Finally Show Signs of a Rebound
description: The American economy is finally creating more middle-income jobs, according to a new analysis released Thursday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in a turnabout from the feast-and-famine pattern earlier in the recovery, when hiring was strongest at the bottom and top of the wage scale.

title: Ukraine Releases More Details on Payments for Trump Aide, Paul Manafort
description: MOSCOW  The Ukrainian authorities, under pressure to bolster their assertion that once-secret accounting documents show cash payments from a pro-Russian political party earmarked for Donald J. Trumps campaign chairman, on Thursday released line-item entries, some for millions of dollars.

title: Hillary Clinton Told F.B.I. Colin Powell Advised Her to Use Private Email
description: Pressed by the F.B.I. about her email practices at the State Department, Hillary Clinton told investigators that former Secretary of State Colin L. Powell had advised her to use a personal email account.

title: 5 Neglected New York City Parks to Get $150 Million for Upgrades
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Thursday announced that he would spend $150 million to upgrade five large New York parks  $30 million to one in each borough  in what he called an effort to combat an unequal system in which parks in wealthier parts of the city were well financed while those in poorer neighborhoods were neglected.

title: Timeline of Ryan Lochte's Long Night in Rio
description: Ryan Lochte and three other American swimmers claimed they were held up at gunpoint while taking a late-night taxi at the Rio Games, but the police said they lied. We retraced their steps that night.

title: Dance Listings for Aug. 19-25
description: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.

title: If Hillary Clinton Wins, Foundation Will Stop Accepting Foreign Donations
description: Facing criticism for some of the donations given to his familys philanthropy, Bill Clinton said on Thursday that the Clinton Foundation would no longer accept foreign or corporate money and that he would resign from its board should Hillary Clinton win the presidency.

title: Olympic Races, in Your Neighborhood
description: What would Olympic races look like if they took place near you?

title: Mexican Federal Police Executed 22 People in Raid, Rights Group Says
description: MEXICO CITY  Mexican federal police officers summarily executed at least 22 people last year during a raid on an alfalfa ranch that had been occupied by members of an armed group, the countrys National Human Rights Commission said Thursday.
