title: Steven Matz, Bone Spur and All, Has Settled Into the Mets Rotation
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When a sizable and painful bone spur was discovered in the back of Steven Matzs throwing elbow in early May, he took a brief break, received a cortisone shot and returned to the mound. Surgery was considered when the discomfort returned in June, but Matz and the Mets decided he would continue pitching as they all tried to manage the problem properly.

title: U.S. Concedes $400 Million Payment to Iran Was Delayed as Prisoner Leverage
description: The State Department conceded for the first time on Thursday that it delayed making a $400 million payment to Iran for several hours in January to retain maximum leverage and ensure that three American prisoners were released the same day.

title: John Timoney Had the Gall to Change Minds, One Police Department at a Time
description: Shorts and sneakers, a T-shirt and a boss: The chief of the New York Police Department turned up at the Police Academy to school some young officers.

title: Photos of Migrant Holding Cells Released
description: A federal judge made public still images from video in a lawsuit alleging that migrants caught illegally entering the country are held in dirty, crowded cells.

title: The Olympics Are the End of a Track From Poverty
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  As she tells it to me, the memory sounds like a home movie in a childhood rich in joy.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I look out there and it just seems completely hopeless to me. The political system seems so overwhelmingly broken that I have no idea what to do about it.

title: For the Spotlight? Ryan Lochte Was Ready to Do Anything
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  In 2008, one of the swimmers poised to foil Michael Phelpss bid for a record eight Olympic gold medals was his American teammate Ryan Lochte, who was competing against Phelps in the individual medley events. While Phelps adhered to a regimented existence in the athletes village in Beijing, Lochte made himself sick gorging on free Big Macs.

title: Serbia Defeats United States in Womens Volleyball Semifinal
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Maracanzinho Arena came to life on Thursday for the women's volleyball semifinals, but there was one thing missing: the team belonging to Brazil.

title: 100? 200? Doesnt Matter. They Still Cant Catch Usain Bolt.
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Usain Bolt spread his arms wide as his name was announced to the Olympic Stadium crowd late Thursday night. He flashed a grin toward a television camera and wiggled his eyebrows mischievously.

title: Understanding the Controversy Over Caster Semenya
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Caster Semenya of South Africa, heavily favored to win the Olympic womens 800 meters, ran a quick opening round this week and then breezed past reporters.

title: Entertainment for General Audiences
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Its not every day that we get to watch word usage evolve right in front of our eyes, but today Im going to show you how, over the course of about 70 years, a dog can change into a drinking game. Youll love this; its like magic, but in grid form.

title: Donald Trump Steps Out of Character to Voice Unexplained Regrets
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Donald J. Trump on Thursday expressed regret for making statements that have caused personal pain, a rare display of contrition that followed the shake-up of his campaigns leadership this week.

title: John W. Vessey Jr., Who Was Chairman of Joint Chiefs, Dies at 94
description: Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., a soldiers soldier who lied about his age to enlist in the service, won his commission on a battlefield in World War II and became a four-star general and then chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff in the Reagan administration, died Thursday night at his home in North Oaks, Minn. He was 94.

title: U.S. Court Upholds United Nations Immunity in Cholera Suit
description: A United States federal appeals panel has upheld the argument that the United Nations cannot be sued in American courts, dealing a setback in a class-action lawsuit brought on behalf of thousands of cholera victims in Haiti.

title: Rafael Nadal Crashes Out in Cincinnati
Weight Lifter Is First to Be Stripped of Rio Medal for Doping
description: Izzat Artykov, a weight lifter from Kyrgyzstan, became the first athlete at the Rio Olympics to be stripped of a medal after failing a drug test. Serghei Tarnovschi of Moldova could soon join him for failing a precompetition doping test before earning bronze in 1,000-meter canoe singles.

title: Mens Basketball: Spain Makes U.S.A. Sweat, but Just a Little
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The United States mens basketball team defeated the team that many felt would be their toughest opposition of the Olympics, beating Spain, 82-76, in a semifinal on Friday.

title: A U.S. First, and the Usual for Jamaica
description: Helen Louise Maroulis became the first woman from the United States to win a wrestling gold medal. Usain Bolt won the 200-meter dash, cementing his legacy as a sprinter.

title: Frank Ocean Releases a Visual Album, With More to Come
description: Frank Ocean is taking delayed gratification to a new level with the extended release of his new album.

title: Whats on TV Friday: A Bigger Splash and Fearless
description: A rock star and her lover see their vacation go awry in A Bigger Splash, starring Tilda Swinton and Matthias Schoenaerts. A young womans disappearance sends her lover and best friend into each others arms in LAvventura. And Brazilians take a wild ride in Fearless.

description: FRONT PAGE

description: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

title: Mets Bats Wake Up, Briefly, but Pitching Fails Them
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Predict an outcome from this scenario: Jacob deGrom, the Mets best pitcher, was staked to a four-run lead when Justin Ruggiano, fresh off the disabled list, smashed a grand slam off Madison Bumgarner, one of the best starters in baseball. In addition, the San Francisco Giants offense has been meager of late.

title: The Week in Pictures, Aug. 19, 2016
description: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

title: Larry Wilmores Characteristically Low-Key Farewell
description: The emotional high point of The Nightly Show With Larry Wilmore on Thursday night  the moment that resonated  belonged to the hosts former boss, Jon Stewart. Dropping by to support Mr. Wilmore on the final episode of his Comedy Central series, which was abruptly canceled this week, Mr. Stewart said, What you were tasked to do, you have done and done beautifully. This, Mr. Stewart said, was to provide a forum for underserved voices.

title: Fractured Lands: Arab Writers on a Region in Crisis
description: Last week, The New York Times Magazine devoted a special issue to a report on the historic tumult and turmoil in the Middle East. Here, three Arab writers respond, and reflect on the legacy of the Arab Spring revolutions.

title: Were Winning!
description: Looking for refuge from the gust of insanity blowing across the fruited plain, I went to the highest perch I could reach in North Cascades National Park. I needed a break from the politician who has roused the lowest impulses of the American character.

title: The Flood Brings Us Together. Lets Not Forget the Divides.
description: Baton Rouge, La.  Her eyes were a shade of red that could be achieved only by equal parts crying, worry and lack of sleep. Ive lost everything, she said. In the past week, Ive heard that phrase too many times.

title: The Good, the Bad and the Gold
description: The story of the two runners in a 5,000-meter heat, Abbey DAgostino of the United States and Nikki Hamblin of New Zealand, helping each other to the finish line after they suffered a nasty tumble has become the sportsmanship moment of the Rio Olympics, depicted in many an article, post and video clip as a counterpoint to all the bad swirling around the Games.

title: The Bowe Bergdahl Case and Other Threats to the Press
description: The cases against Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, who is accused of being an Army deserter and is being prosecuted in military court, and Nasean Bonie, a former building superintendent in the Bronx who was recently convicted of killing a tenant, have little in common. But litigation stemming from both could set a dismal precedent for press freedoms by broadening the criteria under which prosecutors are allowed to obtain unpublished material gathered by journalists.

title: How Garbage Trucks Can Drive a Green Future
description: The administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York has set clear, aggressive goals for reducing greenhouse gas emissions that would make the city a national leader in mitigating climate change. But other decisions now in the works could prevent the city from meeting them.

title: Obamacare Hits a Bump
description: More than two and a half years have gone by since the Affordable Care Act, a.k.a. Obamacare, went fully into effect. Most of the news about health reform since then has been good, defying the dire predictions of right-wing doomsayers. But this week has brought some genuine bad news: The giant insurer Aetna announced that it would be pulling out of many of the exchanges, the special insurance markets the law established.

title: Is Our Country as Good as Our Athletes Are?
description: Pessimism has flavored this election campaign. America is in decline. The country is on the wrong track. Were getting our clocks cleaned in global trade deals. Were still suffering from the humiliation of Iraq.

title: Picture Prompt | Favorite Olympic Athletes
description: Have you been watching the Olympics? Who have been your favorite athletes in the Games this summer? Who have been your least favorite? Why?

title: Hong Kong Objects to Alien Presence in Its Skyline (No, Not the Spaceship)
description: HONG KONG  Why are they here? asks a tag line on a poster for the forthcoming Hollywood science-fiction movie Arrival, an apparent reference to the visitors aboard a mysterious spaceship hovering above Hong Kongs harbor.

title: Chilling Tale in Dutertes Drug War: Father and Son Killed in Police Custody
description: MANILA  Even amid the slaughter of President Rodrigo Dutertes war on drugs, the killings of Renato and Jaypee Bertes stand out.

title: From Montreal to Minnesota, by Inland Sea
description: The waiting room at St. Lambert Lock in Montreal looks out at a quarter-mile of chain-link fence, six security camera towers, a blaze-orange derrick and a guardhouse. There, three armed men stare at a 750-foot stretch of placid, blue-green water waiting to lift 33,000-ton freighters up along the St. Lawrence Seaway.

title: When the Dog Decides Where You Live
description: Last year, Kaitlin and Ben Fund decided to give up their rental near Penn Station and look for an apartment several blocks south of the commuter tumult. It was a perfectly understandable decision, but the couple worried about how the move would affect their golden retriever, Hobie.

title: Poor Sanitation Persisted at U.N. Missions Long After Haiti Cholera Crisis
description: Years after medical studies linked the 2010 cholera outbreak in Haiti to infected United Nations peacekeepers, the organizations auditors found that poor sanitation practices remained unaddressed not only in its Haitian mission but also in at least six others in Africa and the Middle East, a review of their findings shows.

title: Bikini Moms and Petty Squabbles at a Beach Club Fit for Reality TV
description: They are hard to miss, the four glamorous women in bikinis who sunbathe every day in the same spot on the sand at the Silver Gull Beach Club.

description: August is generally considered off-season among book people. The big summer blockbusters have already come out. Publishing people are out of the office. Everyones biding his or her time for the big books of fall.

description: Question:

title: Exxon Mobil Fraud Inquiry Said to Focus More on Future Than Past
description: For more than a year, much of the public scrutiny of Exxon Mobil was captured by the #Exxonknew hashtag  shorthand for revelations about decades-old research on climate change conducted by the company while it funded groups promoting doubt about climate science.

title: These Airlines Are Making It Easier to Share Miles
description: It is nearly a given in the world of loyalty programs that things can only get worse. Every change that a travel company or a retailer refers to as an enhancement, it seems, will actually mean that you earn fewer points, need more of them to earn rewards, or have less flexibility in redeeming them.

title: The Cost of Sharing Frequent Flier Miles
description: Want to share your frequent flier miles with a friend or a family member? It may cost you. Here are the pooling policies at some of the biggest United States airlines. Some may have minimum or maximum transfer amounts per transaction or per year. Taxes may also be an added cost.

description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: A Wish for My Daughters
description: Yesterday, the waves on the lake were as muscular, as quick, as white-capped as any Ive seen in the five summers weve been renting a house in Douglas, Mich., on the states southwestern shore. The vast blue expanse of Lake Michigan can be especially daunting on a windy day, here at the edges. Forbidding, even.

title: Donald Trump Catches Critics by Surprise With One Word: Regret
description: Donald J. Trump went Thursday night where Donald J. Trump, the candidate, seemed to have never gone before: He expressed broad regret about some of his caustic language during the campaign.

description: Take the Quiz

title: Morning Agenda: Italys Banks Pile On the Debt
description: Feltrinelli, an Italian publisher, stacked up three consecutive years of losses totaling nearly 11 million euros, or about $12.4 million. It managed to secure a 50 million line of credit at an interest rate below what top-rated companies in Europe were paying.

title: For the Olympian Gwen Jorgensen, the Triathlon is a Mental Race
description: When the Olympic triathlete Gwen Jorgensen was competing in London four years ago, an unexpected flat tire at mile 13 rattled her to the core. Her hands were shaking as she rushed over to the mechanical pit, and it took her a moment to calm down and explain the situation before getting the repair and jumping back in the race. A medal contender at the start, she settled for a devastating 38th-place finish.

title: 1916: Austrians Bomb Venice, Again
description: VENICE  There is great indignation throughout Venice, and indeed throughout Italy, at the wanton destruction by Austrian aviators of the church of Santa Maria Formosa and the damaging of that of San Pietro in Castello.

title: The 8.7.16 Issue
description: RE: PATIENT H.M.

title: How to Pass a C.I.A. Background Check
description: Withholding information from us will not work in your favor, says Ronald S. Patrick, deputy director of talent development at the Central Intelligence Agency, which receives up to 150,000 rsums a year. Applicants who are offered a job go through a monthslong security clearance, including an intense background check. To pass, you cant have been convicted of a felony (Thats a showstopper for us); also, no recent illegal drug use. You will be asked about drugs in the application. Tell the truth. We dont expect you to be shockingly, squeaky clean, Patrick says. We expect you to have lived a life, to have exercised bad judgment, to have gone through adolescence and made mistakes.

title: Why Is the Countrys Most Dominant Distance Runner Not in Rio?
description: On a blustery Sunday in late March, Edward Cheserek reclined in a leather chair and narrated his journey through the aftermath of a Kenyan monsoon. We were sitting in a corner athletic-department conference room at the University of Oregon, Eugene, overlooking Hayward Field, which steamed in the rain, as track and fields Fenway Park ought to. The room was carpeted in Ducks green and everywhere decorated with the competitive grimaces of Oregons many famed distance runners. Across from me was its latest star, a 22-year-old senior from Kenya, who sat pecking at his iPhone, a leg dangling over the chair arm.

title: Seeing What My Muscles Can Do
description: On Day 3 of the 31st Olympiad, I sat on the couch with my 11-year-old daughter and watched the Hungarian swimmer Katinka Hosszu  a.k.a. the Iron Lady  roll out onto the pool deck like the assassin that she is. The woman is tough as nails, in her body and her mind. She knifed into the water; her back and shoulders exploded; she won gold in the 100-meter backstroke. Among her mottos is this: The problem is not the problem. The problem is your attitude toward the problem.

title: Think Your Obamacare Plan Will Be Like Employer Coverage? Think Again
description: When Obamacare was developed, one goal was to allow middle-class Americans to use the new marketplaces to buy the same kind of health insurance they had at their jobs. People could retire early, or quit a corporate job and become a freelancer, and still have the great care and financial protection that come with high-end plans.

title: When Loyalty Delays a Career Change
description: I have a two-part question, related to a major career shift. Specifically, I want to leave the publishing business to pursue a manual trade. Its something Ive wanted to do for a long time, but Ive been scared because of cultural pressure to stick with a more staid, office-based career. And I still wonder: Is this a crazy change to make?

title: The Plum Eater
description: From the age of 39 to 51, I have worked as a kitchen hand. It hasnt been such a bad way to make a living. It has afforded me time to walk about, meet people, write, read, listen to music, watch movies, practice my golf swing. It has always been my wish that one day I might have a companion in life, but as yet that hasnt happened.

title: The Familiar Has Taken Leave
description: Selected by Matthew Zapruder.

title: Not Forgotten: Alice Coachman, Who Won a Gold Medal but Came Home to Segregation
description: Alice Coachman became the first black woman to win a gold medal, at the 1948 Olympics in London, then returned to racism in the United States.

description: This interview with Bracken P. Darrell, C.E.O. of Logitech, the technology accessories maker, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Becoming Disabled
description: Not long ago, a good friend of mine said something revealing to me: I dont think of you as disabled, she confessed.

title: On DVD, an American in Paris (and in the Soviet Union)
description: American insouciance melts Russian sanctimony in Arthur Freeds 1957 production Silk Stockings, the jauntiest of Cold War movies.

title: Bill Opening Wilderness Areas to Bikes Also Opens Debate
description: BELLINGHAM, Wash.  Rose Wakeland, 13, who got her first two-wheeler at age 2, flew over a jump on a dirt trail here one recent morning like an old hand. Good one, Rose! a friend shouted.

title: The Gates at Harvard Have Stories to Tell
description: To Blair Kamin, the Pulitzer Prize-winning architecture critic of The Chicago Tribune, the wrought-iron gates that ring the campus green at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass., are more than decorative. They are storytellers through design and time capsules of university history, which he and the students he taught as a fellow at the schools Nieman Foundation for Journalism explore in the book Gates of Harvard Yard (Princeton Architectural Press). Its thoughtful essays examine the 25 gates surrounding the yard, popular with tourists as well as students, alumni and staff. The following are excerpts from an interview with Mr. Kamin, the editor of the book.

title: Its Not a Chicago Steakhouse, but Theres Plenty of Beef
description: The building had the right bones.

title: A Storied Chicago Hotel With a Modern Spirit of Play
description: Doubles start at $289.

title: Trumps America
description: Four of 10 voters are still squarely in Donald J. Trumps camp. To understand who they are we turn to J.D. Vance, the author of Hillbilly Elegy, which has been described as the best explanation of Mr. Trumps political rise. Were also joined by the New York Times reporters Nicholas Confessore and Nate Cohn.

title: Understanding the Trump Voter
description: Yes, Donald Trump has fallen behind in the national polls. All of them. But heres a number you dont hear enough: 41 percent of voters are still supporting him. Four out of every 10 people.

title: Treasury Wants to End Tax Deal for Some Family-Owned Businesses
description: The Treasury Department has moved a step closer to tightening the way family limited partnerships are valued for tax purposes. And the prospect that the tax code could be changed by the end of this year has tax planners pushing their clients to consider stepping up estate and business planning, or risk paying more taxes.

title: In Newark, a New Chapter Unfolding
description: In Newarks Central Ward, not far from the site of the 1967 riots, a market-rate rental building opened earlier this year with 152 apartments and its name, 24 Jones, emblazoned in cheerful orange lettering on the blocky, colorful facade. Promotional materials invite prospective tenants to come to a place where everything is possible.

title: A Single Mom Escapes the Friend Zone, One Non-Date at a Time
description: The nicest thing I own is the first thing you see when you walk into my house: a red handmade rug bought in Tehran, haggled over in Farsi and delivered, in person, to the Brooklyn apartment of the man who would become my husband.

title: Heres a New Angle on the Shape of the World
description: Its time to start thinking inside the box.

title: Germany, Like France, Questions Place of Islamic Veils in Its Society
description: BERLIN  Europes battle over public attire for Muslim women moved on Friday from the outcry over banning burkinis in France to a strong call from Chancellor Angela Merkels governing conservative bloc for a ban in Germany on face veils in schools and universities and while driving.

title: 1966: Tumultuous Antiwar Hearing
description: WASHINGTON  The House Un-American Activities Committees explosive probe into anti-Vietnam-war groups ended today [Aug. 19] with more shouts, denunciations and disorderly conduct arrests. Cries of yellow-bellied racist cowards and murderers were flung at the panel and a retired Marine general witness in the fourth day of snarling confrontation between the probers and young leftists.

title: A Happy Warrior in a Faltering Battle for Indonesian Gay Rights
description: SURABAYA, Indonesia  After the United States Supreme Court legalized same-sex  marriage last year, a leading Indonesian television station held a prime-time debate about whether this Muslim-majority democracy should do the same.

title: 2 Are Killed and 17 Injured After New Jersey Buses Collide in Newark
description: Two New Jersey Transit buses collided in Newark during the early morning commute on Friday, killing one driver and a passenger and injuring at least 17 other people, the authorities said.

title: Popcast: Race and Hip-Hop, a Conversation
description: A discussion about the current wave of white rappers trying to elide conversations about race, with varying success.

title: Popcast: Race and Hip-Hop, a Conversation
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | RSS | Stitcher| Audioboom

title: Rio Today: Olympic Official Jailed, and Relay Gold for U.S. and Jamaica
description: Europes top Olympic official, arrested at an oceanside hotel here this week for scalping tickets to the Rio Games, has been denied bail and sent to Rios Bangu Penitentiary Complex, a maximum-security jail.

title: Chinese Claim That World Accepts Its Organ Transplant System Is Rebutted
description: HONG KONG  Chinese state news media and pro-Beijing newspapers in Hong Kong said on Friday that an international organ transplant conference in Hong Kong demonstrated that Chinas transplant system, which for decades used organs from executed prisoners, had global backing.

title: Edgar Ramrez Speaks Five Languages and Has One Peculiar Habit
description: To portray the Panamanian boxing legend Roberto Durn in Hands of Stone, Edgar Ramrez learned how to throw a punch  and to take one.

title: Does Mozart Defy the Limits of Dance? Mark Morris Begs to Differ.
description: Im sick to death of being told no one can choreograph to Mozart! Mark Morris practically yelled from his desk at the offices of the Mark Morris Dance Group in Brooklyn a few weeks ago. (He is not known for his tact.) Everything is so masterpiecey, youre not supposed to touch it.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Paul Manafort Quits Donald Trumps Campaign After a Tumultuous Run
description: Paul Manafort, a professional Republican political operative since the 1970s, was supposed to impose order on Donald J. Trumps chaotic presidential campaign.

title: Another Reason to Save the Good Stuff
description: One amusing account of whiskys origin holds that it was invented by the Irish as an embrocation for sick mules. Then the Scots learned the knack of distilling fermented grain mash and discovered it was much more enjoyable to drink than rub on the skin of ailing animals.

title: Patient Advocates Help Navigate Health Care
description: After Elsa Newmyers surgery last year went terribly wrong, she was laid up in a hospital bed for months. Dozens of medical bills, some 30 pages long, began piling up. Her husband Larry, who had to manage the payments, was overwhelmed.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Fall of Heaven

title: At the Bottom of a Whisky Glass, a Beautiful Experiment
description: How different are whisky and coffee? Yes, one gets you drunk, and the other wakes you up. But they also linger in different ways.

title: Reeling From Effects of Climate Change, Alaskan Village Votes to Relocate
description: Residents of a small Alaskan village voted this week to relocate their entire community from a barrier island that has been steadily disappearing because of erosion and flooding attributed to climate change.

title: A Challenge To My Fellow Evangelicals
description: Many well-intentioned evangelicals have been drawn to the Republican Party platform with the hope of making an impact on culture and voting their values. But instead of actually helping fill in the hole in our gospel, as Richard Stearns describes in his book of the same title, this focus has had the opposite effect, helping to create the imploding black hole of evangelical politics we are seeing now in the Republican party. As painful as this has been to watch, this may be the best thing that has happened to American evangelism in a long time.

title: Ryan Lochte Apologizes for My Behavior After Rio Robbery Claim
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Ryan Lochte, the 12-time Olympic medal winner who claimed to have been robbed here last weekend by men identifying themselves as police officers, issued an apology on Friday for my behavior in an episode that has cast a pall over the Games.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include a ranch in Montgomery, N.J., and a 1914 house in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: The Latest on the Ryan Lochte Case
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The American swimmers Ryan Lochte, Jimmy Feigen, Jack Conger and Gunnar Bentz left a lavish Olympics party hosted by the French authorities early Sunday morning. They got into a taxi for the ride across Rio de Janeiro to their lodgings in the athletes village. What happened next has been the subject of intense police scrutiny, diplomatic debate and widespread criticism  first for Rios crime problems, and then for the behavior of the four American athletes.

title: Joseph ONeill on The Glamour of Strangeness
description: THE GLAMOUR OF STRANGENESSArtists and the Last Age of the ExoticBy Jamie JamesIllustrated. 364 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $30.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Kim Severson is filling in for Sam Sifton, who emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Tama Janowitz Grows Up
description: SCREAMA Memoir of Glamour and DysfunctionBy Tama JanowitzIllustrated. 285 pp. Dey Street/William Morrow Publishers. $25.99.

title: Death & Co. Plans Its First Branch, in Denver
description: Just in time for its 10th anniversary, Death & Co., the seminal cocktail bar in the East Village, is planning a second location, in Denver.

title: Eight Graphic Black and White Bags
description: In strong prints and classic shapes, these styles are thoroughly Mod  and thoroughly modern.

title: Gomorrah Brings a Familiar Italian Import: Dark Crime
description: ROME  Roberto Savianos best-selling 2007 book, Gomorrah, his reportage about the Neapolitan crime syndicate the Camorra, was dark. Matteo Garrones award-winning 2009 film adaptation  was darker. And the hit Italian television series of the same name is by far the darkest.

title: Ts New Womens Fashion Issue: Editors Letter
description: A desire to have fewer things in our lives can be seen in phenomena as diverse as the decline in luxury spending and the cult success of the decluttering superstar Marie Kondo. Whether were buying fewer things or just bidding thanks and adieu to things we already own that fail to spark joy in us, we seem, collectively, to feel we need less. Which, of course, is true.

title: In a New Biography, How Marconis Start-Up Changed the World
description: MARCONIThe Man Who Networked the WorldBy Marc RaboyIllustrated. 863 pp. Oxford University Press. $39.95.

title: Daily Report: Uber Dominates Thursday
description: It was sort of a slow news week in Silicon Valley. Then along came Uber.

title: Halt and Catch Fire Clears Its Cache for Season 3
description: ATLANTA  When it comes to AMCs 1980s tech drama Halt and Catch Fire, its main cast members have been one of the shows few constants. The relationships, subject matter and locations have all gotten a CTRL-ALT-DEL at the outset of each of the shows three 10-episode seasons.

title: God Speed the Plow: The British and Their Relationship to the Land
description: LANDSKIPPINGPainters, Ploughmen and PlacesBy Anna PavordIllustrated. 250 pp. Bloomsbury. $35.

title: In the Shadow of the Olympic Park, Womens Sports Lag Behind
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Across the city from the Olympic Park, in a community sports center called Vila Olmpica Greip, though it doesnt have a thing to do with the Olympics, a group of teenage girls has arrived to play handball. They want to play handball. They need to play handball.

title: Coming Out to His Conservative Parents: Is It Time?
description: I am about to be a senior in high school, and Im gay. No one knows except my best friend, a straight girl. She keeps telling me to come out, saying its the courageous thing to do. But my parents, unlike hers, are extremely conservative and religious. (Ive heard my mother say that gay people can change if they want to.) I want to be brave, and I know the world is better now for gay men and lesbians. But I dont want to be thrown out of the house. What should I do?

title: A Web Series About Raising Kids and Lowering Expectations
description: The web series began as a catastrophe.

title: In Florida, Pregnant Women Cover Up and Stay Inside Amid Zika Fears
description: MIAMI  Amanda Paradiz is 16 weeks pregnant, and she has a mission: to get through her entire pregnancy without a single mosquito bite.

title: Picking a Digital Publishing Format
description: Q. What is the best publishing method for digital books? I dont want my readership to be limited to users who have Apple devices if I use iBooks Author. Is the .pdf format viable?

title: As Donald Trump Falters, Democrats Plan to Press Fight for Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON  Emboldened by their electoral prospects in November, Democrats are planning to redouble their efforts to make the fate of the Supreme Court a signature election issue, with the Democratic leader in the Senate threatening to stall Republican legislative priorities if no action is taken on the confirmation of Judge Merrick B. Garland.

title: A Novel Imagines Putin Is Retired and Has Dementia
description: THE SENILITY OF VLADIMIR P.By Michael Honig329 pp. Pegasus Books. $24.95.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: I Contain Multitudes
description: This week, Ed Yong talks about I Contain Multitudes; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Meghan Daum discusses Egos, her new column about memoirs; and Gregory Cowles and John Williams on what were reading. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Marveling at the Soaking Wet Rockettes of the Olympics
description: Fred Astaire, as the famous saying goes, may have been a great dancer, but Ginger Rogers did everything he did  only backward and in high heels.

title: News Anchors Mad as Hell in Network and Suicidal in Kate Plays Christine
description: On the morning of July 15, 1974, Christine Chubbuck, the 29-year-old anchor of Suncoast Digest, a talk show broadcast in the Sarasota, Fla., area, made a distressing announcement to her viewers. In keeping with Channel 40s policy of bringing you the latest in blood and guts and in living color, she said, you are going to see another first: an attempted suicide.

title: A Poet Subverts the Defense Departments Official Dictionary
description: LOOKPoemsBy Solmaz Sharif98 pp. Graywolf Press. Paper, $16.

title: Art Deco Luxury for $24 Million
description: Daniel Stephen Hafner, the chief executive of the software company that operates the travel website Kayak.com, bought a four-bedroom four-and-a-half-bath duplex at Walker Tower, a 24-story Art Deco condominium conversion in Chelsea, according to city records. At $24,000,000, it was the most expensive closed sale of the week.

title: Sebastian Coe Seeks to Rebuild Trust in Track and Field
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The door opened to the presidents box on Wednesday, and Sebastian Coe, standing and watching the steeplechase below, was outlined against a backdrop of empty blue seats in the vast Olympic Stadium.

title: In Emma Rathbones New Novel, a 26-Year-Old Virgin Seeks Sex
description: LOSING ITBy Emma Rathbone258 pp. Riverhead Books. $26.

title: The Latest and Best in Crime Fiction
description: Welcome to MichaelKorytas latest nightmare. In RISE THE DARK (Little, Brown, $26), Eli Pate, a self-anointed messiah capable of calling up a homegrown army of more than 200 heavily armed and deeply paranoid white men, is preparing to shut down the electrical grid supplying energy to half the country. (Good night, Seattle. Good night, Portland.) Very few, very brave linemen have the nerve and technical skills to pull off this feat. One of them is Jay Baldwin from Red Lodge, Mont., and to ensure his participation Elis confederates are holding Jays wife hostage. When darkness fell, chaos would reign, and Eli intends to be the man who controlled the chaos.

title: What You Should Watch: Amazon Pilots and Mission: Impossible  Rogue Nation
description: Welcome to Watching, The New York Timess what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. You can browse previous guides here, and to receive recommendations straight to your inbox, sign up here. Stay tuned for our coming website.

title: Ban the Box? An Effort to Stop Discrimination May Actually Increase It
description: Policies aimed at ending discrimination against people with criminal records may actually have the unintended consequence of increasing racial discrimination.

title: The Mets Sputniks, Once Stuck in Orbit, Go Back in Service
description: The sputniks, as the Metropolitan Operas starburst-shaped crystal chandeliers are known, were stuck in orbit for more than a year. But thanks to a mechanical overhaul, they can now come back to earth  ensuring that a beloved Met ritual can resume next month as the curtain rises on the companys 50th-anniversary season at Lincoln Center.

title: Recalling an Early Martha Stewart at the Webb-Deane-Stevens Museum
description: Forced by exhaustion to leave his career as a Congregational minister in his early 40s, Wallace Nutting turned his photography hobby into a thriving business. That led him to buy and restore several Colonial-era homes during the early 20th century and to become a leading authority on early American antiques.

title: Paperback Row
description: Seven new paperbacks to check out this week.

title: Review: Dancing in the Aisles to Mamma Mia! in Northport
description: Catchy tunes and a clever plot helped make Mamma Mia! a 14-year-long hit on Broadway, and those qualities continue to provide buoyancy for the production at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport.

title: Review: A Kings Long Goodbye in Madison
description: Death is not to be laughed about, usually, but Exit the King is a tragicomic consideration of mortality that spins a good deal of absurd mirth from a grave subject.

title: Review: At Penguin Rep Theater, Lonely Neighbors Bust a Move
description: For a charming play rich with positive sentiment, Mark St. Germains Dancing Lessons, now getting a funny and skillful production at Penguin Rep Theater in Stony Point, is driven by some pretty downcast dynamics.

title: Trumps New High of New Lows
description: If the disgusting and corrupt media covered me honestly and didnt put false meaning into the words I say, Donald Trump tweeted on Aug. 14, I would be beating Hillary by 20 percent.

title: A Foreign Correspondents Day at the Beach
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this article, Kirk Semple, a Times correspondent covering Mexico, Central America and the Caribbean, shares a lesson he learned recently on assignment in Tulum: Beware of tourism directors bearing gifts.

title: War Stories
description: THESE HEROIC, HAPPY DEADStoriesBy Luke Mogelson184 pp. Tim Duggan, $24.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Hell or High Water
description: David Mackenzie narrates a scene from his film featuring Ben Foster and Chris Pine.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: I Contain Multitudes
description: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

title: Keeping a Cool Head in the Kitchen When Temperatures Rise
description: We all know people who just dont cook in June, July and August. Too hot, they claim. Why heat up the kitchen? But these folks dont subsist only on ice cream and cold beverages. The food they eat instead generally comes from someone elses efforts.

title: Inside the List
description: Election Fever Dream: If Hillary Clinton did not exist, conservative writers would have to invent her  if, that is, they wanted to continue churning out best sellers. With little more than two months until Election Day, three of the top five spots on the hardcover nonfiction list are occupied by anti-Clinton books: Gary J. Byrnes Crisis of Character (with Grant M. Schmidt) at No. 5; Dinesh DSouzas Hillarys America at No.4; and Armageddon, by Dick Morris and Eileen McGann, at No. 3. Morris, of course, was Bill Clintons political adviser and chief campaign strategist during the 1990s, and he and McGann, his wife, have written other negative treatises about the Clintons with the zeal of converts. Morris resigned from Bill Clintons 1996 re-election campaign after a tabloid revealed Morriss affair with a prostitute; he has since become the chief political commentator and correspondent for The National Enquirer.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are in Morningside Heights, East Harlem and Brooklyn Heights.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: David Mackenzie Narrates a Scene From Hell or High Water
description: Two brothers rob banks in Texas, and dont do a great job oft it, in Hell or High Water, starring Ben Foster and Chris Pine. Its from the British director David Mackenzie, who creates both levity and tension in his modest thriller.

title: Nate Parker and the Limits of Empathy
description: As I get older, I try to have more empathy for other people, for the ways we fail one another. I often fall short. Today, I am struggling to have empathy for Nate Parker, a man experiencing the height of his career while being forced to reckon with his past.

title: The Fight For Falluja
description: Experience firsthand the battles Iraqi forces endured to retake the city of Falluja from ISIS.

title: 10 Things to Do Now in NYC
description: A guide to cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And there's much more where these came from.

title: Got a Classic Piece? Here Comes the Sequel.
description: Composers have always wanted to fondle the pieces that they love, John Adams, of Nixon in China fame, said in a recent interview. They have long borrowed from their predecessors: quoted them, evoked them, effaced them, mocked them. They have transcribed them, orchestrated them, built sets of variations from their seeds. They have tried to build on them, forget them, ignore them.

title: Slow Learners
description: Larry Summers has a very nice essay that takes off from a new paper by John Williams at the San Francisco Fed, which is noteworthy because Williams is the highest-placed Fed official yet to suggest that maybe the inflation target should be higher. Its not a new argument  see, for example, my paper for the ECB in 2014, but seeing it come from a senior official is news.

title: What to Buy at Kanye Wests New York Pablo Pop-Up Shop
description: Before his Saint Pablo tour kicks off, Kanye West is selling exclusive merchandise in cities around the world.

title: An Aging Boy Band Calls It Quits, but Japan Cant Let Go
description: TOKYO  For nearly three decades, millions of Japanese have clamored for their every album, lined up with breathless anticipation for their concerts and gathered on Monday nights for their hit television show.

title: Coaching Tip via Text: A New York Olympian Is Instructed to Have Fun
description: Just play.

title: Pregnant Women Advised to Avoid Travel to Active Zika Zone in Miami Beach
description: MIAMI BEACH  With the Zika virus spreading to Miami Beach, federal health officials on Friday advised pregnant women not to visit a 20-block stretch of one of the countrys most alluring tourist destinations. They also told them to consider postponing travel anywhere in Miami-Dade County.

title: The Dodgers Defy Expectations, and Logic, After Their Best Player Goes Down
description: PHILADELPHIA  The last time Clayton Kershaw took the mound, in late June, the Los Angeles Dodgers dropped to eight games out of first place. Everything has been uphill since they lost the best pitcher in baseball.

title: The Obama Years: The Best of Times to Be a Stock Investor
description: President Obama hasnt boasted much about the performance of the stock market during his time in office, but if he were inclined, he could do so with gusto.

title: New York State Bans Use of Unclaimed Dead as Cadavers Without Consent
description: A bill that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York signed into law this week concerns the dead as much as the living and signals a big change in public attitudes about what one owes the other.

title: Burrata With Romano Beans and Eggplant
description: Crisp Romano beans, roasted eggplant and luscious garlic confit come together with burrata to create a hearty main course salad.

title: Consider This Permission to Eat Burrata for Dinner
description: Once, in a restaurant in Puglia, Italy, I ate an entire burrata by myself.

title: The Olympic Games and Athletic Sex Assignment
description: This commentary was recently published in the Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Colicchio & Sons to Close
description: After six years in business, the chef Tom Colicchio will close Colicchio & Sons, his spacious restaurant on the edge of the meatpacking district, after dinner on Sept. 4.

title: My 10 Favorite Books: Garth Greenwell
description: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the Garth Greenwell, author of What Belongs to You. He shares his list exclusively with T.

title: An Appetite for Harlem Apartments
New Flophouses: Chinatowns Internet Cafes
description: Amid a housing crisis, the Lower Manhattan businesses serve as an unlikely safety net, where people pay as little as $7 a night for a roof over their heads.

title: At Chappaqua Station, Local Food in an Old Depot
description: Im high on Chappaqua Station cafe, and not only because Im a fan of repurposed rail stations.

title: New Flophouses: Chinatowns Internet Cafes
description: At the beginning of the millennium, the internet cafe was a beacon of the future. But now, amid a lack of affordable housing and a surge in homelessness in New York City, these vestiges of the dot-com boom have become an unlikely safety net, where people pay as little as $7 a night for a roof over their heads. On any given evening in the few remaining 24-hour cybercafes in Manhattans Chinatown, chairs are filled with the exhausted bodies of those who have lived there for weeks or months  or by some accounts, even years.

title: Review: Park & Orchard Reopens With Seasonal Fare and Biscuits Galore
description: Located in a former sheet metal factory near a tangle of roads and highways in East Rutherford, Park & Orchard feels as far from a park or an orchard as you can imagine.

title: The Mediterranean Makings of a Young Chef, Greg Grossman, at Oreya in Southampton
description: Hear that? Thats the sound of critics sharpening their knives for Greg Grossman, the executive chef and owner of Oreya, which opened in June in Southampton.

title: Review: At Lugano Wine Bar in Old Greenwich, a Long List of Fresh Offerings
description: The building on Boston Post Road in Old Greenwich that now houses the Lugano Wine Bar & Salumeria has been home to a number of restaurants over the years.

title: Brazils Economic Crisis Forces Cuts to Paralympics in Rio
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The Paralympic Games, set to start here on Sept. 7, are in a precarious financial position, with significant budget cuts announced Friday.

title: Anthony Weiner Says His Wife Never Agreed to That Documentary
description: Caged mongoose that he is, Anthony Weiner is not easily contained. Neither was my interview with the former congressman, mayoral candidate and apparent sexting recidivist, which appears in this weekends Talk feature of the magazine.

title: Jonas Mekas Gets a Look at His Life Through Another Filmmakers Eyes
description: Jonas Mekas reckons that he has been to tens of thousands of movies in his 93 years, but he had never experienced one quite the way he did on Monday afternoon at a screening in Manhattan.

title: Ryan Howard and Ryan Zimmerman Cleared of Doping Accusations
description: Major League Baseball said on Friday that Ryan Howard and Ryan Zimmerman did not violate the leagues ban on the use of performance-enhancing drugs in the wake of accusations made by a pharmacist in a documentary produced by Al Jazeera.

title: The Playlist: Metallica Flickers Back to Life, and Tayla Struts Into the Spotlight
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos  and anything else that strikes them as intriguing  in the Playlist. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this format? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com.

title: Activists See Racial Bias in Suspects Treatment After Gruesome Florida Killing
description: While investigators in Florida are struggling to understand what prompted an attacker to approach two strangers this week, stab and beat them to death, and then chew on one victims face, many activists see racial bias in the way the police treated the suspect, a white 19-year-old college student.

title: How Carlos Varella and Andressa Junqueira, Rockaways Restaurateurs, Spend Their Sundays
description: The sweethearts of the Rockaway food scene this summer, Carlos Varella and Andressa Junqueira, run the Brazilian restaurant Beach Bistro 96 out of a spruced-up shanty virtually within earshot of the surf. Their corner often resembles a cocktail party for the scantily clad, as guests wait for orders, or a seat inside. Everyone likes to be there. The music is very nice. We play bossa nova, said Ms. Junqueira, 33. She and Mr. Varella, 42, are Brazilian but met in Mexico City while working as models (Ms. Junqueira is still a model). The couple live with their sons, Nicolas, 8, and Kalani, 8 months, in an apartment near the restaurant. For this interview, Ms. Junqueira did the talking.

title: Queen Annes Lace: New Yorks Midsummer Snowflakes
description: In the intense heat of midsummer, abandoned fields and untrimmed roadsides sometimes quite unexpectedly burst into flower. Perhaps it is Augusts furious thundershowers that provide the environmental cue, but many plants put on their best show when it is 90 degrees and muggy. Even heat-stressed New Yorkers stop to stare at these free pop-up shows. And from their expressions, it is quite likely the first time they have noticed a particular forsaken lot in its profuse bloom.

title: The Majestic Hudson and Its Valleys Colorful Denizens
description: Think of The History of the Hudson River Valley From the Civil War to Modern Times (The Overlook Press, $45) less as a commonplace chronological history than as a thematic collection of illustrative postcards sent by Vernon Benjamin, a former journalist who has lectured at Bard and Marist Colleges.

title: Ex-SEAL Member Who Wrote Book on Bin Laden Raid Forfeits $6.8 Million
description: Matt Bissonnette, a former member of Navy SEAL Team 6 who wrote an account of the raid that killed Osama bin Laden, agreed on Friday to forfeit $6.8 million in book royalties and speaking fees and apologized for failing to clear his disclosures with the Pentagon, according to federal court documents.

title: Another Shake-Up of Trumps Campaign Staff
description: To the Editor:

title: When Millennials Say No Thanks to Credit Cards
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding a Common Ground After a Rocky Start
description: Despite Terri Nowak and Dean Alexanders on-again, off-again relationship, they always found their way back to each other. The couple were married on July 29 in Fredenberg Township, Minn.

title: Working Through Their Issues, One Lake at a Time
description: A few weeks before she was to be married, Terri Nowak, her sister and a cousin left Duluth, Minn., for a bachelorette weekend to the Boundary Waters Canoe Area  in the northern part of the state, a place with lakes with names like Saganaga, Fall, Sucker, Moose and Newfound. Their journeys focus was Basswood Lake, a choice Ms. Nowak said had been inspired by an old photo of their paternal grandfather in which he stands before what is believed to be the oldest tree in the state.

title: Refugees Stuck in Limbo in Greece
description: As aid and attention dwindle, more than 57,000 refugees remain stuck in Greece. Their route through the Balkans into Europe was closed off in March, and thousands now wait for their asylum applications to be processed.

title: Could Donald Trump Be Good for Republicans?
description: Donald Trump is the worst presidential candidate Donald Scoggins has seen in over five decades of Republican activism. But for the president of Republicans for Black Empowerment, theres a silver lining to his candidacy. If he loses in November, the party may finally have to take seriously its failure to attract female, minority and younger voters.

title: Cat Exploits, Long Before YouTube
description: The archives of The New York Times reveal a golden era for feline adventures in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

title: In Bolts Long Shadow, Ashton Eatons Excellence Peeks Through
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The decathletes, long ago a source of greater fascination, were in no position Thursday night to be anything more than a warm-up act for the headliner Usain Bolt.

title: Rejection of Takeover Bid at Williams May Stir Up Activists
description: Ignoring an approach from a pipeline rival could stir an activist hornets nest at the Williams Companies. The company, a $21 billion pipeline operator fresh off a failed merger with Energy Transfer, chose not to respond to an offer from the larger Enterprise Products Partners this summer, Reuters reported on Thursday. The rebuff all but invites two investors who joined a board exodus in June to lobby again to oust Alan Armstrong, the Williams chief executive.

title: Australian Premiers Handout Spurs Debate on Best Way to Help Homeless People
description: It was a simple gesture captured in a photograph: Malcolm Turnbull, the prime minister of Australia, leaning over and placing money in the paper cup of a homeless man in Melbourne this week.

title: Some Turtles See Red Better Than You Do
description: You may see red, but you cant see it like some birds and turtles or the ancient eagle-lizards from which they came. According to a study published this month in Proceedings of the Royal Society B, a red gene that originated from dinosaurs isnt just responsible for the red patterns on some birds and some turtles. It also gives them special color vision, allowing them to see differences in shades of red that arent detectable to humans.

title: Should France Ban the Burkini?
description: To the Editor:

title: Republicans Running for Congress Struggle With an Albatross
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Republicans breathed a sigh of relief in late June. Senator Mitch McConnells campaign to lure Senator Marco Rubio into running for re-election in Florida had paid off and Republican control of Congress felt a little more secure.

title: Bird Song Found to Somehow Protect Babies From High Temperatures
description: Though some overachieving parents read and play Mozart to their unborn babies, there is little scientific evidence to suggest that children gain long-term benefits if you expose them to certain sounds before birth.

title: Saudi Arabia Kills Civilians, the U.S. Looks the Other Way
description: In the span of four days earlier this month, the Saudi Arabia-led coalition in Yemen bombed a Doctors Without Borders-supported hospital, killing 19 people; a school, where 10 children, some as young as 8, died; and a vital bridge over which United Nations food supplies traveled, punishing millions.

title: Who Needs Sets or Fancy Costumes for These Mozart Operas?
description: Over the last few summers, Lincoln Centers Mostly Mozart Festival has become an innovative presenter of staged opera. There were miraculously inventive productions of Mozarts Don Giovanni and Le Nozze di Figaro directed and conducted by Ivan Fischer, featuring his crack Budapest Festival Orchestra. Last summer, the festival gave the American stage premiere of George Benjamins Written on Skin, the most important new opera in years.

title: Christie Brinkley, Cindy Sherman and Chuck Close Party in the Hamptons
description: Artists and collectors flock to Guild Halls summer gala, while a new benefit helps Asian elephants.

title: Alienated and Angry, Coal Miners See Donald Trump as Their Only Choice
description: POWELLTON, W.Va.  Deep in the belly of an Appalachian mountain, a powerful machine bored into the earth, its whirring teeth clawing out a stream of glistening coal. Men followed inside the Maple Eagle No. 1 mine, their torches cutting through the dank air. One guided the machine with a PlayStation-like controller; others bolted supports in the freshly cut roof.

title: Christie Brinkley, Cindy Sherman and Chuck Close Take to the Hamptons Circuit
description: Theres something new on the Hamptons charity circuit. Trunks of Love, benefiting Asian elephants and spotlighting the work of Veterinarians International, honored Christie Brinkley and Richard Lair on Aug. 12 at the Baker House. Also that night, Guild Hall drew artists like Chuck Close and Cindy Sherman to its gala. The action migrated from the arts center to nearby Mulford Farm, where the dancing went late.

title: Lyft Is Said to Seek a Buyer, Without Success
description: It is not an easy thing to be an independent ride-hailing company these days.

title: Detached but Sympathetic: Prosecutors Dual Response to Imams Killing
description: In a brief statement this week about the still mysterious murders of a Bangladeshi imam and his assistant, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, captured, perhaps unwittingly, the dueling imperatives a prosecutor faces in a case that strikes at an entire community.

title: Steve Guttenbergs Little Home in the Sky
description: New York apartments are notoriously short on space. A dedicated guest room is a luxury few can afford; the default solution is a sofa bed. Its generally an afterthought, its generally uncomfortable, and maybe thats exactly the point.

title: What I Love | Steve Guttenberg
description: The actor known for roles in Diner, Cocoon and Police Academy, lives in an apartment on the Upper West Side with Emily Smith, a TV reporter.

title: Babies Watching People Eat
description: You may not be surprised to learn that food preference is a social matter. What we choose to eat depends on more than just what tastes good or is healthful. People in different cultures eat different things, and within a culture, what you eat can signal something about who you are.

title: A Suicidologists New Challenge: The George Washington Bridge
description: Madelyn Gould is a preternaturally sunny person. She has a broad, easy smile, a charming Brooklyn accent and an infectious laugh. When she talks about herself, she often starts with the personal: She is the mother of three sons  identical twins who are 35, and one who is 27. She is the grandmother of a 2-year-old boy, and has been married to her husband, a pediatric neurologist, for 38 years.

title: Morgan Stanley Neglected Warnings on Broker
description: A troubling call came in to Morgan Stanleys internal hotline in May 2010.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Obamacare Options? In Many Parts of Country, Only One Insurer Will Remain
description: So much for choice. In many parts of the country, Obamacare customers will be down to one insurer when they go to sign up for coverage next year on the public exchanges.

title: Donald Trump Visits Flood-Damaged Louisiana Area
description: ST. AMANT, La.  If Donald J. Trump were looking for those fed up with the national media and the Obama administration, he had some fertile ground in flood-wrecked southern Louisiana.

title: Is Bandcamp the Holy Grail of Online Record Stores?
description: A lesser-known artist you love makes a new recording  say, the hip-hop group Clipping or the Chicago punk band Mace or the electronic composer Kaitlyn Aurelia Smith. You feel you have to graft it onto your life. How does that go for you these days? Does streaming from Spotify, Apple Music or Tidal answer your needs in terms of audio quality and how well the artist is paid? Do you have a good record store nearby, and does it sell cassettes and vinyl, too? Do you only buy new records directly from artists, with a cash transaction and a handshake? Do you love spending time on iTunes?

title: FringeNYC, a Grab Bag That Calls for Intuition, Not to Mention Dumb Luck
description: If you learn one thing at the New York International Fringe Festival, its not to trust the programs blurbs. And yet what else is there to help make a decision?

title: Headed to Miami? Heres What You Need to Know About Zika
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is suggesting that pregnant women and their partners postpone trips to Miami-Dade County after five people, three of them tourists, were diagnosed with Zika that was transmitted from mosquitos in Miami Beach, the second reported area in the United States where transmissions have occurred. At least fourteen people have contracted the virus from mosquitoes in Miamis Wynwood area, prompting the C.D.C to issue its first call for pregnant women to steer clear of a section in Miami. Here is what travelers need to know if they are in Miami or plan to travel there.

title: Zika, U.S. Presidential Race, Ryan Lochte: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Bloated Pay Came Before Hain Celestials Error
description: The Hain Celestial Group, a maker of natural and organic foods and beverages, has been riding high in the market. But on Monday it came crashing to earth when it disclosed an accounting problem, delayed its full-year financial report and said it probably wouldnt meet its earnings guidance for 2016.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Friday Night Music: Sierra Hull, Black River
description: Not just the virtuosity: the counterpoint!

title: U.S. Officials Move to End Duplicate Health Care Coverage
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is moving to end duplicate coverage for tens of thousands of people who are enrolled in Medicaid and simultaneously receiving federal subsidies to help pay for private health insurance under the Affordable Care Act.

title: What We Know and What We Dont Know About the Zika Cases in South Florida
description: Zika transmission has been confirmed in two neighborhoods in the Miami area, and pregnant women have been advised to avoid both locations. Federal health officials have also suggested that pregnant women and their sexual partners consider avoiding the entire Miami area. Zika infections are also occurring in Puerto Rico and in Latin American and Caribbean countries.

title: U.N. Leader Urges Member States to Fund Haitis Cholera Recovery
description: Just days after the United Nations acknowledged playing a role in a cholera outbreak in Haiti, and a day after it was ruled immune from related lawsuits by a United States court, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon on Friday called on the organizations member states to provide the money and resources needed to end the epidemic and help Haiti recover.

title: Germany Defeats Sweden to Win First Soccer Gold
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Pia Sundhages impressive Olympic adventure came to an end on Friday when her upstart Swedish team ended up with the silver medal in womens soccer while Germany grabbed the gold.

title: Ex-Theater Agent Charged With Raising $165,000 for Fake Broadway Play
description: A onetime theater agent was arrested Friday and charged with bilking his friends by raising money for a nonexistent Broadway play that he claimed was to star the actress Lupita Nyongo.

title: Amtrak Picks Freight Rail Veteran as New Leader at a Critical Time
description: Amtrak, which is pressing to build a new rail tunnel under the Hudson River between New York City and New Jersey, on Friday named a freight rail veteran as its next chief executive.

title: Judge Orders Written Testimony From Hillary Clinton on Emails
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge on Friday ordered Hillary Clinton to provide written testimony under oath about why she set up a private computer server to send and receive emails while secretary of state, ensuring that the issue will continue to dog her presidential campaign until the eve of the election.

title: Russia Asserts Its Military Might in Syria
description: MOSCOW  Russia flexed its muscles again over Syria on Friday, for the first time launching cruise missiles at targets from warships in the Mediterranean Sea days after beginning bombing runs from a base in Iran.

title: Ernst Nolte, Historian Whose Views on Hitler Caused an Uproar, Dies at 93
description: Ernst Nolte, a German revisionist historian who broke academic taboos by equating Nazism with Bolshevism and who was denounced as an apologist for Hitler and even the Holocaust, died on Thursday in Berlin. He was 93.

title: Donald Trump Enters Ad Wars Trailing Hillary Clinton in Spending
description: A transport filled with refugees. Grainy images of undocumented immigrants being escorted to a waiting patrol car by a police officer. A handcuffed suspect who came into the United States from somewhere else.

title: At Viacom, Now Comes the Hard Part
description: In the summer of 1987, Sumner M. Redstone wrested control of Viacom in a hostile corporate takeover that left scorched relationships with the companys management. Still bitter, executives sent Thomas E. Dooley, Viacoms 30-year-old treasurer, to greet Mr. Redstone when he visited the Viacom office, the new boss wearing a plaid jacket bought on his way, the Filenes Basement price tag still visible.

title: Know English? For New York Cabdrivers, Thats No Longer Required
description: Hail a yellow taxi in New York City, and there is a good chance the driver is from another country. Passengers are regularly exposed to a range of languages that span the globe, from Spanish to Bengali to Urdu.

title: Philip Alstons Draft Report on the U.N. and the Haiti Cholera Outbreak
description: A U.N. adviser criticizes the organization for its "morally unconscionable, legally indefensible, and politically self-defeating" response to the epidemic.

title: The U.N.s Cholera Admission and What Comes Next
description: This week, a phrase came out of United Nations headquarters that I thought I would never hear. A spokesman for Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon referred to the organizations own involvement in the 2010 outbreak of cholera in Haiti.

title: Ronald DeLuca, Ad Man Who Helped Revive Iacoccas Chrysler, Dies at 91
description: Ronald DeLuca, who orchestrated the advertising campaign that spared the Chrysler Corporation from insolvency in the 1980s and transformed Lee Iacocca, the ailing automakers voluble chief executive, into a national brand himself, died on Tuesday in Oneonta, N.Y. He was 91.

title: Hampton Creek, Maker of Just Mayo, Is Said to Be Under Inquiry
description: Hampton Creek, a prominent start-up that is trying to bring tech industry panache to the world of mayonnaise, ranch dressing and other food products, has come under scrutiny by regulators for its business practices.

title: Gleam Tarnished, Far From the Pool, for U.S. Swimmers
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  On Saturday evening, the swimming competition at Olympic Aquatics Stadium ended with Michael Phelps winning his 23rd career gold medal and 28th over all. Frank Busch, U.S.A. Swimmings national team director, suspended the normal 1 a.m. curfew for team members 21 or older.

title: U.S. Women Go From Gaffe to Gold in 4x100 Relay
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The United States won the womens 4x100-meter relay on Friday, taking a final for which they almost did not qualify.

title: To Trump, Even Losing Is Winning
description: AMAGANSETT, N.Y.  People run for the presidency for all sorts of reasons. But Donald J. Trump may be the first to run because he sees a presidential campaign as the best way to attract attention to himself. There seems to be no other driving passion in him, certainly not the passion to govern.

title: Usain Bolt Leads Jamaica to Relay Gold; U.S. Disqualified
description: Usain Bolt made it a triple-triple, leading Jamaica to victory in the 4x100 meter relay on Friday night and winning a third gold medal for the third consecutive Olympics. The United States crossed the finish line third but was later disqualified.

title: Pramukh Swami Maharaj, Whose Hindu Sect Became Largest in U.S., Dies at 94
description: MUMBAI, India  Pramukh Swami Maharaj, the spiritual leader who engineered the global expansion of a socially conservative Hindu sect that grew to be the largest in the United States, died on Aug. 13 in Sarangpur, a village in the state of Gujarat in western India. He was 94.

title: Wet Blanket
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Thank goodness for fill-in-the-blank clues. On a Saturday, they can be life savers. Generally the easiest type of clue because your brain loves filling in missing information, even the fill-in-the-blanks are tougher on a Saturday, but they can also provide us with a much-needed toehold in an otherwise impenetrable puzzle. I got started in Mark Diehls puzzle in just this way, filling in The ODESSA File, Edmond DANTES, and ANSON Williams right off the bat.

title: Rangers Sign Jimmy Vesey, Coveted by Much of the N.H.L.
description: The Rangers won the Jimmy Vesey sweepstakes on Friday, signing him to a two-year contract.

title: Who Gets to Race as a Woman?
description: As an Olympic qualifier, Caster Semenya of South Africa has had to face not only her competitors on the track but also critics around the world who claimed she wasnt really female. Now the 25-year-old Ms. Semenya, who is favored to win gold in the 800 meters on Saturday, finds herself at the center of a debate about who gets to compete as a woman.

title: N.F.L. Says Stymied Investigation Led to One-Game Ban for Josh Brown
description: In the wake of the 2015 domestic violence arrest of Giants kicker Josh Brown, which led to a one-game suspension by the N.F.L., the league was aware that Browns wife at the time told the police that Brown had become physically violent with her on numerous other occasions.

title: Affordable Child Care: The Secret to a Better Economy
description: Of the 24 million children under 6 in the United States today, some 12 million need day care, because both parents work or a single parent is the breadwinner. Yet most working families cant afford good care  if they can even find it in the first place. In 2006, a federal study gave a high quality rating to only 10 percent of the nations child care programs, and the proportion today is almost certainly smaller, since government financing for child care has declined in the past decade.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: All it takes is one mosquito bite to change the entire course of our lives.

title: Playing With Fire in Ukraine
description: Two years after President Vladimir Putin of Russia annexed Crimea and began destabilizing eastern Ukraine, tensions are rising anew, with news reports suggesting that he may be preparing for yet another military confrontation with the pro-Western government in Kiev.

title: Judge Refers Arizona Sheriff Joe Arpaio for Criminal Prosecution
description: PHOENIX  A federal judge on Friday referred Sheriff Joe Arpaio and his second-in-command for criminal prosecution, finding that they ignored and misrepresented to subordinates court orders designed to keep the sheriffs office from racially profiling Latinos.

title: Love and Hate On Hold With Verizon
description: I know its not a good idea to hate anyone. I know from an article I read that negative emotions are bad for my health. I would hate to have a heart attack because my internet isnt working. But I do hate Verizon.

title: As Ridership Soars, PATH Service Disruptions Cut Deep
description: Scrambling through a crowd of frazzled commuters at a Lower Manhattan train station on a recent Saturday, Romany Saad navigated his limited options for getting to work, hoping he would not be late for the second weekend in a row.

title: Samantha Wolf and Adrian Cohn: A Relationship Built While Rebuilding Stormy New Orleans
description: Samantha Natalie Wolf, a daughter of Lauren B. Wolf of Port Washington, N.Y., and Howard S. Wolf of Westhampton Beach, N.Y., was married Aug. 20 to Adrian Kirrin Cohn, a son of Vicki H. Cohn and Ian J. Cohn of Manhattan. Rabbi Maurice A. Salth officiated at Wave Hill, a public garden in the Bronx.

title: Christina Zhang and Eric Yeung: An Appointment Worth the (Annoying) Wait
description: Christina Zhang, the daughter of Juanlian Sun and Junxiong Zhang of Belle Mead, N.J., was married Aug. 20 to Eric Gar-yee Yeung, a son of Anh Yeung and George Yeung of Fairfax, Va. Bob Dunn, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, officiated at the Museum of the City of New York.

title: Whats on TV Saturday: Fearless and Youve Got Mail
description: Netflix presents its latest docu-series, Fearless, in which there are plenty of slow-motion sequences to show you just how similar bull riders are to rag dolls. And the Rio Olympics continue with a big night for track-and-field finals.

title: Rising to the Challenge
description: Usain Bolt successfully completed a triple gold medal quest for the third straight time in the Summer Games, and the United States womens water polo team repeated as Olympic champions.

title: Corrections: August 20, 2016
description: NATIONAL

title: Yoenis Cespedes and Asdrubal Cabrera Return, but Mets Fall to Giants
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When the injured Asdrubal Cabrera and Yoenis Cespedes were rehabilitating at the Mets complex in Port St. Lucie, Fla., they talked often about returning as quickly as possible. They watched on television as the sputtering Mets went 7-11 without both players in the lineup and lagged in the playoff race.

title: Decisive Moments at the Rio Olympics, Frame By Frame
description: See the Summer Games in a series of composite images.

title: Jered Weavers Pitches Lack Bite, and the Yankees Feast
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Jered Weavers pitches arrived invitingly, resembling melons to the minds eye and at a pace barely fast enough to break the speed limit on the freeway that runs past Angel Stadium.

title: This Only Confirms the Image of the U.S.A.
description: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

title: Private Equity Pursues Profits in Keeping the Elderly at Home
description: DENVER  Inside a senior center here, nestled along a bustling commercial strip, Vivian Malveaux scans her bingo card for a winning number. Her 81-year-old eyes are warm, lively and occasionally set adrift by the dementia plundering her mind.

title: Why Do You Want a Pet? Can You Afford It?
description: Americans love their pets.

title: What 11 New Yorkers Wear to the Beach
description: When the temperature hit 90 degrees, young and savvy New Yorkers flocked to Fort Tilden beach, where they shed their layers while maintaining style.

title: The Summer of Jack
description: The British clothing company Jack Wills selects energetic 20-somethings to spread its gospel over dinner, dancing and drinks.

title: They Get Paid to Have a Catalog-Perfect Summer
description: One morning last month, the ferry from Hyannis, Mass., to Nantucket Island carried sun-hatted tourists, seasonal laborers and two young blond British women who were three weeks into what was quite possibly the best summer of their lives.

title: North Korea Says Diplomat Who Defected Is Human Scum
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said on Saturday that a diplomat in its London embassy who recently defected to South Korea had fled rather than face punishment for various crimes, calling him human scum.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from Louisiana to Brazil.

title: Delivery by Mail Pail
description: The J. W. Westcott Company delivers mail and goods to freighters passing Detroit.

title: A Mail Boat Stays Afloat
description: A narrow street dead-ends at the Detroit River, where a black-and-white boat bobs in the water, emblazoned with a Postal Service eagle. This is the mail boat J.W. Westcott II, the only floating ZIP code in the United States.

title: A Little Variety
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  This weeks puzzles include:

title: Trumps Empire: A Maze of Debts and Opaque Ties
description: On the campaign trail, Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, has sold himself as a businessman who has made billions of dollars and is beholden to no one.

title: What Donald J. Trump Owns and Owes
description: The Republican presidential nominee has an interest in more than 30 U.S. properties, roughly half of which have debt on them.

title: Farhads and Mikes Week in Tech: Ride-Hailing News Owns the Road
description: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

title: Rio Olympics: Claressa Shields Punches Her Way to Second Gold Medal
description: Hundreds of athletes at the Rio Games showed the many ways to celebrate winning an Olympic medal. This was Claressa Shieldss on Sunday: She dropped to one knee after her middleweight boxing bout and quickly sprang to her feet. Then she kept moving  cartwheeling, laughing, running laps around the ring, the American flag billowing like a parasail over her head. She swayed to some internal music as she waited to step onto the podium.

title: On the Trail: The Week of Aug. 14
description: National security briefings, campaign shake-ups and rallies around the country.

title: A Day Care Center Draws Noise Complaints
description: Our backyard abuts a rowhouse that operates a day care center, which also has a yard. When the weather is nice, the children are outside  crying, shouting and screaming  most of the day. The noise is constant and intolerable. My wife works from home and would like to sit in her yard, working and talking (quietly!) to colleagues and clients on the phone. That is impossible. Is there any way to force the owners to limit the noise? We have called the  center, but the owners say, We are a day care; kids cry, and hang up on us. What can we do?

title: The Gridlock Economy
description: Duncan Weldon has a good think-piece on the peculiar circumstances that have brought negative interest rates to much of the advanced world. As he points out, its not just weak investment demand, with a strong whiff of secular stagnation; its also the choice of major economies to offer a response that

title: Putting John Deere Mowers to the Test
description: Q. What do you do as a field test manager?

title: Afghan Troops Hold Off the Taliban in Kunduz
description: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan  The northern Afghan city Kunduz was on the verge of falling to the Taliban on Saturday, as residents began to flee, and a key district nearby was overrun by insurgents, Afghan officials and local residents reported.

title: Variety: Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  A timely acrostic puzzle from Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon, although I found this one a bit more difficult than some of the past few offerings.

title: The Gas Goes Out and the Train Goes in
description: Dear Diary:

title: Where One Olympic Medal Is a Lot Better Than None
