description: Article: Powerful Earthquake in Italy Kills at Least 120 and Shatters Towns

title: Saudis and Extremism: Both the Arsonists and the Firefighters
description: WASHINGTON  Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump do not agree on much, but Saudi Arabia may be an exception. She has deplored Saudi Arabias support for radical schools and mosques around the world that have set too many young people on a path towards extremism. He has called the Saudis the worlds biggest funders of terrorism.

title: Attack at University in Kabul Shatters a Sense of Freedom
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  As cafes, restaurants, and performance centers in Kabul came under attack one after another in recent years, the campus of the American University of Afghanistan remained a rare oasis for some of the countrys brightest young men and women.

title: For Tennis Elbow, No Such Thing as a Quick Fix
description: Tennis elbow is not exclusive to tennis players; anyone who frequently twists an arm or carries a heavy briefcase can develop it. But whoever they may be, sufferers of the condition in the past 10 years have generally been offered a cortisone shot as treatment. Recent surveys in the United States and Britain show that injections of the steroid, which rapidly dulls pain and fights inflammation, are the preferred first line of treatment among many orthopedic specialists. But growing evidence suggests that the injections, while effective in the short term, can frequently worsen the condition in the months that follow, raising interesting questions about the risks of quick fixes for pain.

title: From Humans of New York to Obamas Office: How a Principal Built a School
description: THE BRIDGE TO BRILLIANCEHow One Principal in a Tough Community Is Inspiring the WorldBy Nadia Lopez with Rebecca Paley266 pp. Viking. $26.

title: The Story of How Handwriting Evolved, and May Soon Die Off
description: THE HISTORY AND UNCERTAIN FUTURE OF HANDWRITINGBy Anne TrubekIllustrated. 177 pp. Bloomsbury. $26.

title: Hopes Dim for Survivors of Italy Quake; Death Toll Stands at 267
description: AMATRICE, Italy  As relatives of the missing and the dead tearfully made their way to the makeshift morgue here in Amatrice, dust-covered rescuers worked Thursday in sweaty shifts, hoping to find people still alive under the remains of buildings destroyed by the earthquake in central Italy.

title: Italy, Hillary Clinton, Leslie Jones: Your Thursday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Morning Agenda: Fed Protesters, the Mylan Furor, Trans-Atlantic Tax Tussles
description: What a difference a couple of years of weak economic growth have made.

title: New York Today: City Staycations
description: Updated, 8:52 a.m.

title: How to Eat Like a Local on the Road
description: Enjoying good food is an essential part of any vacation  at least according to David McInerney, the co-founder of the New York City-based grocery delivery service FreshDirect, who spends most of his time traveling the world sourcing food for the company. The way to savor memorable cuisine, he said, is to skip fancy restaurants and eat as the locals do. Youll get the best meals by eating the way the people do who live in the destination youre visiting, he said. Here, he shares advice on how to do just that:

title: Group to Run Bilingual Anti-Trump Ads in Three Swing States
description: Donald J. Trump says he is starting to win over skeptical Hispanic voters, but his opponents are investing in a new advertising campaign in Arizona, Florida and North Carolina to make sure that does not happen.

title: Donate to Charity, Get a Hotel Discount
description: A hotel discount may warm your heart, knowing youve beaten the system. Now a new hotel booking website aims to warm your soul, too, by linking discounted rates and charitable donations.

title: Sonia Rykiel, Fashion Designer for the Fragile, but Strong, Dies at 86
description: Sonia Rykiel, the Paris fashion designer who planted her contrarian flag on the Left Bank in the 1960s, flouted haute couture conventions and created chic ready-to-wear clothes that caught on around the world with generations of women on the go, died on Thursday at her home in Paris. She was 86.

title: Theater Review: Rodgers and Hammersteins Allegro
description: LONDON  You have to hand it to the British theater: When it comes to considering lesser-known corners of the American repertoire, stages here cast a gratifyingly wide net.

title: Judge John Hodgman on Knitting Dog Fur Into a Scarf
description: Josh writes: My girlfriends roommate Colette has a big, furry dog. She keeps all the fur it has shed in a Ziploc bag (three years worth!). She says she is planning to knit it into a scarf. She has no spinning knowledge or equipment, making her already-questionable goal untenable.

title: Hillary Clinton Says Radical Fringe Is Taking Over G.O.P. Under Donald Trump
description: RENO, Nev.  Hillary Clinton delivered a blistering denunciation Thursday of Donald J. Trumps personal and political history with race, arguing in her most forceful terms yet that a nationalist conservative fringe had engulfed the Republican Party.

title: Jacqueline Woodson: By the Book
description: The author, most recently, of Another Brooklyn loved The Little Match Girl as a child. First, I cried for a week. Then I was done and ready to go out and change the world!

title: After 25 Years, How Well Has Madonnas Truth or Dare Aged?
description: Madonna gagging after Kevin Costner calls her concert neat. Her backup dancers at the New York gay pride parade. Warren Beatty as condescending scold. Singing Like a Virgin on that velvet bed. A variety of cone bras. The glass bottle.

title: A Vegan Ranch Dressing That Rivals the Original
description: Flashback to the mid-1950s: A dude-ranch owner in Southern California whisks buttermilk and mayonnaise with herbs and spices. Later known as ranch dressing, it appears to make perfectly reasonable people lose their minds. The man tries to keep up with his dressings popularity, to harness its power, but in the end, he sells it to a corporation. Subjected to a series of experiments, ranch is transformed into a glorious shelf-stable beast, designed to be better, stronger and able to survive longer outside the fridge.

title: The Electric, Infuriating Nick Kyrgios
description: It was just before noon on a swampy July morning when Nick Kyrgios came walking through the parking lot of the Evert Tennis Academy in Boca Raton, Fla., on his way to practice. He wore black shorts and a black basketball jersey, and his haircut straddled the line between a faux-hawk and a fade; a racket bag was slung over his shoulders, and his eyes were fixed on two smartphones, one in each hand. Kyrgios, a 21-year-old Australian of Greek and Malaysian descent  and quite possibly the most gifted tennis player to come along since Roger Federer  was accompanied by an improbable crew: a 13-year-old from Philadelphia named Tauheed Browning and a 14-year-old from Maryland named Langston Williams, two promising juniors who were training at the academy. They had bonded with Kyrgios over a shared infatuation with Pokmon GO, the blockbuster mobile game, and the three were apparently now inseparable. They had gone to the movies and the mall together.

title: Relaxing Privacy Vow, WhatsApp Will Share Some Data With Facebook
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When Facebook bought the start-up WhatsApp in 2014, Jan Koum, one of WhatsApps founders, declared that the deal would not affect the digital privacy of his mobile messaging services millions of users.

title: Democratic Dream of Two Blue Coasts? Clinton Is in Striking Distance
description: Each week, Nate Cohn, The Upshots elections analyst, based in Washington, and Toni Monkovic, an Upshot editor in New York, discuss the 2016 race and post a lightly edited transcript of their written exchange.

title: Driver in Japan Playing Pokmon Go Kills Pedestrian
description: TOKYO  In the first reported death in Japan linked to the Pokmon Go craze, a man who was playing the popular smartphone game while driving struck two pedestrians, killing one, the police said on Thursday.

title: Federal Officials Want to Ban Swimming With Dolphins in Hawaii
description: Swimming among the dolphins in the clear waters off the Hawaiian coast has long enticed island visitors. But federal officials say it is harmful to the creatures when they are supposed to be resting and socializing, and have proposed a ban on the activity.

title: North Korea Unveils Netflix-Like Service With Propaganda on Demand
description: HONG KONG  Days before North Koreas leader, Kim Jong-un, successfully tested a ballistic missile that he said could hit parts of the continental United States, his reclusive regime unveiled another technical triumph: a Netflix-like streaming service.

title: Not Forgotten: In Cold Blood, Truman Capotes Achievement and Undoing
description: The nonfiction novel In Cold Blood made Truman Capotes career but may have ruined his life.

title: Whyd You Do That? How The Times Decides to Send News Alerts
description: News alerts and push notifications regularly draw questions from readers. So I sat down with Eric Bishop and Michael Owen from the news desk at The Times to answer some of my questions  and hopefully yours  about how the newsroom approaches this area. Last month, The Times announced it was dividing its email alerts into two channels: Breaking News gives readers developing stories as they happen; and Top Stories gives subscribers breaking news plus special reports, investigative stories or live events in sports or politics if The Times deems them important. Soon, subscribers to mobile push notifications will get the same choice.

title: Mylan to Offer Some Patients Aid on Cost of EpiPens
description: Responding to a growing furor from consumers and politicians, the pharmaceutical company Mylan said on Thursday that it would lower the out-of-pocket costs to some patients who need EpiPens, which are used to treat life-threatening allergy attacks.

title: How You Enjoy Our National Parks
description: The National Park Service turned 100 years old on Aug. 25. Here are photos of parkgoers in action  hiking, camping, running.

title: 1966: Apollo Soars From Cape
description: CAPE KENNEDY  The United States today [Aug. 25] rocketed an unmanned Apollo moon ship three-quarters of the way around the world to a Pacific Ocean splash down. The 44,700-pound Apollo rode atop a powerful Saturn-1 rocket that landed 93 minutes after leaving here. The Apollo zoomed to a peak altitude of 700 miles over South Africa. Then its own rocket engine fired to drive it back, heat shield first, into the earths atmosphere at 19,000 miles per hour. Apollo control reported the 11,000-pound capsule impacted south-west of the aircraft carrier Hornet, the prime recovery ship, some 300 miles southeast of Wake Island. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 26, 1966

title: Want to Own a Newspaper? A Vermont Contest Has Trouble Finding Takers
description: HARDWICK, Vt.  Like most people who work for small newspapers, Vanessa Fournier wears many hats.

title: How Parents Harnessed the Power of Social Media to Challenge EpiPen Prices
description: After Mellini Kantayya, an actress who lives in Brooklyn, chatted with her Facebook friends in July about the high cost of EpiPens, she knew she had to do something.

title: On Argentina Plains, Hunters Feel Besieged by Critics Made of Asphalt
description: UTRACN, Argentina  After days in the wilderness, the hunters drove up to the sports club in rusty pickup trucks with carcasses of wild boars splayed on their roofs. One by one, the dead boars were heaved onto a bloodied crane scale, then lined up on planks, their snouts wedged open.

title: Cass McCombs: Imagine Beckett as a Cranky Singer-Songwriter
description: Cass McCombss words are a black hole. It is not wealth to have more than others, this 38-year-old singer-songwriter intones on It, a serene and unsettling ballad from his new album, Mangy Love. And then, a bit later: It is not health to take vitamins and exercise. His lyrics, whether lofty or cranky, often imply that very little is what it seems and that we are all probably doing wrong, or paying into a rotten system. A song is a gift, but what kind of gift is this? What kind of dude is this?

title: Reissues: 50s Moxie, 60s Soul and 90s Hip-Hop
description: LITTLE RICHARD

title: The Race to Save the Films We Love
description: If you have ever seen the 1931 film of The Front Page, based on the jauntily cynical play, you might have been startled by the moment when a wisecracking newspaperman silences his machine-gun-fast patter to raise his middle finger at the mayor and sheriff. Is this what the New York Times reviewer Mordaunt Hall was thinking of when he wrote that the films humor is frequently harsh?

title: Seattles Potential Solution for Heroin Epidemic: Places for Legal Drug Use
description: A task force established to combat a heroin epidemic in the Seattle metropolitan area has endorsed a strategy of establishing places where addicts would be allowed to take drugs without fear of being arrested.

title: Investors Move Next Door, Unsettling a Black Beachside Enclave
description: William Pickens III has spent most of his 80 summers in Sag Harbor Hills, a beach community of modest bungalows on the edge of the Hamptons. His grade-school principal built the house across the street; his family doctor lived two doors down. Ruby Dee and Ossie Davis were his house guests. Those were the people who came to Sag Harbor Hills.

title: 1916: Fire Lights Up Paris
description: A sensation was caused in the northern districts of Paris last evening [Aug. 24], about half-past nine, when a red glow suddenly appeared in the sky, growing brighter rapidly and passing from its primitive hue to a blinding white glare and then through the whole gamut of colors. A stop was put to the alarming rumors which spread among the public when it was learned that a fire had occurred at the Ruggieri fireworks manufactory at Saint-Denis, destroying about 20,000fr. worth of chemical products, but causing no loss of life.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Aug. 26, 1916

title: With Operation in Syria, Erdogan Shows His New Power Over Turkeys Military
description: KARKAMIS, Turkey  In recent years, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan ordered plans drawn up for a Turkish military incursion into Syria. At every turn, though, military commanders, already fighting a war inside Turkey against Kurdish militants, pushed back.

title: Put OS X Photos in the RAW Format
description: Q. Can you process RAW images in Apples OS X Photos program?

title: In Italys Earthquake Zone, Love of Place Trumps Safety
description: Youve likely seen some of the wrenching closeup imagery emerging after a shallow 6.2-magnitude earthquake shattered ancient villages in the Appenine mountains 80 miles northeast of Rome on August 24, killing 241 people at last count.But sometimes a wide view can be as sobering.

title: Survivor Recounts Attack on Kabul Campus
description: A man who survived an hourslong attack on the American University of Afghanistan in Kabul described the harrowing scene. Officials said at least 13 people were killed and dozens were wounded by the militants.

title: Daily Report: Gawker and Truth
description: In one sense, Gawker is gone. In another, its all around you.

title: U.N. Rights Official Calls for Inquiry Into Abuses in Yemen Conflict
description: GENEVA  The United Nations top human rights official called on Thursday for an international inquiry into possible war crimes and other accusations of abuses in Yemen, reviving a proposal that Saudi Arabia and the Yemeni government it supports have fiercely resisted.

title: World Bank President Jim Yong Kim Is Nominated for a Second Term
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday nominated Jim Yong Kim for a second five-year term as president of the World Bank despite persistent complaints among employees about his leadership at a time when the mission of the global development institution is in question.

title: Gyro96
description: An 85-square-foot falafel shop steps from the 96th Street subway station on the Upper East Side.

title: Dizengoff
description: An outpost of the chef Michael Solomonovs hummus stand lands in Chelsea Market.

title: Two New Stops for Middle Eastern Food: Dizengoff and Gyro96
description: Here is pita as its meant to be, just shoveled from the oven, with pocks of scorch and loose blackened flour coming off on fingertips, leaving a dusty spoor on sleeves.

title: Can We Talk About Your Weight?
description: Recently, when attending a medical talk about the connection of unhealthy diets to obesity, heart disease and cancer, I was caught by surprise.

title: Video Review: The Clubman Is a Mini, but in a Larger Package
description: FOR those who complain that vehicles now all look like a bionic wedge of cheese, the Mini brand single-handedly dispels that notion.

title: Brazils Next Must-Watch Event: A Presidents Impeachment Trial
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The Rio Olympics just ended, and Brazilians are quickly switching their attention to another heated competition consuming the country: the bare-knuckle brawl for the presidency.

title: Review: In an Obama Biopic, the Audacity of Hagiography?
description: Something else is pulling at me, the gangly young man with the jug ears says. I wonder if I can write books or hold a position of influence in civil rights, he adds. Politics? the pretty young woman asks. He shrugs. Maybe.

title: Whats So Special About Another Earth?
description: Charlottesville, Va.  Yesterday, the European Southern Observatory announced that astronomers have detected a planet the size of Earth orbiting our nearest star, Proxima Centauri. We discover hundreds of exoplanets every year, but this one is different: It orbits its star at just the right distance so that, in theory, its possible it could sustain life. This detection of a goldilocks planet so close to our own marks a significant achievement for exoplanet astronomy, the young field devoted to the search for and study of planets orbiting stars other than our sun.

title: Paisley Park, Princes Estate, Will Open as a Museum
description: Paisley Park, Princes storied private estate and music complex in Chanhassen, Minn., plans to open as a museum this fall, according to an announcement from the singers estate on Wednesday. Public tours are scheduled to begin on Oct. 6, with tickets going on sale starting this Friday, at OfficialPaisleyPark.com. The family is also planning an official tribute concert for Prince on Oct. 13 at U.S. Bank Stadium in Minneapolis.

title: Is This the Top-Secret KFC Recipe?
description: KFC describes its closely guarded original fried chicken recipe as one of the biggest trade secrets in the world. The company says the original handwritten recipe is housed in a 770-pound safe encased in two feet of concrete and guarded by video cameras and motion detectors.

title: Election 2016 Unit, Part 3: The Campaign Strategy
Prominent Producers Hope to Bring Indecent to Broadway
description: Two Tony-winning producers say they are hoping to bring to Broadway a production of Indecent, by the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Paula Vogel.

title: Unhitched: The Same Arguments, Then Finally a New Direction
description: In Unhitched, longtime couples tell the stories of their relationships, from romance to vows to divorce to life afterward.

title: How Expanding Medicaid Can Lower Insurance Premiums for All
description: The Obama administration for years has been pleading with states to expand their Medicaid programs and offer health coverage to low-income people. Now it has a further argument in its favor: Expansion of Medicaid could lower insurance prices for everyone else.

title: How Philippe Dauman Lost the Battle for Viacom
description: Just a few weeks ago, things seemed to be breaking Philippe A. Daumans way in his legal bid to maintain his grip on Viacom  which owns, among other things MTV, Comedy Central and Paramount Pictures  by having its majority owner and chairman, the 93-year-old media mogul Sumner Redstone, declared mentally incompetent.

title: In a Social Setting, Is It OK to Avoid Saying Where You Work?
description: I work for Planned Parenthood. I love my job and Im proud of what I do. In social settings, when asked what I do for a living, I answer truthfully and in full. But this nearly always leads to a big rehash of the politics surrounding my employer, together with the same old talking points and statistics. I dont like taking my work home (or out) with me. Is there a way to head off these lengthy discussions without withholding the name Planned Parenthood? Saying I work in health care feels like hiding to me.

title: Snakes in the Garden (but These Are Welcome)
description: This summers heat has been bad enough to make you want to shed not just your clothes, but your skin, too. Its a feat humans can only imagine, but on Sunday, Wave Hill will present those who do it regularly.

title: Democrats Weak Bench Undermines Hope of Taking Back Senate
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats, aware of the dead weight that Donald J. Trump has placed on their vulnerable Republican colleagues, can taste a reclaimed majority.

title: The Evolution of a Natural Winemaker
description: SOLICCHIATA, Sicily  When a writer comes calling, most winemakers would consider it in their best interest to offer their proudest efforts for sampling. But Frank Cornelissen has never been like most winemakers.

title: IPhone Users Urged to Update Software After Security Flaws Are Found
description: SAN FRANCISCO  One of the worlds most evasive digital arms dealers is believed to have been taking advantage of three security vulnerabilities in popular Apple products in its efforts to spy on dissidents and journalists.

title: More Life to Be Lived
description: Occasionally I feel so worn down by the exigencies of cancer and of aging that I believe the time has arrived to face the end, though I dearly wish to be proven wrong.

title: Rape, Race and the Jogger
description: When I ran cross-country in high school in California, I was well trained, well coached and professionally sized for my Asics racing flats. Running was a source of pleasurable vulnerability: I courted the limits of how much self-inflicted pain my body could handle, tracing the long curve of Santa Monica Bay, on the hard sand by the water, and the wealthy streets of Brentwood, past hedge-hidden homes. My runs were backlit by privilege.

title: New Faces and Familiar Matchups in Champions League Draw
description: Leicester Citys first visit to the UEFA Champions League, the richest prize from its unlikely Premier League championship last season, will include trips to Portugal, Belgium and Denmark, while the new Manchester City manager, Pep Guardiola, was placed in a group with his former club, Barcelona, in a draw held Thursday in Monaco.

title: Profile in Style: Kelly Slater
description: The pro surfer and fashion designer shares images of some of his personal memories and inspirations.

title: What Disability Means
description: Last week, The Times opened a series about disability, broadly considered, with an essay about disability, pride, and identity by Rosemarie Garland-Thomson. We asked readers to share their own stories in the comments and on Facebook.

title: From the Beach to the Runway, the World of Kelly Slater
description: The world champion shares with T personal images of some of his memories, influences and favorite things.

title: Good News for MTVs V.M.A.s: Music Videos Matter Again
description: As music awards shows go, MTVs annual Video Music Awards ceremony  the V.M.A.s  is by far the loosest, the most vibrant and the most prone to disruption. It has long been the platform where pop stars know a medium amount of misbehavior will be tolerated  encouraged, actually. The show isnt about trophies, but moments. That MTV itself isnt much in the music business anymore only makes the playing field clearer for provocation: Acting out here is like trashing a hotel room, not your house.

title: Students Protest Gun Law With Sex Toys
description: Activists at the University of Texas protested a law allowing concealed handguns on campuses by carrying sex toys  to fight absurdity with absurdity. This video contains explicit language and visuals.

title: A Six-Figure Car Can Still Be a Wallflower
description: Passions are cooling in the lower tiers of the collectible-car world as buyers look for ready-to-roll, not ready-to-restore, vehicles.

title: What Cars Ruled Pebble Beach Auctions? The Ones You Cant Afford
description: MONTEREY, Calif.  Even in the collectible car market, there are the 1 percenters and everyone else.

title: Warren Hinckle, 77, Ramparts Editor Who Embraced Gonzo Journalism, Dies
description: Warren Hinckle, the flamboyant editor who made Ramparts magazine a powerful national voice for the radical left in the 1960s and later, by championing the work of Hunter S. Thompson, helped introduce the no-holds-barred reporting style known as gonzo journalism, died on Thursday in San Francisco. He was 77.

title: Not Forgotten: Aaliyah, Whose Soaring Career Was Cut Short by a Tragedy
description: The princess of R&B released her first album at 15 and helped pioneer a new sound with chart-topping hits before her death at 22.

title: Kenya Disbands Olympic Committee, Citing Disorganization
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Missing uniforms. Shabby post-Games accommodations. Problems with airline tickets that left athletes temporarily stranded thousands of miles from home.

title: Mens Bowling Bags, Now Totally Modern
description: This season, designers have reinterpreted the retro style with slimmed-down silhouettes and supple leather.

title: Apples Gun Emoji
description: To the Editor:

title: Californias Retirement Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Russia, Fuming at Paralympics Ban, Steps Up Campaign Against Whistle-Blower
description: MOSCOW  Enraged by its blanket ban from the Paralympic Games and the exclusion of scores of its athletes from the Olympic Games, Moscow is ramping up a campaign against a Russian doctor who provided detailed evidence of state-sponsored doping.

title: Debate Over Mylans EpiPen Exposes Health Care Flaws
description: Mylan just injected some adrenaline into the American health care debate.

title: The Growing Pains of Obamacare
description: To the Editor:

title: Caribbean Scoops on an Ice Cream Cone
description: Taste the Tropics USA, a West Indian-themed ice cream parlor in Brooklyn, serves ice cream flavors like pineapple, coconut and soursop.

title: When Only a Scoop of Soursop Will Do
description: If you are anywhere near the corner of Nostrand and Avenue D in Brooklyn, it would take an almost herculean effort to ignore Taste the Tropics USA, Jerry Zirinos West Indian-themed ice cream parlor. For the past four decades, hes lured customers with the help of neon, a hand-painted mural, a cheerful clutter of old-fashioned signs  Ask for a taste, please come in  and a glorious rainbow logo whose swoosh connects a sugar cone to a trio of palm trees.

title: Georgia Man Gets 40 Years in Prison for Hot-Water Attack on Gay Men
description: As he waited for a pot of water to boil, Martin Blackwell had plenty of time to change his mind. But instead, he went ahead with what a judge in Georgia said was a soulless decision to throw the scalding water over two gay men sleeping on a mattress, burning them so severely that one was put into an induced coma at the hospital and both required skin grafts.

title: Review: Love, Loss and Spiritual Torment in The Sea of Trees
description: The Sea of Trees is another name for the Aokigahara forest in Japan, such a popular spot for suicides that some believe that the spirits of the dead linger there to trap unwary wanderers. Or perhaps to snare incautious filmmakers, as its also the setting for Gus Van Sants movie of the same name, a numinous meditation on grief thats more likely to inspire laughter than tears.

title: Review: In Level Up, Yanked From a Video Game Stupor to a Real Mission
description: Matt (Josh Bowman) is having a very bad day. For one thing, his hardworking girlfriend, Anna (Leila Mimmack), has reached the limit of her tolerance for his couch-sitting, video-game-playing ways. And for another, three dudes wearing knitted balaclavas have just shown up at his front door, strapped a package to his chest and informed him that failure to deliver it will result in Annas being killed.

title: Photos That Bridge the Gap Between Humans and Nature
description: Jackie Nickersons Terrain series stages creative interactions between people, objects and nature.

title: Send Us Your Favorite Money Question
description: Whats the single best question about money that anyone has ever asked you  or that youve asked of a spouse, family member or loved one? And what was the conversation that ensued?

title: Donald Trump, Wavering on Immigration, Finds Anger in All Corners
description: For 15 months, even as Donald J. Trump vacillated on many other issues, he stuck to a simple, hard-line position on immigration: If elected president, he would form a deportation force, round up people who are in the United States illegally and send them back where they came from.

title: Fighting Campus Carry  With Sex Toys
description: As America slogs through one of the most surreal and disturbing election seasons in recent memory, its sometimes hard to find much to laugh about. But students at the University of Texas have retained their sense of humor, and they are using it for good.

title: Jay Fishman, Who Led Travelers Safely Through the Financial Crisis, Dies at 63
description: Jay S. Fishman, who steered the insurance giant Travelers through the financial crisis of 2008 and into the elite ranks of the companies that make up the Dow Jones industrial average, died on Aug. 19 at his home in New Jersey. He was 63.

title: Review: Pondering All of Lifes What Ifs in Is That You?
description: There is not one day in my life that I didnt think, What if? Ronnie (Alon Aboutboul) says in Is That You?, a bittersweet and lovely little movie. Most everyone else he meets has a story of regret, or a soft feeling of sorrow. Yet among this films surprises is that each scene still exudes affection.

title: How Caroline Wozniacki, Danish Tennis Player, Spends Her Sundays
description: The Danish tennis player Caroline Wozniacki has a soft spot for the United States Open, which begins on Monday in Flushing Meadows, Queens. The atmosphere is always spectacular, said Ms.Wozniacki, 26, who last reached the womens singles final in 2014 (she lost to her good friend Serena Williams). The fact that its in New York makes it even more special. Ms. Wozniacki travels frequently, but she considers herself a New Yorker. During the Open, she appreciates the nightly retreat to her apartment overlooking Union Square, which she shares with her Pomeranian, Bruno. The tournament is also nicely coordinated with another of Ms. Wozniackis favorite events: New York Fashion Week. Perhaps shell go with Ms. Williams, or someone else from her group of close-knit city friends.

title: Review: In The Intervention, Theres a Big Chill in the Air
description: It would be folly to equate The Intervention with The Big Chill, but there are parallels. Both concern friends assembling at an opulent Southern mansion for a reckoning. But the prevailing issue in The Intervention is marriage, not a death: The friends gather to advise a husband and wife verging on divorce, the Type-A Peter (Vincent Piazza) and the sensible Ruby (Cobie Smulders), to break up, though it takes the group a while to arrive at the task.

title: Tensions Rise Between Iran and U.S. in Persian Gulf
description: Iranian naval boats made dangerous maneuvers around United States warships in the Persian Gulf area on at least four occasions this week, Pentagon officials said Thursday, including one episode in which the Americans fired warning shots from a 50-caliber deck gun to prevent a collision.

title: Review: In Order of Disappearance Emits a Dash of Fargo
description: Perhaps the old saying should actually be that revenge is a dish best served cheekily.

title: Review: The Hollars: Domestic Meltdowns in Middle America
description: Too much happens too quickly in The Hollars for the story to be credible, but the film has some likable qualities, among them the fun of seeing actors in unexpected roles.

title: U.S. Open Draws Crowds to Times Square With Promise of Mega-Selfies
description: Have you ever wondered how its possible to command more than a few seconds of someones time in the packed madhouse that is Times Square, a.k.a. the Crossroads of the World and the unofficial sensory overload capital of America?

title: A New, Mesmerizing Music Video to Get Lost in
description: The erstwhile journalist Cyrus Shahrad, who records under the name Hiatus, sees his electronic music career as having begun long before the drum-n-bass nights he D.J.-ed in his smoke-filled basement room as a student at Cambridge University. Rather, he says, it germinated in his early childhood, sitting in the back of the car on pre-dawn drives to visit my English grandparents in Dorset, listening to the warped cassettes of mournful Iranian music my dad would play to keep himself awake. At the time, Iran seemed to him an idea as much as a place, he says: Shahrad was born in the capital just before the 1979 revolution, and his family promptly fled to the U.K. But in 2005, he returned for a stint covering the presidential election for the Sunday Times, discovered his fathers old record collection and realized that hed been missing half of home.

title: Five Sustainable, Super-Simple Underwear Brands
description: A handful of designers from around the world are making minimalist lingerie from organic sources.

title: Grab a Cab, Then Open Your Translation App
description: To the Editor:

title: California Aims Retirement Plan at Those Whose Jobs Offer None
description: California is preparing to create a mandatory state-run retirement plan for an estimated six million workers at companies that do not now offer any retirement benefits.

title: Review: Choreographers Should Stay Away From Mozart. Except Mark Morris.
description: Throughout Mozart Dances, Mark Morris emerges as the most artfully musical choreographer alive. He has so many resources, devices and qualities with which to respond to a score: steps, gestures, patterns, fantasy, charm, humor. Most choreographers should steer clear of Mozart (Haydn and Beethoven, too) because the work can make the dances look crude. But Mr. Morris lets us know (boy, does he let us know) how keenly aware he is of the many aural layers here, and the subtle relationship between details and overall architecture.

title: Doctors Without Borders Exits North Yemen
description: After a bomb from a Saudi jet killed 19 people at a hospital in a residential area near the capital of Sana on Aug. 15, Doctors Without Borders has evacuated its staff from six hospitals in northern Yemen.

title: Theater Listings for Aug. 26-Sept. 1
description: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Italy, Hillary Clinton, Donald Trump: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Tennis Without Thought, or Backhands
description: Every day, Steven Turner, 69, gets up early and walks around the corner with a tennis racket and ball to a schoolyard on East 67th Street in Manhattan, where he volleys against a cracked concrete wall, over and over, for more than an hour.

title: In Books on Donald Trump, Consistent Portraits of a High-Decibel Narcissist
description: Over the last year, weve been plunged into the alternate reality of Trumpland, as though we were caught in the maze of his old board game, Trump: The Game, with no exit in sight. Its a Darwinian, dog-eat-dog, zero-sum world where greed is good, insults are the lingua franca, and winning is everything (or, in tangled Trumpian syntax, Its not whether you win or lose, but whether you win!).

title: How Hillary Clinton Could Win the Debates
description: If you were wondering how Hillary Clinton would handle Donald Trump in a debate, you may have just gotten a preview.

title: Comedy Listings for Aug. 26-Sept. 1
description: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, Aug. 27 Through Sept. 4
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.

title: Review: I Am Not a Serial Killer, but Somebody Is
description: A cross between Dexter and Encyclopedia Brown, I Am Not a Serial Killer follows John Wayne Cleaver, a 16-year-old Midwesterner being treated for sociopathic tendencies  who is trying to resist his worst urges. Maybe John shouldnt help out so much in the family business. His mother and aunt run a mortuary, and hes really into prepping the corpses. He may not be a serial killer, but he sure likes studying them.

title: Colombias Remarkable Peace Process
description: The life of every Colombian alive today has been defined, to varying degrees, by violence. The government has been at war with Marxist-inspired guerrilla groups for more than five decades, a ruinous conflict rooted in earlier cycles of violence.

title: Colombia and FARC Make Peace
description: Colombias government and the largest rebel group in the country have reached a deal to end more than 50 years of conflict. Nicholas Casey, Andes bureau chief, looks back at the history of the conflict.

title: Review: Floyd Norman: An Animated Life: He Broke Barriers at Disney
description: Floyd Norman doesnt think hes special. Many others know differently, and for those who need more proof, Floyd Norman: An Animated Life is delighted to supply it. With all this films jubilance, that delight becomes contagious.

title: Movie Listings for Aug. 26-Sept. 1
description: Read reviews of new releases and search our full database of thousands of films at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, Aug. 27 Through Sept. 4
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.

title: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, Aug. 27 Through Sept. 4
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.

title: Review: Dying to Know How to Turn on, Tune in, Drop Out
description: It is odd that Timothy Leary, an evangelist for psychedelic drugs who urged his followers to turn on, tune in, drop out, should be the subject of a documentary that doesnt seem worth that effort.

title: Things to Do on Long Island, Aug. 27 Through Sept. 4
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.

title: Review: Rachel Weisz Toys With Identity in Complete Unknown
description: Joshua Marstons Complete Unknown is a curious hybrid, teetering between a thriller and a romance only to land in a nebulous spot that is neither. The film concerns Tom (Michael Shannon), a New York agriculture lobbyist whose wife, Ramina (Azita Ghanizada), is weighing a move to San Diego for a graduate program. At a birthday party for Tom attended by, among others, their friends Clyde (Michael Chernus) and Sharon (Condola Rashad), he meets Alice (Rachel Weisz), who recently met Clyde at his office cafeteria.

title: Review: Dont Breathe: Whose Bright Idea Was It to Rob a Blind Man?
description: People who go to see movies like Dont Breathe  some of them, anyway  tend to laugh when people are killed onscreen. And when people believed to be dead open their eyes. Even I laughed when the watchdog, which the three attractive young thieves had drugged into slumber, appeared in the hallway, growling. Ha! Guess he woke up, dudes.

title: Revisiting an Artists Provocative Photographs
description: Photography was the medium of choice for most art critics in the 1980s. Unlike painting, which thrived in a robust art market and came to symbolize the excesses of that era, photography could be used to critique mass media images, male-dominated art history  even photography itself. Despite the rise to prominence of so-called good postmodern artists like Nan Goldin and Cindy Sherman, however, there are still plenty of photographers being rediscovered today. One of them is Jimmy DeSana, who died in 1990 at the age of 40 from AIDS-related causes.

title: Aching for Peace, but Also Justice, Colombians Weigh Deal With FARC
description: Gustavo Moncayo was a primary-school teacher when he got the news that every father feared: His son, an 18-year-old soldier in the Colombian Army, had been kidnapped by rebels.

title: Classical Music Listings for Aug. 26-Sept. 1
description: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.

title: Review: In Blood Father, Mel Gibson Plays With Pulp Fiction
description: Hobbesian to the max, Blood Father is unwaveringly nasty and brutish. Its also short, a combination that pretty much gives you all that you could want from a pulp fiction in which Mel Gibson plays a grizzled loner inking skin in a spot called the Missing Link Tattoo. Hes Link, of course; first name John. A former bad, bad man with a wild beard and a deep well of cynicism, John lives in a trailer parked on one of those picturesquely godforsaken southwestern landscapes where John Ford-style homesteaders once circled the wagons. The dream of the Old West dies hard, especially in the movies.

title: George Washington Really Slept Here. So Did His Slave.
description: Evidence of some of the Revolutionary Wars bloodiest moments and atrocities, as well as the little-known roles of African-Americans in battle and on the home front, will go on view during the next few months.

title: Some Villages in Italy May Never Recover From Earthquake
description: PESCARA DEL TRONTO, Italy  Mostly there was silence, virtually the only sound being that of a river flowing peacefully down the mountain that swallowed this tiny hamlet when an earthquake struck early Wednesday.

title: Review: In Fatima, a Muslim Mother Working in France Hits Her Limit
description: If my daughter is a success, my happiness is complete, declares the title character of Fatima, a small miracle of a film from the French director Philippe Faucon.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for Aug. 26-Sept. 1
description: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.

title: The Guggenheim Is Going Global. Kind Of.
description: Last spring, the Guggenheims board of trustees abruptly severed contact with the Gulf Labor Coalition, an international watchdog group monitoring the living and working conditions of migrant laborers in Abu Dhabi, capital of the United Arab Emirates, where the Guggenheim Foundation is building a new Frank Gehry-designed museum. The move, and the protests that followed, happened to coincide with the third and last of the museums UBS Map Global Art Initiative group exhibitions in New York, this one called But a Storm Is Blowing From Paradise: Contemporary Art of the Middle East and North Africa.

title: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
description: Austrian Cultural Forum11 East 52nd StreetManhattanThrough Sept. 5

title: Mia Madre Review: Moms in the Hospital. The Riot Scene Needs Retakes.
description: Love, death, cinema  theyre all there in Mia Madre, bumping up against one another beautifully. Its the story of a movie director, Margherita (Margherita Buy), who, while shooting a difficult movie about labor strife, learns that her mother, Ada (Giulia Lazzarini), may be dying. Yet even as tragedy surges, flooding scenes and tear ducts, Margheritas featured performer, an outsize American star named Barry (John Turturro), enters laughing, bellowing, acting. The Italian director Nanni Moretti knows how to turn on the waterworks, but he also knows about that burlesque called life.

title: 51 Contemporary Artists, but Just Three Women
description: PHILADELPHIA  After perusing Embracing the Contemporary: The Keith L. and Katherine Sachs Collection at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, a big exhibition featuring works by many famous artists of the last 50 years, including Jasper Johns, Ellsworth Kelly and Gerhard Richter  a visitor might wonder, What about the great female artists?

title: Review: Hands of Stone Returns Robert De Niro to the Ring but Pulls Its Punches
description: Robert De Niro redefined film acting by subjecting himself to a reported 60-pound weight gain to play a gone-to-seed version of Jake LaMotta, the middleweight boxer, in Martin Scorseses 1980 film, Raging Bull. Mr. De Niro, lithe, lean and lethal as LaMotta in his prime, became a bloated, bulbous ball of hostility and confusion for LaMottas post-boxing life. (He won a best actor Oscar for his pains.) But as much as Raging Bull is an exacting portrait of an athlete and his sport, it is not a boxing movie.

title: Jazz Listings for Aug. 26-Sept. 1
description: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.

title: This Weeks Movies: August 26, 2016
description: The New York Times film critics review Southside With You, Hands of Stone and Mia Madre.

title: Dance Listings for Aug. 26-Sept. 1
description: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.

title: What Do You See in Art? Nearly 50 People Told Us
description: MARTIN R. ANDERSON, 65, squints to appreciate the geometry of paintings at the museum. Kate Davis, 24, says the sunlight that bounces off museum walls and onto the art cant be reproduced. Stan Kaplan, 65, flies across the country just to see a Leonardo da Vinci drawing more beautiful than the Mona Lisa. And an elderly woman posts to Facebook a selfie of herself beside a masterwork, presumably commencing an avalanche of social-media approval.

title: Pushback on the Burkini Ban
description: A woman was told to leave a beach in Nice, France because her clothing was inappropriate. The incident has sparked protest against the countrys burkini ban.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Aug. 26-Sept. 1
description: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.

title: Transcript From Volkswagen Hearing
description: On Thursday, Volkswagen told a federal judge it had reached a basic agreement to compensate its 650 dealers in the United States for the troubles they have suffered.

title: Around Town for Aug. 26-Sept. 1
description: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.

title: The Power of Memories: Muriel and Cemetery of Splendor
description: Time and memory were consistent concerns for the French director Alain Resnais, who died in 2014 at 91. Historical trauma was a preoccupation as well, at least during the first stage of Mr. Resnaiss long career.

title: Spare Times for Children Listings for Aug. 26-Sept. 1
description: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.

title: A Complicated Alliance With Turkey
description: The Turkish military incursion into Syria that started Wednesday with American air support is about as good an illustration as there is of the exasperating complexity of Washingtons foreign affairs.

title: With a Pinpoint Sinker, Zach Britton Raises His Cy Young Award Chances
description: Zach Britton visits Yankee Stadium this weekend with the Baltimore Orioles. He will sit in the left-field bullpen and wait for his chance to close out a victory, and no fans will think about Mariano Rivera. But they should.

title: How Uber Lost More Than $1 Billion in the First Half of 2016
description: Uber has upended the transportation industry in the span of a few years. But the ride-hailing company has been losing a lot of money while doing so.

title: Latest Senate Election Polls 2016
description: Get the latest polls on 2016 U.S. Senate races.

title: A Peaceful Day
description: Dear Diary:

title: Californias Emissions Goal Is a Milestone on Climate Efforts
description: LOS ANGELES  California will extend its landmark climate change legislation to 2030, a move that climate specialists say solidifies the states role as a leader in the effort to curb heat-trapping emissions.

title: Rudy Van Gelder, 91, Audio Engineer Who Helped Define Jazz Sound on Records, Dies
description: Rudy Van Gelder, an audio engineer whose work with Miles Davis, John Coltrane and numerous other musicians helped define the sound of jazz on record, died on Thursday at his home, which doubled as his studio, in Englewood Cliffs, N.J. He was 91.

title: Frank Oceans Blonde Amplifies Discord in the Music Business
description: The shoo-in for No. 1 on Billboards next album chart is Frank Oceans Blonde, which has charmed critics and enthralled fans who had waited four years since his last record.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Im in. Looking forward to a beautiful and bright future.

title: VW to Pay $1.2 Billion to U.S. Dealers Hurt by Diesel Scandal
description: Not that long ago, Volkswagen dealerships were among the hottest properties in the retail auto business.

title: Silver, Like Skelos, Can Remain Free While Appealing Graft Conviction
description: In a search on the federal Bureau of Prisons website, the names of two familiar New Yorkers  Sheldon Silver and Dean G. Skelos  now appear.

title: Migrant Lizard, Having Made It in New York, Heads Elsewhere
description: For centuries, New York City has been the gateway to a new land, and now residents believed to have originated around warm, sunny Tuscany are moving on after a few years of city life. How they managed to get by in this colder, more crowded climate is being studied by Colin Donihue, a biologist doing postdoctoral studies at Harvard University.

title: One Guarantee for the Chicago White Sox New Stadium Name: Derision
description: The corporate logo of the mortgage lender Guaranteed Rate is a red arrow pointing downward. It suggests low rates for customers, which is a good thing for them. But when it comes to baseball, the symbol is more like an emoji for losing.

title: ITT College Chain Barred From Enrolling Students With U.S. Aid
description: The federal Department of Education imposed strict new rules on Thursday on one of the nations largest for-profit education companies, ITT Educational Services, barring it from enrolling new students who use federal financial aid and ordering it to pay $153 million to the department within 30 days to cover student refunds if its schools close down.

title: Mnica Puig, Puerto Ricos Favorite Daughter (and Only Gold Medalist)
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  Before she played in her last tennis tournament, Mnica Puig was pretty much like anyone else at San Juan International Airport.

title: Donald Trump Changes Tone on Immigration
description: Donald J. Trump began his presidential campaign with strong language on immigration policy, especially pertaining to Hispanics and Muslims. With less than three months until the election, his tone has softened.

title: Besieged Town of Daraya Agrees to Surrender to Syrian Government
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  After four years of siege and bombardment, residents of the rebel-held Syrian town of Daraya struck a deal Thursday with the Syrian government that amounted to a surrender of territory deeply symbolic to both sides.

title: Revisiting Attica Shows How New York State Failed to Fulfill Promises
description: In her new book, Blood in the Water, Heather Ann Thompson offers the most detailed account yet of the historic uprising by inmates over squalid conditions at Attica Correctional Facility in western New York. On Sept. 13, 1971, Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller ordered state troopers, armed with rifles and handguns, to storm the prison and quash a four-day rebellion. By the time it was over, 39 people had been shot dead, including 10 prison employees. Four others died earlier.

title: At Least 7 Dead as Shabab Militants Attack Restaurant in Somali Capital
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Islamist militants claimed responsibility for an attack on a seaside restaurant here on Thursday evening that killed at least seven people and wounded two others, according to state media.

title: Long Island Congressmen Seek Inquiries Into Veterans Suicide Outside V.A. Hospital
description: Two Long Island congressmen sent a letter to the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Veterans Affairs Department on Thursday asking them to conduct a thorough inquiry into the suicide of a veteran outside the Northport Veterans Medical Center on Long Island.

title: Hope Solos Behavior, and Play, Spells End With U.S. Team
description: For more than a decade, she loomed menacingly between the posts, a muscular, hyper-focused, lightning-quick goalkeeper who seemed able to stop anything.

title: Ex-Military Officers Convicted of Human Rights Crimes During Argentina Dictatorship
description: BUENOS AIRES  A landmark human rights trial concluded Thursday in an Argentine federal court with the convictions of 38 former military officials for their roles in kidnapping, torturing and killing several hundred victims during a period of military dictatorship four decades ago.

title: At the Barclays Tournament, Jostling for Ryder Cup Spots Raises the Stakes
description: FARMINGDALE, N.Y.  It is golfs version of a playoff beard, the wispy shadow of a mustache above Rickie Fowlers upper lip.

title: Dept. of Education's Letter to ITT
description: Federal officials announced a series of actions against ITT that could threaten the survival of the chain, which has been the subject of investigations focusing on its recruiting and accounting practices.

title: This Year in Travers, Its Anybodys Race
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  The Belmont Stakes winner Creator skipped over the racetrack like a school kid, his gray coat glimmering as if he were beneath a spotlight. The Preakness victor Exaggerator, a rangy colt with a commanding stride, quieted onlookers as he sauntered past like a gunslinger in a Hollywood western.

title: The Worlds Catalog of Ideas
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  For those of you just joining us, Friday New York Times puzzles are usually themeless, which gives a constructor the opportunity to salt a grid with longer, livelier fill. They can do this because they are not constrained by setting a theme inside a grid and then trying to fill around it. Thats the thing about the late-week puzzles: You have to work to get the clues and the entries might be a bit tougher, but you will generally be rewarded with entertaining fill and cluing that you wont see earlier in the week.

title: Review: In A Day by the Sea, Words Unsaid or Said Quite Bluntly
description: Theres so much to like about the Mint Theater Companys revisiting of A Day by the Sea that its hard to know what to single out for first-paragraph attention. Lets go with this: Even secondary characters in this 1953 play by N. C. Hunter are given the chance to make an impression, and in this production they do.

title: Review: In The Layover, Strangers on a Plane and Missed Connections
description: Has anyone ever enjoyed a layover? Either it is nerve-janglingly short or grindingly long. The Layover, a disappointing new play by Leslye Headland that opened on Thursday at Second Stage Theater, achieves the novel feat of being both at the same time. Running a little more than 90 minutes, it doesnt succeed in bringing us deeply into the lives of its principal characters. And yet we dont exactly leave pining for more of their company.

title: Not Forgotten: Friedrich Nietzsche, a Renegade Philosopher Whose Ideas Endured
description: Friedrich Nietzsche, a singular philosopher with the style of a romantic poet, influenced the past century in ways he could never have imagined and might not have countenanced.

title: Cyclists Death Shows Biking Perils Persist in New York
description: At 6:30 a.m. on Wednesday, like so many mornings before, Michael Schenkman, 78, was doing what he loved: riding his bike near his home in Queens.

title: Talking About Coming Out With the Cast of Fun Home
description: The volunteers visit schools in pairs. One person is lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender, and the other has a family member in one of those categories. They stand at the front of a classroom and tell their families coming-out stories.

title: Brazilian Police Recommend Charges Against Ryan Lochte
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The Brazilian police recommended on Thursday that prosecutors file charges against Ryan Lochte, the American Olympic swimmer, for the crime of providing false testimony, an indication that while the Summer Games here have ended, his misadventure in Brazil may continue.

title: New York Police Dept., Citing Law, Stops Sharing Personnel Data
description: The bulletins are known around the New York Police Department as personnel orders, a register of the comings and goings across the sprawling agency, with its 36,000 uniformed members and thousands more civilian employees.

title: Sonia Rykiel: A True Original
description: I was so strong in my thinking and my way of seeing fashion, the designer once said. I knew exactly what I wanted. I said to myself, I have no limits.

title: 2 Nuns Are Killed in Mississippi: The Sweetest People to Ever Draw a Breath
description: Poverty is entrenched in the Mississippi city of Durant (population less than 3,000), but violent crime is hardly pervasive.

title: Donald Trumps Campaign Chief, Stephen Bannon, Faced Domestic Violence Charges in 1996
description: The recent appointment of Stephen K. Bannon, the right-wing media mogul, as chief executive of Donald J. Trumps campaign was part of an effort to reset a candidacy that has stumbled with minority and female voters and suffered from controversies surrounding high-level campaign officials.

title: Obama to Create Worlds Largest Marine Reserve Off Hawaii
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is set to vastly expand a marine sanctuary northwest of the main Hawaiian Islands, White House officials said Thursday, creating the worlds largest protected marine area as he seeks to cement his environmental legacy in his last months in office.

title: Esther Jungreis, the Jewish Billy Graham, Dies at 80
description: Esther Jungreis, a charismatic speaker and teacher whose enormously popular revival-style assemblies urged secular Jews to study Torah and embrace traditional religious values, died on Tuesday in Brooklyn. She was 80.

title: Mets Top Cardinals, One of Their Wild-Card Rivals
description: ST. LOUIS  In order to reach the playoffs, the Mets must overcome tough odds. They must jump three teams and erase a three-and-a-half-game deficit with 35 games left in the season to claim the National Leagues second wild-card berth. They kept those hopes alive Thursday with a 10-6 win over the St. Louis Cardinals, the team that currently occupies that position.

title: Corrections: August 26, 2016
description: NATIONAL

title: Whats on TV Friday: The Danish Girl and The Kicks
description: Eddie Redmayne portrays the artist and transgender pioneer Lili Elbe in The Danish Girl. A young soccer player gets her mojo back in The Kicks, adapted from books by the Olympic gold medalist Alex Morgan. And The Day Before ventures inside the fashion atelier of Sonia Rykiel, who died on Thursday.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | incommodious
description: incommodious  \in-k-mo-de-s\  adjective

title: Ai Weiwei Planned to Sculpt a Redline. Chinese Censors Say He Crossed One.
description: BEIJING  For Ai Weiwei, the outspoken Chinese artist, the idea was irresistible.

title: The Women Who Wont Wear Swimsuits
description: This isnt a real thing, my husband grumbled as he followed me up the stairs one morning in June.

title: Colombias Milestone in World Peace
description: The peace treaty announced this week between the government of Colombia and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, marks more than the end of one war. It is a milestone for peace in the Americas and the world.

title: No, Donald Trump, America Isnt a Hellhole
description: Donald Trump has taken a strange turn lately. O.K., he has taken a lot of strange turns  thats what happens when you nominate a short-attention-span candidate who knows nothing about policy and refuses to sit still for more than three minutes. But never mind what passes for Trumpian policy ideas. Whats odd is the shift in what the problem is supposed to be.

title: The Dumbed Down Democracy
description: Are you smarter than an immigrant? Can you name, say, all three branches of government or a single Supreme Court justice? Most Americans, those born here, those about to make the most momentous decision in civic life this November, cannot. And most cannot pass the simple test aced by 90 percent of new citizens.

title: Winds of Change on the Lower East Side
description: On Tuesday evening, to a standing-room audience in an old theater on Grand Street on the Lower East Side, a drama played out that hasnt been seen in the neighborhood in 40 years.

title: The Art of Gracious Leadership
description: Lately Ive been thinking about experience. Donald Trump lacks political experience, and the ineptitude caused by his inexperience is evident every day. On the other hand, Hillary Clinton is nothing if not experienced. Her ship is running smoothly, and yet as her reaction to the email scandal shows once again, theres often a whiff of inhumanity about her campaign that inspires distrust.

title: Lotte Executive Found Dead Amid South Korean Corruption Inquiry
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A top executive at the Lotte Group, one of South Koreas largest family-controlled conglomerates, was found dead on Friday in an apparent suicide, hours before he was scheduled to appear before prosecutors investigating allegations of corruption at the company.

title: The Week in Pictures, Aug. 26, 2016
description: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

title: Picture Prompt | Social Media and Body Image
description: How does seeing social media images of people in bathing suits affect your own self-image? How, if at all, do you think teenage girls and boys are affected by these images differently?

title: The Week in Pictures, Aug. 26, 2016
description: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

description: Article: Colombia and FARC Announce Deal to End the Americas Longest War

title: Dark Horses Abound at the United States Open
description: Cilic, 27, won his first Masters 1000 tournament at Cincinnati on Aug. 21 and vaulted back into the top 10 with a straight-sets victory over Andy Murray, the reigning Wimbledon and Olympic champion. Cilic, who had three match points against Roger Federer in the Wimbledon quarterfinals, kept Murray off balance with a nearly unreturnable wide slice serve, followed by flat bombs up the middle. After parting ways with his longtime coach Goran Ivanisevic, Cilic hired Jonas Bjorkman to help strengthen his forehand and his return, both of which let him down in crucial moments against Federer at Wimbledon. Against Murray at Cincinnati, Cilic returned brilliantly. Cilic is seeded seventh at the United States Open, and his rising level of play suggests that he could be rounding into the kind of form that led him to the title in 2014.

title: Clinton and Trump Campaigns Are Buzzing About the Race  for the Cabinet
description: WASHINGTON  Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump have yet to face off in their first debate, but both candidates have already moved teams into a plush marble-and-glass office building a block from the White House, where they are vetting rsums, sketching out organizational charts and otherwise planning the transition to a Trump or Clinton administration.

title: Hillary Clinton Denounces the Alt-Right, and the Alt-Right Is Thrilled
description: As Hillary Clinton assailed Donald J. Trump on Thursday for fanning the flames of racism embraced by the alt-right, the community of activists that tends to lurk anonymously in the internets dark corners could hardly contain its glee.

title: Painted as EpiPen Villain, Mylans Chief Says Shes No Such Thing
description: America has a new pharmaceutical villain. Her name is Heather Bresch.

title: A Motivational Tool: Believing That Tenniss Big Four Era Is Over
description: On the way to a Wimbledon final this summer, Milos Raonic took a crash course in the attitudinal psychology of advanced mens tennis. The curriculum offered a straightforward application of positive thinking, said his instructor, or coach, Carlos Moy.

title: Security in a Bright Yellow Suitcase
description: On more than one occasion I have rolled my bright yellow carry-on suitcase into the office on a Monday morning to the confusion of my co-workers.

title: Syrias Paradox: Why the War Only Ever Seems to Get Worse
description: WASHINGTON  There is a basic fact about Syrias civil war that never seems to change: It frustrates any attempt at resolution.

title: Shh. Its Naptime at Ikea in China.
description: When browsing coffee tables, kitchen cabinets and dessert plates becomes too exhausting at an Ikea store in China, feel free to pass out under a deliciously cozy Flng duvet or across a Stor loft bed  right in the showroom.

title: West of the Shinnecock
description: The boldface Hamptons lie to the east, so why do some buyers prefer homes on the canals western side?

title: The Plain-Jane Hamptons
description: The Hamptons star-studded cachet has long tilted east of the Shinnecock Canal to the highly prized  and high-priced  areas of Southampton Village, Bridgehampton and East Hampton Town. Expansive oceanfront estates, fashionable shops and chic restaurants add to their aura as premier seaside resorts.

title: The Great Out-of-State Migration: Where Students Go
description: Public colleges and universities have historically served their own state residents, but the number of out-of-state freshmen attending them has nearly doubled since 1986, according to Department of Education data.

title: 2016 Election, Uber, Ryan Lochte: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

description: Question:

title: Monthlong Ordeal for Hiker in New Zealand: Partners Death and Bitter Cold
description: SYDNEY, Australia  A distraught Czech woman who was found after a month alone in a cabin on a famed New Zealand hiking trail described on Friday how she had braved extreme cold and failing health after her boyfriend died falling down a slope amid snow, wind and fog.

title: Morning Agenda: Car Trouble and a Retreat, Sort of, by Mylan
description: Its been a tough year for Volkswagens car dealers. Cheered by the German automakers ambition to become a bigger player in America, they had invested millions of dollars into their franchises. As recently as 2014, dealers were paying premiums of $3 million to $4 million to buy franchises in the United States.

title: A Madrid Tapas Bar With Global Influences
description: The small plates at KultO, one of a growing number of new tapas bars on Calle Ibiza, in the Retiro neighborhood of Madrid, reflect a larger trend of eating out in Spain: After years of molecular gastronomy, a more recognizable cuisine is now the fashion.

title: Tips for Women Traveling Solo
description: After graduating from college in 2008, Kelly Lewis traveled the world solo. She spent a year in New Zealand and backpacked from one end of South America to the other. In the process, she relied on guidebooks. But they didnt give her all the information she needed, especially as a woman. I would have loved if someone would have told me its really hard to find tampons in Buenos Aires, she said. And why doesnt anyone tell you this particular bus station is sketchy at night?

title: The Airbag in Your Car Could Explode. This Is What You Should Do About It.
description: Defective airbags made by Takata have been tied to 12 deaths and more than 180 injuries in the United States alone. The ensuing recall  the largest in automotive history  has turned out to be messy, confusing and frustrating for car owners.

title: In Mexico City, a Modernist Hotel and Temple to High Design
description: From $128 (2,321 pesos).

title: A Cheaper Airbag, and Takatas Road to a Deadly Crisis
description: In the late 1990s, General Motors got an unexpected and enticing offer. A little-known Japanese supplier, Takata, had designed a much cheaper automotive airbag.

title: You Always Remember Your First Bike
description: When I outgrew my tricycle, my mother never replaced my wheels. Enviously I watched as the other kids in my neighborhood mounted their shiny Schwinns, confident cowkids on imaginary mares. They wobbled side to side on training wheels, inserted cards into the spokes as noisemakers, and sailed by with colorful banners flowing from handlebars. I was the one kid on the block with only feet as transportation.

title: New York Today: Madonnas Metropolis
description: Updated, 7:58 a.m.

title: Letter of Recommendation: Safety Razors
description: The first razor I can remember owning is one I received as a present for my 18th birthday. It came in the mail from Gillette. I dont know how the company knew, but I was happy to be in its database. The Fusion, with its novel five-blade design, had recently hit the market. I was thrilled, and I cycled back and forth through the cartridges until they were all hair-clogged and uselessly dull. When I found out the price of a Fusion blade-refill box, I saw my whole life stretch in front of me.

title: How to Sleep in a Tree
description: Start low to the ground, says Andrew Joslin, who first slept in a tree 10 years ago, when he was a tech worker who regularly slept in a hammock in his Boston backyard. Now 60, Joslin lives in rural Massachusetts, where he works as an arborist. If you intend to sleep 15 feet off the ground or higher, first learn to climb safely. Youll need 150 feet of arborist rope, a harness, a helmet, carabiners and a special tree-sleeping hammock, or a lightweight platform called a portaledge. Before you ascend, check the weather. You dont want to be dozens of feet off the ground in the dark during high winds or lightning.

title: Reaching Guantnamo
description: Selected by Matthew Zapruder.

title: Tikis Comeback
description: Drink writing is a hell of an occupation. There are moments when I stop to consider whether certain subjects of my scrutiny really should be subjected to scrutiny. Take tiki: Lavishly garnished drinks, sometimes served in anthropomorphic vessels, may seem the embodiment of silly excess.

title: Familiar Dish, Familiar Friend
description: Gulshan showed up in our lives by chance. She was old, searching for work; Mom wasnt looking to hire anyone. And even if she had been, Gulshan was Muslim and my family Hindu. When I was growing up, most families in India hired help within their own religion unless they could afford English-speaking, Catholic nannies. But there was something about Gulshan. True to her name, which means garden in Hindi, she created a kind of refuge around her. Before we knew it, she was in our kitchen making Moms favorite dessert, phirni  a bit like rice pudding.

East and south-west of the Mouquet farm General Haigs troops pushed forward their front by capturing a line of German trenches extending for a distance of 400 mtres along the Thiepval-Courcelette road.

title: Tim Parks Laments the Excessive Influence of International Book Fairs
description: Its one world, were one community, and so we must all read the same books. Otherwise how could we talk about them to one another? Thus the logic of globalization: ever larger numbers of people worldwide reading the very best (or best-promoted?) authors. Its good news for those authors and their publishers, not so encouraging for the increasing number of people who would like to make a living from writing. And of course it raises the intriguing question: Even when well translated, can we really understand what other cultures are talking about? Will a housewife in Tibet (assuming there are housewives in Tibet) make sense of Jonathan Franzens St.Paul, Minn.? Can other people truly get the hang of Bulgarian etiquette or courtship in Laos or street life in the Philippines? Are we interested? Does it make sense to be interested? In short, do all good books travel?

title: Found in Translation
description: This week, the prolific critic, essayist and novelist Tim Parks temporarily takes over as our Roving Eye columnist. Given the columns focus on international literature, I asked Parks to introduce himself here by recommending five of his favorite translated novels.

title: Read It Later: A Procrastinators Memoir

title: Do People Hate Poetry? According to Ben Lerner, Yes
description: If youre a poet, its easy to spend a lot of time worrying about how people feel about poetry. Its also easy to dismiss how people feel because if you were to consider the blithe indifference with which most audiences actually regard poets and their poems, it would be depressing  and not depressing in the poetic way that, for instance, mortality is depressing, but depressing in the way that, Oh my goodness, we totally forgot you were even here, have you been sitting in this little cubicle all afternoon?

title: A Couscous for the (Not Quite) End of Summer
description: Its that wistful time, as summer fades away  going, going, but not quite gone. Still, the season has changed. Days are shortening. Even if the hot weather hasnt packed up and left town, we all know darker days are standing in the wings.

title: A 70s Pendant Lamp From the Future
description: Designed in 1972 by the Danish architect Louis Weisdorf, this shape-shifting brass pendant lamp doesnt merely illuminate a room; the light it throws can also mirror your mood. Futuristic, with a Fritz Langian appeal, it is made up of two center cylinders encompassed by quarter-spherical shells that can pivot to change the fixtures shape. Recently reissued by the Danish manufacturer Gubi, it is available in brass, chrome, matte white, black or French blue, and can be configured in multiple ways, turning any room into a true reflection of the happily divided self.

title: Some Good News for Investors: The Bull May Still Have Spring in Its Step
description: The bull market in stocks has been supported by two fundamental pillars: high corporate earnings and low interest rates. Both of these mainstays appeared wobbly early this year. Fortunately for investors, there is now some good news for both of them.

title: 7 Essential Money Questions Sure to Start a Conversation
description: Its the season of the long hike, the slow beach stroll, the idle time when you can finally just talk and think for at least a little while. Even if you dont get to go on vacation over these next two weeks, many workplaces will be quieter than usual, allowing, perhaps, for an early escape and a longer evening meal.

title: Resignations at the Bronx Museum Over a Costly International Push
description: Like other small museums nationwide that are under pressure to build attendance and revenue, the Bronx Museum of the Arts has been trying to broaden its reach beyond its New York City borough, with a new building, a free-admission policy and ambitious projects that have international appeal, including several involving Cuba.

title: Was Shostakovich a Martyr? Or Is That Just Fiction?
description: Novelists have every right to use historical data to lend their works verisimilitude, and they are free to go beyond the facts, wherever their fancy leads them. Historians, though, are bound by circumstances, condemned to whatever partial, obstructed view their sources grant them. Their only recourse is to keep on looking and pray. Meanwhile, novelists can soar and gain an untrammeled vista.

title: U.S. Puts Private Student Loan Servicers on Notice: Play Nice
description: BORROWERS wrestling with college debt often complain that it is frustrating to deal with the companies that manage their student loans. This summer, federal regulators have stepped up pressure on loan servicers to treat their borrowers better.

title: Three Stunning Picture Books Take Children on Unusual Journeys
description: For very young children, even a trip to a grocery store can be thrilling. Cheese samples, the fish department and the dewy surprise of automatic misting in the produce section: Lots of marvels are packed in those prosaic aisles. Some of the most enduring childrens books transform something ordinary  a purple crayon, a wardrobe, a red pebble  into vehicles for exhilarating journeys. Three new picture books follow the tradition. In space, at sea, in a twilight world  these books take readers on escapes so transporting its a pleasure to get lost.

title: Four New Picture Books Teach Children the Power of Stories
description: Many creators of picture books become so immersed in the lengthy process of bringing a book into the world, they cant help pitching the idea of making a book about books. I can relate. I have three or four such books in a shoe box under my bed. Looking back, I think I created them for the exclusive amusement of my bookish colleagues. Was I showing off? Maybe. The truth is, the very best picture books appeal to several audiences at the same time. These include parents, fellow bookmakers, librarians, award givers and, one hopes, even children. Four new books about books manage to thread that needle.

You can browse previous guides here, and to receive recommendations straight to your inbox, sign up here. Stay tuned for our coming website.

title: Putting {Style} into the Online New York Times Stylebook
description: In 1895, the editors of The New York Times created the inaugural version of the papers Manual of Style and Usage  a guidebook to the publications particular rules of grammar, punctuation, spelling and capitalization that remains an essential part of our newsroom toolkit. Since then, its been updated regularly to reflect the changing times (the word email, for example, appeared as early as 1985 and was styled as e-mail). In 1999, the first online version of the manual, known as the Stylebook, became available on the NYT intranet.

At the airport, I even tried to use my athlete credential instead of my passport to check into my flight. A shift back to the real world will start for me now. But before too many of my memories fade, I thought Id share a glimpse of life  the athletes, the food, the condoms  from the Olympic Village.

title: Grandmaster Flash Beats Back Time
description: Grandmaster Flash might easily have missed the hip-hop revolution. Born in Barbados and transplanted to the South Bronx as a child, he began his adolescence far from the city, in a group home for foster children in rural upstate New York. By the time he returned to the boroughs Fort Apache section in 1971, things were changing fast. Music was getting more percussive; teenagers with spray cans were scrawling hieroglyphic names and full-fledged murals on subway cars.
