title: Inside the List
description: Fifth Dimension: Remember John Cheevers story The Swimmer? Sure you do: Thats the one where a guest at a garden party decides on a lark to make his way home by water, swimming one by one across his neighbors pools only to find that a year or more seems to pass in the space of a single afternoon. As a surreal gesture  the journey not just through geography but through time  that premise has something in common with Colson Whiteheads novel The Underground Railroad (No.1 in its third week on the hardcover fiction list), in which a runaway slave encounters various examples of racism on her flight north that could come only from a more contemporary America. Yet Whitehead was influenced less by Cheever, he told me via email, than by another 60s artifact of pop fabulism: I can work back through my life, he said, and pick out key moments where I was exposed to some new fabulist gesture  One Hundred Years of Solitude in 12th grade, the Battle Royal chapter of Invisible Man in a seventh-grade English class  but my earliest immersion into the fantastic was probably reruns of The Twilight Zone. Slave girl Cora emerging from the literal underground railroad and seeing a skyscraper: Thats a quintessential Twilight Zone moment, where you take a step in the wrong direction and suddenly youre in a world a little off to the side.

title: A Rite of August Shrinks Away for Some New Yorkers
description: On July 31, 1967, The New York Times ran an article, on Page 29, headlined Vacations Begun by Psychiatrists. It appeared that day among articles with headlines like Pravda Article Assails Castro and Spiraling Rents Worry Officials (about deep concern among bureaucrats over escalating housing costs in New York, especially Manhattan).

description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Kim Jones is a dance detective. That means she rescues lost works by stitching together fragments of ephemera  a choreographers notes, decades-old still images  with original performers fading memories to restage dances that take cues from source material, but are of necessity something new.

description: New picture books include Ming Goes to School and Schools First Day of School.

title: Satisfying the Sweet (and Savory) Tooth
description: The warm brioche doughnuts at the month-old Grindstone Coffee and Donuts in Sag Harbor are made from five basic ingredients: flour, milk, eggs, yeast and butter (of the European, 83 percent butterfat variety), and are flavored with a bit of honey and nutmeg, with hints of salt and sugar. Its the toppings that give them pizazz.

title: Meet Octobot: Squishy, Adorable and Revolutionary
description: Hello, Octobot.

title: Migrants Aid Victims of Italy Earthquake
description: Migrants from Africa have volunteered to help residents in areas of central Italy that were struck by a deadly earthquake this week.

title: Review: Kanye West, Both Close and Out of Reach at His Tour Opener
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Back in June, Kanye West was rumored to be playing a secret concert at the New York club Webster Hall after Hot 97s Summer Jam festival. Well after midnight, the street was filled with hundreds of young people waiting for a chance to see their hero. The show itself didnt happen, but at one point, a car drove past, and Mr. West poked his head out of the sunroof. The crowd surged and surrounded him; after a minute or two, the car pulled away from the throng, leaving a trail of fans chasing it up Third Avenue.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are on the Upper West Side, in Greenwich Village, and in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: Review: At Bricco in West Hartford, Seasonal Italian That Aims for Balance
description: Restaurants are notoriously short-lived, but Restaurant Bricco, a West Hartford mainstay since 1996, is not only alive, but thriving. How many dinners have crossed the counter from the open kitchen whose wood-burning stone ovens greet arriving guests? Assume an average of 275 covers per night, and Billy Grant, its chef and owner, is somewhere around serving Briccos two millionth meal. And this is only one of three restaurants he owns.

title: New York Through an iPhones Lens
description: Selections from a digital diary of the citys streets.

title: Around the City in 10 Tweets
description: Central Park, central Harlem, Centre Street, the Crossroads of the Worlds at the citys center in Times Square, outside the historic Central Synagogue in Midtown in the blaring heat of August: These iPhone pictures (taken, by coincidence, mostly in those locations over a month of regular daily outings, and then posted to Twitter) constitute an informal diary of the ways that, even as strangers, we are at the unacknowledged center of one anothers existence. Like it or not, there is intimacy in our daily encounters with the millions who share our city, even if its duration is no longer than a glance or a shutters click.

title: Review: Colombian Homestyle Cooking at Aqui Es Santa Fe
description: Olga Santos never gave up on her goal of owning a restaurant.

title: Judge in Stanford Sexual Assault Trial Will No Longer Hear Criminal Cases
description: A California judge who came under fire and was the subject of a recall campaign for his sentencing decisions in a Stanford University sexual assault case will be transferred after he asked to be removed from hearing criminal cases.

title: Williams Sisters Could Be in Step for Semifinal Showdown at U.S. Open
description: If the Williams sisters are to face off in Arthur Ashe Stadium once again, it will be in the semifinals.

title: Louis Armstrongs Lip Balm
description: In the mid-1930s, during an extended tour of Europe, Louis Armstrong found himself in Germany with a split lip, a fairly common injury for him. But by luck, he had recently made the acquaintance of Franz Schuritz, a trombonist who also happened to be the inventor of Ansatz-Crme, an invigorating lip balm. Armstrong was an immediate and lifelong convert.

title: An Indoor Trampoline Park Offers Flips and Fitness in New York City
description: Sixteen years ago. Thats the last time Jennifer DeLuca was on a trampoline. It wasnt in a suburban backyard but at Grand Central Terminal, where it had been set up for Action Heroes, a dance production by the daredevil choreographer Elizabeth Streb. Ms. DeLucas friend, a member of Ms. Strebs company, had invited Ms. DeLuca to jump while the trampoline was free.

title: In Chelsea: Gas Station to Boutique Condo
description: As the area around the High Line park continues its transformation from industrial hub to upscale housing district, a gas station is giving way to a boutique condominium.

title: A Skylight Made From Two Mirrors
description: This weeks GIF science lesson shows whats possible with just two mirrors.

title: Obscure Legal Doctrine May Erase Guilty Verdict for Ex-Legislator Who Died
description: In the eyes of federal prosecutors and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the late Thomas W. Libous, long one of Albanys most powerful lawmakers, got away with a lot, in part because time was on his side.

title: Why Is It So Hard to Find a Pool to Swim Laps in New York City?
description: Q. Why is it so hard to find a spot to go lap swimming (for those of us still inspired by the Olympics) year-round? There are so few pools to choose from, and most are so expensive. And the summer crowds at public pools are madness.

title: The Last, Sweet Days of the Irish Alps in Upstate New York
description: The memories started flooding in as we hit Route 145 in East Durham, N.Y., the thoroughfare that winds through the part of the Catskills known as the Irish Alps. We made this drive every summer of my childhood  my father steering a ridiculously large Oldsmobile, unlit Tiparillo cigar clenched in his teeth (he only ever smoked them once we had arrived), my sisters and I fighting over imagined back-seat borders, legs sticking to the scorching pleather.

title: Five Questions for Marina Abramovic
description: Marina Abramovic has lived without privacy at Sean Kelly Gallery for 12 days on nothing but water; shes invited strangers to use 72 random objects (including a gun with one bullet) on her in any way they want; shes walked half the 5,500-mile length of the Great Wall of China to confront heartbreak. Her life as a whole has involved pushing herself to her physical and mental limits, and then going further. So its a surprise when, in person, shes anything but intimidating. Within seconds, shes asking about my right arm (in a sling from tennis-induced rotator cuff surgery) and then about the scar I have on the same arm (souvenir keloid from a childhood dog attack). This is good, she pronounces. Scars I find the most interesting. I see no point in not asking right away  what happened?

title: Pasta From New York Restaurants Aids in Earthquake Relief
description: New York Citys Italian restaurants have started fund-raising to help the town of Amatrice and others in central Italy devastated by an earthquake Wednesday. They hope to attract customer support for the effort by donating funds from orders of pasta allamatriciana, the popular specialty of Amatrice.

title: Travers Stakes 2016: Heres Who We Think Will Win
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  There is a full field of 14 entered for the 147th running of the Travers Stakes on Saturday, including the Preakness victor Exaggerator and the Belmont champion Creator. Still, the Midsummer Derby, as the race is known, is a wide-open affair in a year in which the crop of male 3-year-olds seems evenly matched. The morning-line odds were set by Travis Stone of the New York Racing Association. The comments are by Joe Drape of The New York Times.

title: A Critics Lonely Quest: Revealing the Whole Truth About Mother Teresa
description: KOLKATA, India  Taking on a global icon of peace, faith and charity is not a task for everyone, or, really, hardly anyone at all. But that is what Dr. Aroup Chatterjee has spent a good part of his life doing as one of the most vocal critics of Mother Teresa.

title: Obamas Expansion of a Vast Pacific Reserve, Built on a Bush Foundation
description: President Obama continues to use his final months in office to firm up a remarkable environmental legacy. The latest move is his proclamation quadrupling the size of the Papahanaumokuakea Marine National Monument northwest of Hawaii  a vast and dazzling Pacific refuge for myriad species.

title: Small Cloud Computing Firm Turns to Helping Others Work With Giants
description: Apollo Global Management and Searchlight Capital are making a $4.3 billion bet on capitulation.

title: The Playlist: Thundercat Unplugs, Young M.A. Gets Remixed
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos  and anything else that strikes them as intriguing  in the Playlist. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this format? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com.

title: Ackman and Icahn Contradict Each Other on Herbalife Stock
description: Call it the Bill and Carl Show.

title: Laurie the Moose Lady Puts Heart and Soul Into Roadkill
description: SEATTLE  Laurie Speakman is passionate about moose meat.

title: Elephant Tranquilizer Could Be Linked to Wave of Heroin Overdoses in Midwest
description: Officials across the country are grappling with waves of heroin-related overdoses and deaths this year, an epidemic blamed on heroin mixed with  fentanyl, an opiate estimated to be 100 times as strong as morphine.

title: A Guide to Help Pregnant Women Reduce Their Zika Risk
description: Zika has a foothold in the continental United States now that mosquitoes in parts of Miami-Dade County, Fla., have infected people with the virus. Zika can cause harrowing brain damage in the developing fetus of a woman who is infected during pregnancy, so it is vital that pregnant women minimize that risk. Heres some advice on how to do that.

title: Crossing Boundaries, One Flight At a Time
description: With 2,400 miles between them, a romance between Stephanie Stebich and Anne-Imelda Radice, both museum directors, seemed out of reach. The couple were married on Aug. 14 in Plainfield, Mass.

title: United in Love, But Living on Separate Coasts
description: Of all the skills needed to be a successful museum director  curating collections, charming donors, keeping the lights on  perhaps the most crucial are having a good eye and knowing what you like when you see it.

title: The Good News About Educational Inequality
description: When inequality is the topic, it can seem as if all the news is bad. Income inequality continues to rise. Economic segregation is growing. Racial gaps in education, employment and health endure. Our society is not particularly fair.

title: Nations Parks Turn 100, Saving a Church, and Cooking With Tennis Stars
description: Last weeks parties included celebrating the National Park Services 100th birthday, saving Saint Sava church, and the 17th annual Taste of Tennis.

title: Four Things T Editors Are Really Into Right Now
description: The new quarterly publication Racquet is a deliciously smart magazine created by and for people who love both tennis and language  and before you ask, yes, David Foster Wallace is represented, in the first issues first essay. (In fact, its Sasha Frere-Jones writing on John Jeremiah Sullivans introduction to a collection of Wallaces tennis essays, for a game-set-match of literary bona fides.)

title: Im 46. Is That Too Old to Play the Ingnue?
description: The ingnue police are at my door.

title: Nations Parks Turn 100, a Church Fund-Raiser, and Tennis Time
description: The charity circuit is inching back to the city. The National Park Service celebrated its 100th birthday last Monday at Brooklyn Bridge Park, with Bill Nye, Questlove and other park lovers. An interactive dance floor controlled lights atop One World Trade Center. Save Saint Sava, which seeks to restore the Serbian Orthodox Cathedral of St. Sava, held a benefit at the New York Athletic Club. The church was gutted in a fire last May. And on Thursday, top tennis players gathered for the annual Taste of Tennis culinary event, with proceeds benefiting Wellness in the Schools.

title: Gabons Leader Gives Elephants Free Rein. Rural Voters Dont Forget.
description: KAZAMABIKA, Gabon  For months, Jacqueline Gnagne carefully tended the cassava, corn and peanuts she planted inside a national park. Rangers helped her string barbed wire to protect her crops. Just before harvest time, she even moved into a small cabin at the edge of the field so she could keep a 24-hour watch.

title: It Was Justin Pecks First Rodeo, and He Turned It on Its Head
description: The world premiere of Justin Pecks ballet Rodeo: Four Dance Episodes, in February 2015, caused a sensation. Mr. Peck was 27 and had been resident choreographer to New York City Ballet for a few months. This was his freshest, most assured and most individual work to date.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Trump, on Race and Immigration
description: To the Editor:

title: Miguel Sapochnik on Game of Thrones, and Making 70 Horses Feel Like 3,000
description: The British director Miguel Sapochnik didnt start working on Game of Thrones until the fifth season, but hes since overseen several of the shows best episodes. These include the zombie-raid extravaganza Hardhome, in Season 5, and the final two last season, all of them game-changing installments that combined epic sweep with indelible moments. (Think the Nights Kings highly meme-able Wildling resurrection in Hardhome, or King Tommens shocking, macabrely beautiful suicide in Winds of Winter, last seasons finale.)

title: Bolivia Says Official Sent to Negotiate With Miners Is Killed
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia  A conflict between the Bolivian government and miners demanding that the countrys mining laws be changed escalated on Friday as the authorities said that protesters had kidnapped, tortured and killed a top official sent to negotiate with them.

title: Riz Ahmeds Double Identity: Actor and Rapper
description: When Riz Ahmed, the rising British-Pakistani actor, came to New York to shoot the pilot episode of HBOs The Night Of, in which he stars as a college student from Queens accused of murder, he sought advice from Himanshu Suri, a local musician he had met on Twitter.

title: Nathan Hill Is Compared to John Irving. Irving Compares Him to Dickens.
description: Nathan Hills literary career almost ended before it started.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Donald Trump, Hillary Clinton, Federal Reserve: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Review: Jason Statham in Mechanic: Resurrection, a Hit Man on Cruise Control
description: At the start of Mechanic: Resurrection, the hit man Arthur Bishop (Jason Statham) certainly isnt mourning his dead protg from The Mechanic (Simon Wests 2011 remake of a Charles Bronson movie). No, hes just hanging out in a flawed digital backdrop of Rio de Janeiro, trying to forget his blood-spattered rsum.

title: Donald Trump Hires First and Deals With Background Questions Later
description: Donald J. Trump has called for extreme vetting to determine who is allowed to enter the United States, but when it comes to his presidential campaign, he has shown a propensity to be lenient when it comes to the kinds of red flags that might scare off other candidates.

title: Stephen Harper, Former Prime Minister of Canada, Quits Politics
description: OTTAWA  He led his government to a crushing defeat at the polls last October, then ceded his office to Justin Trudeau and largely vanished from public view. Now, 10 months later, Stephen Harper, the former Conservative prime minister of Canada, says he is giving up his seat in Parliament and quitting politics.

title: Whats New at the 2016 U.S. Open
description: A retractable roof on Arthur Ashe Stadium is not the only new feature at this years United States Open, which begins Monday.

title: A Manhattan Diners New Management Has Servers Singing a Defiant Tune
description: Clutching bottles of ketchup as if they were microphones, three waitresses stood atop vinyl banquettes at Ellens Stardust Diner near Times Square the other day, belting out the chorus of a 1984 Twisted Sister hit: Oh, were not gonna take it! No, we aint gonna take it! Oh, were not gonna take it anymore!

title: Germanys Drag
description: I want to follow up a bit on Brad Setsers post about the German fiscal surplus.

title: As Donald Trump Repels Minority Voters, G.O.P. Fears Its Future in the West
description: PHOENIX  Republicans in Western states fear that Donald J. Trump could imperil their party for years to come in the countrys fastest-growing region as he repels a generation of Hispanics, Asians and younger voters who have been altering the electoral map.

title: Outrage Over EpiPen Pricing
description: The huge increase of the list price for the severe-allergy drug injector has led to backlash against Mylan, the latest in a string of pharmaceutical companies accused of price gouging.

title: U.S. Proposes Immigration Rule Aimed at Entrepreneurs
description: Foreign entrepreneurs building new companies in the United States could soon gain a new immigration option that would grant them temporary entry for up to five years, under a rule proposed on Friday by the Department of Homeland Security.

title: Abbotts No Good, Very Bad M&A Week
description: Abbott Laboratories has announced two large acquisitions over the last year. In recent days, both deals have become major land mines.

title: Max Ritvo, Poet Who Chronicled His Cancer Fight, Dies at 25
description: Max Ritvo, an accomplished poet who spent much of his life under the cloud of cancer while gaining wide attention writing and speaking about it, died of the disease on Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 25.

title: Celebrating a Defeat
description: An exhibition remembers the Battle of Brooklyn, a conflict of the Revolutionary War in which American forces suffered heavy losses  but saved their general from capture.

title: The Battle of Brooklyn: A Loss That Helped Win the Revolution
description: Usually, history celebrates the victories in war  Ulysses S. Grant crossing the Mississippi River on the way to Vicksburg, Theodore Roosevelt and the Rough Riders charging up San Juan Hill, the American troops storming ashore at Normandy.

title: John Ellenby, Visionary Who Helped Create Early Laptop, Dies at 75
description: John Ellenby, a British-born computer engineer who played a critical role in paving the way for the laptop computer, died on Aug. 17 in San Francisco. He was 75.

title: Federal Judge Curbs Enforcement of North Carolina Transgender Access Law
description: A federal judge on Friday curbed the enforcement of a North Carolina law that restricted restroom access for transgender people. The ruling was the first judicial rebuke of a statute that has been condemned as discriminatory and, with lawsuit after lawsuit, has deepened the national debate about transgender rights.

title: Residents Abandon Daraya as Government Seizes a Symbol of Syrias Rebellion
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Hundreds of rebel fighters and their families left a long-besieged suburb of the Syrian capital, Damascus, on Friday, under an agreement with the government that amounted to an opposition surrender of territory and a symbolic defeat.

title: Amtraks Answer for Aging Acela Fleet: 160 M.P.H. Trains
description: WASHINGTON  A new era of high-speed train travel is coming to the nations busiest rail corridor.

title: Another Fight in the Redstone Family Feud Is Defused
description: Peace has come to the land of the Redstones, at least for now.

title: Profane Phone Message Has Gov. Paul LePage of Maine in Hot Water Again
description: Paul R. LePage, the ever-combative Republican governor of Maine, refused on Friday to apologize to a Democratic state lawmaker for leaving a threatening and expletive-studded voicemail message that was criticized by some state Republicans and left top Democrats suggesting that Mr. LePage should resign.

title: Federal Investigators in Brazil to Seek Graft Charges Against Ex-President Da Silva
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Federal investigators in Brazil said Friday that they would seek corruption charges against Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, the former president who has ranked among the countrys most influential political figures.

title: Theyre First-Time N.F.L. Rivals. Their Mothers? Longtime Friends.
description: They have prayed and laughed and traveled together. They have encouraged and consoled each other. They text all the time and are ever so thankful how the first round of the N.F.L. draft unfolded in April.

title: Serena Williams and Novak Djokovic Sit Atop U.S. Open Draw, With Injuries Sharing Spotlight
description: Serena Williams and Novak Djokovic arrived at the United States Open as the top seeds and favorites to win, but both are nursing injuries.

title: Correction Officer Is Charged With Raping Rikers Island Inmate
description: A New York City correction officer was indicted on rape charges on Friday after engaging in sex acts with a Rikers Island inmate last year, the authorities said.

title: Quake Exposes Italys Challenge to Retrofit Its Architecture
description: CASETTA, Italy  Romano Camassi, a seismologist, picked up a sand-colored speck as he surveyed the damage from this weeks earthquake on the green mountain crest where the village of Casetta, now ruins, once perched.

title: Breitbart Rises From Outlier to Potent Voice in Campaign
description: Breitbart News has arrived.

title: The San Diego Chicken Heads Into a Sunset
description: DES MOINES  Ted Giannoulass arrival was delayed four-plus hours; some of his luggage had not arrived. Now, in a brightly lit, empty drive-through restaurant outside of downtown, he savored a double burger as closing time neared. It was a late Sunday night in early August. The surrounding suburban strip malls offered little for sale but boredom.

title: University of Chicago Strikes Back Against Campus Political Correctness
description: The anodyne welcome letter to incoming freshmen is a college staple, but this week the University of Chicago took a different approach: It sent new students a blunt statement opposing some hallmarks of campus political correctness, drawing thousands of impassioned responses, for and against, as it caromed around cyberspace.

title: Judge Rejects DNA Test in Trial Over Garrett Phillipss Murder
description: A judge presiding over a trial in the 2011 murder of a 12-year-old boy in northern New York State said on Friday that the prosecution could not use a cutting-edge and controversial method of analyzing DNA data, dealing a blow to its efforts to convict a former soccer coach accused of the crime.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Elephants can live everywhere; thats not our problem here. There are no jobs in this country. Zero, zero, zero.

title: Mets Beat Phillies, but Prepare to Hand Out Reminders of Their Misfortune
description: Three years ago, a Marlon Byrd T-shirt giveaway at Citi Field was most memorable because Byrd was traded from the Mets before that nights game.

title: Harold Varner III, PGA Tour Rookie, Says, I Want to Inspire Everybody
description: FARMINGDALE, N.Y.  With a 7:20 a.m. starting time for the second round of the Barclays, Harold Varner III was up before sunrise Friday. But three people in his small gallery were awake well before Varner, a PGA Tour rookie and one of six first-year golfers in the FedEx Cup playoffs.

title: Apologetic Hacker? Not if You Peek at His Emails
description: When Alonzo Knowles pleaded guilty in May to hacking into the email accounts of celebrities and athletes, gaining access to unreleased movie and television scripts and trying to sell them for thousands of dollars, he apologized in court, saying he knew what he had done was wrong.

title: Close My Tax Loophole
description: My fellow venture capitalists and private equity investors are paying close attention to the heated election-year rhetoric about the future of carried interest, which is the performance fee we charge to manage other peoples money. Carried interest is the fund managers share of the earnings from a profitable investment, normally paid on top of a much smaller management fee.

title: As Long as You Love Me So
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  If youre planning a pub crawl this weekend, you could do a lot worse than starting off with a trip to a KARAOKE BAR. Jim Page and Will Shortz/Joel Fagliano highly recommend it with the fabulous clue, Where to belt one down and belt one out. Its also a fairly easy and welcoming opening to one of our weekend puzzles.

title: National Monuments From Mr. Obama
description: Bill Clinton was like a kid with a new toy when, fairly late in his presidency, and to the great annoyance of Congress, he discovered his powers under the Antiquities Act to create national monuments with a stroke of the presidential pen  and then busily set about protecting areas of great scenic, environmental or historical significance that might otherwise be ignored by Congress or threatened by development. President Obama, to the delight of conservationists, is now very much on the same schedule.

title: Brooklyns Bicycling Culture Doesnt Ease Risks for Riders
description: The statistic was alarming enough on its own: The number of cyclists killed by motor vehicles on New York City streets in 2016 had matched 2015s total just eight months into the year.

title: New Yorks Disappearing Storefronts
description: My laptop was acting up, dispatching emails before I hit send, so I set off for Tekserve. Its my neighborhood computer-repair store, and its been serving Manhattan for decades  the Apple Store in New York City before there was such a thing as an Apple Store, The Times called it. When I arrived, a clerk told me it was about to close, permanently. The rent had doubled.

title: M.T.A. Contract Workers Will Earn Higher Wages by 2018
description: The company that runs a call center for Access-A-Ride, the Metropolitan Transportation Authoritys service for people with disabilities, and the union that represents its workers have reached an agreement to raise their wages to at least $15 an hour by 2018, the union announced on Friday.

title: Jane Thompson, Designer Who Helped Transform Waterfronts, Dies at 89
description: To imagination-starved American households that needed a dash of style in the 1950s and 60s, and to moribund urban waterfronts that needed a dose of hope in the 70s and 80s, the designers Jane and Benjamin C. Thompson brought vibrancy and variety, colors and textures, and (nice) smells.

title: As Gary Sanchez Ascends, Yankees See Their Fortunes Beginning to Rise
description: As Gary Sanchez jogged around the bases at Yankee Stadium on Friday night, he heard only silence. Sanchez had just cracked another home run, his 10th this month, settling the extraordinary into the routine, and yet his emotions swelled so high that now his ears were betraying him. An entire stadium erupted with glee and he could not take it in. He just kept jogging  at least his legs had not stopped churning.

title: Fair Pay, Safe Workplaces, Republican Objections
description: As the nations chief executive, the president gets to set standards for companies that do business with the government. In 2014, after a Senate report found that many federal contractors had been repeatedly cited for cheating, harassing and injuring their employees, President Obama ordered federal agencies to check how well companies have complied with labor laws before awarding contracts.

title: Josephine Del Deo, Who Fought to Preserve Cape Cod Shoreline, Dies at 90
description: Josephine Del Deo, a writer and preservationist who helped safeguard the embryonic Cape Cod National Seashore in Massachusetts and preserved the historic character of Provincetown, at the capes tip, died on Thursday in Provincetown. She was 90.

title: Arrest in Manhattan Murder After Witness Talks to Police 26 Years Later
description: Juan Deleon was standing in the lobby of the Harlem apartment building where he lived on Feb. 11, 1990, arguing with the mother of his two young daughters, when gunshots, at least eight of them, rang out. She had fled by the time police officers arrived and pronounced Mr. Deleon dead where he had fallen.

title: Italys Tragic Failure on Earthquake Preparedness
description: Italy sits astride a convergence of major and minor fault lines that makes it one of the most earthquake-prone countries in the world. When a deadly temblor hits  as one did on Wednesday  the countrys emergency response systems kick into gear, helping to rescue the injured and sustain survivors.

title: Jessica Yu and Gregory Ter-Zakhariants: A Love Thats Patient
description: Jessica Samantha Yu, a daughter of Dr. Lily Htwe Wong and Dr. Kyi Win Yu of Bayside, Queens, was married Aug. 27 to Gregory Ter-Zakhariants, a son of Tatiana Ter-Zakhariants and Andrey Ter-Zakhariants of San Jose, Calif. Jason Yue Shen, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the Castlewood Country Club in Pleasanton, Calif.

title: Lorraine Stomski and Curtis Herbert: Suspicions Online, Then Real Love
description: Lorraine Christine Stomski and Curtis Scott Herbert were married Aug. 27 at the Wiawaka Holiday House in Lake George, N.Y. Paulina Mustazza, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Corrections: August 27, 2016
description: NEW YORK

title: Whats on TV Saturday: Maggies Plan and In the Heart of the Sea
description: A New York millennials ambitions go awry when life happens in Maggies Plan, starring Greta Gerwig. Ron Howard tries to harness a whale in In the Heart of the Sea. And the 1980s pop star Debbie Gibson reimagines her life, in a way, in Summer of Dreams.

title: Isnt It Also Against Her Freedom of Choice?
description: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

title: Inside a G.E. Factory: Manufacturing a New Way of Doing Things
description: In its factory in Greenville, S.C., G.E. produces giant power generation components as well as evidence that its digital metamorphosis might work.

title: Heres Looking at You
description: You would think, the photographer Clay Benskin said the other day, speaking from an apartment building in TriBeCa where he is the superintendent, that with all the security cameras around the city these days, people might think twice about committing crimes in public.

title: G.E., the 124-Year-Old Software Start-Up
description: It may not qualify as a lightning-bolt eureka moment, but Jeffrey R. Immelt, chief executive of General Electric, recalls the June day in 2009 that got him thinking. He was speaking with G.E. scientists about new jet engines they were building, laden with sensors to generate a trove of data from every flight  but to what end?

title: Venus Williams Gave Me a Tennis Lesson
description: Katie, I am noting your split step isnt happening. Those words set into motion the best tennis lesson Ive ever received. It was from Venus Williams.

title: Black Health Matters
description: The first bloom appeared in the crease of my right elbow, an itchy cluster that I ignored. It was well into summer, so I wrote it off as heat rash, or something similarly seasonal.

title: For Wedding Photography, Some Couples Eschew a Pro in Favor of GoPro
description: Guests at weddings this summer may no longer be surprised by the couples casual manner of dress, or by the circle of food trucks in place of formally catered seated dinners, or even by the fact that an old high school pal of the groom has been ordained online and enlisted as the officiant.

title: Venus Williams, Off the Court
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  Venus Williamss ability to get around a tennis court quickly is well known. She is 6-foot-1 and nearly can get from one side to the other in a single side-step-leap-slide. Less known is her speed in taking meetings.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took readers from the White House to Tortugas National Park.

title: The Accidental Plagiarist in All of Us
description: Sleigh Bells, an indie rock band, has filed a copyright infringement suit against Demi Lovato, accusing the pop star of stealing, at the very least, the beat of one of its songs.

title: SEAL Team 6 and a Man Left for Dead: A Grainy Picture of Valor
description: Britt Slabinski could hear the bullets ricochet off the rocks in the darkness. It was the first firefight for his six-man reconnaissance unit from SEAL Team 6, and it was outnumbered, outgunned and taking casualties on an Afghan mountaintop.

title: A Little Variety
description: VARIETY PUZZLES  This weeks puzzles include:

title: Farhads and Mikes Week in Tech: Ubers Losses Pile Up and So Do Losses for Privacy
description: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

title: On the Trail: Week of Aug. 21
description: A busy week of fund-raising for Hillary Clinton and multiple rallies for Donald J. Trump.

title: Heres Looking at You
description: Clay Benskin, a photographer with no formal training, takes pictures of a city in which surveillance is so pervasive that the people under its eye no longer notice it.

title: On Fed Complacency
description: Is the Fed really repeating its big mistake of the pre-crisis era, dismissing concerns about its ability to respond to recession? Jared Bernstein thinks so, and so do I.

title: Conflict With a Housekeeper
description: Two  neighbors on my floor employ the same maid. Another condominium owner and I have both had verbal altercations with this maid. She swore at each of us and, in my case, pushed me aside during a conflict about who could use a common washing machine. Neither of her employers fired her. When I emailed the managing agent about my concerns, I was told to just keep me posted. Shouldnt the condo association do more? What responsibilities and authority does it have to resolve a matter like this?

title: An Afghan Feud Reignites, Putting Police Families at Odds
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The feud between two police families from the village of Daku, on the northern Afghan Shomali Plain, goes back so far no one really knows what started it. Six dead bodies later, no one sees an end to it, either.

title: Obama the Monument Maker
description: President Obama seems most comfortable outside on an 18-hole golf course, not hunting bear in Colorado, as Theodore Roosevelt did while president in 1905, or deep-sea fishing for tarpon in the Texas Gulf, as Franklin D. Roosevelt, an avid angler, did on a getaway from the White House in 1937.

title: From Bikinis to Burkinis, Regulating What Women Wear
description: PARIS  The policeman in the photo is nattily attired and appears to have a slight smirk as he writes out a ticket for the woman standing before him awkwardly in her offending swimwear; perhaps he enjoys making her feel uncomfortable.

title: Bangladesh Police Kill Man Suspected of Planning Dhaka Bakery Attack
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  A Canadian man suspected of having planned a July attack on a bakery in Dhaka that left 22 people dead was killed in a shootout with the Bangladeshi police on Saturday, officials said.

title: Only in Palm Beach: The $95 Million Tear-Down
description: In 2008, Donald Trump sold a Palm Beach, Fla., estate for $95 million, making it the most expensive single residential property ever sold in town. Now the property is about to set another record  as Palm Beachs most expensive tear-down.

title: Packing Technology Into the Timeless Barrel
description: SALEM, Mo.  Standing on a wooded hillside in the Ozarks, about 100 miles southwest of St. Louis, Brad Boswell watches a chain-saw-wielding logger make several deft cuts at the base of a 100-foot white oak. The logger points to a clearing down the slope and, with one final, quick slash, sends the tree falling, exactly where he pointed.

title: Voices From Texas on Campus Carry
description: As classes resume at the University of Texas at Austin, students and faculty are adjusting to a state law that allows concealed handguns to be carried on campus. Here are voices of those for and against the measure.

title: The Marine Corps: My Boot Camp for the Business World
description: In the 1970s, I quit college and enlisted in the United States Marines. I was young, and there was a war on. As it turned out, I spent a decade on active duty. I was deployed twice to the Far East, and spent time in a dozen other places as well  including a very cold winter in an exercise on the Alaskan tundra.

title: Discipline, Detail and Devices That Work the Way They Should
description: Raul Matias, 31, is a quality assurance engineer at Wink in New York.

title: Taliban Overrun Afghan Border District, Opening a New Front
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Taliban have overrun a border district in the southeastern Afghan province of Paktia and inflicted heavy casualties on the Afghan security forces, officials said Saturday, as the insurgent fighters opened a new front in a once-volatile region.

title: A Car Renters Costly Detour to Collection Center Drive
description: Maybe a day will come when Payless Car Rental stops pointlessly antagonizing its customers, but as far as the Haggler can tell, that day is far off. He has  written twice about the company already in 2016, and the complaints keep flowing in.

title: What University of Texas Campus Is Saying About Concealed Guns
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  As classes began here at the University of Texas this past week amid a new law allowing concealed handguns on college campuses in the state, an accounting student quietly strapped on a pistol and headed to class.

title: The Complaint File of Agnes Bunn
description: Records from the New York City Commission on Human Rights include the file of Agnes Bunn, who complained that she was turned away from a Trump building in 1970 because she was black. Documents in the file included the report of a white tester who said he was offered an apartment in the building.

title: A Recounting of Maxine Browns Complaint
description: A court filing in the Department of Justices discrimination case against Trump Management describes the complaint of Maxine Brown, a young black nurse who sought an apartment at a Trump property in late 1963. The document was contained in the National Archives. The Times has redacted address information from the file.

title: The Timess 1973 Article About the Federal Case Against Trump Management
description: A front page article in The New York Times in 1973 detailed the federal governments civil lawsuit against Trump Management.

title: Affidavit of Donald Trump in 1973 About the Housing Bias Case
description: In a 1973 court filing, Donald Trump denied allegations by the government that Trump Management had engaged in racial bias in its renting of apartments. The document was contained in the National Archives.

title: Applying for Housing at a Trump Property in the '60s
description: In the 1960s, Mae Wiggins and her friend Maxine Brown applied for housing at the Wilshire Apartments in the Jamaica Estates neighborhood of Queens, N.Y. Ms. Wiggins recalled her experience.

title: No Vacancies for Blacks: How Donald Trump Got His Start, and Was First Accused of Bias
description: She seemed like the model tenant. A 33-year-old nurse who was living at the Y.W.C.A. in Harlem, she had come to rent a one-bedroom at the still-unfinished Wilshire Apartments in the Jamaica Estates neighborhood of Queens. She filled out what the rental agent remembers as a beautiful application. She did not even want to look at the unit.

title: The Obama-Era Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Realities of Investing
Exposing Buyback Magic
Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  If you think that the misdirected clues in regular crosswords teach you to think differently and you enjoy that mental exercise, you should give cryptic crosswords a try. Cryptics are actually what the rest of the world (outside of the United States) simply calls crosswords, and they are good fun as long as you know how to read the clues, which adhere to a certain format.

title: Moscow Warehouse Fire Kills at Least 17 Migrant Workers
description: MOSCOW  A fire at a printing warehouse in northern Moscow that killed at least 17 migrant workers on Saturday was triggered by a faulty electrical lamp, officials said.

title: As La Guardia Is Overhauled, the Check-In Line Starts at the Highway
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.s bleak assessment of La Guardia Airport as third-world propelled a complete reconstruction. But the path to a modern La Guardia was not supposed to include travelers dragging luggage through gridlocked traffic on a highway to catch their flights.

title: Cubs Fans Root for Aroldis Chapman While Deploring His History
description: CHICAGO  As Caitlin Swieca nursed a beer in Wrigley Fields upper deck on a recent steamy Saturday afternoon, she was hoping  like other Chicago Cubs fans  that her team could hang onto a slim lead against the rival St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Donald Trump Uses Death of Dwyane Wades Cousin to Illustrate His View
description: Donald J. Trump took to Twitter on Saturday morning to comment on the news that a cousin of Dwyane Wade, the N.B.A. star, had been shot and killed in Chicago, linking the death to his effort to win support from African-American voters.

title: Jeremiah OKeefe, Ace in His First World War II Battle, Dies at 93
description: Jeremiah J. OKeefe, who earned ace status in his first aerial battle when he downed five Japanese planes over Okinawa during World War II and later entered Mississippi politics as a staunch opponent of segregation, died Tuesday at his home in Biloxi, Miss. He was 93.

title: Hillary Clinton Ad Pushes Issue of Race Against Donald Trump
description: The presidential contest between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump this week was marked by accusations  from both sides  of racism and bigotry. The Clinton campaign is pressing the issue of race in a new ad titled Everything, which offers an answer to Mr. Trump, who has sought support from minority voters by asking, rhetorically, What the hell do you have to lose?

title: Voting Narcissistic Sociopath  Until Now
description: Ive always voted for narcissistic sociopaths. Whenever a narcissistic sociopath runs for office, I donate, volunteer and cast my vote for him.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: Can Israel and the Arab States Be Friends?
description: Israel and Saudi Arabia have no formal diplomatic relations. The Saudis do not even recognize Israel as a state. Still, there is evidence that ties between Saudi Arabia and other Sunni Arab states and Israel are not only improving but, after developing in secret over many years, could evolve into a more explicit alliance as a result of their mutual distrust of Iran. Better relations among these neighbors could put the chaotic Middle East on a more positive course. They could also leave the Palestinians in the dust, a worrisome prospect.

title: Living in L.B.J.s America
description: Dr. Kings dream began to be realized when President Johnson passed the Civil Rights Act, Hillary Clinton claimed during her 2008 campaign against Senator Barack Obama, before adding, it took a president to get it done.

title: Sexual Harassment Training With Roger Ailes
description: Two high-profile lawsuits against Roger Ailes, the former Fox News chairman, have painted a shocking picture of brazen sexual harassment at the network. In her bombshell complaint against him, the former Fox host Gretchen Carlson said that he told her, I think you and I should have had a sexual relationship a long time ago. Last week, another former Fox host, Andrea Tantaros, filed her own lawsuit, stating that Mr. Ailes told her to turn around so he could get a good look at her and that she was harassed by other employees and even show guests.

title: A Summer to Make Mistakes
description: I worried constantly about making mistakes, which, it turned out, did not prevent them. It was 1997, the summer Id graduated from college, and I was interning with The Charlotte Observer, a daily newspaper in a city where I knew almost no one. I was a general assignment reporter earning $525 a week. If I performed well, Id be considered for a permanent position.

title: The Misery of the Mini-Trumps
description: In his race against Marco Rubio to become the Republican nominee for one of Floridas two seats in the Senate, the rich, brash homebuilder Carlos Beruff could not be welding himself more tightly to Donald Trump.

title: The Unlimited Power of Ocean Winds
description: The first offshore wind farm in American waters, near Block Island, R.I., was completed this month. With just five turbines, the farm wont make much of a dent in the nations reliance on fossil fuels, but it shows the promise this renewable energy source could have. When the turbines start spinning in November, they will power the island, which currently relies on diesel generators, and will also send electricity to the rest of Rhode Island.

title: Even Roger Federer Gets Old
description: He heard a click. That was how Roger Federer discovered the knee injury that cost him most of his 2016 season. He was running a bath for his daughters  and since he is Roger Federer, we have to assume he was running a gorgeous bath, possibly the greatest bath of all time, perfect temperature, immaculate bubbles, faint scent of lavender, business as usual.

title: A Bug That Eats Baseball Bats
description: The emerald ash borer is a luminescent green insect that probably arrived in the Detroit area more than 15 years ago. These small Asian beetles, possibly coming to this country on wooden packing materials, have been devouring millions of ash trees as they eat their way from Michigan across the Midwest.

title: The Alt-Right Is All Wrong
description: RENO, Nev.  HILLARY didnt hang her head and cry, after she shot a man in Reno just to watch him die.

title: For Hillary Clinton and Democrats, a Public Shift Toward God-Talk
description: Four months ago, as Hillary Clinton turned her attention from the Democratic primary toward a fall race against Donald J. Trump, her campaign released a commercial titled Love and Kindness.

title: Trump and the Dark History of Straight Talk
description: An argument has been raging in the Trump camp this summer. Its not an argument about policy or the electoral ground war, but about rhetorical technique. Isnt it finally time to abandon the improv and the wild one-liners, and restrict the candidate to the button-down rigor of the teleprompter?

title: Trucking on the PGA Tour, With 72,000 Pounds of Equipment
description: FARMINGDALE, N.Y.  Pete Bezuk wanted to build golf clubs. His first employer, Titleist, sent him to truck-driving school.

title: Why Colin Kaepernick Didnt Stand for the National Anthem
description: When the national anthem played before the start of the preseason game with the Green Bay Packers on Friday night, Colin Kaepernick, the quarterback for the San Francisco 49ers, took a stand by not standing.

title: Adopted Koreans, Stymied in Search of Birth Parents, Find Hope in a Cotton Swab
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Five years ago, Sun Mi Stapel, a claims handler at a Dutch insurance company, began searching for her South Korean birth family.

title: Do You Believe in God, or Is That a Software Glitch?
description: Weve all seen them, those colorful images that show how our brains light up when were in love, playing a video game, craving chocolate, etc. Created using functional magnetic resonance imaging, or fM.R.I., these pictures are the basis of tens of thousands of scientific papers, the backdrop to TED talks and supporting evidence in best-selling books that tell us how to maintain healthy relationships, make decisions, market products and lose weight.

title: Why Black Men Quit Teaching
description: How can we help black boys succeed in school? One popular answer is that we need more black male teachers.

title: The Farewell Tour Comes to Vin Scully
description: On the rare nights when Vin Scully is not working at Dodger Stadium, the umpires will finish their pregame meeting at home plate, turn to face the press box and, almost audibly, sigh.

title: Living With Disability
description: Several readers discuss how their lives have been changed, for better and worse.

title: Donald Trump Appears to Take Sheldon Adelsons Advice on Humility
description: Donald J. Trump met privately last week with Sheldon G. Adelson, the billionaire casino magnate, who this spring pledged to contribute as much as $100 million to support Mr. Trumps campaign but has not yet followed through on that commitment.

title: An Electronic Set of Eyes to Feed Data to Tennis Players and Coaches
description: Ten years ago, the United States Open was the first Grand Slam tournament to use the Hawk-Eye technology to review line calls.

title: Embattled Maldives President Faces Accusations of Corruption, Past and Present
description: BANGKOK, Thailand  President Abdulla Yameen of the Maldives, who is under pressure to step down, faces allegations of corruption dating back more than a decade, including oversight of questionable oil sales to a Myanmar dictatorship under economic sanctions.

title: A Big Stage for Golf Animates Female Players Around the Globe
description: It was no surprise that Inbee Park of South Korea, Lydia Ko of New Zealand and Shanshan Feng of China were the gold, silver and bronze medalists at the Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro this month. All three have been winners on the L.P.G.A. Tour.

title: No Longer a Coach, Steve Spurrier Assumes New Roles
description: Last October, after more than 25 seasons as one of college footballs most successful head coaches, Steve Spurrier abruptly resigned from the University of South Carolina, saying that at 70 he did not have enough left in the tank to continue.

title: Gary Sanchez Homers Again as Yankees Gain in Wild-Card Race
description: At some point, on some future day, Gary Sanchez will no longer be the hottest hitter in baseball. He will regress into the promising player he was assumed to be when the Yankees called him up this month, rather than the dominant force he has become since joining them. Sanchez will, most likely, stop hitting like Barry Bonds in pinstripes.

title: The First Shall Be Last
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  Its rare that the theme of a puzzle takes long after Ive finished solving to trickle through my brain, but thats exactly what happened to me today. In hindsight, its very clever, but I can honestly say that I didnt get it.

title: Following the PGA Tour in Big Rigs
description: Golf club technicians for companies like Titleist and TaylorMade drive tractor-trailers to PGA Tour events to make or fix clubs for the players.

title: Chinese-Canadians Fear Chinas Rising Clout Is Muzzling Them
description: TORONTO  Canadas prime minister, Justin Trudeau, is due in China on Tuesday for a much anticipated visit, hoping to reset what had been an up-and-down relationship under the previous government. Closer ties, Mr. Trudeau says, would release untapped prosperity at home and promote Canadian values like good governance and the rule of law in China.

title: U.S. Court Rules Infringement Suit by Trader Joes Can Proceed Against Pirate Joes
description: A federal appeals court said Friday that Washington State has the authority to hear a trademark lawsuit by Trader Joes against a Canadian store called Pirate Joes that resold the grocery chains products.

title: Donald Trump Tries to Clarify Immigration Plan, but Avoids Key Issue
description: DES MOINES  Donald J. Trump provided on Saturday a more detailed look at his immigration policy, returning to the issue after a week in which he faced criticism from across the political spectrum for seeming to soften his hard-line position on deporting undocumented immigrants.

title: Against Distinguished Travers Field, a Freak Wins by a Chasm
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  He was a big colt  gangly, hardheaded and not particularly well behaved. Arrogate required patience and often tried the patience of those charged with transforming him into a racehorse. Every now and then in the mornings, however, Arrogate would flash at what might come, pumping those long gray legs like pistons and chugging down the track like a steamroller.

title: Adam Scott Gets a Grip on His Putting to Stay in the Hunt at the Barclays
description: FARMINGDALE, N.Y.  For much of 2016, including the first two rounds of the Barclays tournament, Adam Scott has been able to relate well to an observation on golfs dark and sometimes elusive art by the British golf writer Peter Dobereiner.

title: Return to Health Fuels Giants Victor Cruz, and Fans
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Of the jersey-wearing fans at MetLife Stadium, many favored current stars from the Giants or Jets, while others, wistful for the past, modeled popular players from the glory days.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: When it was happening to the whites, we thought we were redressing colonial wrongs. But now we realize its also coming back to us.

title: Man Confesses to Killing 2 Nuns in Rural Mississippi, the Police Say
description: A man suspected of stabbing two nuns to death in their rural Mississippi home confessed to the killings on Saturday, according to the police.

title: Holly Donaldson, Adam Casella
description: Holly Thatcher Donaldson, the daughter of Barbara Thatcher Donaldson and Alan P. Donaldson of New Canaan, Conn., was married Aug. 27 to Adam Eric Casella, a son of Ann Irimia Casella and Mark J. Casella of Waccabuc, N.Y. Emily Garvan Lines, a cousin of the bride who received permission from Vermont to preside at the event, officiated at the summer home of the brides family in Landgrove, Vt.

title: Claire ODonnell, Reid Rader
description: Claire Alexandra ODonnell and Reid Whelan Rader were married Aug. 27 at Suncadia Resort in Cle Elum, Wash. Joshua Weiner, a childhood friend of the groom who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Ursula Bailey, William Hagaman
description: Dr. Ursula Violet Bailey, a daughter of Sabra E. Friedman and Percival R. Bailey of Manhattan, is to be married Aug. 28 to William James Hagaman, a son of Andrea T. Hyde and Dr. John F. Hagaman of Princeton, N.J. Canon Lee Alison Crawford, an Episcopal priest, is to officiate at Saltwater Farm Vineyard in Stonington, Conn.

title: Charlotte Chapman, Jorge Vilario
description: Charlotte Moseley Chapman, the daughter of Diane Clark Chapman and Peter Herbert Chapman of New York, was married Aug. 27 to Jorge Vilario, a son of Belen Valle Pereira of La Corua, Spain, and the late Juan Manuel Vilario Gil. description: Caitlin Taylor Landy and Brandon Travis Ponder were married Aug. 27 at the Westchester Country Club in Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Robert Sturdivant, a Methodist minister who is a cousin of the groom, officiated.

description: Richa Tandon, a daughter of Neeta Tandon and Kishore Tandon of South Brunswick, N.J., was married Aug. 27 to Dr. Mrunal Harendrasinh Parmar, the son of Sohagi Parmar and Harendrasinh Parmar of Paramus, N.J. description: Jennifer Michelle Harris, a daughter of Karen N. Youngblood and Kenny D. Harris of Lawton, Okla., was married Aug. 27 to Alexander Jacob Post, the son of Fran A. Layton of Berkeley, Calif., and Robert C. Post of New Haven. Sarah S. Stillman, a friend of the couple who was ordained through the American Marriage Ministries for the occasion, officiated at a property rented for the occasion in Boonville, Calif.

title: Caroline Ross, Davide Giassi
description: Caroline Woods Ross and Davide Giassi were married Aug. 27 at the Lillian and Amy Goldman Stone Mill of the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. The Rev. Dr. Edward J. Thompson, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated.

description: Selina Jessie MacLaren and John Barrow Sprangers were married Aug. 27 at Elings Park in Santa Barbara, Calif. Judge Pamela A. Harris, of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, who has chambers in Silver Spring, Md., officiated. The groom was her clerk in 2014 and 2015

title: Johanna Snyder, John Mahoney

title: Kathryn McCabe, Samuel Boyce
description: Kathryn Jane McCabe and Samuel McNeely Boyce were married Aug. 26 in Brooklyn. Mark R. Dwyer, an acting justice of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, officiated at the My Moon restaurant.

title: Emily Baker, Samuel Mayer
description: Emily Hamilton Baker, a daughter of Martha Baker of Greenwich, Conn., and Chuck Baker of Long Island City, Queens, was married Aug. 24 to Samuel Mayer, the son of Carol Mair and the stepson of G. title: Rachel Reed, Brett Shorenstein
description: Dr. Rachel Lauren Reed, a daughter of Joanne E. Reed and George E. Reed of Rye, N.Y., was married Aug. 27 to Dr. Brett Scott Shorenstein, a son of Barbara G. Shorenstein and Kenneth E. Shorenstein of New York. Cantor Morris Glazman officiated at the Garrison, a private estate in Garrison, N.Y.

title: Jennifer Nedeau, Austin Helm
description: Jennifer Anne Nedeau, the daughter of Janet E. Nedeau and Christopher A. Nedeau of San Francisco, was married Aug. 27 to Austin Frederick Helm, a son of Christine A. Helm and Thomas F. Helm of Greenfield, Wis. The Rev. Ren Iturbe, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Notre Dame des Victoires church in San Francisco.

description: Jillian Ruth Colbert and Carl Fredrik Sebastian Alsheimer were married Aug. 27 on Marthas Vineyard at the Allen Farm in Chilmark, Mass. The officiant was Vernon E. Jordan Jr., the civil rights activist and a friend of the couple, who received a one-day marriage designation from Massachusetts.

title: Sarah Fecht, Charles Choi
description: Sarah Elizabeth Fecht and Charles Quixote Choi were married Aug. 27 at Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y. Sang Kim, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, officiated at Reid Castle.

title: Shahrzad Daneshvar, Travis Viola
description: Shahrzad Daneshvar, the daughter of Afsaneh Pournaderi Daneshvar and Farhang Daneshvar of Fair Oaks, Calif., was married Aug. 25 to Travis Viola, a son of Teresa Viola and Vincent Viola of New York. Judge Ann Claire Williams of the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit officiated in her chambers in Chicago.

title: Erin Hays, Stan Chiueh
description: Erin Leigh Hays and Shenghao Stan Chiueh were married Aug. 27 at Tarrytown House Estate in Tarrytown, N.Y. Cain Soltoff, the best man, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated with the assistance of Faith Simmons, the maid of honor, who also became a Universal Life minister.

title: Jill Brimmer, Patrick Boland
description: Jill Caitlyn Brimmer, a daughter of Sue E. Brimmer of Portland, Me., was married there Aug. 27 to Patrick Morrow Boland, the son of Margaret M. Morrow of Pasadena, Calif., and the late Paul E. Boland. The grooms mother, a retired Federal District Court judge in Los Angeles who received permission from Maine to preside at this event, officiated at Diamonds Edge Restaurant and Marina on Great Diamond Island.

title: Laurel Rapp, Matthew Davis
description: Laurel Trigg Rapp, a daughter of Mary K. Trigg and Ronald J. Rapp of Bernardsville, N.J., was married Aug. 27 to Matthew Justin Davis, a son of Barbara Valente Davis and Michael W. Davis of Evanston, Ill. Thomas M. Frayne, a friend of the grooms family who became a minister of the American Marriage Ministries, officiated at Mount Hope Farm in Bristol, R.I.

title: Hadley Planting, Alexander Powell
description: Hadley Catherine Planting and Alexander Fellows Powell were married Aug. 27 in Northeast Harbor, Me. The Rev. Jane E. Cornman performed the ceremony at St. Marys by-the-Sea, an Episcopal church.

title: Stephen Clayton, Dean Madge
description: Stephen David Clayton and Dean Roy Madge were married Aug. 27 at the Pool Lawn in Central Park in New York. The Rev. Annie Lawrence, an interfaith minister, officiated.

title: Nicole Beserra, Andrew Cox
description: Nicole Lynn Beserra and Andrew Lytton Cox were married Aug. 27 in Denver. Robert Rinne, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony at the Cathedral Basilica of the Immaculate Conception.

title: EJ Dickson, Alex La Ferla
description: EJ Dickson, a daughter of Toby R. Axelrod and Clifford S. Dickson of Manhattan, was married Aug. 27 to Alex La Ferla, the son of Ruth La Ferla and Sandro La Ferla, also of Manhattan. Rabbi Beni Wajnberg officiated at South Farms, a dairy farm and events venue in Morris, Conn.

title: Rebecca Ravski, Mitchell Berkowitz
description: Rebecca Celia Ravski, the daughter of Karyn M. Rosenthal-Ravski and Dr. Norman A. Ravski of Woodbridge, Conn., is to be married there Aug. 28 to Mitchell Howard Berkowitz, a son of Linda B. Friedman of Freehold, N.J., and Lawrence R. Berkowitz of Somerset, N.J. Rabbi Evan Ravski, a brother of the bride who set up the couple in 2012, will perform the ceremony at Congregation Bnai Jacob.

title: Victoria Lui, Scott Wang
description: Victoria Lui, the daughter of Wendy Lui and Thomas Lui of Woodside, Queens, was married Aug. 27 to Scott Xiaozhou Wang, the son of Dr. Yuan Xu and Li Wang of Beijing. The Rev. William G. Britton officiated at the Wind Watch Golf and Country Club in Hauppauge, N.Y.

description: Allison Rachel Ganz, the daughter of Jeanne R. Ganz and Lowell A. Ganz of Los Angeles, was married Aug. 27 to Ethan Benjamin Schiffres, the son of Carole L. Feldman and Manny Schiffres, both of Washington. Rabbi Nick Renner officiated at Rancho Dos Pueblos, an event space in Goleta, Calif.

title: Melissa DeRosa, Matthew Wing
